HEADLINE: The Loopholes in I.R.S. Reform

 BODY:
No one ever lost an election by abusing the tax collector. So it is probably inevitable that a bill overhauling the Internal Revenue Service will become law before November. It has already been passed by the House and Senate in different forms. The Clinton Administration has also clambered on board. The Treasury Department says that Congressional plans to reorganize the I.R.S. bureaucracy and make the agency more user-friendly are almost precisely what it intended to do anyway.
Congress still has some issues to resolve, however. The Senate version of the bill costs three times as much as the House's, and pretends to pay the difference with a ridiculous tax break for rich senior citizens that would bring a short-term windfall into the Treasury, while sucking out far more revenue over the long run. The conference committee should ditch that idea immediately, and also pare back some of the expensive new taxpayer protections, to make sure they are as narrowly targeted as possible. 
 These new taxpayer rights are bound to appeal to the public, even though they will actually only affect the minuscule number of taxpayers who wind up fighting the I.R.S. in tax court. They include the "innocent spouse" protection, which is supposed to keep low-salaried women from being dunned for taxes owed by their former husbands. The bills also shift the burden of proof in court cases from the taxpayer to the I.R.S.
Like most changes in tax law, the taxpayer protections are going to be a big help mainly to the very wealthy. Only about 30,000 of the 118 million individual returns filed wind up in tax court, and few of the taxpayers who fight that long are impoverished widows. Ordinary taxpayers whose skirmishes with the I.R.S. take place on a lower level will have to continue documenting their expenses and responding to auditors' demands just as they did in the past.
Critics are right when they complain that the tax-collecting bureaucracy is inefficient, particularly in regard to its outdated computers, which are the cause of many of the horror stories that have been given wide publicity. But the main cause of the nation's tax phobia is the complicated system of tax exemptions that was created by Congress and that the overhaul bills do little to address.
The danger is that the publicity over the proposed changes will encourage the public to believe the I.R.S. is toothless. The American system of tax collection, much as all red-blooded citizens may hate it, is one of the bulwarks of the economy. Compliance is far higher than in many other Western countries, creating a system that is fairer and collects more money. If Congressional hype over the I.R.S. bill encourages people to underreport their incomes in hopes of dodging penalties later, it will do far more harm than good.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Roslyn Bancorp Is Expected To Acquire T.R. Financial

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Roslyn Bancorp is expected to acquire the T. R. Financial Corporation in a stock swap valued at about $1.1 billion, according to people close to the merger talks.
The boards of both of the Long Island companies were meeting late last evening and had not approved the transaction, although people close to the boards said they were confident that they would do so by tomorrow. 
 It could not be determined if a merger would result in layoffs.
The deal continues a recent wave of mergers by savings and loan institutions in the metropolitan area as they struggle to compete with more aggressive retail banks like the Chase Manhattan and Citibank.
Mortgage lending has traditionally been the bread and butter of the savings and loan industry. Even though industrywide profits have been rising and the economic landscape is more favorable nationally than it was earlier in the decade, savings and loan associations have had difficulty in the increasingly competitive mortgage business.
Though some giant savings and loans, like the West Coast behemoth being created by the pending merger of Washington Mutual Inc. and H. F. Ahmanson & Company, may be survivors, many of these companies will not be able to compete. And so, many have given up the battle and are merging with an eye to making themselves more attractive takeover targets, analysts and bank advisers say. That is particularly true in the Northeast and in the area around New York.
In April, the Astoria Financial Corporation agreed to buy Long Island Bancorp in a $1.8 billion stock swap. That transaction, which is expected to close by the end of the third quarter, would create the second-largest savings institution in New York State, with $16.6 billion in assets. It would rank behind Dime Bancorp, which has about $21.8 billion in assets, and ahead of the Greenpoint Financial Corporation, which has about $13 billion in assets.
A combination of Roslyn and T. R. Financial would create the fourth-largest savings and loan in New York State, with about $7.7 billion in assets.
The deal is expected to close by the end of this year, pending regulatory approval.
Roslyn, which is based in Roslyn, went public only a year ago, and analysts say it has been planning to beef up its banking presence through acquisitions. It has 8 full-service branches in Nassau and Suffolk counties and 12 mortgage units in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. It has about $3.7 billion in assets and $2 billion in deposits.
T. R. Financial, the parent company of Roosevelt Savings Bank, is based in Garden City and has 15 branches in Nassau and Suffolk counties, Queens and Brooklyn. It has about $4 billion in assets and $2.1 billion in deposits.
The new company would retain the Roslyn Bancorp name and be based in Roslyn.
Ten of the new company's 14 board members would come from Roslyn Bancorp, and Joseph L. Mancino, Roslyn's chairman and chief executive, would be president and chief executive of the new company. John M. Tsimbinos, T. R. Financial's chairman and chief executive, would be chairman of the new company.
T. R. Financial shareholders will receive 2.05 shares of Roslyn stock for each share of T. R. Financial that they own.
Based on Roslyn's closing share price of $27.625 on Friday, that values T. R. Financial shares at about $56.63, a 46.6 percent premium to T. R. Financial's closing price of $38.625 on Friday.

HEADLINE: A Pot of Gold For Publishers Of Textbooks

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
If public passion for the printed word has died, as some say, then a textbook case of resurrection is taking place.
Last weekend the British media conglomerate Pearson P.L.C. agreed to buy Simon & Schuster's education division of publishing imprints, boasting about the future of textbooks and education as the "great growth industry of our time" and instantly becoming the industry behemoth. 
 But its sizable $3.6 billion purchase is dwarfed by an even broader public investment in textbooks for new generations of readers -- a trend that does not attract the publicity of a multibillion-dollar corporate deal, but belies longstanding fears in the publishing industry that the printed page is steadily losing favor to the electronic monitor.
Buoyed by increased spending and growing student enrollment, publishers of textbooks and instructional materials registered the strongest gains in sales last year in any category of the $21 billion United States book market, with purchases of elementary school books increasing by 13 percent, to $3 billion, and college texts rising by 7.4 percent, to $2.7 billion.
In Florida, state officials have doubled spending for textbook purchases over the last four years while California legislators are mulling various bills that could raise textbook spending from $30 a student to $60. And next year is expected to be the busiest period in at least a decade for critical state adoptions of textbooks in Texas, California and Florida.
At the same time, libraries are reveling in a wave of new public investment, with more than 85 percent of almost 9,000 American library systems reporting budget increases for fiscal year 1996, according to the Chicago-based American Library Association.
"In the late 1980's and early 1990's much of the talk about education centered on the emerging technologies -- that the book was dead and traditional publishing was out," said Patrick J. Quinn, managing editor of the education group for Simba Information Inc., a market research firm. "And now, through all the hype and hoopla about it, textbooks have actually started to sell at a brisker pace."
With its purchase of the Simon & Schuster division, Pearson executives are speaking in glowing terms about future prospects for English-language textbooks, not only for the United States, but for the world.
They are predicting 10 percent annual growth rates in the international and domestic markets although analysts for the Book Industry Study Group have been more cautious in their projections for the United States.
"There's a national interest and this is not just in the United States," said Peter Jovanovich, the chief executive of Pearson's Addison Wesley Longman unit, who will preside over the merger of Simon & Schuster with his publishing company. "If you're in Canada or the United Kingdom, there's a renewed or growing emphasis on education. Most leaders realize that it's the key to improving productivity, and so what we see worldwide is more enrollment in higher education, more students staying in schools. All these factors have been good for college publishing and for school publishing."
Such sentiments are also shared by rival publishers who all struggled during the early 1990's through a period of declining sales and rising marketing and production costs.
"It's a good time for all of us -- all tides are rising," said Roby Harrington, the director of the college department for W. W. Norton & Company, who noted that this year 79 of the 123 titles in the Norton Critical Editions series showed higher sales.
"These are the sort of books that you can set your watch by," Mr. Harrington said of the editions that include critical essays along with classics like "Paradise Lost," "War and Peace" and "Moby Dick."
The increased sales activity comes after a period of intense competition, struggle and consolidation within the industry, which evolved from MacMillan's first textbook division established in 1906, to more than 50 companies capitalizing on the baby boom generation in the 1960's, to the top 10 publishers, which controlled more than 83 percent of the market in 1996. With its purchase of Simon & Schuster, a unit of Viacom, Pearson vaulted to the first position in that group, ahead of McGraw-Hill and Harcourt General.
The early 1990's were particularly lean times for educational publishers with sales declines that reflected the recession and taxpayer rejection of school tax increases, which resulted in widespread cuts in educational spending.
It was these and other market pressures that intensified consolidation in the industry.
As enrollments lagged and profits declined in the recession, production and marketing expenses were increasing and the major publishers started to merge to compete. College publishers sought to increase their share of the market by developing an expensive array of free perks packaged with textbooks that included graphics, computer disks, transparencies, videos and even jokes for the first day of class. In some cases, the textbook packages included up to 100 different elements, driving up the price of psychology or science books to as much as $100.
Textbooks also became weightier with the addition of graphics that expanded the number of pages in a biology book from 400 several decades ago to more than 1,000 today.
By 1996, within a six-month period, there was a flurry of consolidation in the industry with Addison Wesley Longman buying HarperCollins's education division and two other major players buying other American publishing properties.
"There wasn't as much room for as many players," Mr. Quinn of Simba said. "It became more expensive with a lot more pressure on the margins and the emergence of a used book market."
With its purchase, Pearson is now positioned to be the leading publisher for American students, commanding more than 27 percent of the $6.43 billion education market, which covers higher education and the kindergarten through 12th-grade level, according to Mr. Quinn.
The combined company's size worries the New York-based Authors Guild, a trade association that has formally challenged the merger of two large trade publishing houses, Random House and Bantam Doubleday Dell by the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G.
"There are too few entities that will be deciding what texts are available to readers and there should be diversity in the textbook market," said Paul Aiken, the executive director of the Authors Guild.
At this point the precise shape and form of the new giant in the industry is not clear. Pearson has yet to disclose the name of the new company or even its headquarters, although one executive close to Pearson said the company was considering creating a headquarters out of Simon & Schuster's 475,000-square-foot offices in Upper Saddle River, N.J.
Pearson has said that it intends to achieve annual savings of $130 million by the year 2000 through integration of functions like production, distribution, central management and property. But Mr. Jovanovich declined to discuss whether duplicate publishing imprints would be folded together or eliminated as part of the merger.
But he is not shy about talking of Pearson's vision of the future. "It's a market that will continue to grow faster than the gross national product," he said, adding, "in many ways, education is going to be the growth industry of the 21st century."

HEADLINE: City's Reliance On Wall Street Raises Concern

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Even as Wall Street's boom continues to feed the budget surplus in New York City, fiscal monitors and others say City Hall remains dangerously tied to the fortunes of the securities industry and question whether it has done enough to prepare for any downturn in the markets.
Since 1990, jobs in the securities industry have accounted for 97 percent of the inflation-adjusted growth in wages in the city, according to the State Comptroller's office. And those salaries, along with the even bigger bonuses that Wall Street gives out each year, have contributed to the largest budget surplus in city history -- $2 billion. 
 The city's budget boom is especially stunning because New York's economic and job growth has trailed the nation's. So, given this mixed overall economic picture, financial experts warn that the city's fortunes are increasingly dependent on an industry whose fortunes can turn suddenly on the Delphic pronouncements of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, or the unfolding events in a distant place like Indonesia.
They also raised doubts about how government officials have used the current period of plenty to prepare for an inevitable decline.
"We have traditionally viewed New York and the metro area as having a broad and diverse economic base, but recently, especially since 1995, that base has become dominated by the securities industry," said Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's Investors Service, a bond-rating agency. "Wall Street has been historically volatile. Years of huge profits could evaporate just as quickly."
Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting and research firm, has a similar view. "Increasingly," he said, "we get the sense that governments are beginning to believe these kinds of revenue gains are going to be around for a long time and they're starting to base their policy decisions on that belief -- and that's the risk."
Analysts prescribed a menu of policies that would improve the city's ability to respond to a downturn on Wall Street, including bigger reserve funds, smaller spending increases and the use of more of the surplus to reduce long-term debt.
Last week, the City Council put the Giuliani administration on the defensive by proposing to use $500 million to retire some of the long-term debt next year. But the Giuliani administration said that plan was merely a ploy by the Council to spend an additional $226 million on various programs.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has tended to play down Wall Street's importance to his budgets, arguing that his fiscal policies are responsible for their surpluses.
And he has pointed out that the number of jobs in the city's securities industry, roughly 155,000, has fallen from its historic peak in 1987 and that employment has grown in other sectors. But what he fails to mention is that many of the securities industry's low-paying jobs have been eliminated by computers and other technological advances, thereby raising the industry's share of high-paying jobs and their importance to tax revenues, analysts said.
In 1987, the securities industry's jobs accounted for 4.5 percent of the city's total employment and 11 percent of all wages earned. But now, the industry still makes up 4.5 percent of the city's total employment but 17 percent of all wages. No other industry comes even close to having salaries with such a disproportionate impact on the city's tax base, economists said.
By almost any measure, analysts said, Wall Street's boom has made a significant and ever-growing impact on the budgets of not only New York City but also that of New York State and its neighbors. In 1985 and 1986, the height of the last decade's boom, the securities industry recorded $9.6 billion in profits. But they have been eclipsed by Wall Street's profits over the last two years of $23.5 billion, which has far outpaced inflation over that time.
In fiscal 1996, the city had a $224 million surplus; in the last two years, the surpluses shot up, in sync with the market boom, to $1.4 billion and $2 billion, respectively. Surpluses also reached record highs in Albany, $1.4 billion and $2 billion in each of the last two years.
Bonuses earned on Wall Street totaled about $27.6 billion over the last three years, compared to the $6.5 billion recorded from 1985 to 1987. Perhaps even more importantly, Wall Street workers now receive a greater share of their total compensation from bonuses, more than double the level of 1987, according to estimates by the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget. Because the size of bonuses depends on profit levels, the tax revenues they produce can swing from year to year.
"The bonuses can go down as quickly as they went up," said Donald J. Boyd, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany. "It's hard to base spending or tax-cutting decisions on what may be extraordinary good luck."
In particular, Mr. Kurtter said that bonuses could quickly change the fortunes of Albany, which gets more than half of its tax revenues from personal income taxes, compared with 24 percent for the city. A one-year dip in the market, he said, could mean a drop of hundreds of millions of dollars in tax money for Albany.
Reflecting such concerns, the state's long-term fiscal health continues to be ranked last in the nation by Moody's.
In addition, city taxpayers realized more than $11 billion in capital gains last year, up from $4.5 billion in 1994, before the boom began, according to the Office of Management and Budget. The gains were mostly from the stock market, ranging from Wall Street tycoons cashing in stock options to average New Yorkers selling off some of their mutual funds.
And in a broader sense, economists said, governments are benefiting from a host of other tax revenues that have risen with the stock market. The bull market has kept lawyers busy on mergers and acquisitions, sent tourists to Manhattan and encouraged consumers to spend on everything from clothes to computers to apartments.
Using historical relationships between the stock market and tax revenue growth, Mr. Zandi calculated that since 1996, Wall Street has produced 43 to 72 percent of the annual tax revenue growth of New York State.
And he estimated that at least 31 percent of Connecticut's tax revenue growth since 1996, and at least 18 percent of New Jersey's, resulted from Wall Street.
"This makes the 1980's look like small potatoes," said Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission. "Most people think this is merely another boom period that we've had, a reflection of the cyclical nature in the New York economy. This is a megaboom compared to earlier booms.
"But," he added, "the bigger the boom, the bigger the bust."
As an example of how Wall Street's wild swings can hurt the city, Thomas L. McMahon, the New York City Council's finance director, pointed to 1994, when the bond market tumbled suddenly in February after the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates. That year, Wall Street's profits plummeted 87 percent from the previous year, to $1.1 billion.
So only weeks after the city adopted a budget in late June of 1994, Mr. McMahon said, City Hall had to cut $700 million from it, because tax collections were far lower than expected. As the market worsened and tax revenues kept shrinking, the Mayor and Council fought over how to cut more than $1 billion in November. "It got so wild that we ended up in court," Mr. McMahon said. "Services were affected in every area of the city."
So how well prepared is the city government for the next downturn?
Joseph J. Lhota, the Mayor's budget director, said, "We have prepared for the volatility of Wall Street by being fiscally disciplined and not dramatically increasing the rate of growth in spending." He noted that 38 percent of the city's revenue came from property taxes, which are more stable than personal income taxes.
"Our diversity is our strength," Mr. Lhota said. "While Wall Street represents 17 percent of our revenues, other industries represent 83 percent."
But some analysts said the Giuliani administration had not done enough to put the city's fiscal house in order. The government's spending is still growing faster than its revenues, contributing to multibillion-dollar budget gaps that the city has been able to patch recently with the Wall Street revenues but that, in Mr. Giuliani's early budgets, the city closed through service cuts and one-shot budget maneuvers.
Mr. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission said the Wall Street boom masked the budget gaps and other inherent problems in the city's budget, and it had driven Mr. Giuliani from his pledge to make the municipal government more productive. Lengthening the workweek of city employees by two hours, to 37, would have saved the city millions and would have been a real but politically difficult reform, Mr. Horton said.
Mr. Lhota dismissed the criticism as politically unrealistic. "You would get a better budget analysis by turning on the Psychic Friends Network," Mr. Lhota said.
In general, analysts on Wall Street and in government reacted favorably to the budget Mr. Giuliani has proposed for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, especially compared with the state budget.
"This year's budget actions show that the Mayor and the City Council have been more attentive to the long-term problem of Wall Street's volatility than officials in Albany, both the Governor and the Legislature," said H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller.
Mr. McCall endorsed the Mayor's proposal to patch short-term budget gaps with the surplus, instead of spending it. But he said the city was failing to use the boom to tackle long-term problems, including retiring some of its $32 billion in debt. The Giuliani administration, however, says the city should focus on getting its current house in order.
Once the short-term budget gaps shrink, the city should begin paying off debt as a way of addressing long-term problems, the Mayor said Sunday. Explaining why he opposed the Council's plan to spend more money on programs, the Mayor cited the uncertainty of city finances.
"Anything," he added, "can happen on Wall Street."

But financial experts fear city and state budgets are depending too much on this unstable trend to continue. Chart shows securities industry wages and total city wages, from 1987 through 1997. HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Indonesia's New President Plans a Vote Before 2003
Bowing to pressure from inside and outside his Government, Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, said he would be a transitional figure and would hold an election before his term ends in 2003. A spokesman said voting might come this year. Indonesian political experts reacted with skepticism, saying it was not clear how far the electoral system would be opened to allow for opposition and whether Mr. Habibie would be able to steer such a course. A1 

Russia Tries to Calm Investors
Russia assured investors that it would not follow the path of faltering Asian economies. President Boris N. Yeltsin summoned bankers and industrialists to an unusual Kremlin meeting on ways to end the financial crisis and the new Prime Minister addressed foreign investors. The test for the Government: to stabilize the ruble's rate against the dollar. A1
 
Cult Crimes Tallied in Japan
In repeated germ attacks in the early 1990's, a Japanese cult tried to kill millions of people throughout Tokyo and, a cultist has now testified, also thousands of people at nearby American military bases. An examination of court testimony and confessions of the cult's members, as well as interviews with Japanese and American officials, show that the group's germ attacks were far more numerous than previously known. A1
 
Swiss Ignored Nazi Looting
A long-awaited report about wartime dealings in Nazi gold concluded that by 1941, Swiss National Bank officials knew that some gold sent to Switzerland had been taken in occupied areas, but that officials turned a blind eye toward whether gold was stolen from Holocaust victims. A6
 
Costly Sludge Problem in Spain
The toxic sludge that burst from a mine reservoir and flooded rivers and farms in Spain last month will cost $100 million to clean up. The Minister of Environment said crews would try to finish as much as possible before autumn rains. A5
 
Jews Build in Muslim Quarter
Jewish settlers poured foundations for new homes in the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem's walled Old City, thereby expanding their foothold in the Arab neighborhood. Although the settlers claim ownership of the land where they are working, they appeared to be operating without a building permit from the Jerusalem Municipality, which periodically demolishes illegally built Arab homes in East Jerusalem. A3
 
Israel May Concede More Land
The Israeli Defense Minister, Yitzhak Mordechai, said that Israel would have to agree to turn over a "double-digit" percentage of West Bank land to Palestinians. It was the first time he has publicly envisaged a transfer above the 9 percent already offered by Israel in the second stage of a three-stage withdrawal. But his remarks stopped short of acceptance of the 13 percent proposed by the United States. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A12-18
 
Improved Air Safety Is Goal Of Laser Detection System
A laser-based system for detecting air turbulence and other invisible hazards to planes has been tested at Kennedy International Airport in New York. The results of the technique, which uses lasers to listen for the sound of rapidly moving air, could improve airline safety. The laser system could detect the wake behind large jets, which can toss about smaller planes. Scientists also hope to adapt the technique to hear the microbursts that cause wind shear, a deadly hazard to planes at low altitude, and clear-air turbulence. A16

A bomb caused the explosion that ripped through the First Assembly of God Church in Danville, Ill., Sunday morning, Federal officials said yesterday. The blast, which injured 34 people, is the second church bombing in Vermilion County in five months. A similar explosion in December at the United Methodist Church in Oakwood, Ill., just eight miles away, killed one person. Federal officials would not say whether the two bombings were related. A18

Dialysis Equipment Inquiry
Defective tubing used in a dialysis machine is believed to be the cause of illnesses reported in three states, including two deaths in Maryland. The company that makes the tubing issued a recall today and dialysis centers where dozens of patients became sick in Nebraska, Massachusetts and Maryland shut down temporarily. Tests show a blockage in the tubing, made by Gambro Healthcare of Lakewood, Colo., and sent to 31 dialysis clinics, that could damage red blood cells in patients. A Gambro spokesman said the company was recalling three lots of cartridges that send patients' blood through the dialysis machine. A18

Aspiring to Be House Speaker
Springtime in Washington makes Robert L. Livingston the man to see. As chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, he allocates the money that keeps the Government running and keeps members of Congress in good standing at home. Now he has added to his power by declaring that he wants to be Speaker of the House. As a candidate for Speaker, Mr. Livingston needs to please his colleagues to win their votes. As chairman of Appropriations, he has a very direct way to please them. A18

As Drug Raids Increase, More Residents Sue City
The Giuliani administration has stepped up its anti-drug initiatives, forcing many low-level dealers off the sidewalks, leading the police to double the number of narcotics search warrants executed each year. Most allow the police to enter without warning and they say most raids yield drugs. SCIENCE TIMES F1-6
 
A Clue to AIDS Immunity
There is one eerie similarity between the bacteria that caused the Black Death and H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS: Both attack macrophages, which are the scavenger white blood cells of the immune system. Now scientists at the National Cancer Institute have reported that they have found that a genetic mutation that protects against the AIDS virus emerged in Europe around the time of the Black Death, or bubonic plague. And the resistance gene is astonishingly common in people whose ancestors lived in areas of Europe ravaged by the plague. F1
 
Using DNA to Track Poachers
Wildlife officials are increasingly turning to the tools of human forensics and using DNA testing to help them convict poachers by taking evidence from the crime scenes and matching them up to the trophy items the hunters take home. F4

HEADLINE: Putting Africa On Coke's Map;
Pushing Soft Drinks on a Continent That Has Seen Hard, Hard Times

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
On the edge of the black South African township of Soweto, perched atop Vic de Villiers's gas station roof, is a retired South African Air Force warplane, known as the Coke Bomber. Earlier this month, workers showed up to give the plane, which bears the Coca-Cola Company's trademark red logo, a fresh paint job, courtesy of Coke. Coke is now also paying Mr. de Villiers to illuminate the plane at night.
Elsewhere in South Africa, in the vast Orange Farm shantytown outside Johannesburg, the refrigerators at tiny "spaza shops," run out of the backs of tin and cinderblock houses, carry Coca-Cola products supplied by local distributors who have plenty of incentive to keep them filled with Coke bottles. Meshack Malindi, one such distributor, says if he can beat all his rivals to double-digit sales growth, he will win a trip to the soccer World Cup in France this summer. 
 And to the north, in war-shattered Angola, local officials in the town of Bonjesus are awaiting the construction of a $30 million Coke bottling plant. Meanwhile, in Ghana, on the West African coast, another $34 million plant is already in full swing.
These are among the many signs that Coke is heating up its efforts in Africa. Sure, Coca-Cola has been available in South Africa for 60 years and West Africa for 30, and its trademark glass bottles turn up in Ugandan villages, Madagascar roadside huts and Zairean refugee camps. But the company has long tended to ignore Africa's underdeveloped markets and only recently has the continent acquired priority status -- a decision made largely by the new chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester.
Mr. Ivester toured Africa in January 1997, nine months before getting Coke's top job. His Africa strategy, presented to the board in December, aims to double sales -- they were 712 million cases last year, a meager 3 percent of the company's global total -- in five years.
The strategy has several parts: strengthening the bottler network, increasing the number of outlets and intensifying the marketing to consumers. During Phase 1 last year, an estimated 50,000 coolers and refrigerators were installed, many in places like Orange Farm that only recently got electricity, to put Coke products within easier reach.
Coke is spending freely to build its network of bottlers and sales people, both on its own and through its anchor bottler, Coca-Cola Sabco. It is also using local institutions, from universities to soccer tournaments, to propel its strategy along.
"To be very candid, Africa has not historically been a real priority for the Coca-Cola Company," Mr. Ivester declared in a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, earlier this year. "But over the past two years, we have come to a very different perspective."
That shift came about, he said, because of population growth -- there are 610 million people now, possibly a billion by 2020 -- and disproportionately low sales. The per-capita consumption is 27 eight-ounce Coke servings a year, microscopic compared with North America (358) and Latin America (187).
Even though Coke, at 20 to 80 cents a bottle (in returnable glass bottles), is relatively cheap compared with prices in the United States and Europe, Africans drink far more water, fruit juice and other beverages. The market is "grossly underdeveloped with some very large populations," said Andrew Conway, a beverage analyst with Morgan Stanley.
Not everyone agrees that getting the world's poorest, most undernourished continent to double its consumption of a sugar-filled, nutritionally empty beverage is a good thing.
"The direct adverse public health effect is mostly on teeth," said David Sanders, a professor of public health at South Africa's University of the Western Cape. "As for indirect effects -- it's an inefficient use of a low income. If people are encouraged to spend some of their meager incomes on empty calories, they won't have money to spend on more nutritious foods."
In an interview, Mr. Ivester said he had personally researched the nutrition question. "Actually, our product is quite healthy," he said. "Fluid replenishment is a key to health, and when you have a population that has appropriate fluid intake, what you find is they have a lot less kidney problems and kidney disease." Although the World Health Organization says that kidney disease ranks low on the long list of illnesses that afflict Africans, Mr. Ivester said he had spent time with scientists who specialized in the issue, and "some of them will tell you Coca-Cola does a great service because it encourages people to take in more and more liquids."
Coca-Cola prides itself on promoting entrepreneurship, which the continent badly needs. A hawker who can raise $7 to buy a case can sell it quickly on a hot day and re-invest the profits in more. S'bu Mngadi, chief spokesman for Coca-Cola Southern Africa, pointed proudly to the Kunene brothers of Mpumalanga, South Africa, who started out as spaza shop owners selling Coke and now own a multimillion-dollar bottling business.
Coke also does charitable work in Africa, paying for mobile clinics and college scholarships to the tune of about $7 million a year, Mr. Mngadi said, although Professor Sanders dismissed that amount as "peanuts" relative to its sales. Still, Coke's per-case profit margins are lower in Africa than in many other parts of the world. One analyst, Emanuel Goldman of Paine Webber, estimates profit in the region at about 24 cents a case last year, up 5 percent over 1996 but still only two-thirds of the company average.
In any case, the terrain for expansion is tough. Twelve of the continent's 55 countries have fought civil wars in the last decade. Some major highways are pocked with potholes big enough to flip a truck. In Angola and the former Zaire, trucks risk landmines and ambushes by soldiers-turned-bandits. And poverty limits sales growth.
But as far as competitors go, Coke has the territory pretty much to itself. South Africa is the gateway to the continent and Coca-Cola never really left, even during the years of anti-apartheid sanctions. The company moved its syrup plant to Swaziland, a tiny nation virtually inside South Africa, selling off its bottling interests, but it continued to advertise and sell in South Africa.
Pepsi, which did honor the sanctions and pull out, has twice tried to get back in, and twice failed. It is now sold in only 11 African countries but holds a 50 percent market share in Uganda and has a strong presence in Ethiopia and Nigeria. Africa is less of a priority for Pepsi, which is focusing on India, China and Russia, though it does not exactly admit that. Pepsi is a unit of Pepsico.
"We think there's a lot of growth opportunity in Africa," said a Pepsi-Cola International spokesman, Keith Hughes, "and we intend to continue building a solid business to tap that."
Over all, Coke has a 79 percent share of the African soft-drink market. "Coke's biggest obstacle to growth in the region," says Michael Branca, a beverage industry analyst with Lehman Brothers, "is themselves."
On his 1997 trip, Mr. Ivester personally discovered the region's potential during an impromptu stop along the road between Johannesburg and Soweto. "There was a squatters' camp that had arisen there, with people coming from Mozambique and the outlying territories," Mr. Ivester recalled.
"I ran across this guy who was selling ice cream," he said. "I started interviewing him about how much ice cream he sold, where he got it, how much money he was making. It was clear to me that an entrepreneurial environment exists at all levels of society, even in these squatter camps."
Coke has one anchor bottler, Coca-Cola Sabco, based in Port Elizabeth, in which it holds a 21 percent stake, and scores of smaller ones. Some analysts think it will soon assemble at least one more anchor bottler -- important, since it is through them that headquarters in Atlanta drives its marketing and sales objectives. It vastly prefers to use fewer, more efficient bottlers than a fragmented network like the one that has slowed its strategy in India.
With the strategy has come re-education for bottlers. Most of them saw their jobs only as selling Coke where people wanted it. The bottler's role, however, is "not just about fulfilling demand, but about creating demand," said Carl H. Ware, president of Coke's Africa group.
For example, last year a group of executives visited Angola, which is slowly recovering from decades of civil war, and glimpsed people feasting and dancing by lamplight in town squares late at night.
"Our strategy would call for us to get in there and place coolers, to help give people a simple moment of pleasure," said Charles S. Frenette, recently named Coke's chief marketing officer after two years running Coca-Cola South Africa.
Coolers are not alone on the Angolan agenda. In September, Coke signed an agreement with the Government to build the bottling plant in Bonjesus, near Luanda.
Similar agreements are being negotiated in other countries. The company makes sure most of the materials used in the plants, from the sugar in the processing to the wood in the crates, are locally produced. "As a result," Mr. Ivester said, "we are able to price the product in almost local wage terms so it is affordable."
To create new customers, Coke is helping to open shops from Uganda to South Africa. By making irresistible offers -- it often pays the entire cost of a kiosk or an ice chest and sponsors business and management classes for budding micro-entrepreneurs -- it is generating markets where there might have been none.
"The infrastructure in terms of people and equipment that is already in place should enable them to capture per capita growth as Africa develops," said John D. Sicher, editor of Beverage Digest, a trade publication.
Moving to the academic sector, the company has set up "Coca-Cola Forums" to train entrepreneurs, usually to work for Coke, at the University of Zimbabwe and the University of Nairobi in Kenya.
"What we've seen in South Africa is somebody who starts by standing on a street corner, then moving up to a kiosk," Mr. Frenette said.
One of the chief marketing vehicles has been sports, especially soccer, Africa's passion. Coke was lead sponsor of the African Cup of Nations, a continentwide tournament held this year in Burkina Faso, a tiny impoverished country that borders Ghana on the north.
Every local bottler on the continent had posters and ads linking Coca-Cola with the Cup. To build good will and brand identification, Coke also re-sods local soccer fields and hands out new goal posts and scoreboards with the Coke logo.
Coke supplied free soft drinks, telephones and transportation to officials and reporters at the tournament. On a continent where television stations are too cash-strapped to send their own reporters to the games, the company contracted with a reporter from a Nairobi station to present a nightly two-minute feature that it broadcast without charge to any station that asked.
"It's a very happy marriage," said Brendan Harris, Coca-Cola Africa's marketing director. To be linked with soccer "is very good for us; at the same time, we were able to put something back."

HEADLINE: Russia Takes Steps To Assure Investors Economy Will Hold

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 25

 BODY:
Shaken by global financial turmoil, Russia tried to assure anxious investors today that it would not follow the path of Indonesia and other faltering Asian economies.
President Boris N. Yeltsin summoned leading bankers and industrialists to an unusual Kremlin meeting this week on ways to end the financial crisis. 
 Meanwhile, Mr. Yeltsin's new Prime Minister told foreign investors that the Government would not allow the downturn in Asia to infect Russia's economy. "We intend to live up to our financial obligations," Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko said told a group of American pension fund and money managers.
The Government's assurances come as Russia has been knocked off balance by a series of economic and political body blows. In recent weeks the Government has had to cope with anxious foreign investors, a decline in oil prices, tough talks with the International Monetary Fund and labor unrest, all while Mr. Kiriyenko, a determined but politically untested Prime Minister, was trying to assemble his Government.
The key question is whether Russia can maintain the stability of the ruble and avoid the panic both among investors and ordinary Russians that would almost certainly follow a currency devaluation. So far, the Central Bank has managed to keep the ruble steady, though it has been forced to spend from its reserves to do so. But investors say Russia is approaching several critical tests: avoiding the collapse of cash-strapped banks, attracting bidders for its long-awaiting selloffs of state property and winning the support of the International Monetary Fund, which is considering whether to provide the latest installment of a $10 billion loan.
"Unfortunately, the situation has not developed in a favorable way," Sergei Dubinin, the chairman of the Central Bank said. "I believe this reflects not only our dependence on international events, including those in southeast Asia, but also our own internal problems."
Russia's economic crisis is all the more unsettling because this was supposed to be the year when the economy finally began to take off. But with such an array of problems one senior Government official predicted that the economy -- which grew at a rate of eight-tenths of a percentage point last year -- would be generally flat this year.
Russia's economic woes stem from a dangerous interaction between events beyond the Kremlin's control and the nation's heavy dependence on deficit financing.
Foreign investors have been fleeing emerging markets in recent months as Asian economies stumbled. That has hit Russia hard since it is heavily dependent on foreign investors to finance its enormous budget deficit.
To encourage investors to keep buying Russian treasury bills, the Central Bank raised interest rates to over 50 percent. Paying such high interest will divert Government funds from other pressing needs.
The exodus of foreign investors has also taken a serious toll on Russia's stock market, which fell by more than 30 percent this month. The drop in world oil prices has hurt Russian exports and deprived the Government of badly needed revenue.
Meanwhile, the central bank has been dipping into its reserves to buy rubles and prop up the nation's currency.
There are several reasons the Government feels that it needs to maintain the ruble at its current relation to the dollar. A stable ruble would buttress the solvency of banks and prevent the ballooning of the Government's debt. It is also important to ordinary Russians, who see a firm exchange rate as a barometer of the nation's economic and political stability.
The Government is also trying to cope with problems inflicted on the economy by Russian nationalists. In a move that scared many investors, the Parliament voted earlier this month to restrict foreign ownership of the electrical monopoly, Unified Energy Systems. Since foreigners own many shares in the monopoly, that has spurred fears that some of those shares will be confiscated. The Yeltsin Government is challenging the law in the Constitutional Court.
Another pressing question is whether the 35 year-old Mr. Kiriyenko and his team of young aides can get the economy back on track.
Mr. Kiriyenko told foreign investors today that he would work to protect the rights of shareholders, promote tax reform and reduce the Government's borrowing costs by cutting spending drastically. Some investors were clearly pleased by what they heard.
"They're answering all the questions that my colleagues and investors are asking and they're answering them right," said Peter Aldrich, chairman of AEW International, in Boston, which has $50 million invested in Russia.
Walter Stern, chairman of Capital Group International Inc., in New York, was more skeptical.
"His talk was favorably received but the question is how he will implement these reforms," Mr. Stern said. "The next two to three weeks are going to be critical."
There are, in fact, some immediate challenges. One case that investors are closely monitoring concerns Tokobank, an institution that has run into trouble.
Tokobank has received a temporary infusion of cash from the Central Bank. But the Central Bank also says that it does not plan to prop up Tokobank after this week and that shareholders and creditors need to work out a long-term plan to keep the bank afloat. A collapse of the bank could send shock waves through the banking sector.
Another potential bellwether concerns the Government's plans to sell Rosneft, a state-owned oil company. The Government has stipulated that bids start at $2.1 billion.
But with many companies experiencing a cash crunch and with oil prices depressed it is not clear which companies, if any, will bid. A failure to sell Rosneft would be taken by many investors as a sign that Russian assets are no longer so desirable.
Beyond that, the Government is waiting to hear from the I.M.F. following talks here last week. Russian officials say they expect the fund to approve a $700 million disbursement, though fund officials say they are still studying the Government's deficit reduction plan.
One issue on which the Government has made headway is in defusing swelling labor unrest.
Mr. Kiriyenko's team has persuaded coal miners to stop blocking rail lines in Siberia and other parts of the country by rushing back wages to them. Most of the wage arrears for the miners, however, remain unpaid and just where the money will come to pay them is unclear.
Today, Mr. Yeltsin convened a meeting of his Security Council to discuss the plight of the coal miners and ethnic strife in the Caucasus.
Mr. Yeltsin's press spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, later underscored the severity of the woes, while insisting that the worst was over.
"The deterioration of the situation posed a threat to political stability in the country and in several cases to the national security," he said.

HEADLINE: After School and Before Home;
Parents Seek Havens Like 'Homework Club' to Fill the Gap

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 25

 BODY:
Pam Carrano tells one child to take off his hat before dinner, another to abandon the computer and the rest to settle down. She asks who wants sesame chicken and who wants baked ziti.
Homework is finished. So is softball practice and a few screechy turns on the violin. There will be enough daylight after dinner for a tussle with the dogs. 
 The scene could be a Saturday Evening Post cover of a suburban family spending an evening at home. But it is not. This is Ms. Carrano's business venture, the Homework Club, a place for children to go after school and before their parents come home from work, where they study, play and enjoy the amenities of home from 3 to 8 P.M.
It is also one small effort to bring some safety and order to these five weekday hours that have become the focus of growing national attention, anxiety and debate -- particularly for preteen-agers and young teen-agers who seem too old for baby sitters and too young to be left on their own.
These are the hours that working parents everywhere dread, and that experts agree are the most dangerous time of the day for youngsters.
Studies -- and common sense -- indicate that unsupervised youngsters are more likely to use drugs or alcohol, have sex, get poor grades or commit crimes. But even for children who steer clear of such trouble, the after-school hours can loom long and empty.
In recent months, policymakers have turned their attention to the risks and opportunities of these hours, particularly for vulnerable early adolescents. In Washington, President Clinton has proposed spending $200 million a year on after-school programs. In New York City, George Soros, the philanthropist, is offering up to $25 million to establish such programs.
And around the nation, there is a push to keep schools open from dawn to dark, sanctuaries for the children of working parents.
"A majority of them are lonely," Ms. Carrano said. "Who wants to go home to an empty house? It goes against nature. Kids this age are social creatures."
The twin perils for these children are over-scheduling and isolation. Some race from Little League to rehearsals for "Guys and Dolls," without a moment to spare. Others pass afternoons at home with Oprah, Final Fantasy and a bag of Doritos for company.
"Both create the sense that nobody cares," said Edward Zigler, director of the Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy at Yale University.
And that has two results: "One is the acting-out, aggressive kind of stuff," he said. "And the other, which is rarely discussed, is depression."
Around the country, people like Ms. Carrano have begun to see opportunity in the changing face of America's families. Car services have proliferated in recent years in the suburbs, to replace the mothers who once spent their afternoons ferrying children to play dates and other activities. Tutors are hired to supervise homework, so parents can spend their meager time at home in more pleasant pursuits.
The Homework Club, Ms. Carrano says, tries to be scheduled without being hectic. Loneliness is not a problem. After snacks and school work, a half-dozen children sit on bean-bag chairs and dissect their day. They talk about a math teacher so mean she does not allow gum chewing during tests. They debate the merits of the Spice Girls and the Backstreet Boys.
Ms. Carrano, who started the Homework Club for elementary school children in 1995 and added preteen-agers six months ago, tells parents that her philosophy is to try to fill their shoes.
"I tell them, 'I want your child's life to be as normal as if you were home,' " said Ms. Carrano, who gave up a career in New York City as a fashion stylist to rear two daughters. "If your kid forgets lunch, I'll bring it to school. If your kid falls in Sugar Pond, I'll bring dry clothes. If they're sick, they come here with a pillow and I feed them chicken soup."
The Homework Club is just one place in the after-school universe of this economically diverse Westchester County village of about 8,000 people. Indeed, at a cost of $25 a day, and $10 more for dinner, for each of the 30 children who take part in the sessions either at Ms. Carrano's house or at a nearby church, the club is the sort of solution only the relatively well-to-do can afford.
Here in Hastings, 3 to 8 actually begins at 2:45, when youngsters rich and poor tumble out of the red-brick building that houses the middle and high schools. Toting backpacks, sports equipment and musical instruments, they fan out in all directions: to confraternity classes and dance lessons, to tutors and karate instruction, downtown for pizza or up to a meadow where the police often find empty beer kegs.
Many actually stay at school. Seven of 10 youngsters belong to sports teams, the elementary school runs a popular after-hours program and the high school library and computer lab stay open until 5. But the district's commitment to keeping schools open later to accommodate working parents is matched by only one-third of the nation's schools.
And those teen-agers whose parents cannot afford music lessons or the Homework Club after the schools close their doors are often left to fend for themselves. They also get in trouble more often. During a recent week, one was arrested for scrawling anti-Semitic graffiti on parking meters and six others for scaling a fence at the local swimming pool to have a beer party.
Their hangouts are a shabby community center that has cigarette butts littering the stoop, cast-off furniture and a boom box that works only sometimes, and a village landmark known simply as "the Wall," a stone rampart outside the V.F.W. Hall where generations of teen-agers have congregated.
The middle class and wealthy children are more likely to be supervised, but even in richer families, stay-at-home mothers are rare -- the middle school principal, Jennifer Dolan, can find just a few when she rifles through her Rolodex of parents.
It is the many working parents in Hastings who keep Pam Carrano's dinner table full -- the parents who juggle work and home and sometimes end up feeling they are doing neither terribly well.
Many of the children there complain that their mothers are inattentive after a long day of work and their fathers do not get home until bedtime.
Danny Lebost, who is 11, says his mother is so cranky at night that he dare not "get in her way one tiny bit." And she does not contradict him. Sondra Lebost says that a job at the New York Botanical Garden, a husband who works all hours and elderly parents who need her help leave her frayed. She comes home to a pile of mail, a blinking answering machine and a dog who needs walking. Too beat for anything better, the evening meal is often a can of soup.
"He enjoys Pam's dinner table enormously," Mrs. Lebost said. "I know he's lonely."
Homework is the centerpiece of Ms. Carrano's program, with the younger children at work in her basement and older ones at the parish hall at Grace Episcopal Church. One recent day, Kate Frey hunched over her fifth-grade social studies workbook, answering questions like "Why did the founders think we needed a government?" Next, for a language arts lesson, she used new vocabulary words in a sentence: "The king has a lots of dictums. The girl would gloat about her tests."
Bennett Faber, also 11, invaded her tranquillity to announce that his class had just seen a film about puberty. Kate shut him up with a sharp, "Thank you, Bennett," before he could offer details. "I had to go to the nurse, I felt so sick," Bennett said, determined to get the last word.
Supervising, from a respectful distance, was Melanie Anderson, a former psychologist who now works for Ms. Carrano. She had picked up the children at school, given them a snack of crackers and peanut butter and set them to their homework. "If you have practically nothing to do, that means you have something to do," she told one recalcitrant boy. "So get to work on your something."
Next came an activity -- pottery, carpentry or cartooning, the last taught by a high school senior, Zack Mason, who showed the children how to change a face from worried to angry just by reversing the tilt of the eyebrows. Most of the children were picked up by a parent before 6 P.M., the rest by Ms. Carrano, who drove them up the hill for dinner.
The last to leave the parish hall was Bennett, who grew agitated as other mothers came and went with no sign of his. He finally settled into his favorite activity, drawing gory pictures of a man with his head cut off and another with blood dripping from his mouth, the sort of images common in computer games.
All the mothers look haggard when they come to claim their children. And they agonize about the appropriate age to leave youngsters unsupervised. Susan Frey, Kate's mother and a librarian in nearby Dobbs Ferry, lets her 15-year-old son go home by himself after school. But he is not allowed to answer the telephone.
And some children experiment with independence. Bennett is now permitted one day a week at home with a friend, a concession his mother made after much pestering.
"I call constantly," said his mother, Ginny Faber, a book editor. "This is the age where they say they don't need you, but they really do."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Blocking Promising Students From City University

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
California's decision to outlaw the use of race in public college admissions has barred most black and Latino students from the elite campuses and raised the specter of a whitening professional class in a steadily browning state. Politicians elsewhere have recognized the potential for harm and have backed away from proposals that would limit minority access to higher education. But a different and more destructive plan has emerged in New York City, where Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is pushing a proposal that would scuttle open admissions at the City University of New York. This would depress graduation rates, not just for blacks and Latinos but for every ethnic group. Such a result would be terrible for the city's work force and economy.
Open admissions at the City University began in 1970, when the trustees allowed high school graduates who finished in the top half of their classes into the four-year colleges and anyone who graduated at all to attend the two-year junior colleges. CUNY's freshman class nearly doubled in a single year, with the largest increases occurring among ethnic whites who, like blacks and Latinos, had traditionally gone to worse public schools and done poorly on entrance exams. 
 Critics saw the new plan as radical. In truth, it was already common practice around the country -- most notably in California, which had historically offered broad access while maintaining the best public university system in the nation.
CUNY's version of open admissions has been called the most studied program in higher education history. The history of that research is summarized in the recently published book "Changing the Odds: Open Admissions and the Life Chances of the Disadvantaged," by the sociologists David Lavin and David Hyllegard. Nearly a quarter of a million New Yorkers who would otherwise have been shut out of college have gone on to receive degrees from CUNY. "Changing the Odds" documents significant income differences between students who took advantage of open admissions and their peers who did not.
Despite its obvious success, Mayor Giuliani has termed open admissions "a mistake." One alternative to that policy would forbid the senior colleges to offer the remedial courses that make open admissions work. Mr. Lavin calculates that the new policy would bar 38 percent of whites, 67 percent of African-Americans, 70 percent of Latinos and 71 percent of Asians from the four-year schools. Half of these students are immigrants, many of them better educated than their American peers but in need of schooling in English. Many of the rest are native New Yorkers whom the city schools have cheated of full educations.
The junior colleges that would supposedly catch these students are overcrowded and vocationally oriented, and tend to steer students away from more valuable, four-year degrees. In addition, junior college students are about half as likely to complete bachelor's degrees as are students who begin their educations on senior campuses.
The junior college system would smother many of the students who aspire to careers in science, medicine and engineering. This is clear from what happens at CUNY's most prestigious school, the City College School of Engineering, which is recognized as one of the country's best and ranks as one of the top producers of minority engineers nationwide. A significant number of engineering graduates begin with remedial calculus. Those who take this course at the engineering school thrive. But those who get it at junior colleges struggle.
Enemies of open admissions call it a blight on the university. But students who need one or two remedial courses are consistently among the system's most distinguished and highest-earning graduates, and graduate at only a slightly lower rate than students who do not need remediation.
Open admissions is not to blame for New York City's education problems. The trouble lies with a public school system that has consistently cheated the students whom CUNY must accept. Killing open admissions will not make the public schools better.
Californians pleaded ignorance after passing a seemingly innocuous law that proved catastrophic. But if the CUNY trustees pass this remedial plan, they will do so with full knowledge of the damage it portends.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Closing of Plant Moved Up

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Efforts have failed to persuade Imperial Wallcoverings to stay in Plattsburg, N.Y., and the 90-year-old company moved up its deadline to close, which would leave 350 people without jobs by October.
Imperial's closing announcement came in February as a result of a merger between Imperial and an Ohio-based wallpaper company, Borden Decorative Products. 
 The employees had been told that the plant's operations would be phased out over 18 months. But on Friday, without explanation, a sign went up on a bulletin board informing employees of the new deadline.
Union officials have called a meeting for today, when they are expected to provide details of the closing schedule and benefits package.

HEADLINE: Green, the Energizer Candidate, Proudly Holds the Liberal Line

SERIES: EARLY STEPS: The Senate Campaign

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Mark Green opposes the death penalty; in fact, as he likes to tell audiences, he is the only candidate running for United States Senate who is against it. In a field of Democrats who all support abortion rights, he goes so far as to assert that "life begins at birth," opposing virtually any restrictions on the procedure.
Mr. Green, New York City's Public Advocate, opposes tax credits for parents who send their children to private schools. He wants to raise the minimum wage. And as he campaigns for the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, he reaches back to the New Deal to inspire the foundation of his campaign: what he calls a Social Security system for children, with new spending on education and health care. 
 In a decade when such positions have fallen into some disrepute, Mr. Green at times sounds like a throwback, appealing to liberal voters at the risk of making himself an easy target for Mr. D'Amato and his chief political adviser, Arthur J. Finkelstein, both of whom have made a career out of attacking liberals.
But with far less money than either of his Democratic opponents, and seeking his second -- and if he does not succeed, no doubt last -- chance to unseat the Senator he has pursued for 12 years, Mr. Green may have little choice. While such a campaign by another politician might be readily dismissed, his candidacy is emerging as a test of his redoubtable capabilities as a politician, and a fresh measure of the vibrancy of liberal thinking in New York.
Of the three candidates seeking the Democratic nomination to unseat Mr. D'Amato, no one has been at it as long as Mr. Green. He ran unsuccessfully against Mr. D'Amato in 1986, and filed the complaint that led the Senate Ethics Committee to reprimand Mr. D'Amato in 1991. Mr. Green is known as a wily, resourceful and clever (perhaps, some of his friends say, a bit too clever) candidate who has been presenting himself as a consumer advocate and dedicated government servant; in short, anything but an ideologue or a career politician.
"I have spent more years as a public interest lawyer with Ralph Nader than I have in elective and appointive office," Mr. Green said over sushi and wine to a small gathering at the Park Avenue apartment of Eleanor Guggenheim the other evening. "I have spent more years writing and editing books than I have in elective office. So while I am a politician -- I wear dark suits, I'm nice to people I don't always like -- I am really, in biography and philosophy, more an advocate than a politician."
In truth, Mr. Green has been something of a fixture in New York politics for the better part of a decade. And in some significant, if not yet obvious, ways, he is different from both his Democratic opponents, Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Vice-Presidential candidate, and Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn. That difference is a point he has been subtly making with increasing frequency in the days leading up to tomorrow's Democratic state convention at the Rye Town Hilton in Westchester County, where the party will select candidates to run in the September primary.
Unlike Mr. Schumer and Ms. Ferraro, Mr. Green opposes the death penalty, which has long been an ideological marker in this state. Unlike Ms. Ferraro, Mr. Green opposes the ban on late-term abortions.
He lets his audiences know that he would have opposed the bill that effectively banned marriages between homosexuals. Mr. Schumer voted for the legislation in 1996, known as the Defense of Marriage Act, and Ms. Ferraro said she would have supported it had she held office at the time. And Mr. Green is far more inclined to advocate ambitious social spending programs -- financed by the projected Federal surplus -- than either rival.
The differences go to tactics as well. In a campaign in which Mr. Schumer and Ms. Ferraro have concluded that attacks on Mr. D'Amato's ethics are of dubious political value -- "To be quite frank, the voters all know he's a sleaze," Ms. Ferraro said the other evening -- the man who made his statewide name attacking Mr. D'Amato shows not the slightest interest in restraint. Mr. Green assails Mr. D'Amato at every microphone as an "ethical embarrassment who often votes against the interests of our children and our state," and he presents himself as "the un-D'Amato."
"Now I will not belabor, at the risk of insulting you, the topic of Al D'Amato," Mr. Green assured an audience of like-minded Democrats in Morningside Heights. He then proceeded to do precisely that.
"His idea of economic development is to get Federal contracts to his big contributors," Mr. Green said. "I would maintain that the last person you want, entering the 21st century, as our political leader is someone who is an old-fashioned, big-money, political boss."
In sketching out his attacks on Mr. D'Amato, Mr. Green is addressing the concerns of party members who remember the brutal campaign of 1992. Mr. Green asserted that his opponents were naive in concluding that attacks on Mr. D'Amato's values might not work.
"How can a candidate avoid talking about the problem of public ethics in a year of so many campaign finance scandals?" Mr. Green asked in an interview. "The public is interested. The issue is important. And it's relevant to how we govern the Senate. This issue has been the No. 1 issue to me in my first 30 years in public life."
As he heads to Westchester for the convention, there are indications that he has less organized support than his rivals; he certainly has far less money. Characteristically, Mr. Green has sought to turn that into an advantage, contending that it actually makes him a stronger candidate. "It's not very likely that Al D'Amato and Chuck Schumer can survive the liability of their millions of dollars in the popular vote," he said.
Along the same lines of trying to turn a little into a lot, Mr. Green has repeatedly shown his ability to use his public office -- consumer affairs commissioner and now public advocate -- to win public attention, on issues small and large. He was one of the earliest people to take credit for the effort to bar tobacco advertising aimed at children. Speaking to a luncheon of Harlem ministers, he took some credit for City Hall's effort to curb the influence of the mob in carting.
As Mr. Green presents his record, there are few chapters that escape his mention, even those that might seem to have little bearing on what he might do in the Senate. At Ms. Guggenheim's apartment, he boasted to a mostly female audience about his success in pursuing dry cleaners who charge more for cleaning women's clothes.
Among other politicians, Mr. Green is known for turning quickly to gimmickry to win press attention. At times, he can be "over the top," to borrow a description he once used for himself as he pulled a tattered copy of his typed bar mitzvah speech and began reciting it while accepting endorsements of Jewish leaders in front of City Hall. Similarly, Mr. Green turned up to denounce Mr. D'Amato's re-election announcement the other Sunday a full two hours before Mr. D'Amato's event.
He is given to alliteration and unlikely rhyme (once Mr. Green sought to rhyme "Manhattan Island" with "Staten Island"). He is quick to find parallels between his campaign and current events, relevant or not. "Thank you for civic commitment in coming here over watching the replay of David Wells's perfect game," Mr. Green told a group of Chelsea Democrats. "I am not throwing a perfect campaign. But it's not a bad campaign." His audience sat silent.
At another stop, Mr. Green told how he began in politics as an intern on Jacob K. Javits's Senate staff in 1968. "Apparently, at that time, an intern program meant something different," Mr. Green said, waiting for laughs. "He didn't lay a hand on me! I swear!"
Even his friends say Mr. Green can sometimes be a bit much; that said, there are indications that that style might be effective. At a candidates' forum the other evening, as Ms. Ferraro waited in the back of the room, Mr. Green made disparaging mention of her as a candidate who "seems to run on the fumes of fame and polls."
Ms. Ferraro was not smiling when she followed him to the lectern. "I just floated in on the fumes of fame and polls and I am delighted to be with you," she said sharply.
In the midst of this, Mr. Green has begun to lay out what he would do in the Senate. "First, I will push for the systematic campaign finance reform to end the Senate for sale," he said. "Second, I want a consumer H.M.O. bill of rights," to protect abuses by health maintenance organizations. His third priority would be the Social Security system for children, which would include increased Federal spending, after-school programs, prenatal care for mothers and universal health care for young people.
The key question is whether Mr. Green can emerge from the primary without being vulnerable to the ideological attacks that have become a staple of Mr. D'Amato's arsenal. Significantly, Mr. Green never uses the word "liberal" when describing himself. Speaking over a cellular telephone from Buffalo, he said he had no doubt that the attacks Mr. D'Amato had used successfully in the past would fail this time, for one reason in particular.
"I've never ever voted for a spending increase and I've never voted for a tax increase," he crackled over the phone. He paused for effect before delivering the political punch line.
"That's because I never voted!" said Mr. Green, who has never served in a legislature. "Arthur Finkelstein is going to have to dig long and deep to have his stale rhetoric stick to me."
 
Early Steps
 
A series of articles examining the political appeal and early campaign strategies of candidates in the New York Senate race.

PUB-DATE: May 26, 1998,

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International Banks Pulled Money From Asia in 1997
International banks began pulling their money out of Asia during the last half of 1997, with South Korea and Thailand bearing the brunt of the withdrawals, according to a report released by the Bank for International Settlements. Page D9.
 
Dollar Climbs Above 137 Yen
The dollar rose above 137 yen for the first time in almost seven years amid expectations that neither the United States nor Japan would be willing to stem the yen's decline. The dollar also gained against the mark. D9. 

Gas Prices Remain Low
Drivers on the road for Memorial Day weekend paid some of the lowest prices for gasoline in decades. The drop in crude oil prices brought the national average price for unleaded regular gasoline close to $1.10 a gallon last week, according to the American Automobile Association, about 14 cents lower than last year. Most oil industry analysts predict that prices will go up only moderately since crude oil prices are expected to remain low. D2.
 
Comcast Seeks Cable System
Comcast agreed to buy a 37 percent stake in Jones Intercable, for $500 million, as it seeks to bolster its cable television system in the mid-Atlantic region. D3.
 
Tyco International Makes Bid
Tyco International, a manufacturing company with domestic headquarters in New Hampshire, announced that it has offered to acquire United States Surgical, a maker of surgical tools, for $3.3 billion in stock. D4.
 
20 Advertising Questions
Should Procter & Gamble create a new brand of facial tissues called Puffs Daddy? At what price Diet Coke merchandise? Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D6.
 
U.S. Markets Reopen
Financial markets in the United States are open today; they were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day.
