HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
Indian Culture, at Risk at Home, Finds Fans Abroad

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Heilman Brooke 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
While American Indians fear that their languages, songs, dances, arts, crafts, rituals and oral history may not survive the cultural melding of the 21st century, they are finding a growing audience in Europe and Asia.
For instance, this year a Navajo poet will be published in Navajo by an Irish publishing company that will provide English and Gaelic translations. A group of Lakota musicians and storytellers will take tales of Lakota stellar traditions to a Cheshire, England, planetarium. And the Hopi's Nuvatukyaovi Dancers will be the first American Indian dancers ever to perform in Slovenia when they sing and dance in Maribor in early July. 
 In 1995 and 1996, the Navajo's Chinle Valley Singers donned their colorful native dress and sang in Estonia, Finland and the Philippines. In 1996, a Cherokee children's book author and illustrator toured Singapore.
Of course, Buffalo Bill first recognized an international market for the lore of the America Indian in the late 1800's when he took bareback riders and sharpshooters on tour throughout Europe.
Rather than Indian and cowboy showmen, today's Buffalo Bills are more likely to be anthropologists, historical guardians or savvy artists. Many Indian performing artists have begun to establish European contacts and regular European venues, but others have an agent handle details of museum exhibitions, folk festivals, fund-raising and transportation of sacred objects.
Jason Yazzie, economic development specialist for the Navajo nation, said that often "the native dancers are naive about how to market themselves." But the naivete works both ways. Birgil Kills Straight, a Lakota who has lectured in various European universities, said, "They still ask me if Indians wear feathers and live in teepees." Mr. Kills Straight is the executive director of the Oglala Sioux Parks and Recreation Authority and since the 1980's has been helping the Lakota's Takini Dance Group get performance dates in Paris, Geneva, Milan and Marseilles. In 1996 the 10 singers and dancers of the group performed for Prince Rainier in Monaco. This year, the group will perform June 4-12 in Bologna, Italy.
"Our group has always performed right out of the reservation," Mr. Kills Straight said. "We bring onto the stage the genuine moves with very little lighting. We've had great success." Mr. Kills Straight deals with logistics and scheduling.
In general, transporting sacred eagle feathers across international borders has not been a problem, but he said: "In New Zealand they wanted to fumigate my eagle feather. I am always very cautious with our eagle feathers. We regard the eagle feathers as sacred, and before we make a journey and before and after a performance we have our own purification ceremonies. We smudge the feathers with sage."
Burning sage scented the Robert H. Johnson Planetarium in Lakewood, Colo., one evening as Ben Artichoker, Ben Sherman and Jessica Bordeaux-Vigil told Lakota tales of "The Stars, the Black Hills and the Buffalo," a presentation of ancient star knowledge that will be repeated in England this year.
Mr. Sherman is the chairman of the Western American Indian Chamber of Commerce and has traveled to France and Germany with a performing group of Dakota and Lakota, members of the Sioux nation.
"We had a wonderful reception even in Paris, where some seem to despise Americans but seem to love Native Americans," Mr. Sherman said. "Our drum group met several Frenchmen who were fluent in Lakota, but couldn't speak English."
Gordon Bronitsky, a white anthropologist based in Denver, represents Lakota, Hopi, Navajo, Blackfeet, Cherokee, Zuni, Isleta Pueblo, Inuit, Tlingit, even Sami from Finland. Originally from Albuquerque, Dr. Bronitsky was teaching in Frankfurt in the mid-1980's when he noticed German appreciation for American Indians. Later, while teaching at the Institute of American Indian Arts in Santa Fe, he realized "the depth, breadth and variety of Native American talent."
Since 1990, he has been "helping Indians do business overseas," as an agent and grant-proposal writer. Dr. Bronitsky, who has been fondly called in Navajo the "talkative cowboy," has a little gray ponytail and lots of big turquoise-studded Navajo jewelry. He works the phone and a fax from an apartment decorated with Hopi and Apache baskets and Navajo rugs. His German partner, Horst Eilers, is based in Bergamo, Italy, and scouts possible performance sites throughout Europe.
European interest "started with a romanticized vision of Native Americans," Mr. Eilers said. "The conquest of the West has left its impact on Europe." Mr. Eilers said an Italian comic magazine about cowboys and Indians is read by millions, and he wants to build on this interest and bring American Indian artists or even American Indian comic writers to Italy.
Europeans have been intrigued by American Indians since the 1890's, when a German fiction writer, Karl May, who had never met an Indian, began a series of books with characters like Winnetou and the Oil Baron. Mr. May's series never took hold in the United States, which already had its own cowboy and Indian writer, Zane Grey. Today there are Karl May theme parks in Austria and Germany.
The next issue of Capital magazine in Italy is to have a feature on four contemporary American Indian artists. Japan has an Old West village with an Indian theater and facade of a Western town. "Indian Time" is a current French magazine. Nanai-Notes is a Dutch magazine, and there is a Netherlands Action Group on Behalf of American Indians. First Americans Magazine is published in St. Petersburg, Russia, and in Minsk there is a Belorussian American Indian Friendship Society. When William Yazzie, a Navajo flute player and storyteller, performed in Minsk, a group of tall, blond Russian Indian hobbyists put on a powwow in his honor.
Kendrick Coochyamptewa, lead singer with the Nuvatukyaovi Dancers, a traditional Hopi dance group based in Flagstaff, Ariz., said he would leave the United States for the first time when he and the 10 other members of his group go to Slovenia and Italy at the end of June. He said they would be nervous getting on the airplane, but he would be happy to give people an accurate picture. "Native Americans still have a lot of traditions they hold sacred," he said. "People there think we must be wearing moccasins, but a lot of us have Nikes."
William Yazzie, the Navajo flute player from Chinle, Ariz., has been to Belarus, Germany and Greece, thanks to Dr. Bronitsky's initiative. "When I give my presentations," Mr. Yazzie said, "I talk about Navajo life. It is a simple way of life. My message is that the Navajo have a simple respect for nature, and if we all take time to show that simple respect for the earth, maybe the world would be a better place. Then we get the audience to participate, to dance with us in the Round Dance, which is like life: everything goes in a circle."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ben Sherman, left, who represents Indian artists, and Calvin Standing Bear, a Sioux, playing a native flute at an Arvada, Colo., school. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE ARTS IN: El Paso -- Dreams on the Streets of El Paso;
Home-Grown Culture Blooms in a Struggling Border Town

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
The gallery that just opened in the heart of this city's historic downtown has a dreamy, almost flower-child feel to it. Just a few blocks from the Mexican border, it is an artists' collective, with the exhibition space in an old furniture showroom on the ground floor, chaotically messy studios upstairs and a performance area in the basement.
Most of the artists are Hispanic, and they have filled the walls with fresh paintings. They are friendly, stoned-out types ("We smoke a little grass," one of them said with a shrug) who speak earnestly about self-expression, harmony and partying. They are essentially squatters, rent-free occupants of a building that would otherwise be empty, providing a genuine spark of exuberance on a once-bustling commercial strip that has gone seamy and listless, a casualty of the collapse of the peso. Almost as a bonus, not all the art is terrible. 
 "For now, we're here on the benevolence of the owner," said Gilbert Sanchez Lujan, a Chicano artist who goes by the name Magu and, at 57, is the oldest member of the collective and the most aware of the economic realities it faces. "But eventually we need $73,000 a month to operate this place, and these guys, they want to be anarchists. I mean, I do, too. That's what artists are. But it's not realistic. I know we can do something here, and I'm frustrated, because I see a lot of potential."
And so the new gallery, known as the Alternative Ark, sits here like a daisy placed in a gun barrel, unrealistically abloom in an unnatural environment and perhaps unlikely to survive but indisputably a good idea.
Which is not a bad metaphor for the arts overall in a city as poor and remote as this one, where they endure rather nobly in a kind of vacuum. It is a place, for example, where the city is building a new art museum and trying to develop its own arts and entertainment district.
Yet it is also a place where the local symphony orchestra is often featured on National Public Radio, but where few if any of its players make a living as musicians.
"I have an evangelistic spirit, but it's been tempered by reality," said Kwang-Wu Kim, who gave up a career as a concert pianist in Baltimore five years ago to run El Paso Pro Musica, an organization that presents chamber music events and runs introductory music programs in elementary schools. "A lot of people will never be interested. You make things accessible and count your successes one person at a time."
For another example, the city has a long tradition of muralistas; walls throughout the city are skillfully painted with the iconography of Mexican and Southwestern culture. But sadly, this draws attention to a dearth of conventional spaces for artists to show their work. The city's galleries can be counted almost on one hand. "We have no constituency," said Mr. Lujan. "We're not Houston, not Santa Fe, not L.A. There aren't any art buyers here."
And yet painters and sculptors are plentiful; among the best known are Tom Lea, now in his 90's, whose paintings (and writings, as a journalist and novelist), focused on the Southwest during the middle of the century; Luis Jiminez, whose fiberglass sculpture of alligators crawling over one another is a much beloved downtown landmark, and James Drake, whose work concentrates on the violation of Hispanic culture by modern industry here.
 
Always Struck By the Light
Perhaps most eccentrically, there is James Magee, who creates abstract sculptures from industrial bric-a-brac, but who also paints, in expressionist style, Southwestern land and skyscapes, under the name of Annabel Livermore.
Mr. Magee, who once lived in a junkyard beneath the Bayonne Bridge on Staten Island, sounds more like Annabel when he speaks of the appeal of El Paso.
"One of its most interesting aspects is the light," he said. "The aridity of the air. I'm always struck by how harsh and crisp the light is."
Annabelle, who Mr. Magee considers to have her own identity -- "Alter ego is a term that doesn't explain her," he said -- also has her own following. Sales of her work are brisk, much brisker than Mr. Magee's, said his local dealer, Adair Margo.
Writers also abound; the literary history of the region is strong. William Carlos Williams visited and was inspired to write "The Desert Music," a long narrative poem that begins with his encountering a huddled body on the bridge to Mexico and uses a day in El Paso to examine the mind of a poet. The novelist John Rechy grew up in El Paso; his novel "City of Night" begins here. Jack Kerouac wrote about El Paso; so did Carlos Fuentes, in "The Old Gringo." Since 1985, there has been a small publisher here, Cinco Puntos Press, run by two writers, Bobby Byrd and Lee Merrill Byrd, out of their home.
Even so, the literary community is fragmented. Writers don't seem to have the inclination, or the place, to come together. The reclusiveness of Cormac McCarthy, the reigning local literary celebrity, is a bit of an exasperation to many of his colleagues. "Cormac? He hangs out with golfers, not writers," is a frequently heard sentiment. No one expected him to respond to an interview request, and he didn't.
 
'We're Kidding Ourselves'
More striking, there is not a single independent bookstore here, astounding in a city of some 600,000 people.
"We're kidding ourselves if we think we're affecting the city in any way," said Abraham Verghese, a doctor and the author of "My Own Country," about his experience treating AIDS patients in rural Tennessee, who came to El Paso in 1991. His forthcoming book, "The Tennis Partner," about a drug-addicted colleague, is set here. "People are much more aware of me as a doctor than as a writer," he said.
El Paso is a sprawling city, having nearly doubled in size since 1970, expanding some 20 miles to the east from its downtown, past the Franklin Mountains, which now split the city like a great spine and glow red at sunset. Surrounded by high desert, it is isolated from the other big cities in Texas, more than 500 miles from San Antonio and Dallas, almost 700 from Houston; El Paso is in a different time zone.
Indeed, one interesting paradox seems to be that much of what makes the city appealing to artists as a subject is also what makes it a struggle for them to be heard: it's off on its own, a long way from the mainstream culture circuit. That's one reason it exports talent. Theater companies struggle here; they could use the hometown actors F. Murray Abraham and Judith Ivey, who left long ago.
It doesn't help that El Paso is one of the poorest and most undereducated cities in the United States. Unemployment hovers at about 11 percent, and nearly 20 percent of the population has not completed the ninth grade.
"There has always been an interest here, but there is not a lot of cash flowing for entertainment," said Alejandrina Drew, the director of the city's Arts Resources Department, most of whose $500,000 annual budget is allotted for presenting performances in the city. That's unusual, a city government in the business of producing shows, which it does for reasonable prices. But it focuses on bringing in performers from out of town -- the Missoula Children's Theater, the performance artist and director Ping Chon and and the Cuban guitarist Manuel Barrueco have all been here this year -- an acknowledgment that mainstream culture exists elsewhere and must be imported.
Still, it's a rich social fabric, unusual and complex. Just to the south across the Rio Grande, walkable for dinner from downtown, is Ciudad Juarez, a Mexican city of 1.5 million, which has far more of an effect on the identity of El Paso, whose population is 70 percent Hispanic. The border, with its issues of immigration, drugs, language and dual cultures, tends to dominate the local discourse, which has been especially volatile lately. On April 20, El Paso celebrated the 400th anniversary of the discovery of El Paso del Norte, the north pass across the Rio Grande, by the Spanish explorer Don Juan de Onate.
 
'The Idea Of a Border'
"For a lot of people, the place right before you fall off the earth is El Paso, but I don't think that," said Benjamin Alire Saenz, a Chicano novelist and poet. Much to his displeasure, he is the only Hispanic faculty member in the 33-member English department of the University of Texas at El Paso. "It's not marginal. This is a real cultural center for me. I like the idea of a border, and what it does to one's identity. Borders give you the opportunity to critique the very idea of nationalism."
For American travelers, El Paso has tended to be little more than a place to refuel or sleep between distant stations, a situation the city is trying to address with a redevelopment project just west of downtown focusing, as in many other cities, on arts and entertainment. Located alongside the city's convention center and its science museum, the project, called Union Plaza, is to revamp several square blocks of abandoned storehouses into a neighborhood of restaurants and nonfranchise entertainment spots.
"We can't generate the numbers for a Hard Rock, or anything like that," said Christopher Allen Peck of the Goodman Corporation, a Houston-based consultancy that is overseeing the downtown development project. "But there are 48 million cars that pass through El Paso on I-10 every year, and the bulk of them never stop. We want to give them a destination."
Toward that end, the city has also spent $8 million for a new building on the foundation of the old Greyhound Bus Terminal downtown to house the El Paso Museum of Art; it is scheduled to open in July, enabling the museum to show off more of its recent acquisitions in modern and contemporary art of the region. It's a project with optimism behind it.
"We want people to see what the artists of this region think about it," said Becky Duval Reese, who as the museum director since 1991 has been transforming it from a stodgy, elitist institution to a more accessible one. "This is a place unique to itself. It's not really Texas. It's not New Mexico. It's not Mexico. It's truly bicultural and bilingual. And it's like a frontier. Anything's open. You don't have the New York or L.A. attitude of 'It's been done,' or 'It won't work.' "
Indeed, the artists of El Paso tend to see the city as, pardon the expression, a blank canvas.
"The community just has so many needs that you can do anything," said Mr. Kim, the pianist, after teaching a class for elementary school students. "This is a harsh testing ground for artists, but the spirit is here."

SECTION: Section F; Page 5; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1060 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Languedoc Succeeds by Switching from Quantity to Quality

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THE Languedoc, a vast scimitar-shaped region that sweeps from the Rhone almost to the Spanish border, is France's oldest, largest and most troublesome wine-producing area. The vines reach from Montpellier in the east through the ancient Roman city of Narbonne, northwest to Carcassonne and south to Perpignan and the foothills of the Pyrenees.
Almost a third of France's vineyards are in the Languedoc, and not too long ago there were many more. The region was called France's wine reservoir: quantity was the hallmark, quality was inconsequential. In fact, much of the Languedoc's wine was vile stuff. 
 In the first edition of his "World Atlas of Wine," published in 1971, Hugh Johnson wrote off the Languedoc this way: "It is the home of vin ordinaire, mainly red, of low strength and no character, which is usually built up with stronger imported wine to be sold as the everyday drink of the French workman."
As much of France moved into the middle class in the years after World War II, the taste -- indeed, the need -- for immense quantities of cheap red wine diminished drastically. But the conservative and politically powerful farmers of the south refused to change. Year after year, as wine-drinking habits changed throughout France, the Government continued to subsidize the production of millions of gallons of unsalable wine, only then to distill it into equally unneeded commercial alcohol.
While meridional France clung grimly to the old ways, the rest of the wine world was changing rapidly. Led by the United States, winemakers from Australia to South Africa were learning how to produce light, fresh, delicious wines that put to shame the cheap wines of the Languedoc, which were based on the carignane and aramon grapes.
In the late 1970's and early 80's, the picture began to change. The European Economic Community, now the European Union, did not look kindly on France's recurring price-supported wine surpluses, and from 1976 to 1984, 74,000 acres of indifferent wine grapes were uprooted. A new generation of growers and winemakers, many of them university trained, had learned the benefits of modernization.
Overcoming the traditional preference for regional names for their wines -- Fitou, Minervois, Corbieres -- the winemakers of the Languedoc and neighboring Roussillon plunged into the world of varietals, which are wines named for the grape from which they were made.
Slowly at first, the world became aware of these new wines -- chardonnays, merlots, cabernet sauvignons and others -- from this arid, desert-like region. By the late 80's, names like Les Jamelles and Val d'Orbieu began to appear in wine shops around the globe. By 1995, the biggest producer of these new varietals, Fortant de France, based in Sete, was turning out 35 million bottles a year. The Languedoc, once written off as a serious wine-producing region, had bounced back.
Significantly, the market for these wines was almost all export. The French had yet to put aside their preference for geographical and proprietary names. Chateau Lafite-Rothschild would never be called a cabernet-merlot blend; no waiter would ever refer to a Batard-Montrachet as a top-quality chardonnay.
Fortunately for French wine lovers, and ultimately for the rest of us, a separate trend began to develop in the Languedoc and Roussillon about the same time that the new varietals were beginning to appear: the production of top-quality wines named proudly for the region and often the estate where they were made.
In bringing modern viticultural and winemaking techniques to the region, French experts discovered what some of the local producers had known all along: that the Languedoc had the weather and the soil to produce great wines. To encourage fine-wine development and to tempt the local growers with better income from their land, the Government began in the 1980's to upgrade a number of Languedoc districts by granting them Appellation Controlee status, recognizing their commitment to lower yields in the vineyards and better winemaking techniques. Previously, the best that most Languedoc vineyards could hope for was the lowly rating of Vin de Table, or table wine. Appellation Controlee status tells the world that the wine is well made and is worth more money. Even so, these wines are bargains; almost all sell for $10 or less.
Even as these inexpensive varietals were making their mark, the traditional grapes of the fine wines of the Rhone -- syrah, mourvedre and grenache -- began to appear in a new group of higher-quality Languedoc wines, some of which have achieved recognition beyond France. Some are estate wines like the best of Bordeaux and Burgundy. In 1970, Mas de Daumas Gassac became one of the first producers to lead the fight to raise the reputation of the Languedoc wines. These new wines can reach $30 a bottle.
Pic St.-Loup, a community southwest of the old Roman city of Nimes, is producing exceptional wines from traditional Rhone grapes. The Pic St.-Loup from the Chateau La Roque is a worthy example of what can happen when syrah, mourvedre and grenache are skillfully blended. The wines of the Domaine St. Martin de la Garrigue, another estate, can be outstanding, too. The Domaine's Cuvee St. Martin, a syrah-mourvedre blend, is an attractive example of the good things happening in this once forlorn wine region.
 
Tastings
A Dijon Clone
Millbrook Vineyards Pinot Noir Grand Reserve, California central coast. About $24.
 
NO, it's not a misprint; Millbrook Vineyards is indeed in Millbrook, N.Y., and this wine comes from California. Well, if the shoe business can be globalized, why not wine? John Dyson, the founder and owner of Millbrook, has branched out to California and Italy, and this wine is a result of that expansion.
May his other adventures away from home be as successful. Clone talk is all the rage, especially when the conversation is about wine from Burgundy. This California wine was made from grapes known as Dijon clones. Dijon, as in Burgundy. They are said to be more flavorful than the usual American pinot noir clones, mostly because the yield -- the amount of grapes produced by each vine -- is lower. Whatever the reason, the end result here is a top quality, quite Burgundian pinot noir. The fruit is intense, and the oak, for a change, is helpful rather than intrusive.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ANCIENT GROUND -- Vineyards near the medieval city of Carcassonne. (Tor Eigeland for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RETRO IN NEW YORK;
Rusty, Maybe, but Not Forsaken

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
WHAT with all the seductive new kitchen equipment on the market these days, it's a miracle anything old survives. But some things do -- or should -- because they're just better, no matter what Madison Avenue says.
I have my own aging favorites. The omelet pan and the crepe pan -- the black steel models, uncorrupted by modern nonstick surfaces -- have always been with me. Then there are the kitchen tools that I gave up on too soon and sent to the basement mortuary, only to rescue them when I realized the error of my ways. 
 The Foley food mill was the first piece of retro equipment to regain my ardor. There is nothing like it for making mashed potatoes, pureeing the vegetables for a soup or turning apples into applesauce. The mill is a bowl-shaped device, with a crank-operated handle that pushes the food through the holes in the bottom of the bowl.
Probably everyone tried to make mashed potatoes in a food processor when it first came out. But after two attempts I gave up and dug out the food mill. Potatoes and food processors are not made for each other, unless you want to serve library paste. A food mill delivers mashed potatoes with the kind of coarse texture and hominess craved by just about everybody, even the most accomplished chefs.
So I'm back to making terrific, soul-satisfying mashed potatoes (skins on or off) with buttermilk and garlic instead of butter and cream, and that food mill is earning its keep.
Fortunately, food mills, even if neglected by most home cooks, are still being produced. My old rusty version has only one bottom. The modern Italian and French versions have three bottoms, each with different size holes. And they do not rust because they are stainless-steel.
Steven Bridge at Bridge Kitchenware, 214 East 52d Street in Manhattan, which caters to both home and professional cooks, recommends the Italian version for home cooks because, at $35, it is less expensive than the slightly larger French model for $110.
The fact that my pressure cooker was still in the basement not too long ago had nothing to do with my mother's experience, when the lid blew off and the contents deposited themselves on the newly painted walls and ceiling. No. The pressure cooker had been relegated to the basement because most meals I put together just don't require long cooking. But mine has found a new home in Santiago de Compostelo, Spain, where my son, Michael, has a restaurant. He uses it for stocks and beans. "I couldn't live without it," he said the other day.
In a pressure cooker the heat builds up much more than it can in an ordinary pot. So you can achieve the moist, tenderizing cooking required for, say, a stew without spending hours at it.
Carolynn Bridge, Steven's mother and the widow of the founder of Bridge Kitchenware, has seen kitchen tools come and go for decades: she is also a home economist, trained in the Betty Crocker kitchens. Mrs. Bridge knows what deserves to be in use today, old-fashioned or not. She can't live without her pressure cooker, either. She particularly likes it for soups, which, she said, she can prepare in 40 minutes instead of the hours they usually take her.
"I've used a pressure cooker since I was 10," Mrs. Bridge said.
Like the food mill, there are refined new versions of pressure cookers. Today's models, made of stainless steel instead of aluminum, are not as likely to explode because of their modern safety valves. And Mrs. Bridge prefers the stainless steel, she said, because it is a nonreactive metal.
When my son took my old pressure cooker, he paid for it in the perfect currency: his high-carbon-steel knives, the sort I gave up years ago for stainless steel. The stainless seemed so much better. No rust. But for a really sharp edge nothing beats an old-fashioned high-carbon-steel knife, and I'm using one again. Chefs, who value sharpness over convenience, often prefer them, too. So if you have any rusting away in a drawer, think about resurrecting them. Or buying them in a shop catering to restaurants. They do need to be sharpened more often, and they can't be left in the sink overnight.
It is also worth learning how to use a sharpening steel and a stone, no matter what kind of knife you use. Very retro but really quick. Now, my electric knife sharpener has become obsolete after I rediscovered the old steel my stepfather taught me how to use. It is so much faster.
For slicing, Mr. Bridge swears by his old French mandoline made by Bron. The food processor, which promised to do everything, and does quite a bit, cannot do many things as well as a mandoline can, like slicing and creating julienne strips. Mr. Bridge admits the Bron is intimidating, especially since it doesn't come with instructions. But another French company, Mafer, is now making a $140 version with instructions, which he recommends for the home cook.
If you don't want to spend that much, he recommends the poor man's mandoline, the Feemster, a $9.90 gadget that can slice ingredients thick or thin. "I love it," Mr. Bridge said, even though it once sliced off the tip of his finger. "It's very sharp and does a great job, and it isn't as technical as a mandoline. We've had it about 35 years."
Marion Cunningham, a longtime food authority who made her name revising the Fannie Farmer cookbooks and who values the tools of the past, agrees that a food processor isn't the be-all and end-all. She is putting the finishing touches to a book based on her cooking classes for adults, "Learning to Cook With Marion Cunningham," to be published by Knopf. In her classes she insists her students learn to use a mezzaluna, the two-handled half-moon-shaped chopping blade. "I want them to know there are other things besides a food processor," she said.
In her own kitchen, a flour sifter is indispensable, instructions on flour bags to the contrary. "I frankly think that despite what the bags say, for something very delicate you have to sift the flour," she said.
But for the essence of retro, nothing beats the electric knife. I didn't know they were still making them but found four brands at Zabar's. Mine is long gone, so I bought one last week after seeing it recommended in recent newspaper and magazine articles. I brought it to the office to try out on a few foods never associated with an electric knife in the 1960's. Colleagues gathered around. Everyone had fond memories. One remembered how important it was to her father, who was a master carver of roast beef and turkey. Another said it had been the wedding gift of choice when she was married in the late 1960's.
Today Daniel Boulud of Restaurant Daniel in Manhattan swears by it for roasts with crusts and for terrines. An article in the June Gourmet magazine suggests an electric knife for a meringue ice cream cake. I tried it for a foie gras mousse and a coarse pate. The results: excellent, smooth slices. Then on a fruit tart with a butter crust. Just fair, but better than a sharp knife when I used it to cut the crust. And finally on flaky puff pastry, which tends to send crumbs flying when cut. There were many fewer crumbs with the electric knife.
Would I go out and buy an electric knife for my home? Probably not. But if I still had one in my basement, I'd sure consider bringing it upstairs.
 
BASIL-GARLIC MASHED POTATOES
Time:20 minutes

 2 pounds scrubbed, unpeeled thin skinned potatoes (Yukon golds if possible). sliced 1/4 inch thick
 3 large cloves garlic
 1/2 cup chopped fresh basil leaves
 1 cup or more lowfat or nonfat buttermilk
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

 1. Cook the potato slices and garlic in water to cover until the potatoes are tender, about 10 minutes.
 2. Mash, peel and all, in a food mill. (The little bit of skin that goes through is not a problem.). Stir in the basil and buttermilk to a creamy consistency; season with salt and pepper.
 Note: If it is necessary to reheat potatoes, cover and reheat in microwave oven. If potatoes become too dry, add a little more buttermilk.
 Yield: 4 to 6 servings.

They include, clockwise from left, the flour sifter, the electric knife, the food mill for mashed potatoes and applesauce, and the Feemster, a poor man's mandoline, for slicing. HEADLINE: Taming Little Tyrants

BYLINE: By Mary Ann Cantwell; Mary Ann Cantwell is the author of "Homosexuality: The Secret a Child Dare Not Tell."

DATELINE: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.

 BODY:
For some years there has been conflict between older women who were stay-at-home moms and their career daughters and sons about the rearing of their children. I, along with several other grandmothers of my acquaintance, believe that children today are being indulged.
When we see these parents cater to their children -- letting them interrupt any conversation at will -- we view it as a criticism of our own mothering. We wonder what was wrong with the way we did it. Aren't our daughters smart, successful women who exhibit common sense? Aren't our sons decisive men? 
 We agree that it's a good idea to avoid spanking, but we would like to keep it as a sanction. The parent must run the show. That is what we grandmothers don't see happening.
We can't go backward to a time before economic necessity dictated two incomes per family, but we must go forward, away from these tiny tyrants. The conflict is no longer just familial.
Public Agenda, a research group, recently published a report called "Kids These Days: What Americans Really Think About the Next Generation." The answer seemed to be: not much. Younger children, ages 5 to 12, were seen by adults as acquisitive, lazy and demonstrating a lack of respect. "Only 37 percent of Americans believe that when today's children grow up, they will make this country a better place," the report said in bold print.
Another sign that the conflict is going public comes from two news items about children who were arrested in incidents that the family would traditionally have handled. In Pensacola, Fla., a 5-year-old girl was charged with assaulting a school counselor. In Miami, a 10-year-old boy in a pizza shop was arrested after he kicked his mother and a waitress called the police.
The father of the 5-year-old pointed out that officials might have sought another solution before resorting to arrest. Still, the parents' reactions were telling. In their anger at the authorities, they seemed to have forgotten to save some of their ire for their abusive children, whom they staunchly defended as they sprang them from juvenile detention.
Another crotchety grandmother and I were having coffee the other day when she quoted her career daughter as approving of kindergarten because it provided structure for her child. "Doesn't she realize," I asked, "that the teacher is earning the girl's respect, while the parents are not?"
Then I had a moment of clarity. It was not that we were overly strict mothers. We were full-time mothers. The buck stopped with us. Whatever we allowed, we had to endure. I remarked to my friend that today's parents couldn't stand to be around their toddlers 24 hours a day.
"If they had them all day," my friend said, "you can bet they'd have a firm bedtime."
I'd like to suggest a disciplinary experiment short of arrest. Let one parent and a child spend, say, five days in a small structure or apartment that contains all the necessities of life but few diversions. Books, certainly. Let them get to know each other. A one-way mirror might be useful. I'd like to watch.
I don't think there's much chance of a parent feigning control of the child to secure early release. They're too oblivious -- parents are often unaware of what their children are perpetrating on them. But maybe, given enough time, they would learn how pleasant and rewarding it is to be the parent of a well-behaved child.

GRAPHIC: Photo (Art Hughes)

HEADLINE: Home Resales Down Slightly; Consumer Confidence Slips

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Two economic indicators released today suggested that the economy might be throttling back from the pace it reached earlier this year. Sales of previously owned homes fell in April, while consumer confidence edged lower this month.
Sales of existing homes in the United States declined 2.5 percent to an annual rate of 4.77 million units last month, according to the National Association of Realtors. And the Conference Board said consumer confidence declined to 135.2 in May from 137.2 a month ago. 
 "The economy is cooling off in the second quarter," said Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
While both economic indicators declined, they stayed close to historic highs. Home resales for April receded from a record annual rate of 4.89 million units in March, and matched the level of sales set in February. The May confidence index was just below February's 30-year high of 137.4.
That suggests the economy is still expanding, though at a pace below the first quarter's 4.2 percent annual rate, the fastest in a year. Mr. Thayer expects growth to slow to 2 percent in the second quarter.
The Conference Board's index, which gauges consumer expectations for the next six months, fell to 112 in May from 115.8 in April, while the index tracking assessment of present conditions rose to 170 this month from a revised 169.3 last month.
And so far this month, consumers appear to be making their way to the stores at a slower pace than they did in April, according to weekly industry reports. In the first two weeks of May, sales at stores open at least a year fell three-tenths of a percent from the pervious month, according to LJR Redbook Research.
Home resales declined in three regions in April. In the West, existing home sales rose 1 percent, while resales fell 2.4 percent in the Midwest, 4.2 percent in the South and 4.1 percent in the Northeast.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Signs of Economic Slowdown Help Aid Treasury Price Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rallied yesterday, spurred by a strong dollar and signs that the economy may be slowing, thus easing the threat of inflation. The slumping stock market also created strong demand for short-term Treasuries.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 31/32 , to 104 2/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.83 percent from 5.90 percent on Friday and was the lowest in more than a month. For investors, the gains amounted to nearly $10 per $1,000 invested in bonds. 
 The Conference Board's report on consumer confidence in May gave investors some relief. The confidence index declined to 135.2 from a revised 137.2 in April. Sales of existing homes in April fell 2.5 percent to a rate of 4.77 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. Analysts said both reports came in close to expectations.
Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday's rally was also fueled by rumors from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin would support a sharply higher value for the dollar versus the yen. "As these stories circulated, the dollar reached nearly a seven-year high against the yen and thereby produced renewed foreign interest in the U.S. credit markets," Mr. Chan said. A strong dollar makes United States dollar denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive because of the higher rates and the potential gains from currency translation.
The regular weekly bill auction, which was conducted yesterday because Monday was Memorial Day, went well, but there were fewer bids than had been expected.
The following are the results of yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Slide on Concerns About Valuation and Profits

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
A growing fear among investors that stocks may be overvalued and that corporate earnings growth may be stalling sent equities tumbling for a third day, as all major market gauges lost more than 1 percent of their value yesterday.
The sharp declines in stocks contrasted with a rally in the bond market that was fueled by waning inflation fears. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.83 percent, its lowest level since mid-April. 
 A rise in the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen also helped increase the attractiveness of bonds to foreign investors.
Stock prices opened higher, climbing as much as 54 points, before meandering lower through the rest of the session. A number of computer-generated sell programs heightened the losses, lopping more than 149 points off the Dow Jones industrial average. In fact, in the final hour of trading, the computer programs chopped more than 107 points off the blue-chip index.
The Dow closed down 150.71 points, or 1.65 percent, to 8,963.73.
Yesterday's decline in the Dow was the largest since Jan. 9, when the index fell 222.20 points. It eclipsed a 146.98-point drop in late April, which was spurred by concerns that the Federal Reserve was inclined to raise short-term interest rates to curb economic growth.
While an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve is no longer anticipated anytime soon, there are fears that economic growth is slowing significantly with no catalyst in sight to justify pushing stock prices above current levels.
"The U.S. economy is doing just what we hoped it would do -- slow," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "There are growing concerns about the economy and earnings, and that there aren't strong enough earnings to support stocks."
Yesterday's downturn was fueled in part by economic reports showing a decline in the sales of existing homes in April and a May drop in consumer sentiment, which had been holding near 30-year highs.
Although analysts have been cautioning that stocks have been overvalued for some time, they have also pointed to continued strong consumer confidence and spending as a catalyst that could help sustain high stock prices.
Analysts also pointed to renewed concerns about the economic downturn in the Asia-Pacific region and its impact on American companies and the economy, in part illustrated by last week's report of a $13 billion United States trade deficit in March, a six-year high.
Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 16.45 points, or 1.48 percent, to 1,094.02. The Nasdaq composite index lost 26.91 points, to 1,778.09, a 1.49 percent decline.
While most analysts are not forecasting the end of the bull market, many think that a pullback in stock prices is warranted in the near term.
Robert F. Dickey, a technical analyst at Dain Rauscher, thinks the Dow could fall to anywhere from 8,500 to 8,000 in the next three to six months before moving higher again.
"I don't think this is all we're going to get," Mr. Dickey said of recent market declines, adding that the full impact of Asia's crisis has not been felt by American corporations.
Yesterday, Barton M. Biggs, global equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, reduced his recommended investor allocation of stocks to 48 percent of investments from 51 percent. He recommended selling domestic stocks and those of emerging markets, and holding onto cash, which he believes should be at 5 percent of assets, up from 2 percent.
"The tone of equity markets around the world is deteriorating," he said. "After so many false alarms, a serious decline finally could be coming."

HEADLINE: Business Travel: Road Warriors Losing Options;
Corporate Ire Rises Along With Business Air Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Corporate air travel is no longer the land of the blank check.
Seagram sometimes suggests that employees headed for San Francisco fly instead to San Jose, Calif., then make the hour-plus drive north, saving hundreds of dollars on fares. 
 Bell Atlantic, rebelling at the high fares out of Charleston, W. Va., where it has a local headquarters, often charters a small plane to Washington or other cities.
Dresser Industries has been known to chauffeur London-bound employees from its upstate New York plant two hours to Toronto, to save about $1,000 a ticket.
And when the trip is a short one -- say, four or five hours by car -- Dresser, Bell Atlantic and many other companies are urging employees to drive, not fly.
In short, corporate America has grown increasingly irritated by steadily rising business air fares, especially to smaller cities. In response, companies are giving more and more of their employees less and less choice and flexibility in making travel arrangements.
Many companies, in fact, dictate not only what airlines employees can fly on -- if they let them fly at all -- but also what hotels and rental car companies they must use. And video conferences are more often pushed as an alternative to a trip.
Some employees resist switching from a favorite airline or hotel, but companies are making that harder. "If they still insist on traveling out of policy," said Bob Grant, who runs the travel program at Charles Schwab & Company, "they have to go to the executive vice president for approval. That usually convinces them they don't want to do it."
Over the years, companies have repeatedly tried to hold down travel costs, particularly when profits and the economy are weak. The difference in the crackdown this time is the unusual lengths companies are going to and the fact that it is being done in the midst of a roaring economy. Business travel amounted to an estimated $156 billion last year, according to American Express.
An indication of companies' determination can be gleaned from a survey released this month by the National Business Travel Association, whose 1,200 travel manager members booked $21 billion in air fares last year and $29 billion in other travel expenses.
Through March of this year, 62 percent of member companies reported using lower-priced advance-purchase fares, compared with 45 percent in 1996; 54 percent said they had increased their use of low-cost carriers, up from 30 percent in 1996; 52 percent reported using video conferences, up from 27 percent, and 54 percent have reduced the number of employees on a trip, up from 36.5 percent in 1996.
In addition, Topaz International, a Portland, Ore., company that audits fares, said that lower air fares negotiated by corporations soared to 56.9 percent through last year, up from 42.5 percent in 1994. And more than a third of those fares represented lower-cost nonrefundable tickets, more than double the percentage three years earlier.
"This indicates a very heightened sense of how businesses are trying to contain costs by changing travel behavior and travel patterns," said Valerie Estep, the president of Topaz.
While air fares are usually the biggest single travel expense, other costs add up. "On the average four- or five-day trip to New York, for example, where rooms can easily cost $250 a night, hotel costs will be about the same as air fares," said Earl S. Foster, director of global travel management at Seagram. "That's why you have to manage the whole trip."
For Seagram and other companies, that also means limiting the number of employees allowed to attend particular meetings, sometimes by substituting video and audio conferences.
Even top managers are affected. Presidents or chief executives are allowed to fly first class at 39 percent of companies that normally decree coach-class seating, according to a survey compiled this month by the Bureau of National Affairs, a Washington research firm. But at many companies, no one is allowed to fly first class. Even Charles Schwab, the financial company's founder, rarely flies first class, although he has access to a corporate jet.
Of course, airlines are so eager to please business travelers that whenever possible they upgrade them, or give them aisle seats and keep the middle seat empty, or provide better service.
For companies, an important part of the calculation is the bulk discounts that can be negotiated. These depend on how many airline seats or hotel rooms they deliver, and for some the savings easily run into seven figures. And Mr. Grant of Schwab, for one, insists that employees do not feel the pinch.
"By using five airlines whose routes don't overlap, one rental car company and 71 hotels instead of the 1,500 we used to have," he said, "we saved $1.9 million last year. That's cash to the bottom line. And we achieved it without sacrificing the comfort, care or security of our travelers."
Schwab's air fare costs have plummeted from 41 cents a mile in 1995 to 21 cents last year, Mr. Grant said, compared with an industry average of 34 cents.
Corporations clearly want to put pressure on airlines to holding back on further increases in business fares, which, even adjusted for inflation, have risen by 22 percent since 1992.
Company travel managers, however, recognize that the airlines, after losing $14 billion from 1990 to 1994, are trying to chalk up healthy profits while they can. The travel managers are understanding, but only to a point. "It's in everybody's best interest to have a healthy transportation system," said Will Tate, the travel manager of Dresser Industries, of Dallas. "But there comes a time when no matter how much you sympathize with the airlines and wish them well, you have to say, wait a minute."
That is exactly what companies are doing, as can be seen in the push to drive, not fly. "We've done some studies that show it's not only cheaper to drive to some of those cities," said Bob McGurk, vice president for business development at Rosenbluth International, "it's also faster when you add getting to and from the airport, checking in and all the rest of it."
Bell Atlantic also authorizes its travelers who stay with friends or family, instead of in a hotel, to give their host a gift equivalent to the amount of money they would spend on meals in a single day.
And instead of paying some $700 for employees at its plant in Alexandria, La., to fly round trip to Houston, Bell Atlantic asks them to drive, which take four and a half hours each way.
Republic National Bank asks overseas-bound employees to combine journeys where possible -- for example, visit Singapore and Hong Kong on the same trip, instead of two. And on flights between New York and Miami, it asks employees to consider landing at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., if and when fares are cheaper, as they often are depending on the day and the time of day, and driving the remaining 25 miles.
"Our goal is to get as close to 100 percent of maximum return on our travel investment," said Andrew W. Menkes, vice president of Republic National's for global travel, "which means no wasted trips and no unnecessary expenditures."
Like most companies, Seagram and Schwab prefer to save money whenever it is cost effective to do so. By flying on transcontinental flights that make a stop between Washington and San Francisco, rather than using nonstop flights, Mr. Foster said, Seagram employees save the company a bundle. Schwab employees save about $1,000 on round trips between San Francisco and Denver by flying on Frontier Airlines, instead of on a major carrier.
And when Seagram employees have to fly to London, then Brussels and Madrid, they are asked to rejigger their schedules, if possible, to avoid flying to London first, thus avoiding the high cost of flying directly to Heathrow airport.
Employees of Mariner Health, a Connecticut-based company that provides health-care services in many states, often use nonrefundable airline tickets. "Even when we have to pay the $75 penalty for changing the itinerary, we save money," said Lou Togneri, its travel manager. Moreover, ever since Southwest Airlines moved into Eastern markets like Providence, R.I., Baltimore and Nashville, Mariner has been booking its employees on that low-cost carrier, raising its overall flights on Southwest to 16 percent from 10 percent in the past year. It also uses Nashville-based Corporate Airlines, whose 19-seat planes fly six daily nonstop flights between Nashville and Atlanta.
Although Seagram presents the revamped London itinerary and the San Jose option as suggestions, not decrees, most employees choose them -- in no small part, obviously, so as not to displease superiors. But they also do so because managers at Seagram, as at other companies, increasingly use seminars, internal electronic communications, newsletters and similar presentations to show the savings in dollars and cents.
While companies can be expected to fine tune or even loosen various aspects of this or that policy, travel managers say, the potential to hold down costs just about insures that limits on corporate travel are here to stay. And while only bigger companies have the clout to barter for discounts, many small companies are also becoming creative at the travel game.
Richard J. Keating, president of Keating Communications, a New York public relations firm, always has his travel agent tell him the different fares for different times of day. He learned, for instance, that it would cost about $700 for a round-trip flight to Atlanta departing at 7:30 A.M., but only about $300 if he left two hours later. "Since my client reimburses our expenses," Mr. Keating said, "I gave him the choice of what flight he wanted me on, and he chose the later one."
Mr. Keating also recently gave three associates who are scheduled to fly to Los Angeles with him next month the choice of flying on an unrestricted coach ticket or on an advance-purchase fare that costs about half as much but requires a Saturday stay. If they chose the cheaper fare, he told them, they could bring their spouses. All three took him up on it.

HEADLINE: Wuhan Journal;
Selling in China: A Smile, a Shoeshine and a Scam

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: WUHAN, China

 BODY:
Door-to-door sales networks can seem dangerously intriguing to people still gullible about tales of easy money, so when a craze for selling ankle massage machines hit this city early this year, it spelled trouble.
Many thousands of wide-eyed men and women clamored for a chance to sell, convinced that it was the road to riches. They were willing to pay up to $500, almost a year's salary for most urban workers, just for the right to cart an ankle massager door-to-door. 
 But the frenzy for selling was limited, it turned out, to selling. Few people wanted to buy. And no wonder: anyone who looked closely could see that the ankle massager does not really massage the ankle at all. It simply shakes it back and forth.
"I lost my own money, my wife's money, my parents' money, my brother's money, my friends' money," said Fu Yanbing, who borrowed from so many to buy a small truckload of ankle massagers. "My wife says I have a year to pay it all back or she wants a divorce."
Door-to-door sales captured, and destroyed, the hopes and dreams of millions of people across China, sketching a painful episode in this nation's elaborate move from a planned to a market economy.
In April, citing a rash of fly-by-night operations like the one that tricked Mr. Fu, the Chinese Government banned all door-to-door selling, or direct sales. When the announcement was made, managers at many of those companies closed shop and fled, provoking riots in Wuhan and other cities where salespeople were unable to return unsold goods.
The ban has been a disaster for American companies like Amway, Avon Products and Mary Kay, which have spent heavily trying to apply a direct sales formula for soap, cosmetics and other products in China's vast market. Suddenly their prospects look very dim.
The ban was intended to clamp down on illegitimate sales operations, many of them run by local Chinese and Taiwanese businessmen, which played shamelessly on the naive aspirations of a people still emerging from poverty and not yet wise to the dark side of capitalism.
"Do you want to get rich? To afford a mistress? To own a villa?" cried one local newspaper advertisement in Guangdong Province, trying to attract sales personnel.
Yet the ban has also deprived millions of legitimate work. Tens of millions of urban workers in China are already unemployed, and many of those who went into direct sales had lost a job in a state-run enterprise.
Officially, more than 1,500 direct-sales companies employed 2.6 million people, though many more unregistered companies operated as well.
For a direct-sales giant like Amway, it has been a lesson in the utter unpredictability of doing business in China. Amway has invested more than $100 million since it came to China in 1995, and it was careful to secure official approval while building a network of 80,000 distributors, or people selling door-to-door full-time. In 1997, Amway sold $178 million of personal care products.
Chinese officials met extensively with Amway executives in Beijing recently, insisting that Amway shift its sales from the street into stores. Amway executives say they are committed to staying in China but want to try to avoid sacrificing their core sales method.
"We realize the Chinese have concerns," said Richard Holwill, Amway's director of international affairs, based in Washington. "But we have a basic bond with our distributors worldwide that we will not sell in retail outlets."
Executives at Avon and Mary Kay also expressed amazement that faced with a situation that called for better regulation and supervision, the Chinese authorities instead issued a blanket ban on door-to-door sales, effectively punishing legitimate operations along with fraudulent ones.
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, coincidentally visiting Beijing just after the ban was announced on April 21, objected that it unfairly penalized American companies operating openly and accountably.
Yet in China, where the central authorities have difficulty cutting through layers of bureaucracy and corruption to get local officials to act on many issues, Beijing's leaders appear to have decided that only a complete ban would be taken seriously in the endless push-and-pull between the center and the provinces.
Here in Wuhan, several former salespeople said local officials had paid little attention to even the most blatant rip-offs by direct-sales companies until Beijing made a major issue of them.
"No one stopped these Taiwan bosses from operating, even when it was obvious what they were doing," said Fang Yibin, a disappointed saleswoman. "Officials are very busy, always having banquets. They don't care about ordinary people."
Perhaps even more alarming to Chinese leaders, who remain deeply suspicious of any organization they can not easily monitor or control, was the independent nature of direct sales. Anyone building a network of salepeople, encouraging a commitment so fervent that it often looks cult-like to outsiders, was sure to ring alarm bells in Beijing.
"Some companies engaged in evil missionary teaching, gang activity and superstition," the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily wrote on May 8, describing direct sales. "They formed sellers into 'families.' Even if the salesmen were not religious believers, it was like being trained for illegal religious activities."
Although Amway once mixed Christian evangelical teaching with its teaching on how to sell in the United States, Mr. Holwill said, it now tries to keep them separate.
"If you go to a sales motivational meeting at GM, you'll hear pretty much the same language we use at Amway," said Mr. Holwill, maintaining that Amway had received no official complaints about its sales teachings in China. "We were given guidelines when we came to China about what was allowed, and we have followed them."
Those guidelines are now suddenly obsolete. But the root of China's direct-sales problem was that so many shady companies were ignoring the guidelines in the first place.
In Wuhan, the main supplier of ankle massagers for door-to-door salesmen was a Taiwan-run company called Xintian. It lured sales representatives by telling them that ankle massagers were growing ever more popular and that it was well worth spending $500 for the right to sell one.
Never mind that the machines were on sale in any department store for less than $100, or that they could barely deliver on giving a massage. People were so eager to believe in sales and to win commissions by recruiting new salespeople that they fell for it.
Attempts to return unsold goods at Xintian often met with a runaround. The company closed shop almost immediately after the ban was announced. In late April, outraged salesmen burned their wares and vandalized automobiles outside Xintian's closed storefront. In a city in Hunan Province, four people were killed in similar disturbances.
More legitimate sales operations, like Amway, Avon and Mary Kay, never charge sales agents a premium for the right to sell, ask them to sell goods easily available in nearby stores at a lower price or refuse returns on unsold goods.
After the ban, and much publicity about all the fraud, door-to-door sales have such a bad name in China that it may be hard to recover.
"Direct sales -- it's really tricking yourself," said Fang Siming, a woman reduced to selling ankle massagers on the sidewalk for only $25, a fraction of what she paid for them. "You tell yourself you can succeed where everyone else is failing. You tell yourself you can make a fortune where everyone else is up to the neck in debt."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wang Yanxi, standing, and a partner trying to sell ankle massagers in Wuhan. "Oxygen exerciser" is a loose translation of "aerobic." Few people wanted to buy: the device simply shakes the ankle back and forth. (Seth Faison/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bilingual Education Battle Splits Santa Barbara

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 21

 BODY:
On the night this city's school board decided whether to end a quarter-century of bilingual education, more than 600 people showed up. It was the largest board meeting that anyone could recall. It was also the most emotional.
The board's five members said they were haunted by accusations that the proposal before them amounted to "ethnic cleansing" and posted six police officers in the auditorium. 
 And when it was finally time for the vote, after three hours of anguished pleas from all sides, several dozen proponents of bilingual education moved within a few feet of the board members and glared at them. But the board unanimously approved the proposal that, beginning in September, would put the district's many Spanish-speaking children into classes where English would take precedence.
"Then the police walked us back to our cars," said Fred Rifkin, the board's president. "It was very tense."
Four months after that mid-January meeting, the situation is still tense -- not just in Santa Barbara, but also in much of California. On June 2, California voters will decide whether to approve Proposition 227, the sweeping ballot initiative that would do statewide what Santa Barbara has already done: dismantle bilingual education.
The debate in this city is a microcosm of the complex politics swirling around Proposition 227 and a painful preview of the potential fallout in a racially, ethnically and economically diverse state.
"This is a multilayered debate," Robert Pohl, an educational consultant who is a member of the elected school board, said in an interview. "It's about politics. It's about culture. It's about power. It's about disenfranchisement. And it's about what is the purpose and responsibility of the school system."
Polls suggest that Proposition 227 will be easily approved and that a majority of Hispanic voters favor it. Even so, the initiative has ardent opponents and, coming on the heels of initiatives that sought to deny public services to illegal immigrants and that ended affirmative action in public employment and university admissions, has become the latest lightning rod in a state with a burgeoning minority population.
In Santa Barbara, the lightning struck early and with particular force, illuminating a variety of agendas embedded in the bilingual education debate.
The board's fiercest opponent of bilingual education was Alan Ebenstein, an affluent candidate for the State Assembly. His efforts won him local press attention and the favor of fellow Republicans, including Ron Unz, a wealthy entrepreneur from Northern California, who is the principal proponent of Proposition 227.
On the other side, the debate drew the local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., which seized the occasion not merely to support bilingual education but also to denounce institutional racism and the neglect of African-Americans in Santa Barbara's schools.
The debate attracted a woman upset that the city had a day honoring Hispanic people in general but not Mexican-Americans in particular, and it caught the attention of students and faculty members from the University of California at Santa Barbara, who complained that diversity was under siege.
Even if the debate had focused only on the best way to teach children English, it would have been no cakewalk.
Proponents of bilingual education pointed to studies suggesting that in the long run, children learned best if allowed to take instruction in their native language while gradually incorporating English into lessons. Opponents cited the poor standardized test scores and low college enrollment of many children in bilingual programs as evidence that they did not work.
If neither side wanted to give an inch, it was partly because the well-being of children was in the balance. A bilingual education teacher told the school board in January, "You are playing with the very lives -- the futures -- of our children."
School districts in California are theoretically required to provide instruction to children in their primary languages until teachers deem them suitably proficient in English.
While many districts have been unable to comply fully with that goal -- only 30 percent of the 1.4 million children in the state with limited English proficiency are actually enrolled in bilingual education programs -- others, including Santa Barbara, have put thousands of children in Spanish-language classes and often kept them there for five years or longer.
Santa Barbara is among a handful of districts that eventually sought and received state permission to end bilingual programs. Proposition 227 would essentially require all districts to do so. Under its mandate, most students who speak limited English would get about a year of intensive instruction in the English language, then be put in general classrooms where teachers would be forbidden to speak Spanish.
Santa Barbara's plan, which could be eclipsed by Proposition 227, is slightly different. It would immediately put students with limited English skills into general classrooms, but would call for Spanish-speaking teachers or teachers' aides to speak some Spanish, as needed, to help the children keep up with the class. It would also provide supplementary tutoring after school and during the summer for Spanish-speaking children with limited English.
Like the rest of California, Santa Barbara, a city of 90,000 residents, has experienced dramatic growth in its Hispanic population over the last two decades. From 1980 to 1990, the last year for which an accurate racial and ethnic breakdown of the population is available, the percentage of Hispanic people rose to 31.5 percent, from 22 percent.
Also, like the rest of California, Santa Barbara embraces stark extremes of wealth, distributed unevenly between the Hispanic residents and the non-Hispanic white ones, with the former providing much of the elbow grease that burnishes Santa Barbara's aura as an oceanside, mountain-crowned resort.
In the city's elementary schools, more than half of the Hispanic students are in bilingual programs, but there has been mounting concern over the last several years about how well they were being prepared for the future.
Mr. Ebenstein constantly underlined the statistic that showed that less than 15 percent of eligible Hispanic students in Santa Barbara's high schools were taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test, a requirement for admission to many colleges, and that last year, not one student from bilingual programs scored higher than 1,000 out of a possible 1,600 on the S.A.T.
Proponents of bilingual education contend that the problem is not bilingual education but the shoddy way it was being implemented, and they suggested tinkering with the system by incorporating more English more rapidly into bilingual classrooms in kindergarten through third grade.
But Mr. Ebenstein, other board members and some Hispanic parents said they were troubled by a Balkanization of Santa Barbara's elementary schools, where non-Hispanic white students clustered in one set of classes, Hispanic students in another and seldom the twain did meet.
Suspicion was aroused last summer when the board members, all of whom are white and non-Hispanic, began discussing the total abolition of bilingual programs.
Critics openly wondered if the board's mission was to stamp out the sounds of Spanish in Santa Barbara. Words like "racism," "oppression" and even "genocide" were thrown around.
In an article published in a local newspaper, Pete Relis, a public school teacher who supports bilingual education, summoned the specter of ethnic cleansing. And at one board meeting, Mr. Rifkin said, a woman compared him to Adolf Hitler.
"Imagine being a Jew and hearing that," he said.
Meanwhile, many bilingual teachers here who supported the status quo seemed to resent the intrusion of the school board members on their work, along with the implication that they had devoted years to a failed experiment.
The arguments also delved into what, if any, role the schools should play in preserving the culture of Hispanic people, whose presence in California pre-dated that of English-speaking settlers.
The three children of Ruben and Maria Rey began school speaking only Spanish -- not because their parents did not know English, but because the couple made a cultural decision to rear them that way. The couple, vocal critics of the board's plan, said the schools should respect and celebrate that decision while also teaching their children English through bilingual programs.
Yolanda Broyles-Gonzalez, a professor at the University of California at Santa Barbara, concurred, saying that the point of bilingual education was not just the effective acquisition of English.
Referring to her sixth-grade son, Professor Broyles-Gonzalez said, "He dreams in two languages and two worlds, and I wanted that to be cultivated." So she recently transferred him to a private school that would do so.
But several board members questioned whether it was reasonable to ask schools to give a level of consideration to Hispanic people that had not been given to other ethnic groups, and several white parents clearly saw bilingual programs as the coddling of one group of students, which was somehow hurting other students.
At the January school board meeting, one non-Hispanic white parent called bilingual education "the biggest factor in the downfall of education in this state," while another said it had driven his family and many other middle-class families to private schools.
Mr. Ebenstein said, "They don't want their kids to go to a school where half the kids speak Spanish. People want their children to have a happy, open learning experience."
In the days before the board's vote, more than 300 Hispanic families boycotted the schools, sending their children to a community center instead. The morning after, some critics accused board members of having made up their minds in private sessions and pressed unsuccessfully to have them criminally charged with violating the state's open-meeting law. They also began a petition drive to recall Mr. Ebenstein.
The board members said that they had forged ahead with their plan, even though Proposition 227 loomed, because the voter initiative could become tangled in legal challenges. The board members are split in their positions on the statewide proposition.
Mr. Rifkin opposes the initiative, saying it deprives local districts of control. But Steve Forsell, another member, favors it, saying it would enable school districts elsewhere to follow Santa Barbara's lead without taking the heat.
"I don't know that other school boards in the state could stand up to that kind of abuse," Mr. Forsell said.
