HEADLINE: U.S. Delays World Bank Loans For India in Response to A-Tests

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Administration made good today on its threat to make India pay for conducting five nuclear tests earlier this month, forcing what the World Bank called "an indefinite delay" on $865 million in loans for an electric power grid and other projects.
While the action was directed at New Delhi, it was clearly intended to send a signal to Pakistan about how it would suffer if it responded with a nuclear test of its own. Today the Central Intelligence Agency reported that Pakistan had completed preparations for such a test. 
 Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan is under enormous pressure from militant Islamic groups to demonstrate his nation's nuclear ability, too, but it is unclear whether he has decided what course to take after weeks of intensive American diplomatic efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear tensions.
Tonight the Foreign Ministry in Islamabad said reports that a test is imminent are "absolutely incorrect."
The World Bank action today hits India where it most needs help: Building a reliable electrical system.
The biggest single loan put on hold today -- $450 million -- is part of a $5.7 billion program to build a national power distribution network that would increase the reliability of electric service. It is exactly the kind of project that the United States favors: using loans from international institutions to attract private investors and promote competition in an industry dominated by money-losing government agencies.
Without the World Bank's financing, India will have to either scale the project back or seek loans from private banks, at a far greater cost. Such loans are not likely to be forthcoming: India's powerful State Electricity Boards have lost roughly $3 billion in recent years.
As a result, the prospect of more sanctions has sent the Indian rupee plunging to a record low against the dollar. The decline of the currency is perhaps the harshest sanction of all because it makes it more difficult to cut interest rates to attract investors, and thus to bolster an economy that is deeply troubled.
The World Bank also postponed a $130 million loan to build small hydroelectric generators throughout the country, especially in remote villages that have no other source of power. The projects tend to raise few environmental objections -- especially compared with coal-fired power stations -- and the equipment often comes from American and European suppliers.
A third loan was to provide $275 million for road construction in Haryana state, near New Delhi.
The United States was not alone in acting to force the World Bank to delay the loan; Japan, which is the second-largest contributor to the bank, also sought a delay, and the major contributors have the greatest weight when decisions are made.
But there is a widening gap between Washington and several allies over using World Bank loans and other international assistance to punish New Delhi. Most European nations, including Britain, view economic sanctions as unwise and unlikely to deter India from turning its nuclear capacity into weapons.
The United States and Japan could delay India's loans for months at the least. But officials familiar with the bank's inner workings say Washington would find itself on shaky ground if the subject ever came to a formal vote.
The politics of the World Bank are less than clear-cut. The United States and Japan can prevent the issue of money for India from coming to a vote for a time because the Bank generally operates by consensus rather than by formal vote. No one foresees a vote for at least several months and perhaps longer.
But eventually, if the matter did come to a vote, a majority of board members would likely vote for the loans, American and other officials say.
Such a step would almost certainly enrage Congress, especially when some legislators are attacking the size of American contributions to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and others are upset that the United States contributes at all.
The United States has also cut off bilateral aid to India, including trade credits, private American bank loans to the Indian Government and loan guarantees to American companies doing business there.
But some companies have been working behind the scenes to ease the regulations under which the sanctions will be imposed. Though the law mandating sanctions was passed in 1994, the regulations to implement them were never written and are only now being hastily assembled.
"It's just beginning to dawn on people that this is going to undercut years of trying to get American companies into India," one Administration official said last week. "But at this point, it is unavoidable."
India has also been working to undermine the sanctions, officials say, offering to open up long-closed markets in the hope of giving Europeans and others an incentive to part ways with Washington's policy.
One reason the United States was eager to mete out punishment this week was to show Pakistan, which is more dependent than India on international aid, that it could suffer the same fate.
It is unclear whether that message is getting through.
The C.I.A. told the White House today that Pakistan could detonate an underground nuclear explosion at any moment. Intelligence officials said they had irrefutable evidence that the preparations, which began two weeks ago after India's tests but were slowed by the pleadings of senior American officials, were complete except for minor technical details. But Pakistani officials say reports that a test is near are incorrect.
Pakistan's test site is in the Chagai Hills, in the Baluchistan desert near the Iranian border. The United States monitors activities there with spy satellites and reports from foreign intelligence agents inside Pakistan.
United States officials, from President Clinton down, have all but begged Pakistan not to conduct a test, saying it would set off a dangerous arms race.
"If Pakistan's leaders do not test, they will defy India's expectations and foil India's desire to drag Pakistan's world standing down," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said. "They will pull South Asia back from an arms competition that nations there cannot afford and might not survive."
The United States held out promises of renewed military and economic aid, which was suspended in 1990 because of Pakistan's nuclear-weapons program. In the 1980's Pakistan received up to $600 million a year in American military and economic aid, making it the third-largest recipient of such assistance, after Israel and Egypt.
The United States also suggested that it might deliver some or all of the 28 F-16 fighter jets that Pakistan has paid for but never received because of the 1990 sanctions.

HEADLINE: Welfare Workers Rate High In Job Retention at Companies

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Some companies hiring welfare recipients say they have found, to their surprise, that such workers stay on the job longer, with less turnover, than other employees.
The findings run counter to the expectations of many skeptics, who said that welfare recipients lacked the skills and the motivation needed to hold jobs. 
 The companies, Borg-Warner, Giant Food, Marriott International, Salomon Smith Barney, Sprint, United Airlines, owned by UAL, United Parcel Service and Xerox, said they had made systematic efforts to hire welfare recipients in the last year. And in separate interviews, executives at those companies said that they had retained a larger proportion of former welfare recipients than other entry-level employees.
"It's been a real pleasant surprise for us," said Ricki C. Crescenzi, manager of employment at Giant Food, a regional supermarket chain based in Landover, Md.
She said the company had hired more than 100 welfare recipients as cashiers, pharmacy clerks, baker's assistants and apprentice meat-cutters. After 90 days, she said, 79 percent of welfare recipients were still on the job, while the retention rate for other Giant employees in similar jobs was 50 percent.
Janet M. Tully, director of community employment and training at Marriott International, said her company hired 360 welfare recipients last year and 100 so far this year, with retention rates very similar to those reported by Giant.
The efforts to hire welfare recipients, to be recognized at the White House on Wednesday, come at a time of low unemployment, and those efforts have several features in common. Most of the companies work with local government agencies or nonprofit community organizations that recruit and train welfare recipients for particular jobs.
Also, many of the employers use mentors, job coaches or some type of "buddy" system to help welfare recipients learn skills needed for their jobs and many offer welfare recipients extra help with child care and transportation to and from work.
Welfare experts sounded a note of caution, saying that some of the people still on welfare might have more difficulty getting and holding jobs. They include homeless people, drug addicts, people with serious mental disorders, convicted felons, battered women and people with a limited ability to read or speak English.
Ms. Tully attributed the high retention rates at Marriott to the "training, personal attention, coaching and counseling" given to welfare recipients.
"That's a luxury that a lot of other employees don't have," Ms. Tully said.
LaDonna A. Pavetti, a welfare expert at Mathematica Policy Research, said that welfare recipients were given access to job training, child care and transportation services that was unavailable to people "hired off the street."
"In Massachusetts," Ms. Pavetti said, "if you find a job while you're on welfare, you are guaranteed child care."
The work requirements of the 1996 welfare law may also be a factor. "Welfare recipients have a mandate to work," Ms. Pavetti said. "If they lose this job, they'll have to get another one."
Barbara A. Silvan, senior vice president of Salomon Smith Barney, said her company had retained 92 percent of the 53 welfare recipients hired in the last year. Some of the new employees took jobs paying more than $24,000 a year, and in the last few weeks, she said, "we hired someone off welfare at $30,000."
Company executives said their main reason for hiring welfare recipients was to create a more stable work force and to improve the bottom line. Such hiring is essential to the success of the welfare bill that President Clinton signed in August 1996. But the executives said they were not hiring welfare recipients as a favor to Mr. Clinton.
Eli J. Segal, president of the Welfare to Work Partnership, said 5,000 companies had made commitments to hire and retain welfare recipients.
The Welfare to Work Partnership, a nonprofit corporation formed to promote the hiring of welfare recipients, has been praised by Mr. Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican.
Michael E. Schlein, director of corporate development at Salomon Smith Barney, said, "The transition from years of welfare to corporate life can be rough." Before being hired for full-time jobs, he said, welfare recipients must complete 16 weeks of preparation at the Wildcat Service Corporation, a job training and employment agency, and they go through a 16-week internship at Salomon Smith Barney.
Jeffrey Jablow, senior vice president of Wildcat, said his company trained 1,500 welfare recipients a year, teaching them work habits, clerical skills, computer skills and the language skills and mathematics needed for their jobs.
Tony Molinaro, a spokesman for United Airlines, said the company had retained 70 percent of the 760 welfare recipients it had hired in the last year. Among other people hired for similar jobs, he said, the retention rate was 40 percent.
Paula Fulford, a spokeswoman for United Parcel Service, said: "Since January 1997, we have hired more than 10,400 welfare recipients as part-time package sorters, at an average wage of $8.50 an hour. We make no distinction between a former welfare recipient and anyone else hired for an entry-level job in terms of salary, benefits and hours."
But, she said, many of the welfare recipients receive extra "supportive services" from U.P.S. and community organizations.
Peter B. Edelman, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, resigned in protest over the new welfare law in September 1996. In March 1997, he said that the law's work requirements were unrealistic because many welfare recipients lacked basic skills.
But in an interview today, Mr. Edelman said, "In the short run, more people are getting jobs than I would have thought."

HEADLINE: Clinton Projects $39 Billion Budget Surplus in '98

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
President Clinton announced today that the Federal Government would run a budget surplus of $39 billion this year, as he maneuvered to deprive Republicans of an election-year issue by demanding that the money be protected from "short-term schemes" for tax cuts.
The Clinton Administration had estimated in February that the Government would run a deficit of $10 billion this year. But officials from Mr. Clinton on down have signaled for months that because of surging tax revenue they expected instead to see the first surplus since 1969. 
 In making his announcement today in the Rose Garden, the President was trying to make a point of his economic stewardship and dominate the news with Congress out of town, his aides acknowledged. But he was also seeking to frame what his advisers expect to be one of two dominant domestic issues, together with tobacco legislation, before the November elections.
Hoping for a potent issue in the fall, Republicans are bent on delivering a big tax cut as part of the budget this year. But Mr. Clinton, repeating his call to devote any surplus to preserving Social Security, said today that talk of tax cuts should be postponed until at least next year, after negotiators devise a plan to shore up Social Security.
"We cannot abandon the strategy of fiscal discipline and investments in the future which has brought us to this moment," the President said.
Republicans have argued that Mr. Clinton was hoarding taxpayers' hard-earned gains. Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said, "Because of record-high taxation, the surplus is surging out of control."
Saying he feared that politicians would use the surplus to create new Federal programs, Mr. Archer added, "I believe we should use the surplus to pay down the debt, save Social Security and use a portion for tax relief."
In issuing its estimates for the surplus today, the Administration revised, with some eye-popping results, the numbers that it released as part of the President's budget in February. It said today that the surplus would accumulate to $495 billion over the next five years, compared with the $127 billion it had forecast. Over 10 years, the Administration said, the surplus would amount to $1.477 trillion, compared with its previous estimate of $846 billion.
"America can now turn off the deficit clock," Mr. Clinton said, "and plug in the surplus clock."
By law, the Administration is required to issue a revised estimate, called a "mid-session review," of the budget deficit or surplus. Such revisions are required by July 15 and are usually made in July. Republican Congressional aides questioned whether the Administration made its estimate earlier this year in the hope of producing a lower number that would constrain budget negotiators.
Jack Lew, the acting budget director, said the Administration acted early because of the "intense interest" in the budget number. Waiting another month, Mr. Lew said, would not have improved the forecast because the most important factor is the April tax receipts, which have now been counted.
"We think that this is the right way to continue the debate, the policy debate, for the balance of this year, and it shows the most accurate picture that we have of the state of the budget and the state of the economy," he said.
The Administration was careful today to emphasize the surplus for this year, rather than the much large figures for later years. But Republicans seized on the latter numbers to emphasize that money would be rolling in and to make the case for tax cuts. "Why is the Government collecting this much excess taxation?" asked Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for the Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Clinton's aides argued that public polls showed overwhelming majorities prefer using the surplus not to cut taxes, but to preserve Social Security or to increase spending on programs like education.
One Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, maintained that Republicans ran the risk of "letting us be both the defenders of seniors and the champions of fiscal discipline."
The official added, "We can't do that on our own, but it looks like they're hellbent on doing that for us."
Janet Yellen, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the Administration's new surplus estimates were based on a forecast of slower annual economic growth of 2 percent over the next three years, rising to 2.4 percent after that. She also predicted that unemployment and inflation would edge upward.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Assesses New Indonesia Government

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 26

 BODY:
Indonesia's political upheaval has worsened its severe economic problems, and a high-level team from the International Monetary Fund arrived here today to explore ways to restart its rescue package.
The country's political and economic crises have become dangerously intertwined, and the fund's Asia director, Hubert Neiss, said on his arrival that the country must urgently address its leadership questions if it is to begin a real recovery. 
 "We have to recognize that the economic measures will only work and be truly effective if there is political stability," he said. "Along with political stability, it is important that the trust of the people in the Government is restored, the support of foreign governments is obtained and market confidence is returned."
But the politics today are far from stable. President B. J. Habibie, who took office on Thursday when President Suharto resigned under pressure, promised on Monday to hold a new election. But he did not set a date and the promise has only accelerated a widening struggle over the future leadership.
Rather than an orderly transition to a stable leadership, there is the possibility of political chaos as long-suppressed forces jockey to fill the vacuum left by the sudden departure of the strongman who governed Indonesia for 32 years.
New political parties have begun to form and the formerly illegal labor movement and newly potent student movement have marshalled their forces. Opposition figures debate ways to hurry a transition of power, and the military waits in the wings, its agenda still uncertain.
Mr. Neiss said he would assess the situation as quickly as he could and report back to the fund's board, which must decide whether to resume disbursements from its $40 billion rescue package. They were suspended on Friday, after Mr. Suharto stepped down.
On the same day, the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said it would be premature for the fund to resume disbursements as long as the political situation remained unclear.
Mari Pangestu, a leading economist here, said the I.M.F., the World Bank and international investors remain wary of Mr. Habibie's Government, although he has installed a credible economic team.
"The greatest fear is that we will have months of uncertainty," she said. "Certainly the economic conditions have gotten much, much worse. Analysts used to say recovery would take three to five years. Now they are saying four to five years."
Apart from the political questions, Mr. Neiss will find a severely weakened economy, and the fund will need to lower its estimates of the country's potential, economists said.
Foreign exchange reserves have fallen dangerously low and the Goverment has compensated by printing new money, driving up inflation to a projected 47 percent this year, one foreign economist said.
The country's private foreign debt, estimated as high as $70 billion, remains an intractable problem. The banking system is on the verge of collapse, its peril heighted today by a run on the country's largest private bank, Bank Central Asia.
That bank, which is partly owned by two of Mr. Suharto's six wealthy children, was a prime target of rioters two weeks ago, reportedly closing 122 offices and losing 1,250 automatic teller machines to vandals and thieves.
Surveying the wreckage, private economists have dismissed an I.M.F. estimate of recent trends showing a 5 percent contraction in the economy. Various estimates now put the shrinkage at anywhere from 10 percent to 25 percent.
Ms. Pangestu estimates that unemployment will rise to more than 15 million this year, or nearly 20 percent of the workforce. With food prices rising sharply, she said, this means that as many as 58 million people would soon be in poverty, far above the 22.5 million at the start of the year.
"You aren't going to see any investment coming in for a while," she said. "The more you look at the numbers, the gloomier it gets."
The situation is compounded by the worst drought in half a century, which has parched harvests and made it necessary to spend huge amounts of scarce foreign currency on imported food.
In a speech on Monday after his first Cabinet meeting, Mr. Habibie acknowledged the need for stability to attract foreign investment and aid.
"We must honestly admit that our success in overcoming the economic crisis depends largely on foreign loans, especially to finance imports of raw material and spare parts," he said. "Foreign loans are influenced by our success in stabilizing domestic political life."
His chief economic minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, said over the weekend that Indonesia would cooperate with the I.M.F. Since the rescue package was first agreed to last October, Mr. Suharto delayed and equivocated, promising reforms, then retreating, time and again.
In a challenge to his own Government, Mr. Ginandjar agreed with critics who say Mr. Habibie's Government cannot provide the needed confidence. "One thing is for sure," he said. "We need to have a new Government with a new mandate from the people. This means general elections as soon as possible."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President B. J. Habibie visited a burned-out bank in Jakarta yesterday, a symbol of how the riots that preceded his inauguration last week left the Indonesian economy in tatters. An I.M.F. team arrived yesterday to reassess Indonesia's ability to use the $40 billion in loans that were promised last October. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Microsoft Has A Stronghold In Office Suites

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
When employees of the New York Attorney General's office sat down last week to prepare the final draft of the multistate lawsuit accusing the Microsoft Corporation of monopolistic, anticompetitive behavior, they typed the document using Microsoft Word, the word processor installed on the office's computers as part of a group of business programs known as Office.
"We have Windows 95 and the Microsoft Office suite," Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco acknowledged with a rueful chuckle. 
 So does virtually every other office in America, which is one of the reasons that Mr. Vacco and 19 other state Attorneys General have targeted Office in their lawsuit.
Dataquest, a market research firm, said that Microsoft Office now has 93 percent of the world market for the collections of business software known as suites. The other 7 percent is divided between two other suites built around former industry heavyweights. Lotus Smartsuite, has 4 percent of the market, and Corel Wordperfect Suite has 3 percent.
In addition to Word, Microsoft Office includes the Excel spreadsheet program for financial analysis and management, and Outlook, a personal information manager for keeping schedules and contact directories. Microsoft offers Office in three versions -- standard, professional and small-business editions. Various versions also include Powerpoint presentation software for developing slide shows on a computer screen; Access, a data-base management tool for finding and analyzing information stored in large computer filing cabinets, or Streets, a mapping and directions program.
The part of the states' lawsuit dealing with Office accuses Microsoft of using predatory pricing strategies to gain dominance in the market for office suites.
The Justice Department argues that Microsoft's pricing policy for Office leaves computer manufacturers the practical choice of installing Microsoft's suite on all the computers they make or on none of them. The result, the suit says, is that competition "is threatened to be curtailed and foreclosed."
But some experts in the industry argue that the states are mounting a battle that may already be lost, since Microsoft Office already enjoys the same level of monopolistic dominance held by the company's Windows operating system.
Just three years ago, Wordperfect was the world's best-selling word processor, with more than half the market. Lotus 1-2-3, the venerable spreadsheet program, had a similar market share.
No one argues that Microsoft's pricing strategies alone are responsible for the sharp decline of these competing suites.
Most analysts say that Microsoft gained its monopoly position in part by figuring out more quickly than others that most people want programs bundled in a suite and designed to work with and look like one another. The company also produced updates that took advantage of technological advances far more quickly than competitors did.
As an example, Dennis Tevlin, Microsoft's director of marketing for the desktop applications division, said that when Windows 95 was released, "Lotus and Wordperfect had ample time to develop updates. But they just didn't do it. So we were already on to our second generation when they were just shipping product."
Corel assigns blame for Wordperfect's decline largely to its previous owner, Novell Inc. And a senior Lotus Development executive, who, under company policy declined to be identified, said that the many shifts in the industry the last five years, including the move to suites, brought the downfall of Lotus 1-2-3. Neither company placed primary emphasis on the pricing policy described in the states' lawsuit.
Whatever happened in the past, said Chris Le Tocq, an analyst for Dataquest who follows this industry, "it's very tough to see a way anyone could come in with a word processor or a spreadsheet and turn this around" in the future.
And Lewis E. Platt, chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company, said: "By now, it's over in that business. Most people find it more difficult to switch applications programs than to even switch operating systems."
Even Attorney General Vacco, when told of the latest sales figures, said: "Wow! Perhaps it has gone too far, but only the marketplace can provide an answer. Given a more level playing field, can another player compete? I don't know."
A senior Government official involved with the state and Federal lawsuits said, "When a market tips as decisively as this, there's a real question whether or not it makes sense to try to generate competition."
Microsoft, the state lawsuit said, offered computer manufacturers -- known in the industry as an O.E.M., for original equipment manufacturer -- two choices when buying the office suite. They can buy individual copies of the program for installation on some computers at a price of roughly $170 to $190. Or, they can buy the program at a far lower price, roughly $125, if they purchase it for installation on every computer in a company line -- the Dimension series of Dell computers, for example.
This is called a "per system" license, and the suit says: "It is impractical in an economic sense for an O.E.M. to install a competing office productivity suite on a computer subject to a per-system license. In order to do so, the O.E.M. would have to pay for both Office and the competing product, and likewise would be required to pass along to the customer the cost of offering both Office and the competing product."
But Mr. Tevlin said that Microsoft's pricing was set in this manner because retailers would complain if manufacturers could buy single copies at a cost far below theirs.
Executives of the Corel Corporation, the Canadian company that owns Wordperfect, said sales may have been hurt by this -- but not very much. "The fact is, sales to O.E.M.s are not really a big money maker for us; the retail market is more important," said Cindy McGann, Corel's corporate counsel. Mr. Tevlin of Microsoft said manufacturers accounted for only about 6 percent of the Office market.
Still, Don Sylvester, a senior vice president at Corel, argued that Microsoft's pricing "absolutely harms everyone in the market, and nobody wants to wake up six months from now and find that Micorosoft is the only one standing in the word processing and suite market."
As it is, Corel has changed its marketing strategy. "It's clear to us that Microsoft isn't our competition anymore," he said. "They are our environment, and we need to deal with that fact by making our product completely compatible with Microsoft Office so users can move files back and forth between their programs and ours."
The senior Lotus executive agreed that compatibility was essential for survival. And both companies are now selling their products at a fraction of the cost of Microsoft Office. This leaves Microsoft officials wondering aloud what all the fuss is about, since predatory pricing typically means selling a product for far less than a competitor. Corel sells Wordperfect Suite to manufacturers for about $15, and the retail price for the program is only $99. Lotus is owned by I.B.M., and its suite is bundled free on most I.B.M. personal computers. The retail price of Microsoft Office is $399.
Even with rock-bottom prices, both companies said they believed they could survive and both have large bases of customers who buy updated versions of the programs. A survey early this year of about 300 companies by the Olsten Corporation, a temporary worker company, found that 21 percent of the offices surveyed still used Wordperfect, and 27 percent still used Lotus 1-2-3.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 29, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about a lawsuit filed by 20 states against the Microsoft Corporation misidentified the antitrust officials who contend that the company's pricing policies for its Office suite of programs leave computer makers with the practical choice of installing the software on all their computers or none. They are the states' attorneys general, not staff members of the Justice Department.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC EYE;
Beyond Tape Measures: A New Human Scale

BYLINE: By Phil Patton 

 BODY:
HOLLYWOOD, for one, knows that you need scale: "His tail is as big as four subway cars." "His foot is as big as this billboard." Even Godzilla's scales have scale.
Scale makes us feel significant or insignificant, and soon designers will have a new human scale, thanks to a project that has just been initiated by the Wright Research Laboratory at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. On April 27, a laser scanned the body of the first of some 9,000 people in the United States and Europe; their measurements (in every dimension) will help the Air Force develop a new database of body scale. The aim is to "improve hundreds of goods and services, anything a person might wear or use," said an Air Force spokesman, Bobbie Mixon. 
 Some 20 companies, including Nissan, Boeing, Levi Strauss and Sara Lee Knits, are part of the joint project, called Caesar, which stands for the Civilian American and European Surface Anthropometry Resource. Kathleen Robinette is the head of the lab where the whole-body scanner was developed. Ms. Robinette said that the scanner goes beyond the tape measure by also assessing surface and volume. The goal is to provide a set of three-dimensional measurements that will supplant the classic standards first compiled in 1960 in "Human Scale" by Alvin Tilley.
As information crazy as society has become, Ms. Robinette said, many of our designs are based on obsolete statistics. And marketing further twists our sense of proportion: the smallest cup of coffee Starbucks sells is "tall." From there you move on to "grande" and "vente" -- meaning the 20-ounce size. At the movies, popcorn sizes start at medium and escalate to milk pail.
Sizes are especially askew for women's clothing; they are still based in large part on a 1942 Agriculture Department survey. Ms. Robinette has also noticed what many women have long suspected: buy the more expensive labels, and you, too, can slip into a size 4.
Because many of the scales for clothing and equipment were derived from measuring military men, they had limits in civilian application. And because men chiefly set the scales, women have suffered.
The military has led the way in setting standards ever since the Civil War, when boot makers introduced the first system of standardized sizes for the Union Army. World War II saw the birth of ergonomics -- taken from the measurements of many soldiers, which were used to create better cockpits and gunnery stations.
Now, the Air Force is doing it all over again in three dimensions. The device in its lab scans a human body in 17 seconds. To assure a wide sample, Caesar will look to Europe, where, on average, the Dutch are nearly four inches taller than the average American, Ms. Robinette said. (Americans seem to have leveled off in height since 1970.)
It's all in an attempt to give us an even greater grip on our world. Without scale, we become Gulliver, wandering from Brobdingnag to Lilliput.
"Some people lose their sense of proportion," says the narrator of "Scale," a story by Will Self, an heir to Swift. "I've lost my sense of scale." The hero dreams he walks into a scale model of his hometown and descends down six levels of scale. "It took me two months to climb out," he adds.
The best designers have always understood the importance of scale. One of Charles and Ray Eames's most important designs is not a chair or table but the film "Powers of 10," with its famous recession from the atomic to the cosmic scale, turning exponents into images.
The Air Force's goals are less cosmic: it aims to provide the numbers that will help make furniture that won't cramp your legs, bike helmets that fit children, aircraft seats that make customer's bottoms happier.
The information will offer manufacturers the potential to save money, too. One beneficiary could be the catalogue business, which must deal with merchandise that has been returned because it didn't fit.
Levi Strauss already offers Personal Pairs, custom-fit jeans for women, but in the not-too-distant future less expensive versions of Caesar's $400,000 scanner may be coming to a mall near you, for perfect sizing -- if you want it.
My son will probably still prefer his baggy jeans.

HEADLINE: Orchestra Celebrates Clarinetist's 50 Years

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
Stanley Drucker has a succinct but vivid memory of his first rehearsal as a member of the New York Philharmonic's clarinet section. The orchestra's home was Carnegie Hall then, and Dmitri Mitropoulos was on the podium. The work at hand was Strauss's "Also Sprach Zarathustra." And it was fully 20 years before that score's opening phrase -- the slow, rising arpeggio and the two brass-heavy chordal blasts followed by pounding kettledrums -- became irrevocably linked to Stanley Kubrick's film "2001: A Space Odyssey."
"The sound was overwhelming on the Carnegie Hall stage at that time," Mr. Drucker said. "But you know, it feels like it just happened. I feel as though I'm just starting out. I still love this." 
 That rehearsal was a few months shy of 50 years ago. Twelve years later, in 1960, he became the Philharmonic's principal clarinetist, and in that capacity he has made more than 150 appearances as a concerto soloist with the orchestra. The Philharmonic and its music director, Kurt Masur, are celebrating Mr. Drucker's anniversary in the closing subscription concerts of the season, tonight and Saturday at 8 P.M.
At those performances, Mr. Drucker is to be the soloist in the Copland Concerto for Clarinet, Strings, Harp and Piano, a work he has played with the orchestra several times, and which the Philharmonic is about to take on its spring tour to Asia. And not to make things too easy on himself, he is playing Bartok's "Contrasts" and Leonard Bernstein's Clarinet Sonata with some of his Philharmonic colleagues in a Prelude concert at 6:45 both nights.
"The Copland is an old friend," said Mr. Drucker, who was nominated for a Grammy for his 1989 recording of the work with Bernstein and the Philharmonic. "It was commissioned by Benny Goodman. So was Bartok's 'Contrasts.' Do you realize, Goodman commissioned music from Milhaud, Hindemith, Copland, Bartok? If he had started earlier, we would probably have gotten more concertos. It would have been great to have one from Samuel Barber, for instance.
"The Bernstein Sonata was his first published work, but I played what was probably one of the first performances when I was a student. Its second movement is pretty difficult rhythmically. He always wrote pieces with a lot of interesting rhythms, and this one has passages in 5/8 and 7/8 going pretty fast. It's a good piece, I've played it a lot, and I've recorded it twice."
No one on the current Philharmonic roster has played in the orchestra longer than Mr. Drucker, and he does not remember other golden anniversaries occurring during his tenure. It is rare, in fact, for an orchestra player to hold his post so long, not least because musicians are normally well into their 20's before they have sufficient experience to land a position in a major orchestra.
Mr. Drucker was 19 when he joined the Philharmonic, but his resume was hardly blank. He was born in Brooklyn and began studying the clarinet when he was 10, an age that would be considered late for a pianist but, Mr. Drucker said, is when wind players typically take up their instruments. He attended the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia when he was 15, but at the end of his first year he was spotted by the conductor of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, who invited him to join that ensemble as principal clarinetist.
After one season in Indianapolis, Mr. Drucker toured for a year with the Busch Little Symphony, a conductorless chamber orchestra led by the violinist Adolph Busch, and from there he became principal clarinetist of the Buffalo Philharmonic. On Busch's recommendation, the New York Philharmonic invited Mr. Drucker to audition when a clarinetist's chair opened up in 1948.
Mr. Drucker, whose impeccable tone and broad coloristic palette have regularly been praised in reviews, shrugs off the suggestion that his career trajectory -- from his first lesson to the New York Philharmonic in less than a decade -- was unusually steep.
"It does seem that way," he explained, "but you know, the clarinet was never out of my hands. And in those days, one did what one could to move to better orchestras. The seasons were very short. One didn't really make any money at it, and there was no unemployment insurance. Playing had to be a labor of love. Now the seasons are year round, and one can live well."
Plenty else has changed as well. Auditions, for example, were both simpler and more perilous: instead of auditioning for a committee and going through preliminary and final rounds, Mr. Drucker said, a musician played for the conductor, who had full hiring and firing power. The concept of tenure had not reached the orchestral world. Nor had diversity. Blind auditions, in which the musician plays from behind a screen to minimize potential gender or racial biases, though typical today were unheard of in 1948.
How has the Philharmonic itself changed? "Well, it was all male, for one thing," he said. "And they were all Europeans, with only a few exceptions, of which I was one. Most of the orchestra had been trained in Europe and had come from European orchestras. It was an orchestra of great individuals, people with a great sense of humor and persona, people who really had something to say individually. It was a real United Nations mix of players, at that time."
Mr. Drucker lives in Massapequa, N.Y., where he and his wife, Naomi, also a clarinetist, reared two children who followed in his footsteps, more or less. Their daughter, Rosanne, is a pop singer and songwriter, and their son, Leon -- better known by his stage name, Lee Rocker -- was the bassist in the Stray Cats, a rockabilly trio that disbanded a few years ago but recently reconvened to play at a memorial concert for Carl Perkins. Mr. Rocker also has a blues band.
"No, I never did get to play with the Stray Cats," Mr. Drucker said. "I don't think I'd fit. I don't have the right kind of hair. But I thought they were wonderful. It was old-fashioned stuff, very pure, very accessible, and it put a smile on your face."
During his years as the Philharmonic's principal clarinetist, Mr. Drucker has played virtually all the major clarinet concertos and has been the soloist on several notable recordings, including the Copland; a 1967 account of the Nielsen Clarinet Concerto, with Bernstein conducting, and two recordings of John Corigliano's Clarinet Concerto (one with Bernstein, one with Zubin Mehta), which the orchestra commissioned for him in 1977.
A recording of the premiere of the Corigliano Concerto was included in the recent 10-disk compilation of the Philharmonic's historic radio broadcasts. More recently, Mr. Drucker played the premiere of William Bolcom's Clarinet Concerto, also commissioned by the orchestra.
He points out, too, that beyond concertos, an orchestral clarinetist has plenty of great music to play, and he cites crucial lines in Rimsky-Korsakov's "Scheherazade" and "Capriccio Espagnole," the short but memorable clarinet phrases in Strauss's "Til Eulenspiegel," the slow movement of the Rachmaninoff Second Symphony, and passages in Bartok's "Miraculous Mandarin," Kodaly's "Dances from Galanta" and the Shostakovich symphonies.
Mr. Drucker turns 70 next February, but his playing is as agile as ever, and he said that his plans for the foreseeable future do not include retirement. (The orchestra has no mandatory retirement age.)
"I'm going to play as long as I can," he said, "I think loving it and having something to offer are very important. At any rate, I'm not the oldest player in the Philharmonic, there are a handful older than I. I've been there the longest, because I started so young. But time compresses, you know? Fifty years doesn't really seem so long.
"I tell my colleagues that I've lasted so long because I commute. All that running up and down the stairs to the train keeps me in shape."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Raising cigarette taxes will surely punish tobacco's victims.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
BIG Tobacco is on the run. While specific provisions of the Federal legislation remain in doubt, there is no question the industry will pay hundreds of billions of dollars to compensate states, individual smokers and their lawyers for the medical costs and premature death of smokers. Nor is there much doubt that the settlements will be financed almost entirely by new cigarette taxes.
By the same token, it is safe to assume that virtually any resolution that prices teen-agers out of the cigarette market and generates hundreds of billions of dollars in "sin tax" revenue will enjoy widespread public support. 
 But economists and legal scholars who generally share the public's distaste for cigarette pushers still wonder whether a tax-based fix for tobacco is good public policy.
In some cases, their concerns could be resolved with a little more care in the division of the spoils. There is a more fundamental drawback, though, to any political consensus that turns on enormous increases in the retail price of tobacco: it punishes the victims.
INCENTIVES FOR BETTER CIGARETTES -- When the smoke clears, 40 million adults -- most of whom have tried and failed to stop smoking -- will still be addicted.
The tobacco companies apparently have some good ideas about making cigarettes that minimize their ill effects on health, said Adam Jaffe, an economist at Brandeis University and an expert witness for Blue Cross in the Minnesota litigation.
But under the terms of the legal settlements to date, the companies' financial liability for past transgressions is proportional to their share of the future market. Hence they lack incentives to invest in making a safer cigarette that persuades addicts to switch to their brands.
THE LIGGETT WINDFALL -- When Bennett S. LeBow, chairman of the Brooke Group, the parent of the Liggett Group, broke ranks and settled with the state Attorneys General, it was widely understood that he had made a lucrative deal for his company. But not many people understand just how ahead of the curve Liggett will be if LeBow-lobbied amendments to the White House-backed bill, sponsored by Senator John McCain of Arizona, become law.
The company would not be required to turn over a $1.10-a-pack tax to Washington over the next quarter century as long as Liggett's market share remains below 3 percent. Assuming Liggett takes full advantage of the break by pricing to maximize profits, it will be worth $15 billion, according to calculations by Jeremy Bulow, an economist at Stanford's business school. "Unless Congress removes this handout, Bennett LeBow will be the next member of the Forbes 400," Mr. Bulow said.
LEGAL FEES -- Without Federal legislation, Michael Horowitz of the Hudson Institute, a research group, estimates that the private lawyers in the state Medicaid suits stand to reap $1 billion to $3 billion a year, while contingency fees from suits on behalf of individual smokers could run from $2 billion to $12 billion annually. Even with the bill's $8 billion cap on payouts for individual suits, Mr. Horowitz said, the lawyers' total fees could still touch $6.5 billion a year.
And what is wrong with rewarding the entrepreneurs who spent their own millions to breach the legal defenses of Fortress Tobacco? For one thing, the rewards will be disproportionate to the risk -- especially on cases that come after the initial disclosures of the tobacco companies' misdeeds and are built around early settlement precedents. More important from Mr. Horowitz's perspective, failure to cap fees at, say, five times the highest charges paid to cigarette company lawyers, would set back the general cause of legal reform.
"Trial lawyers already use their riches to influence legislatures and courts," he said. "What will happen when they have billions more to promote their interests?"
TAXING ADDICTS -- It is widely understood that future smokers will pay most of the cost of both the state settlements and any new Federal programs financed with the tobacco tax. What has not sunk in yet is how regressive this tax is likely to be. "The tobacco companies are almost certainly right that the bulk of this tax will be on people making less than $30,000" a year, said Mr. Bulow -- quite a bite for a 500-pack-a-year habit.
Part of the logic in taxing low-income smokers is to recover the costs of smoking-related illnesses covered by Medicaid, Medicare and nonsmokers' health insurance premiums. Yet most of the research on these costs suggests they are largely offset by reduced Social Security payments to smokers who die young. And existing taxes offset the rest. "The idea that smokers cost the rest of us money is simply wrong," said Thomas Schelling, an economist at the University of Maryland.
How, other than taxing cigarettes, might the Government deter teen-age smoking? Perhaps by insisting that stores not sell tobacco to minors, Mr. Bulow said. "But that puts the burden on state and local governments," he reminded -- hardly as popular an idea as handing them freshly collected excise taxes.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Who's Losing Russia?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It can't happen here, but assume our Dow average were to drop substantially. Not just the 10 or 15 percent correction customary after big run-ups, but all the way down to 4,000. What would our reaction be?
After the disbelieving shock would come the rage. Fingers would point at economists who failed to foresee, corporate merger maniacs, bankers and brokers, at surplus budgeteers and muckraking journalists. 
 Most of all, we would fix our fury on the President. Having taken credit for the rain, Bill Clinton would be blamed for the drought. As his popularity plunged, impeachment for other than economic actions would be in the air.
Now let's take a look at Russia. The Russian stock market is the worst-performing market anywhere, down more than 50 percent this year, a panic-stricken 10 percent this week. The young unknown whom Boris Yeltsin put in as Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, has had to raise interest rates to 150 percent to avoid a run on the ruble. Desperate for $2 billion to pay government workers, he put a huge government-owned oil company up for sale, but nobody came to the auction.
And yet the populace has not risen up to demand a change in government. Unlike Americans with pension funds or 401(K) accounts, most Russians are not personally affected by the stock market. And published economic figures on the above-ground economy are misleading because three-quarters of business done in Russia is barter or paid with i.o.u.'s.
What would worry the average Russian most is inflation, which is now relatively low, running about 1 percent a month. That's why Yeltsin's untried new team is desperate to avoid devaluation, pressure for which is building.
Although it would restore some economic equilibrium, devaluing the currency would drive up the price of imports and hit Russians in their pocketbooks, causing political unrest.
The only calls for impeachment of Yeltsin come from the Communists in the Duma they dominate, but that's just a trick: the Constitution forbids the President to dissolve the Duma if it is considering impeachment, and the Communists don't want to face the people yet.
That's because the Communists are stuck at one-fourth of the electorate. Last week's unscientific telephone poll on the popular TV show "Itogi," with 30,000 respondents, showed the Communist Gennadi Zyuganov with only 18 percent; Moscow's Mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, and the newly elected Krasnoyarsk Governor, Aleksandr Lebed, tied for 25 percent, and the Yabloko reform leader, Grigory Yavlinsky, at 32 percent. Yeltsin, whose latest shake-up evidently inspired no confidence, was nowhere.
How does Russia's President restore investor confidence? To keep the wolf from the door, he will seek to borrow more from the International Monetary Fund, grimly promising to collect more taxes from deadbeats.
That's just a palliative. If Yeltsin is to build the global market's confidence, he should tax the state-owned Gazprom, the railways and oil pipeline monopolies; bankrupt Soviet-era collectives and give the farmers their land; reduce and simplify taxes on individuals so he can collect them; close hundreds of tottering banks and make transparent the accounting of the remainder; break the system of official bribery and protect small business from the Mafiya. That's for starters.
Confidence does not come from loans; it's the other way around. When Russia replaces its present crony capitalism with free enterprise under contract law, it will build business confidence. When it stops endangering the world by selling nuclear technology to Iran and allying itself with Iraq, Russia will gain the diplomatic confidence of the Western nation that can do it the most good.
America's national interest is in advancing democracy and competitive capitalism. With the Soviet Union gone, we no longer have to support corrupt, autocratic regimes, as we did Suharto's Indonesia and the Shah's Iran, only because they are non-Communist.
Thanks partly to Yeltsin's courage, Russia is no longer Communist, but largely because of Yeltsin's economic ignorance, his resource-rich land with its literate people is stagnating and imploding. Confidence will overcome panic only when enterprise is freed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Boeing to Cut Production Of 747 Jumbo Jets in 1999

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that weakening demand from Asian airlines would probably force it to cut production of its 747 jumbo jet next year. The company also said it still faced difficulties meeting demand for the new version of its popular 737 narrow-body jet.
Boeing, the world's largest aerospace company, had been saying for months that the financial crisis in Asia was having only a limited effect on its commercial airplane business. But executives acknowledged yesterday that declining demand from Asian airlines would most likely force the company to reduce production of the 747, its most profitable airplane. 
 Boeing recently began building five 747's a month, up from four a month, to meet orders received two or more years ago. That production rate will likely be reduced next year, but the company said it would not decide until next month.
"We think the rate will be down in mid-'99," said Ronald B. Woodard, president of Boeing's commercial plane unit. "We have to figure out when and where we want to go to."
Many analysts who follow Boeing have been expecting such a move for months. But the announcement still hurt Boeing's stock price. Investors are apparently worried that the worldwide demand for commercial aircraft will be in decline by the time the company overcomes production difficulties that it first disclosed in October. Shares of Boeing fell 75 cents yesterday, to $46.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. They have fallen 17 percent from a high of $56.0625 on April 6.
Paradoxically, the loss of confidence in Boeing stock comes when analysts are beginning to think the company is surmounting the production problems caused by parts shortages, regulatory delays and inexperienced workers.
"The level of disruption and turmoil is clearly declining, and the ability to predict is clearly improving," said Howard A. Rubel, who follows Boeing for Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.
But the credibility of Boeing's leaders has badly deteriorated in recent months. From the moment the production problems were first disclosed last fall, Boeing managers were upbeat about their ability to rebound only to surprise Wall Street with more bad news.
The company registered its first annual loss in 50 years in 1997, saw profits tumble in this year's first quarter and has taken several pretax charges totaling nearly $3 billion to account for the production problems.
In their monthly production update to reporters and analysts yesterday, Boeing executives said that they still expected to deliver 550 airplanes in 1998 but that deliveries of the new 737 would suffer delays for the rest of the year.
Boeing recently began producing 737's at a pace of 14 a month, up from 7 a month, and plans to increase that to 21 a month later this year. Mr. Woodard said that while more 737 production fell behind schedule the last month, Boeing was still meeting its recovery plan.
"The facts are the situation on the field and our bottlenecks are improving, not getting worse," he said, responding to what he called unfounded reports of a growing number of unfinished 737's parked at Boeing's Renton production center near Seattle.
Earlier this month, Boeing said it would shift some finishing work on some 737's to its Douglas Products Division in Long Beach, Calif. The move upset Boeing's largest union, the International Association of Machinists, which does not represent the California workers. But the company said that it might add a 737 production line in Long Beach.

HEADLINE: Carl H. Builder, 67, an Expert On Military at Rand Corporation

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Carl H. Builder, an analyst with the Rand Corporation whose views on military affairs were widely quoted, died on May 20 at his home in Culver City, Calif. He was 67.
The cause was cancer, said Jess Cook, Rand's director of public information. 
 At his death, Mr. Builder was a senior operations research specialist at Rand, the research concern based in Santa Monica, Calif. He was on its staff for 29 years.
Mr. Builder worked with and advised the Army, the Air Force and Government agencies on aspects of American security policy, contributed to operational doctrines for nonnuclear strategic weapons and was a main designer of an early computer-based military war-games system.
In 1976, an internal memorandum he wrote, in a year off from Rand as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's director of nuclear safeguards, was made public by another Government agency. It said the commission supported the view that safeguards to prevent theft of explosive materials by terrorist or other criminal elements were inadequate.
Mr. Builder was awarded the Meritorious Service Medal by the commission and the Certificate of Merit by the Air Force Systems Command.
In his analyses, Mr. Builder sometimes emphasized human factors. In the late 1980's he wrote that to halt the search for larger and better intercontinental ballistic missiles would be a blow to the self-image of people who had spent their careers on that kind of weaponry.
"For their sense of personal worth," he said, "people will fight long and hard."
In his highly praised book "The Masks of War: American Military Styles in Strategy and Analysis" (Johns Hopkins, 1989), he wrote, "The military services have acquired personalities of their own that are shaped by their experiences."
In a 1996 interview commenting on the differing severity of the sexual harassment problem in different services, he said: "The Marines and the Army focus on being rough, tough and mean; 'We beat up on people.' In the Air Force, machismo takes a different form -- gallantry, brave aviators in long silk scarves taking off into the wild blue. And in the Navy, much of the machismo is simply facing the elements."
His book "The Icarus Syndrome: the Role of Air Power Theory in the Evolution and Fate of the U.S. Air Force" (Transaction, 1994) was applauded in Public Administration Review as "an excellent and provocative study."
Another book, "Information Technologies and the Future of Land Warfare" (Rand, 1995), by Mr. Builder and Brian Nichiporuk, was praised in Foreign Affairs as a useful contribution "from the think tank world."
A native of Allendale, N.J., Mr. Builder served in the Navy after World War II, attended the United States Naval Academy and earned bachelor's and master's degrees in engineering from the University of California at Los Angeles in the late 1950's.
His first marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his wife, Gabriele Menke; a son, Mark, of Oxnard, Calif.; a daughter, Susannah Lone Horse, who lives in Southern California; six grandchildren; and a brother, Rear Adm. James A. Winnefeld, retired, of Annapolis, Md.

HEADLINE: New Evidence Of China Tie To Clinton Is Asserted

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
In a bid to jumpstart an inquiry hampered by recalcitrant witnesses and staff defections, House Republican investigators today released what they portrayed as further evidence of a Chinese Government connection to President Clinton's re-election campaign in 1996.
Investigators for the panel led by Representative Dan Burton of Indiana said bank records showed that a bookkeeper for a Democratic fund-raiser, Yah Lin Trie, had shared several bank accounts here with two Chinese officials -- a senior executive of a Chinese state-run corporation and a former Chinese Embassy attache in Washington. 
 Investigators acknowledged that the evidence was highly circumstantial. But they decided to release it in part to try to breathe life into Mr. Burton's inquiry, which has been hamstrung by partisan wrangling and strategic missteps.
The bookkeeper, Keshi Zhan, shared a checking account at the International Monetary Fund credit union here with Zhengkang Shao, a senior executive at China Everbright, a financial holdings conglomerate owned by a Chinese state council, according to bank records. From 1988 to 1994, Mr. Shao was a permanent resident of the United States and an economist with the International Monetary Fund.
But the investigators found no evidence that Mr. Shao's money was funneled to the Democratic Party and no connection between Mr. Trie, who was indicted earlier this year, and China Everbright.
Ms. Zhan and Mr. Shao also shared an account with Yongli Su, an attache at the Chinese Embassy until 1992 and a friend of Ms. Zhan.
The disclosures were made by senior investigators for the Committee on Government Reform and Oversight, which Mr. Burton heads. The investigators said the information bolstered the so-called "China connection" to the 1996 elections. They said they decided to release the information after recent reports that a Democratic fund-raiser, Johnny Chung, had told the Justice Department that nearly $100,000 in his contributions originated with a lieutenant colonel in the Chinese Army.
Investigators called Mr. Shao an "intriguing figure" who could have important information about "Mr. Trie's money-laundering network."
Mr. Burton said in a statement: "The material developed by the Committee regarding Charlie Trie, Keshi Zhan and others raises serious questions. Did representatives of the Chinese Government have a hand in this conduit contributions scheme or is it all just a coincidence?"
The panel's disclosures also raise new questions about Ms. Zhan, a former clerk for the Arlington County, Va., government and a part-time hostess for Mr. Trie, a former Little Rock restaurateur known as Charlie whose $645,000 in donations to the Democrats were returned when their origins could not be determined. After being granted immunity by the Senate campaign finance committee, Ms. Zhan answered questions under oath for two days.
Ms. Zhan's lawyer, Breckinridge L. Willcox, said: "To me, what Mr. Burton is doing is simply an exercise in completely unwarranted and creative inference building in a desperate search for a Chinese connection. This is a complete joke."
Mr. Willcox said that much of the information released by the House panel was gathered by the Senate campaign finance committee led by Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee.
"They did not view it as evidence of a Chinese connection," he said. "Isn't it ironic that Mr. Burton now views it that way?"
Indeed, there may be other motives for the disclosures. Mr. Burton's committee has been reeling in recent weeks from criticism by Democrats, particularly after the bungled release of audiotapes of Webster L. Hubbell's prison conversations, and the dismissal of the panel's chief investigator, David Bossie.
Much of the attention has shifted away from Mr. Burton's committee since Speaker Newt Gingrich appointed a special select committee, led by Representative Christopher Cox of California, to investigate Clinton Administration policy that has permitted American satellites to be launched by Chinese rockets.
Kevin Binger, Mr. Burton's chief of staff, denied that the disclosures amounted to the panel's final piece of business. "These circumstances raise a lot of questions that have not been answered," Mr. Binger said.
Still, there are signs that Mr. Burton's inquiry is slowing down. Several investigators said in interviews that they intended to leave the committee in the weeks ahead to pursue other opportunities. And the House leadership has said it would like to move to a different House panel the testimony of four witnesses who have been denied immunity by Democrats on the Burton committee.

HEADLINE: Jerry Brown Dominates Oakland Race

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., May 27

 BODY:
Propelled by unbeatable name recognition, unmatchable press attention and a potent appeal to voters willing to try something new and decidedly different, Edmund G. Brown Jr. has zoomed so far ahead in this city's mayoral race that he seems poised to win outright in the primary on June 2, according to a new poll.
The poll, published today in The San Francisco Chronicle, showed that 46 percent of registered voters in Oakland favored Mr. Brown, the former two-term Governor of California, while 30 percent remained undecided. 
 Under the rules of Oakland's nonpartisan primary, Mr. Brown can avoid a November runoff between the top two finishers if he gets more than 50 percent of the vote. The telephone survey of 600 registered voters was conducted by Baldassare Associates from May 21 to 25 and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
The poll showed that Mr. Brown's nearest challenger in the field of 11, Ed Blakely, an urban planning professor, was favored by 8 percent of voters. Shannon Reeves, president of the Oakland chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, came in third, with 5 percent.
Mr. Brown credited his showing in large part to his record as Governor from 1975 to 1983.
"I'd say there's a memory here of a certain period in California politics when I was Governor," he said in an interview today. "It was a time of creativity and inclusiveness, and in the stagnant waters that are engulfing the mediocrity of politics today, that memory has power."
Opponents attributed Jerry Brown's enormous lead to his celebrity wattage, which they said was more blinding than they had anticipated. "It's been virtually impossible for anyone to get any play in this race except Jerry," said Gale Kaufman, a consultant to another mayoral candidate, Ignacio De La Fuente, a City Councilman. "This is the most unusual race I've ever been in. There's just no way of breaking past Jerry. People seem dazzled by him."
If elected, Mr. Brown would be the first white mayor in two decades in Oakland, a city where African-Americans represent the largest racial group but not a majority.
The poll suggested that Oaklanders were ready not only to elect Mr. Brown, but also to grant him more power than other mayors have had. Mr. Brown is about to start circulating a petition to put a referendum on the November ballot that would strengthen the city's weak mayor system, and the poll showed that voters favored that proposal by a margin of 2 to 1. Two years ago, voters defeated a similar proposal.
When Mr. Brown announced the petition drive about two weeks ago, his opponents disparaged it as an act of extraordinary hubris and predicted that it would turn off voters. But Mr. Brown's numbers in the new poll were higher than in the last published poll, in March.
Political analysts noted that Oakland had not participated as fully in the state's current economic boom as other cities and that its residents resented that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edmund G. Brown Jr. is far ahead in the polls in the mayoral race in Oakland, Calif. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: As India Adds Up Costs of Its A-Tests, Dissent Grows Louder

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 27

 BODY:
Only two weeks after India detonated five underground nuclear tests to popular acclaim, the Hindu nationalists who lead the Government ran into a storm of protest in Parliament today that reflected growing disquiet about the risks and costs of acquiring nuclear weapons.
"The nuclear tests are a great achievement for India, no doubt, but we can't even supply ordinary drinking water and electrical power to the people of this country," said Indrajit Gupta, a Communist. He was Interior Minister in the coalition Government that ran the country for 20 months until March, when a new, 14-party coalition headed by the Hindu nationalists took over. "Where does all this lead to?" he asked. 
 The scene in Parliament, meeting for the first time since the tests, appeared to dismay Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and other senior nationalists, who listened in stony silence.
Other signs that the wave of support might be breaking have included several incidents in the capital in the past 48 hours in which angry crowds in areas lacking electricity for days attacked power substations, smashing equipment and beating employees.
In an attack on Monday, a mob in a district that had been without power for 15 days, in temperatures rising above 115 degrees, ransacked a local office of the main Hindu nationalist organization, the Bharatiya Janata Party. Mr. Vajpayee is the party's parliamentary leader.
The attack came 24 hours before the United States, carrying out economic sanctions brought on by the nuclear tests, forced a delay in $865 million in World Bank loans for the upgrading of India's badly outdated, vastly underpowered electricity grid.
Mr. Vajpayee entered Parliament in a subdued mood that contrasted with the triumphalism displayed by many nationalists after the tests. He noted that his Government had declared a "voluntary moratorium" on tests, and renewed an earlier offer by India to sign a pact with Pakistan that would bind each nation not to be the first to use nuclear weapons against each other. He also repeated a longstanding offer to forswear nuclear arms as part of a global pact binding the United States and other nuclear powers to abandon their arsenals.
"India is now a nuclear weapons state; this is a reality that cannot be denied," the Prime Minister said. "It is India's due, the right of one-sixth of humankind. Our strengthened capability adds to our sense of responsibility. We do not intend to use these weapons for aggression or for mounting threats against any country; these are weapons of self-defense, to insure that India is not subjected to nuclear threats or coercion. We do not intend to engage in an arms race."
Immediately after the tests, with polls showing popular support at more than 90 percent, opposition politicians offered only mild dissent. But in today's speeches, shown throughout India on live television, the opposition accused the Government of abandoning Mohandas K. Gandhi's legacy of nonviolence, of isolating India and of courting economic disaster because of the trade, banking and aid sanctions imposed by the United States and others.
The opposition leaders also accused the Hindu nationalists of "inventing" the threats posed by Pakistan and China to justify the tests, and to artificially increase their popularity with a view to holding a new election. In so doing, several opposition spokesmen said, the Vajpayee Government had forged an anti-India axis of three nations, the United States, China and Pakistan, that had all shown signs of wanting stable, friendly relations with India.
"Before the mushroom cloud had died down, you and your ministers were talking about nuclear weaponization, about mounting warheads on missiles, about unfinished agendas and about a fourth war with Pakistan," said Palianappan Chidambaram, a Harvard-educated lawyer who served as Finance Minister in the previous Government. "And if anybody asks why, where is the threat, they are branded as a traitor. That is the depth of your political cynicism."
In the March vote, the Hindu nationalists registered their best result in 50 years. But they won only 26 percent of the popular vote and a little more than a third of the seats in Parliament, forcing them to round up a dozen smaller parties in a governing coalition. Their minority status makes them vulnerable to parliamentary maneuvering by the Congress Party and other long-established groups that oppose the nationalist creed of Hindu supremacy, considering it a threat to India's minorities, especially the 120 million Muslims.
In today's debate, leading opposition figures even accused the Government of risking war through a spate of aggressive warnings about India's enhanced military power that leading nationalists, including Lal Krishna Advani, the Interior Minister, have issued to Pakistan.
Mr. Advani said last week that the tests had "brought about a qualitatively new stage" in relations between India and Pakistan, and that India would adopt a more "pro-active" policy in dealing with Pakistan, especially over the long-running war that Indian troops have been fighting with Pakistan-backed insurgents in the disputed territory of Kashmir.
Mr. Chidambaram, the former Finance Minister, spoke of "people in this Government who would travel down the road to war." And Natwar Singh, a senior Congress Party leader who is a former Foreign Minister, noted that one of Mr. Vajpayee's ministers had suggested that India was prepared to send troops on "hot pursuit" into the part of Kashmir that has been held by Pakistan since the partition of British India in 1947.
"Do you know what the consequences will be?" Mr. Singh said. "The United Nations Security Council will be summoned within minutes, and mandatory sanctions will be imposed on India."
But the central theme was that the Hindu nationalists had betrayed the 350 million Indians who live in dire poverty. Some speakers dwelled on the possible cost of sanctions to India, which some Western economists have put as high as $20 billion; others cited the huge costs involved in developing, deploying and maintaining an arsenal of nuclear missiles.
Many Indian business executives are also worried, and their doubts have been reflected in a steady slide on Indian stock markets, in credit ratings and in the value of the rupee. When markets closed today in Bombay, the country's main financial center, the Indian currency hit a record low for the third day in a row, 41.35 rupees to the dollar, down 4 per cent since May 11, the day of the first nuclear tests.
