HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Recoup Most Losses, With the Dow Off 27 Points

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Asia's continuing financial crisis reverberated around the world yesterday, sending some financial markets into a tailspin and briefly punishing stocks in the United States.
At one point in the afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 175 points, or almost 2 percent, before buyers piled back in, leaving the blue-chip index down just 27 points for the day. The market's action followed a down day on Tuesday, when the Dow fell 150.71. 
 Political uncertainty in Indonesia, banking and economic woes in Japan, a labor strike in South Korea and recessionary warnings from Hong Kong's chief executive helped push jittery investors to the exits.
Russia, in deepening financial trouble, tripled its overnight lending rate in hope of restoring lost confidence in the ruble and stemming the outflow of capital. European stock indexes fell across the board.
The combination of events signaled to American investors that Asia remained a wild card that could reduce corporate profits here.
"Asia rearing its now ugly head spooked the market a bit," said Rick White, a managing director and portfolio manager for Salomon Brothers Asset Management in New York. "It made people focus on the fact that earnings for the year are probably too high."
Companies are reluctant to gauge what the impact of Asia's financial woes will be or how long the negative effects may last. But National Semiconductor, Callaway Golf, Kent Electronics, Analog Devices, Boeing and Ford have all hinted that the effects of the Asian malaise could carry into the second half of the year, jeopardizing forecasts for corporate earnings growth.
Yesterday, the Boeing Company confirmed what some analysts had anticipated, telling investors that the Asian troubles might force it to cut production of the 747 jumbo jet, its most profitable aircraft, as orders from the Pacific region weaken for 1999.
Slowing Asian demand also led Matt Berler, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, to lower his second-quarter and full-year 1998 estimates for several paper and forest-products companies, including Boise Cascade, International Paper and Georgia-Pacific. In lowering his forecasts, Mr. Berler warned that pricing and volume would remain under pressure because of the strong dollar and weak Asian markets.
At the Ford Motor Company's annual meeting earlier this month, the chairman, Alexander Trotman, warned that the automobile industry had yet to feel the full impact of Asia's weakness, which could lead to lower prices and rising auto imports.
More companies may sound alarms in coming weeks as the Asian economic turmoil shows few signs of improving soon, despite initial hopes of a quick recovery.
"A normal business cycle would dictate a recovery in 12 to 18 months -- but this is anything but normal," said Jesper Koll, an economist with J. P. Morgan in Tokyo. "The risk of a long and drawn-out adjustment process is pretty high. It's not meaningful to talk about a bottom yet."
Last October, Morgan forecast that Asia's emerging markets would grow about 6.5 percent. That forecast is now about 1.4 percent, Mr. Koll said, adding that he expected 6 of 11 countries in that region, excluding Australia and Japan, to see declines.
"People had become less concerned about the Far East almost to the point of believing that there's nothing to worry about," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. But "if you do your homework, you know there's not much growth" in the region.
In United States equity markets, analysts expect earnings of the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to increase by 4.3 percent in the second quarter, according to data compiled by I.B.E.S. International. Their forecast rises as high as 12.7 percent growth in the third quarter and 17 percent in the fourth quarter, with corporate growth ending the full year at 8.4 percent. Estimates compiled by First Call, a competing firm, put annual growth a little higher, around 10 percent, said Chuck Hill, research director.
But Joseph Abbott, an I.B.E.S. equity analyst, expects earnings to grow 4.5 percent this year. Referring to the more optimistic forecasts, he said, "We do believe it will come in much slower than that, primarily due to a slowdown in Asia" and the weaker currencies in the region.
Companies most likely to see earnings falter as the result of weak Asian demand include semiconductor makers. David Wu, an analyst with ABN Amro, has lowered earnings forecasts for several companies, including Applied Materials, Novellus Systems and Lam Research because of their vulnerability to Asian economic conditions.
"Everybody has Asia exposure and everybody's in trouble," Mr. Wu said. The next 12 months are not going to bring a lot of good news."
Other likely candidates include companies in the energy, aerospace and military goods industries. According to a recent Morgan Stanley Dean Witter research report, these companies generated more than 10 percent of their revenue in 1996 from Asia, excluding Japan.
The Asian fiscal crisis may also force American investors to realize that a rosy economic expectation of slower economic growth and low inflation may not translate into strong corporate earnings, said George Jacobsen, chief investment strategist with Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen in New York.
"The economy's been expanding since 1991," he said, "and people have come to expect that as long as the economy's good, corporate profits will grow and stock prices will rise."
Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments, believes that a further deterioration in Asia could provoke a 10 percent pullback in the market, sending the Dow Jones industrials down to 8,000.
The Dow closed yesterday at 8,936.57, down 27.16 points, its lowest level since April 28. The S.& P. 500 slipped 1.79 to 1,092.23, but the Nasdaq composite index gained 3.01 points, closing at 1,781.10. All made marked comebacks in the last hour or so of trading.

Bonds a Bit Lower
By Bloomberg News
 Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday, erasing earlier gains, as stocks recovered much of their losses.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32, to 103 30/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.84 percent from 5.83 percent.
Treasury prices were kept in check in part as investors digested $13 billion of new two-year notes sold yesterday by the Treasury. Today, it auctions $11 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading yesterday, the new five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.54 percent.

HEADLINE: Next 'Asian' Crisis?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The financial panic that struck Russia today had distinctly Russian causes: the Government cannot collect taxes, it suffers from an economy that is nearly moribund and it has an untested new economic team. But in Washington the Russian crisis looks very much like the next phase of the Asian crisis.
In fact, the two are related. In recent days, as President Suharto was being toppled in Indonesia, the yen was falling in Tokyo and workers were striking in South Korea against long-delayed layoffs, investors began to fear that Asia's troubles were far from over and could easily spread to other emerging markets. 
 In that atmosphere, a senior American official said today, "Russia is particularly vulnerable."
Like Indonesia, it has a rocky banking system. Like South Korea last November, it is seeing its foreign currency reserves dwindling to alarming levels. Russia's foreign debt of $145 billion is not huge as a percentage of its economy, but lenders around the world are clearly unwilling to put more on the line.
And while the economic plan put together by Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko has impressed American officials, no one yet knows whether the 35-year-old handpicked by President Boris N. Yeltsin has the clout to turn reform into reality.
"Russia is facing substantial financial strains, arising from a combination of factors," a senior Treasury official said today. But he tried to dampen speculation that it was about to suffer an Asian-style meltdown, suggesting that Moscow might rise to the challenge -- much as Brazil did last fall when it appeared to be in danger of catching the Asian flu.
He may be right. Russia's recent economic history has been a series of narrow escapes after flirtations with disaster. It has repeatedly gone to the brink, requiring assistance from the International Monetary Fund.
But if its economy requires massive help anytime soon, it is not clear where the assistance might come from. Pinned down in Asia, the International Monetary Fund -- the world's lender of last resort -- says it is strapped for cash.
The monetary fund estimates that it has only $10 billion to $15 billion easily available to fight another national meltdown. Congress has declined so far to commit $16 billion more to the fund, and until Washington acts, other governments refuse to increase their contributions.
So if Russia's troubles deepen, the I.M.F.'s remaining reserves could prove insufficient to support the Russian currency and help the country meet its debt payments.
After all, South Korea needed a bailout package that totaled more than $50 billion from the fund and other sources, though only a fraction of that has been spent so far. And its economy is far healthier and more developed than Russia's.
Clinton Administration officials insisted today that they had not discussed using American funds to help the Russians out, even with the kind of backup financing offered to Indonesia and Korea.
Instead, the Americans are offering plenty of private advice and public encouragement designed to calm the markets. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers visited Mr. Kiriyenko 10 days ago, and the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today that Washington was confident that the Russian Government was "capable of leading the economy in a direction of successful economic growth."
But unlike Washington, the world's currency traders and investors do not dwell on Russia's strategic importance or its nuclear capabilities. They are interested in hard evidence that the country can pay its debts. And these days, they have a lot of reason for doubt.
Declining oil prices have cut into the country's revenues and prevented Russia from getting the price it wanted at the auction of the last big Government-owned oil company. The outlook has worsened with disturbances triggered by coal miners and with the Government's inability to force profitable companies to pay their taxes.
While none of those problems are particularly new, the revival of the Asian crisis -- which makes investors nervous about any emerging market -- is creating a bad case of economic contagion.
"The markets are just waking up to the fact that the Asian crisis is far from over, and in some places it is getting worse," Kenneth Courtis, the chief economist for Deutsche Bank, said recently, before Russia's problems took center stage. "People just pull their horns in. They are much more attuned to risk than they were even a few months ago."
The connections are more than psychological. Among the heaviest investors in Russia were the South Koreans, who lent to the country and began to build factories there as part of their strategy of isolating North Korea from its onetime ally. Now, with the South Korean stock market at an 11-year low and South Korean manufacturers cutting back around the world, that source has dried up.
Once there was hope that Japan would see Russia as an enormous opportunity, within sight of its northern islands. But with Japanese banks reeling and the Japanese currency in rapid decline, there is little hope that Japan will help anyone but itself.
So for Russia, the next few days are critical. Its decision to jack up the interest rate paid by its central bank to more than 150 percent was meant to send a message that Russia will defend the ruble. But it cannot afford to pay such rates for long.
It must somehow convince investors that Mr. Kiriyenko's reform plan to cut spending and raise revenues is about to become reality. Otherwise, Russia could suffer the fate of many of Asia's high-flyers.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Antitrust Suit Against Intel Prepared by Regulators
The Federal Trade Commission is readying a major antitrust suit against Intel, charging the company with abusing its position as the dominant manufacturer of microprocessor chips for personal computers and bullying some computer makers, lawyers said.
The suit marks the second front in the Federal Government's antitrust assault on Wintel, as the computer juggernaut built around Microsoft's Windows operating system and Intel's microprocessors is known. Microsoft was sued last week. Page A1. 

Financial Crisis in Russia
The financial disarray in Russia has forced that country to raise interest rates to 150 percent in order to defend the ruble's value and stem the exodus of foreign investors. A1.
 
In Washington, the Russian crisis looks like the next phase of the Asian crisis. Administration officials consider Russia particularly vulnerable. News Analysis. A14.
 
Boeing Hurt by Asian Weakness
After asserting for months that Asia would cause minimal impact on its airplane business, Boeing said orders from Pacific Rim airlines are weak and probably will force it to reduce 747 production next year. Boeing is also having difficulties meeting demand for its new 737. Disillusionment with Boeing is reflected in a 17 percent drop in its stock price since early April. D2.
 
Korean Workers Strike
Tens of thousands of workers in South Korea struck to protest layoffs and the increasing use of temporary workers. Many directed their anger at huge South Korean conglomerates that helped cause the country's economic crisis by amassing heavy debts. A7.
 
Moody's downgraded ratings for five major Japanese banks because of economic weakness in Japan and Asia overall. D18.
 
Lucent's Expanded Reach
Extending its business beyond traditional telecommunications equipment, Lucent announced new products that transmit digital information using Internet technology. Lucent's stock price rose 3.8 percent. D2.
 
Medicaid For Impotence Drug
The Clinton Administration has told state officials it intends to require their Medicaid programs to pay for medically approved uses of Viagra. The Administration has upset state officials, who contend such decisions should be left to the states. A1.
 
Digital TV Pact Blocked
Europe's antitrust regulators have blocked a digital television alliance formed by three German media companies that wanted to offer a wide array of pay-TV services. D4.
 
Wisdom of Tobacco Tax Debated
There is little question that the public wants the tobacco industry to pay for measures that would discourage smoking. But economists and legal scholars wonder whether a tax-based fix for tobacco is good public policy. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. D2.
 
BBDO to Handle Most Frito-Lay Ads
Frito-Lay has decided to consolidate most of its creative advertising assignments at BBDO Worldwide. BBDO has created campaigns for several of the snack-food giant's brands, including Baked Lay's, Doritos, Ruffles, Tostitos and the new Wow! line of snacks made with the fat substitute Olestra. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D4.
 
Mexican Unions Fight For Migrants
Four Mexican unions have filed an unusual legal complaint charging that thousands of Mexican migrants who pick and pack apples in Washington State are deprived of their basic labor rights as guaranteed under the North American Free Trade Agreement. A18.

HEADLINE: MOSCOW ATTEMPTS DRASTIC MEASURES TO SAVE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 27

 BODY:
As Russia's financial markets teetered on the brink of collapse, Moscow mounted a drastic effort today to preserve the value of its currency and stem the exodus of foreign investors.
In a quick series of steps to address the new Russian Government's most serious economic crisis, officials tripled interest rates, announced that they would be willing to accept a far lower price for the sell-off of Russia's last big oil company, and appealed for support from the International Monetary Fund. 
 "This will become a cold shower on those who are counting on the weakness of the Government and the Bank of Russia," said Sergei Dubinin, the head of the Russian central bank.
All week, Russia's financial markets have been under siege as fears have mounted among investors and United States officials that the economic turmoil in Asia would spread to Russia.
The Moscow stock market is now the world's worst performing market, off more than 50 percent this year, bond prices are declining and efforts to boost the ruble by buying up the currency on the open market have cost more than $1 billion over the past week from a cash reserve that is alarmingly low.
The swoon in the markets has also turned into a profound political crisis here and has become a major worry for American policymakers who have thrown their support behind President Boris N. Yeltsin's reform Government.
Mr. Yeltsin has staked the credibility of his new team on defending the value of the ruble, which for ordinary Russians is the ultimate barometer of the nation's economic and political health.
The value of the ruble determines what many everyday staples cost. A failure to stabilize the currency could lead to a devaluation and a chain reaction of debt problems for the Russian Government, bank failures, inflation and political unrest.
If ordinary Russians joined the foreign investors who are exchanging their rubles for dollars it would be extremely difficult for the central bank to maintain the current ruble-dollar exchange rates.
Against a backdrop of a currency crisis in Indonesia that led to the resignation last week of President Suharto, and a widespread belief that Asia's economic troubles are far from over, nervous investors are increasingly shunning markets in developing countries like Russia.
Today those jitters had an effect all over the world as stock markets fell from Hong Kong to Frankfurt, from London to New York fell.
In Russia, "the market has crashed," said Mark Mobius, money manager for Templeton Worldwide Inc. "We are seeing a so-called meltdown."
Most analysts agree that Mr. Yeltsin's new young Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, has worked hard to reduce the nation's budget deficit with a series of proposed spending cuts, though tax collection remains a major problem.
Now, the focus of the crisis is the ruble and the reserves the central bank has on hand to boost its value.
Today, the bank disclosed that its reserves have dwindled to about $14 billion. However, about $4.5 billion of those reserves are in gold and are not readily available to spend to prop up the currency.
Last October, by comparison, the central bank's reserves were about $23 billion.
As the reserves have shrunk, foreign investors have become increasingly worried that the Government would be forced to devalue the currency.
There are some additional sources of funds -- though they may be far too modest to put out the financial fire. The International Monetary Fund is expected shortly to approve the next $700 million disbursement of its $10 billion loan. So far Russia has received $5.2 billion of the three-year loan. Russia may also be able to obtain financing through commercial banks.
"We have some proposals from the biggest private banks," Oleg Vyugin, the Deputy Finance Minister, said today in an interview. "We have to consider whether that would be useful or not."
Also, the Government hopes to press ahead with the auction of state property. Mr. Kiriyenko cancelled the sale of Rosneft, the big oil company, after the Government failed to receive a single bid by the Tuesday deadline.
But today, Russian officials said that a new auction would be quickly arranged with an asking price of $1.6 to $1.7 billion instead of $2.1 billion, a cut of more than 19 to 24 percent. The Government said it hopes to announce a winner by the middle of next month.
Still, a growing chorus of Russian officials and foreign investors think a large bailout, akin to the rescue packages for Indonesia and South Korea, may be required.
"Russia desperately needs some kind of standby facility," said Marc Holtzman, the president of corporate finance for ABN AMRO, a major Dutch bank. "The Russian Government has done a very commendable job to date. The I.M.F. has to take some decision action."
Prime Minister Kiriyenko has also talked about the need for additional assistance from the Monetary Fund to help it restructure its debts.
Mr. Kiriyenko spoke by telephone last night with Michel Camdessus, the Fund's managing director, who is attending a conference in Kyrgyzstan.
After that conversation, the Fund's chief Russian specialist, John Odling-Smee, was dispatched to Moscow. But the Fund tried to play down the seriousness of the Russian financial situation and it was unclear whether it would be willing to provide more aid.
"Contrary to what markets and commentators are imagining, this is not a crisis," Mr. Camdessus said. "This is not a major development."
The perception in Moscow, however, was very different. Russia's stock market, which was already seriously depressed, plummeted more than 10 percent today.
Meanwhile, interest rates on Russian Treasury bills have soared to almost 90 percent, as the central bank tries to attract investors to buy the securities. Russia depends heavily on the sale of Treasury bills to finance its budget deficit.
The latest financial shocks reflect investors' anxiety over emerging markets, declining world oil prices and Russia's difficult negotiations with the Monetary Fund. But they were also sparked by the Government's failure on Tuesday to receive any bids for Rosneft, a development that many investors took at a vote of no-confidence on the Russian economy.
The most dramatic increase came today when the central bank tripled its refinancing rate, an interest rate it charges on loans to banks, to 150 percent from 50 percent.
Boosting that rate, in effect, encourages investors to hold rubles and discourages investors who have rubles from selling them for dollars.
Mr. Yeltsin plans to meet with Mr. Kiriyenko, Mr. Dubinin, and his Finance Minister on Thursday. Russian officials said that the Kremlin was weighing various steps, including a Presidential speech, to try to calm the markets.
Meanwhile, Mr. Yeltsin's foes sought to exploit the financial crisis. Gennadi Zyuganov, the Communist leader, describe the financial crunch as a "national catastrophe."
Before he left for Moscow, Mr. Odling-Smee, the expert at the Monetary Fund insisted that there was no need to devalue the ruble.
"There is no objective case for devaluing the ruble in terms of Russia's competitiveness or exports and the likely medium to long-term flows of capital," Mr. Odling-Smee said

GRAPHIC: Charts: "Beware the New Russian Bears"
Russia's stock markets have taken a beating this year as investors have fled over worries about Russia's economy. To protect the ruble, Russia's central bank has responded by raising interest rates.

"SORTING IT OUT: A Domino Effect"
In the wake of the Asian currency crisis, investors have become wary of putting money into emerging markets, including Russia. The result is that the country's already shaky financial picture has worsened in the last few weeks.
 
Russia is short on cash and is having trouble paying its debts.
 
It saves money by failing to pay some workers.
 
Workers strike.
 
Russia pays strikers with money set aside for other things.
 
Russia borrows from banks and the International Monetary Fund.
 
The I.M.F. tells Russia to raise taxes or to trim its budget deficit.
 
Russian stock, bond and currency markets falter as other emerging markets decline.
 
Russia tries to stabilize the value of the currency by buying rubles and by raising interest rates to encourage people to hold rubles. (pg. A14)

LENGTH: 892 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Out of the Shadow of a Noted Family Name

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
PEGGY DULANY was always considered one of the more unorthodox "Cousins," as the fourth-generation Rockefellers are known, although she was utterly orthodox when it came to family rebellion. Ms. Dulany joined the S.D.S. at Harvard, lived in a squatters' colony in Brazil and was among the first to drop the Rockefeller name for Dulany, her middle name from her mother's side. In the 1980's she met Oliver Tambo, the president of the African National Congress.
"I told him I wanted to do something," Ms. Dulany recalled. "And he said, 'Don't get arrested outside the South African Embassy.' Of course that was what I was thinking of doing. But he said, 'We have plenty of people who can do that. What we don't have is people with connections to the business community.' And it gradually gave me the notion that there could be a role helping people across gaps." Change at the "grass roots" was fine, Ms. Dulany concluded, "but that's not where my value-added was." 
 Sounds sensible for a Rockefeller.
Ms. Dulany smiled. "It only took 20 years to figure out," she said.
Ms. Dulany, 50, is now the founder and chairman of Synergos, a small Manhattan-based nonprofit group -- built on her considerable connections -- that works to alleviate poverty in the developing world. Her father is David Rockefeller, the former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Her great-grandfather was John D. Rockefeller Sr., the founder of Standard Oil. On Tuesday night Synergos (pronounced sin-AIR-gose) gave a dinner at the United Nations. Kofi A. Annan, the Secretary General, came; so did James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank.
Yesterday at noon, in her offices at Park Avenue and 85th Street, Ms. Dulany talked for an hour about Synergos and her family. It is, after all, a time of renewed debate about the Rockefeller legacy.
Consider this: At exactly the same hour, Ron Chernow, the author of "Titan," a new biography of John D. Sr., talked at the University Club about his subject's "visionary" philanthropy.
"In the 19th century, rich people typically gave money in a sentimental or haphazard way to their alma maters or to museums or to local hospitals, which they still do," Mr. Chernow said afterward. But John D. Sr., he said, went from "retail" to "wholesale" philanthropy, creating Spelman College in Atlanta, the University of Chicago and the Rockefeller Foundation.
MS. DULANY said that Synergos had no ambitions on that scale -- its annual budget is $2 million -- but that she was proud of her family for creating "perm-anent institutions" for social change.
"Money has a finite use if it's not used in a constructive way," she said. She has also learned -- from her father and her uncles Nelson and John D. Rockefeller 3d -- that "even if I could provide all the funding for an organization, which I couldn't, it's not a good idea.
"Because then people say, 'Oh, that's just a Rockefeller-funded organization. They don't need money.' Which sometimes people say anyway."
In the decade since Synergos was founded, Ms. Dulany has contributed more than $1 million of her own money, but not more than 10 percent of the yearly budget. (Other contributors are Fortune 500 companies, foundations, Unicef and Dwayne O. Andreas, the friend and donor to many Republicans.)
Ms. Dulany is thoughtful, serious and wary. She would probably be happier not having to talk about her family at all -- she said she has not yet read "Titan" and finds the comparisons of Microsoft to Standard Oil only "vaguely interesting" -- but seems to accept it as her fate. She billed the Synergos dinner as a "University for a Night," and instructed each table to discuss a pre-selected world problem, which friends say was classic Peggy. At her father's table, the question was: "What can business leaders do to raise the living standards of the poorest in the United States and abroad?"
Ms. Dulany said that some of the best work of Synergos was in Ecuador, where her group helped create a foundation that trained 1,200 women who make what Americans call Panama hats. The women formed a cooperative, eliminated the middlemen, found their own source of straw and developed markets in Europe. Ms. Dulany grew up in Manhattan and spent weekends at Pocantico Hills, the Rockefeller estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. (She still does, although she now has her own house on the Upper East Side. She has a 21-year-old son, Michael, a student at Northwestern University, and is separated from her second husband.) She earned a masters and doctorate from the Harvard School of Education and for six years ran an alternative high school near Boston. In the early 1980's, she moved back to New York and worked at the New York City Partnership, a civic organization; her father was then its chairman. Ms. Dulany looks back on the move as the end of her rebellion against the family.
"I think my willingness to come back to New York and work with the partnership was an indication that I was ready to use the access that my part of this family provided me," she said.
If she had it to do over again, would she prefer not to live life as a Rockefeller? "I don't think I like that question," she said, more or less pleasantly. "If I had the chance to rewrite anything, I would have preferred to have figured out sooner to make use of the cards that were dealt to me."

HEADLINE: Giving Money Local Color;
A Small Connecticut Town Issues Its Own Currency To Urge Hometown Spending

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: WILLIMANTIC, Conn.

 BODY:
At the end of a 60-foot mahogany bar under a celestial 21-foot ceiling, Cindy Wollner watched the final lunchtime stragglers seep out of her new restaurant and fingered a few bills, part of the afternoon's take.
But the image on the lavender notes wasn't a portrait of George Washington, or even Thomas Jefferson, but an engraving of a covered wagon and three pioneers; the bills' motto declared not "In God We Trust," but "In Community We Trust." 
 "It's real money in this town," explained Ms. Wollner, who runs her restaurant, the Willimantic Brewing Company, in a gray, granite monolith that once was a United States post office. "It's worth 10 real dollars. And we take it for 100 percent of a bill."
Even as much of Europe is moving to rip down national monetary systems with the creation of the euro, a currency that will start circulating in 11 European countries in 1999, a small but growing number of communities in the United States and Canada are digging small monetary moats around their towns and villages.
In more than 60 municipalities, groups of citizens, some with broad political agendas to increase local activism, others looking to keep money in their economically troubled communities, have begun printing and issuing their own currency. In Hot Springs, N.C., much business is done in Mountain Money. In Halifax, Nova Scotia, there are Maritime Hours. And in Bolinas, Calif., a bit of trading is done in Sand Dollars.
And here in New England, as well as in New York State, a peppering of towns have well-entrenched systems of local currencies or, in some cases, fledgling efforts just taking shaky wing.
"This is a way people are using to rebuild communities without going to Washington, or to their local governments," said Lewis Solomon, a law professor at Georgetown University who has studied both the economics and legalities of local currencies. "The foundation of this is that the U.S. currency is not backed by gold, but by trust. In the same way, local currencies are backed by community trust, by goods and services in the community."
Crucially, said Mr. Solomon, such currency systems are perfectly legal in this country, because there are no laws barring citizens from issuing their own currencies in their communities. But the Internal Revenue Service requires that all earnings in these currencies be declared in United States dollars for tax purposes.
Here in Connecticut, where little towns straddle two-lane rural highways, the city of Willimantic sits hard against the rush of the spring-swollen Willimantic River. In the last century, that river brought industry here, its waters driving the great water wheels of the American Thread Company, once one of the nation's largest thread manufacturers.
But in the 1980's, the last of the mills closed. Unemployment rose and lights in the storefronts of Main Street's stretch of two- and three-story red brick buildings began winking off. Even the monolithic granite post office closed.
At City Hall, a red-brick pile of Victorian architecture, the first selectman, Walter M. Pawelkiewicz, has worked to get urban redevelopment grants to renovate the old mills. "Since '93," Mr. Pawelkiewicz said as he slumped in a leather armchair in an office piled with sheaves of project time lines, artists' renderings and unreturned phone messages, "we've been trying to do a lot of regional economic development. Our whole notion in the mill project is capture a biotech park."
But elsewhere in town, a group of citizens decided that it should do something besides wait for the state to pump millions of dollars into the town. So last summer, Donna Nicolino, the director of a local arts council, gathered about a dozen peopletogether, including a business consultant, the manager of the local food cooperative and some faculty from the local college, Eastern Connecticut State University, and decided to print their own money.
They called it Thread City Bread.
"There were a lot of businesses opening up on Main Street and then closing down," Ms. Nicolino said. "It's hard to be a small business person in this town. So we thought this was a way to keep the wealth in the community."
Modeling the town's currency on a similar system in Ithaca, N.Y., where a local currency has been in use for seven years, Ms. Nicolino had two bills designed, one for a single unit of Thread City Bread and one for a quarter unit, with each unit pegged at $10 in American currency.
"We liked the idea of everyone's labor being of equal value," she said. "Of course, people set the rate for their work differently, but the exchange is in our currency." Most systems using local currencies peg each unit, also called hours, at a value of $10, roughly keyed to double the minimum wage, asserting a shared belief that the minimum wage is too low.
Under the system of local money used in Willimantic, and elsewhere, the local currency is distributed in a rigidly controlled manner to businesses and service providers who agree to participate in the system. Those businesses can give change in Thread City Bread to willing customers. The businesses will also accept the local currency for up to 100 percent of their goods and services. The business people often use the local currency in one another's businesses, much like a barter system. "This is to let people know that they have some alternative to the dollar economy if that isn't working for them," Ms. Nicolino said.
For businesspeople like Ms. Wollner, the restaurant owner who is one of the leaders of the Downtown Business Council, which represents the interests of local merchants, spending the local currency they take in is not necessarily easy because not all businesses accept it. A local directory lists about 100 businesses and individuals who will take the bills.
Willimantic's experiment with local currency is barely a year old and some people think it has a long way to go before it is widely accepted. In Ithaca, however, the system is deeply embedded in the community.
Founded by a bearded, graying environmentalist named Paul Glover, the Ithaca Hours currency is accepted at more than 350 businesses in the town of 30,000 people. "We're looking for control over our local economy," Mr. Glover said. "People are less comfortable with control of their economy by distant elites who will invest or disinvest at the snap of a finger without concern for the fate of communities."
But unlike other forms of community advocacy, the local currency systems are in many ways politically diverse, appealing to and used by people with a spectrum of political and economic views.
Indeed, a key member of the Ithaca Hours advisory board, a sort of central bank that is informally called the Municipal Reserve System, is a former economist at the Federal Reserve Bank and the International Monetary Fund, Monica Hargraves.
"I came here in 1995," Ms. Hargraves said, "and I was amazed that this worked. It's trust that holds the system together, the confidence that people will accept Ithaca Hours."
So far, there are the equivalent of $65,000 in Ithaca Hours in circulation. But not unlike the concerns of the Federal Reserve, the committee that oversees the issuance of the currency wrestles continually with questions of economic liquidity, money supply and economic benefits.
"At the moment," Ms. Hargraves said, "there's a debate over are there enough Hours out there. It's really hard to get the data that one would want. The Federal Reserve has an enormous data-gathering apparatus and a long track record on how much money is right. The question is tricky even if you have a lot of data. So we end up with little alternative to a fairly anecdotal process."
Back in Willimantic, about halfway down the half-shuttered Main Street, Bruce Carver padded across the 1890 oak floorboards of his toy store, With a Wink and a Smile, to show a customer a windup yellow tin automobile. "This is a bit of a retro toy store," Mr. Carver said with a laugh. "No battery toys here."
But like a growing number of merchants in town, Mr. Carver, who tends his menagerie of stuffed animals, shelves of windup toys and bins of kites with the fastidiousness of an organic gardener, said he welcomed Thread City Bread.
"It's our local money," he said. "There's not enough around. There should be more, and I hope we'll see more. It's one of the ways I see us being able to bring this town back. It's good stuff."

LENGTH: 1174 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Frenzy of Global Anxiety Kicks Up Dust That Had Been Settling

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Investors stampeded in and out of financial markets around the world yesterday, raising new concerns about the global reverberations of the Asian economic crisis that began nearly a year ago.
Such heightened uncertainties helped further deflate a financial rebound in developing countries that began earlier this year. Now, the outlook for these emerging markets has grown even cloudier because of severe problems in Russia. 
 Russia, moving to keep investors from abandoning its shaky economy, tripled interest rates to 150 percent yesterday as its stock market plummeted 11 percent. That led to a dizzying wave of global speculation that roiled stock markets and currency exchange rates elsewhere.
The Brazilian stock market, down nearly 5 percent at one point, finished the day up 2.46 percent. In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average ended only marginally lower after falling as much as 1 percent during the day. Markets in other countries weakened more substantially.
Hong Kong's chief executive warned of a looming recession as the stock market there plunged 5.3 percent. Japan's stock market fell 1.4 percent, Germany's dropped 3.1 percent, France's 2.4 percent and Britain's 1.7 percent.
At its midday break today, Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 122.52 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent. The South Korean market was up 4.09 percent early today, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index was down 81.14 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Economists and analysts have a bleak term for financial problems that seep out of one country and begin to swamp the economies of other nations: "contagion." While it is still unclear whether full-blown financial contagion is afoot, analysts are finding little to be optimistic about overseas.
"As I look at it with a broad brush, there are a lot of things going south at the same time," said Morris Goldstein, a former International Monetary Fund official and a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "Where's the good news coming from? There's no silver bullet out there."
Without good news, nervous investors are quick to seek safe havens. And in an era when vast amounts of capital can be moved swiftly around the globe merely by tapping a computer keyboard, bad news can have rapid and brutal economic consequences.
Currency traders said they were finding shelter in strong currencies like the Swiss franc, German mark and United States dollar. That has put pressure on weaker currencies like the South African rand, the South Korean won, the Mexican peso, and, of course, the Russian ruble.
"The Russian situation is serious indeed, and they've made it clear they're going to defend the ruble at all costs," said Chris Turner, a currency analyst with I.D.E.A., an economics consulting firm in New York. "Foreigners own about $15 billion of Russian treasury bills, and the Russians are trying to discourage them from pulling out."
Traders also said Russia's precarious financial position helped cause sell-offs of the Polish zloty, Hungarian forint and the Czech koruna.
Russian officials in recent days have expressed confidence about the nation's economic prospects.
"Those who have been speculating in the Russian market have shown a little nervousness," Andrei Kozyrev, a former Russian Minister of Foreign affairs and current member of the Parliament of the Russian Federation, said in a recent interview. "But those companies that are long-term investors, I don't think they will run out. They know better, and I think they will tell you that there will be a growing market in Russia.
"I think there is a high-percentage chance that the Government will be able to keep the currency stable. We are faced with an unfortunate combination of low oil prices and Asian market turmoil. That has probably scared some investors, who have extrapolated their fears about the Asian markets to Russia. But that is not justified."
Such explanations do not necessarily offer reassurance to American investors who have watched their holdings in Russia go from a stellar performance last year to disastrous losses in recent weeks.
For example, Lexington Troika Russia fund, a mutual fund that invests primarily in Russia, was the fourth-best performing equity fund in the United States last year, gaining 67.5 percent. But the fund's value has fallen 45 percent from the beginning of the year through Tuesday.
Similarly, the value of several closed-end funds that invest in Russia and Eastern Europe have declined sharply. (A closed-end fund invests like a mutual fund, but its shares are traded on a stock exchange.) Shares of the Templeton Russia fund, which had $150 million in assets at the end of the first quarter, making it the largest such fund devoted to Russian investment, fell $1.1875 yesterday, to $24.9375, down 39 percent since the beginning of the year and down 63 percent from a high of $64.75 last July.
Mark Mobius, who manages the Templeton Russia fund, told Bloomberg News that the Russian stock market "has crashed." Although Mr. Mobius said Templeton would continue investing in Russia, he said "we are seeing a so-called meltdown" in the financial markets there.
The first companies to feel the downdraft from the emerging-market turmoil are financial services firms because they are the most directly connected to economic problems ravaging those markets. So it was no surprise that the stocks of American banks and brokerage firms were battered yesterday by fears about potential losses from overseas operations.
The Bankers Trust Corporation, which has a significant presence in Asia, was hit hardest. Its shares fell $5.75, or 4.38 percent, to $125.5625. The BankBoston Corporation, which has a big presence in Latin America, dropped $3.9375, or 3.56 percent, to $106.8125. Citicorp fell $4, to $148.875; the Chase Manhattan Corporation fell $3.25, to $136.0625, and J. P. Morgan & Company fell $3.375, to $126.6875. The brokerage giant Merrill Lynch & Company fell $3.5625, to $88.50, and American International Group dropped $1.4375, to $124.25.
"There seems to be a capital panic in all of the emerging markets," said David Berry, a banking analyst with Keefe Bruyette & Woods Inc. "We were all feeling better in April about bank exposure to emerging markets, but maybe we're all a little guilty of taking our eye off the ball."
In a recent report, Charles Peabody, an analyst with Mitchell Securities Inc., noted that most United States banks operating in Asia have been hesitant to establish reserves that would provide a buffer if Asian financial problems worsened because the banks have been optimistic about an economic rebound in the region.
"The point is that, when there's a shock to the system, bankers generally assume it to be abnormal," Mr. Peabody said. "It is only after a certain period of time has passed that the 'abnormality' then becomes a 'reality.' Bottom line: The full economic impact of the Asian crisis has yet to be fully reflected in banks' earnings reports."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Inside Intel, Latest Setbacks Provoke Worries

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Immortal. Beloved.
That's how investors see the Intel Corporation, the world's premier maker of microprocessors, the guts that run computers. Even though the stock has fallen 21 percent from its February high, Intel has remained one of the most widely held and deeply loved stocks in America. For many investors Intel is not just a stock, it's a religion. 
 This reverence is not without reason. Intel dominates the chip business: its microprocessors power 85 percent to 90 percent of the world's computers. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has generated average annual earnings increases of 42 percent over the last five years. Its sales have risen 34 percent annually during that period to $25 billion last year. Profitability has also been immense: in 1997, net profit margins came in at almost 28 percent, versus 13 percent for the semiconductor industry.
But Intel's industry dominance has attracted the scrutiny of the Federal Trade Commission, which is expected to file an antitrust suit against the company within the next week. At question is whether the company abused its position as the dominant producer of chips for personal computers and whether it bullied some computer makers, according to lawyers familiar with the suit.
What impact would an antitrust action have on Intel's business? Not much initially. But over the longer term, being embroiled in a battle with the Government could take its toll.
Scott Randall, who tracks semiconductor stocks and is a principal of Soundview Financial Group, says the Government must have great confidence in its case against Intel because the commission investigated the company previously, between 1991 and 1993, but took no action. It wouldn't want to come up empty-handed again, he said.
The company says it has done nothing wrong. "We believe that we have behaved legally and that we continue to behave legally," said Chuck Mulloy, an Intel spokesman.
But Intel could suffer tremendously if the Government's suit resulted in, say, guidelines on the company's technological advancements. "The industry changes so fast that to be under any constraint about what the technology could migrate to would be a nightmare," Mr. Randall said.
The job of steering Intel falls to Craig R. Barrett, who took over the chief executive's job from longtime leader Andrew S. Grove, just last week.
Even without the F.T.C. pressure, Intel was facing much stronger headwinds than it had only two years ago. Circumstances beyond Intel's control -- a sharp drop in demand for personal computers, turmoil in Asian economies, a sharp increase in competition from other chip makers -- pose serious threats to Intel's hegemony and to its shares. "Intel has lost control of its market," said William J. Milton, semiconductor analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
Adding to the anxiety surrounding the company: some Intel insiders seem to be losing faith in their company's stock. During the last six months, insider selling has picked up.
Intel stock, which fell 37.5 cents in heavy trading yesterday, to $74.3125, is already well off its 1998 high of $94.19. But trading at around 24 times expected 1998 earnings of $3.15 a share, the stock is not cheap, especially given that revenues, flat for the last five quarters, actually fell 7 percent in the first quarter of 1998. Margins are falling as well: Operating income dropped from 44 percent of sales in the first quarter of 1997 to 32 percent this year.
The company has stated that although near-term prospects are gloomy, sales will pick up in the second half of the year on back-to-school and holiday purchases. Most Wall Street analysts are buying the "things are looking up" argument. Of the 47 investment-firm analysts following the company, 31 have buy recommendations on the stock; 14 call it a "hold," and only 2 analysts advise selling.
One skeptic is Larry Woods, an independent technology analyst in Stony Creek, Ontario, and author of The Tech Review newsletter. He said: "Investors are paying more for less and less profitability at Intel. The stock holds up because Wall Street analysts say that everything will be sweet in the second half. I say nonsense."
Analysts are notoriously upbeat, of course. And their optimism grows even rosier the further out their estimates go. For example, according to First Call, the consensus estimate for Intel's first quarter among analysts following the company back in July 1997 was $1.13 a share. Six months later, when the new year rolled in, the consensus had fallen to 93 cents a share. The actual number Intel reported for the quarter: 81 cents a share.
What most Wall Street analysts don't want to talk about is how much Intel's world has changed. Gone are the days when Intel had virtually no competition. Today, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is producing an impressive chip called the K-6 that in many measurements matches the speed of Intel's Pentiums at a price 25 percent less. And National Semiconductor's Cyrix chips -- the higher-priced Media GX and lower-priced MII's -- are winning converts.
Computer manufacturers that once put only Intel chips inside their boxes are moving to other suppliers. Compaq Computer, the world's largest computer maker, and I.B.M., the No. 2, are using Advanced Micro Devices chips as well as those from Cyrix. I.B.M. is making its own chips and chips for Advanced Micro to compete with Intel, too. And last week, Packard Bell-NEC, the world's fifth-largest PC producer, announced that it was ending its exclusive use of Intel chips in its machines. Its new supplier: National Semiconductor's Cyrix, at much lower prices.
Increased competition isn't Intel's only problem. The company, which got the majority of its revenues from Pentium and related board products last year, is selling into a computer market that is becoming saturated. In spite of PC price cuts in the neighborhood of 50 percent, the portion of American households owning computers has inched up only 3 percentage points over the past year and a half to 43 percent.
According to PC Data Inc., a research company that tracks the industry, PC sales in April were up only 6 percent from a year earlier, way down from the double-digit increases that computer makers have grown accustomed to in recent years. The slowdown appears to be worsening: compared with March 1998, unit sales were down 31 percent in April and revenues fell 30 percent.
Those computers that do sell go for bargain-basement prices, not a positive factor for manufacturers' margins. The average selling price of a PC at retail is now about $1,000, down from the $2,200 average for the past few years. Even Dell Computer, the industry's stellar performer, saw its average sales price for a PC drop 9 percent in the most recent quarter.
The computer industry was counting on sales overseas to pick up some of the slack from falling demand in the United States. But the economic turmoil and currency woes in Asia, particularly Japan, mean computer purchases are no longer a priority for consumers there.
One relatively new approach for Intel is to focus on the low-end chip market with its two-month-old Celeron chip designed for use in under-$1,000 PC's. But users report the chip is slower than the competition's, and it is not doing well.
"Intel has to protect its margins to protect its stock price," said Fred Hickey, technology analyst and author of the High-Tech Strategist newsletter. But this may no longer be possible. Although Intel will not divulge its average selling price per chip, an industry source estimates it at $200. Advanced Micro Devices has said it can make money with an average selling price of $100 a chip.
Even more ominous to some Intel watchers is how many insiders are exiting the stock. "For years, Intel insiders were reluctant to part with their stock," said Bob Gabele who follows insider transactions at CDA Investnet in Rockville, Md. "Now, the inclination of Intel insiders to sell increasing numbers of shares into weakening share prices is troubling."
From July through early October 1997, Intel executives sold less than 150,000 shares. When the shares started to tumble in October, insiders sold almost 700,000 shares at prices of $80.86 to $85.44. In January 1998, Intel executives sold 916,000 more shares at $75 to $82.50 each. Three months later, six insiders announced plans to sell 800,000 shares at prices of $74 to $84.
"The increased selling seen at Intel is not reflected across the semiconductor industry," Mr. Gabele said.

LENGTH: 1028 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Preparing to Sue Intel Over Microchip Dominance

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission is preparing to file a major antitrust lawsuit against the Intel Corporation, charging the company with abusing its position as the dominant manufacturer of microprocessor chips for personal computers and bullying some computer manufacturers, Government lawyers said today.
The suit will accuse Intel of selectively withholding key technical information about its microprocessor chips from the computer manufacturers with which Intel is involved in patent and related product disputes. Without that data, the manufacturers are unable to design new products. The commission is expected to ask that Intel be forced to share information about its processors with all manufacturers. 
 If filed as planned, the suit would be the second front in the Federal Government's assault on Wintel, as the personal computer juggernaut built around the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system and Intel's microprocessors is known in industry parlance. Intel's processors and Microsoft's operating systems are the brains and nerves, respectively, that run 90 percent of personal computers.
The Justice Department and 20 state Attorneys General filed antitrust actions against Microsoft on May 18. A Federal judge in Washington combined those cases, and they are set to be heard in September.
Later this year, the trade commission lawyers said, the F.T.C. may file even more charges against Intel, accusing the company of using predatory pricing and contract provisions to expand its dominant position and to squeeze its few competitors out of the market. Those are the same general complaints filed against Microsoft last week.
Within the next week, the trade commission staff is expected to forward its recommendation for the antitrust suit to the full commission for approval. The commissioners are expected to vote to move forward with the lawsuit a week or 10 days later.
Chuck Mulloy, a spokesman for Intel, in Santa Clara, Calif., said: "Our view is that we are not going to comment because this is not public yet. We are cooperating with the commission fully. We are very sensitive about antitrust enforcement, and at the end of the day, once the appropriate processes have been concluded, we believe they will determine that we behaved lawfully."
The lawyers involved with the investigation said that Intel executives had attended meetings with trade commission staff members in Washington earlier this month in an attempt to avert the lawsuit. But the Intel executives had not made any significant concessions, in the view of Government officials, and had insisted that all their business practices were lawful.
The F.T.C. and the Justice Department have equal jurisdiction to enforce the nation's antitrust laws, and the two agencies decide between themselves which will handle each new case. Since the Justice Department was already preoccupied with the Microsoft case, the commission took the Intel case.
At the heart of the Government's case, one lawyer said, is the charge that "a monopolist cannot cut off a customer who has no other alternatives in the market, causing him severe economic harm, just because they are having a dispute."
The proposed lawsuit charges that Intel illegally retaliated against four companies, including the Digital Equipment Corporation and the Intergraph Corporation, a maker of computer work stations. Intergraph and Digital both filed their own civil lawsuits against Intel last year. In a preliminary ruling last month, a Federal judge in Birmingham, Ala., found that Intel had violated antitrust law in the Intergraph case.
Intergraph and Intel were involved in a patent dispute. As leverage in that fight, the proposed Federal suit will charge, Intel refused to give Intergraph the product data books that set out the specifications for Intel's Pentium II family of microprocessors.
Since those chips serve as the brain of a personal computer, manufacturers must have the information to design their new machines, and holding back the data "is a nuclear weapon for a monopolist," one commission lawyer said.
In that case and in other public statements, Intel said it had the right to supply or withhold its own proprietary information according to its own business interests. Company executives made the same arguments in discussions with the Government. But the Government, the lawyers said, will argue that a monopolist does not have that choice.
If computer manufacturers were able to buy microprocessor chips from another company, then Intel's behavior would not brush up against antitrust laws, the lawyers said. But since Intel is the sole source for the chips, Federal Judge Edwin L. Nelson ruled in the Intergraph case last month that Intel was an "essential facility, similar to electrical power" and therefore did not have the right to supply crucial information to some companies but not to others.
Digital, like Intergraph, was involved in a patent dispute with Intel last spring. In its lawsuit, Digital charged Intel with infringing on Digital patents in the design of some of its Pentium chips. The proposed Federal suit charges that Intel then threatened to stop supplying microprocessors to Digital. The two companies settled their dispute last summer. Digital has since agreed to be purchased by the Compaq Computer.
The trade commission will charge that Intel has engaged in a pattern of similar behavior involving at least two other companies. All those cases show "a monopolist engaging in exclusionary conduct designed to enhance its monopolistic position," one lawyer said.
The commission is still investigating the other possible charges against Intel and has not decided whether to present additional cases. One possible complaint would charge the company with offering special pricing and joint advertising deals to computer manufacturers who agreed to install Intel chips on entire lines of their computers.
That charge is similar to one included in the state Attorneys General's suit, which accuses Microsoft of offering special prices to computer manufacturers who agree to install certain Microsoft software on all their computers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As the Federal Trade Commission prepared to file an antitrust lawsuit against Intel, the company introduced a new network controller chip. An Intel technician holds the new chip at right, and an old controller at left. (Feature Photo Service)(pg. D3)

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Drastic Action in Russia To Stabilize Its Markets
As its financial markets teetered on the brink of collapse, Russia attempted to preserve the value of its currency and stem the exodus of foreign investors. In order to address the economic crisis, Moscow tripled interest rates, announced that it would be willing to accept a far lower price for the selloff of its last big remaining oil company, and appealed for support from the International Monetary Fund. A1 

Opposition to Testing in India
Only two weeks after India detonated five underground nuclear tests to popular acclaim, the Hindu nationalists leading the Government, including Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, ran into protests in Parliament that reflected growing disquiet among Indians about the risks and costs of nuclear weapons. A3
 
U.S. Irks Allies on Kosovo
America's closest European allies, having been pressed hard by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to impose sanctions on Serbia over its crackdown in Kosovo, are upset that Washington has shifted yet again, quietly easing the pressure on Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic despite his intensified repression there. A12
 
Journalist's Return Permitted
After months of refusing to allow a Zimbabwean journalist to return to fight a deportation order, the South African Government has reversed itself. The journalist, Newton Kanhema, had been living and working in South Africa but is in the United States on a journalism fellowship. Advocates of a free press say the South African Government is trying to chill freedom of the press by deporting a journalist who has angered Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. A6
 
Workers Strike in South Korea
Tens of thousands of South Korean workers walked off the job and staged polite protests against layoffs and the increasing use of temporary workers. Workers expressed anger at conglomerate owners who seem to be escaping the hardships of average Koreans, and at the Government, which passed a law making it easier to lay off workers. A7
 
Gingrich Confers With Arafat
Under sharp criticism from the White House for interfering with its efforts to broker an Israeli-Palestinian peace, the House Speaker Newt Gingrich took a conciliatory stance with the Palestinian leadership. Meeting with Yasir Arafat on the West Bank, Mr. Gingrich and other members of his Congressional delegation underscored their support for the negotiations. A3
 
Workers in Greece Protest
Thousands of Greek workers, protesting Government privatization plans, launched a 24-hour nationwide strike today that disrupted transportation, ports, banks and schools. The Athens stock market fell almost 4 percent on concerns about reduced international confidence in some Greek state-owned banks. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A18-26
 
Secret Session Preceded Ruling on Clinton's Aides
A Federal judge ordered two top White House officials to appear before the grand jury investigating the Lewinsky matter only after the independent counsel made a presentation to the judge, outside of the presence of Administration lawyers, to demonstrate that the need for the aides' testimony outweighed President Clinton's right to claim executive and attorney-client privilege. Court papers revealed some previously secret arguments on both sides of the executive privilege issue and much of the judge's reasoning for rejecting Mr. Clinton's attempt to block some testimony by top aides. A1
 
States Told to Pay for Viagra
The Clinton Administration has told state officials that it intends to require their Medicaid programs to pay for medically approved uses of Viagra. But states could limit the number of pills and prescriptions for the impotence drug. State officials contend the decision should be theirs because they share the cost of Medicare. A1
 
Decrease in Welfare Rolls
President Clinton announced that another 900,000 people have left the welfare rolls since September, reducing the total receiving welfare benefits to 8.9 million. A White House ceremony marked the one-year anniversary of his "Welfare to Work Partnership," a nonprofit group intended to encourage businesses to hire welfare recipients. A26
 
Fund-Raising Disclosure
In a bid to revive an inquiry hampered by recalcitrant witnesses and staff defections, House Republican investigators said that they had unearthed further evidence of a Chinese Government connection to President Clinton's re-election campaign in 1996. But investigators acknowledged that the evidence was highly circumstantial. A26
 
Support for Initiative Falls
For months, the conservative effort to shatter organized labor's political war chest in California looked like a sure winner. But support for Proposition 226, which would require unions to obtain a member's annual written approval before spending that member's dues on political activities, has shrunk dramatically. A18
 
Brown Leads in Mayoral Race
Propelled by unbeatable name recognition, unmatched press attention and a potent desire among Oaklanders to try something new and decidedly different, Edmund G. Brown Jr. has zoomed so far ahead in this city's mayoral race that he seems poised to win outright in the primary on June 2, a new poll shows. A18
 
Oklahoma Blast Sentencing
Instead of receiving a maximum sentence of 23 years in prison, Michael J. Fortier, who had failed to warn anyone of the Oklahoma City bombing but later testified against the men convicted in the plot, was sentenced to 12 years by Judge G. Thomas Van Bebber. A18
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Democrats to Face Primary In the Gubernatorial Race
At the state Democratic Party convention, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross and James L. Larocca, a former state Transportation Commissioner, said they would circulate petitions to force themselves on the gubernatorial ballot. The state party voted to set up a two-way primary for its gubernatorial nomination, foiling a campaign by Peter E. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, to become the favored candidate to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki this year. B1
 
Dropping Remedial Classes
In deciding to phase out remedial courses at four-year colleges, the trustees of the City University of New York have set in motion a sketchy but sweeping transformation of the university. The new policy, which prevents freshmen or transfer students from enrolling unless they have passed placement exams, may give the 11 senior colleges a screening tool they have lacked since open admissions was instituted in 1970. A1
 
Police to Hold Suspects Longer
Responding to the shooting of a police officer by a fugitive parolee who was mistakenly set free, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that anyone arrested for even minor offenses, like drinking in public, must now remain in police custody until a computerized fingerprint check is run. The policy will add hours to the processing time of the 80,000 people who receive desk-appearance tickets each year for low-level offenses from disorderly conduct to possession of small amounts of narcotics. SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 149 words

HEADLINE: Skittish Speculators Didn't Reform Asia

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, May 23) searches for a figure of speech to characterize the vast movements of liquid capital daily around the world and settles for the jet airplane, to which the markets were likened by Deputy Treasury Secretary Larry Summers. 
 A better description was developed by the historian Oswald Spengler after World War I. He described the modern powers of liquid capital as the new "plutocracy." He said that capital would flow like electricity through a vast network of high-voltage lines and that it would not be controllable by politicians or governments.
Those who controlled the conduits would in effect determine the course of a technologically advanced world, and it would be impersonal, as nonhuman as its form and function implied. Spengler seems to have hit on it precisely.
 
JASCHA KESSLER
Santa Monica, Calif., May 23, 1998

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Regional Economy Was Strong in May

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Business activity in the New York region grew at a faster pace this month as manufacturing and services strengthened, according to a survey of service and factory executives released yesterday.
The National Association of Purchasing Management-New York index rose in May to 58.4 after falling in April to 52.6. An index reading of 50 or more suggests that the region's economy is expanding; a reading below 50 signals weakness or even a potential contraction. 
 The index for the region's factories rose to 54.9 in May from 47.9 in April. The April reading was the weakest since March 1997. The index for nonmanufacturers increased to 58.8 in May from 53.1 in April.
The outlook for the next six months remained positive in May, although businesses were more optimistic in April.
The outlook index edged down to 70.3 in May after a 73.6 reading a month earlier. Inflation was well behaved during the month. An index tracking prices paid by businesses for goods and services was unchanged at 51 in May.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Parcells and O'Donnell Defrost Cold War, a Bit

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., May 27

 BODY:
For the first time in 156 days, the coach of the Jets spoke to his (starting?) quarterback today, adding to the confusion.
Don't read anything into this five-month noncommunication, Coach Bill Parcells cautioned -- even though quarterback Neil O'Donnell admitted he was concerned by what had been going on. And who can blame him? O'Donnell knows as much about his status as callers to WFAN. A large part of it is that Parcells seems genuinely perplexed. 
 And yet, there appears to be some sort of understanding between Parcells and O'Donnell as a result of today's meeting. It was the first time they had spoken since Dec. 22, the day after the season ended with the Jets' 13-10 loss to the Lions, which kept the Jets out of the playoffs. O'Donnell was replaced several times in the game.
But what transpired at the meeting? Will O'Donnell have to take a pay cut to remain a Jet? Or can O'Donnell start an informal search for a job with another team?
"Basically, we still believe Neil will be a Jet," his agent, Leigh Steinberg, said today. "Bill has never wavered in that he wants Neil back. We feel the contract is fair, and our position is that the Jets should honor the contract. At this point there hasn't been much negotiation."
Parcells also reiterated to reporters today that he expected to keep O'Donnell this season. And O'Donnell, in his first news conference in more than five months, said that he expected to start. For what it was worth, O'Donnell repeatedly took the first snap when the minicamp for veterans began today. Then Glenn Foley came in. Foley had replaced O'Donnell as the starting quarterback last season, but soon was out for the season with a knee injury.
Parcells said that the players who took the field today had "more skill" than last year's 9-7 team. But he was not ready to say they were better. He pointed out that everyone in the backfield catches the ball well, especially with the addition of Curtis Martin at running back for Adrian Murrell, who was traded.
In addition, said Parcells, "I'm rooting for Jerald Sowell to make it at fullback." Sowell was the Packers' last draft pick of 1997, then was cut and picked up by the Jets. He will be tutored by the veteran Keith Byars, who was acquired in the off season. But Sowell seems certain to remain a Jet. And O'Donnell?
"Neil and I have a clear understanding of what's going on here," Parcells said after their meeting. "The June 1 date may change that."
After Monday, the Jets could cut O'Donnell and save millions of dollars for this year's salary cup. If he is cut on or before Monday, the Jets will be charged $4.2 million against the 1998 cap, but only $1.4 million afterward.
Last January, Parcells tried unsuccessfully to renegotiate O'Donnell's 1998 salary. But through Steinberg, O'Donnell balked, and Steinberg said O'Donnell believed he had had a fine season and saw no reason to take a cut in pay.
Yet, only a few minutes after bringing up the June 1 date at today's news conference, Parcells denied it had any significance. He said he had conclusively explained "my view of the economics" to O'Donnell. "We have to separate the economics from the football," he said.
Then Parcells added an ominous note, reminiscent of the line from "The Godfather." Reflecting on the fact that O'Donnell had been told not to participate in the recent off-season workouts, Parcells said he had told him, "It's business."
"I'm not letting him go June 1," Parcells said.
O'Donnell said yesterday that for the first time in months he felt confident that he would be back with the Jets. He admitted that when Parcells told him to stay away from the off-season conditioning program, it became "a different kind of off season."
With the start of today's camp, O'Donnell can avail himself of the Jets' facilities once again.
"I expect to start," he said. "I'm not a backup."
Foley would not comment on O'Donnell's status, but said, "I showed last year I can play on a pretty high level."
Foley has added about 15 pounds during the off season and has been a regular in the weight room in an attempt to avoid the types of injuries that have ended his seasons two of the last three years.

LENGTH: 847 words

HEADLINE: Allies Upset as U.S. Eases Stance on Kosovo

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
America's closest European allies are upset that Washington has changed tack yet again on the issue of Kosovo, pushing to ease the pressure on the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, despite his intensified repression in the province.
To induce Mr. Milosevic to begin a dialogue with Ibrahim Rugova, the moderate leader of the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo, the allies, at Washington's urging, recently suspended the economic sanctions that would hit Mr. Milosevic the hardest, measures that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had insisted on in the first place in the name of international cohesion. 
 "There has been a real shift of tactics and tone that is bound to cause real confusion in Belgrade," said a senior Western diplomat, who like the others did not want his name or country attached to his comments. "Now the pressure is all gone."
Another diplomat said, "The Americans have switched too quickly, for unclear ends, and we think Milosevic should not be let off the hook too easily."
The diplomats said they feared that Mr. Milosevic was again successfully manipulating Washington. All he has agreed to do, one diplomat said, is to open talks with Mr. Rugova. They met on May 15.
The diplomat expressed skepticism at the effectiveness of rewarding such a small step, saying: "Milosevic has agreed only to talk, not to strike an agreement on the future of Kosovo. The Americans have used our leverage to get the dialogue going, rather than to get somewhere."
The Contact Group on the former Yugoslavia consists of the United States, Britain, Germany, Italy, France and Russia. Britain and Germany are the countries most unhappy with the American shift, while the Italians and French, who supported the dialogue but thought sanctions ineffective, are less unhappy, but annoyed with what they consider excessive American flexibility. The Russians never agreed to sanctions other than a United Nations arms embargo on the former Yugoslavia.
The American shift originated with Richard C. Holbrooke, the former diplomat who is the architect of the Bosnian peace settlement. Mr. Holbrooke, known for his strong relationship with Mr. Milosevic and his flexible tactics, was invited to help and visited the Balkans with the American special representative for the former Yugoslavia, Robert S. Gelbard, this month. The trip resulted in the allies' decision to suspend imposing a ban on investments in Serbia that had been agreed on a week before. It remains suspended, even though Mr. Milosevic has intensified a crackdown in Kosovo, is shutting down independent media throughout Yugoslavia, and is trying to manipulate a vote on Sunday for the presidency of Montenegro.
Senior American officials said they recognized the dangers of reducing pressure on Mr. Milosevic, but they said inducements were the only way to have him talk with Mr. Rugova. Time matters, the officials said, because as pressures on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo grow, Mr. Rugova, who embraces nonviolence, loses credibility with his people.
The Americans argue that it was clear that the sanctions were not pushing Mr. Milosevic into dialogue, an echo of the very argument that European countries like Italy made to Ms. Albright.
"The fact that Milosevic and Rugova are finally talking for the first time ever is very important," Mr. Holbrooke said today. "But we need these talks to make real progress."
"We know there are enormous risks here," Mr. Gelbard said. "But absent any effort to get talks going there are even more enormous risks. Others failed at getting a dialogue going, and we succeeded."
Mr. Gelbard emphasized that the sanctions remain on the table, were "suspended" and could be imposed later, if Mr. Milosevic did not behave responsibly. "We need to be able to turn these measures on and off," Mr. Gelbard said.
But turning the crucial sanction -- the investment ban -- on and off is impossible, a Western diplomat said.
Mr. Rugova and his negotiating team arrived in Washington today for meetings with American officials, and President Clinton on Friday. The Kosovo issue will be an important subject for a NATO meeting that Ms. Albright is to attend in Luxembourg.
The American attention to Mr. Rugova is intended to help his credibility at home and with Mr. Milosevic. He is also expected to meet J. Brian Atwood, head of the Agency for International Development.
Other officials said that Mr. Holbrooke and Mr. Gelbard were suggesting, as an incentive to Mr. Milosevic if two or three meetings with Mr. Rugova go well, a lifting of sanctions that were applied in March. Those include a freeze on Serbia's foreign assets, a ban on visas to officials responsible for the crackdown in Kosovo and a halt to the financing of export or import credits for trade and investment.
But no decisions have been made, the officials said. "It's a matter of style and substance," a Western diplomat said. "It's a little embarrassing, but we have a good chance to go forward in Kosovo if we stay united and we don't change our stance too quickly."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 29, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about American policy toward Yugoslavia misstated the positions at stake in elections in Montenegro on Sunday. The elections are for Parliament, not the presidency.
