Museums and Sites
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. On permanent display are costumes, set pieces, filming equipment and other items relating to film, television and video. Exhibitions include "Behind the Screen," a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate the production, marketing and exhibition of moving images. Daily screenings include classic shorts, shown in Tut's Fever Movie Palace: through Sunday, the cartoons "Mickey's Circus" (1936) and "Beep, Beep" (1952). The film series "Indie New York," with movies by independent filmmakers often working on shoestring budgets, continues through June 28. Tomorrow at 2 and 5 P.M., Jim McBride's "David Holzman's Diary" (1968); at 3:30 P.M., Peter Goldman's "Echoes of Silence" (1965). Sunday at 2 P.M., Spike Lee's "She's Gotta Have It" (1986); at 4 P.M., John Sayles's "Brother From Another Planet" (1984). "Computer Space '98," a continuing exhibition of classic arcade games and contemporary home-entertainment software that visitors can play. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. All activities are free with museum admission unless indicated otherwise: $8; the elderly and students, $5; ages 5 to 18, $4; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077. 

AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design, 1892-1922," which includes all coins issued during this period. Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history since 600 B.C. Free. An exhibition of the Stepney Hoard of Connecticut Coppers will remain on view through Sunday. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.

"Portraits of the Spanish Generation of '98"; through Oct. 1. "Spanish Painting, 1860-1930"; Saturdays only through July 25. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M.; closed holidays. Free. Information: (212) 926-2234.
THE MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place (West Street and Battery Place), Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videotapes and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Exhibitions include "Life a Century Ago," featuring memorabilia from Jewish rituals and celebrations in Europe in the early 1900's; "War Against the Jews," detailing the years 1933 to 1945, and "Jewish Renewal," focusing on life after the Holocaust. Hours: Fridays and days before Jewish holidays, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.; Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.; closed Saturdays and Jewish holidays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; 5 and under, free. Some same-day tickets are available at the museum; because of heavy attendance, tickets should be purchased in advance through Ticketmaster: (212) 307-4007. Information: (212) 968-1800.
NEW YORK CITY FIRE MUSEUM, 278 Spring Street, SoHo. In a renovated 1904 firehouse is a collection of fire-related art and artifacts from the 18th century to the present, including a firetruck, hose wagons, hats, toys, paintings and hand-drawn pumpers. Also, an exhibition, "Fire Marks: Emblems of Insurance," features a selection of 18th- and 19th-century British and American fire marks from the museum's collection. Insurance agencies would give bonuses to firefighters when they saved the premises of a policyholder. The decorative emblems were used to distinguish policyholders from the uninsured. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Suggested admission: $4 for adults; $2 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 691-1303.

On view through Oct. 4. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 11 A.M. to 4:30 and for concertgoers during concerts. Free. Information: (212) 903-9629.

Winiker," 40 images of contemporary cruise ships and ocean liners, on view through June 21. Also, "Traveling in Style: 20th-Century Ocean Liners." Museum hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, until 8 P.M.; stores in the marketplace: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. HEADLINE: Re-election Struggle in Panama Could Affect Transfer of Canal

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
The slogan is blunt and emphatic, and it has begun appearing on glossy billboards and as crudely scrawled graffiti: "No Re-election!" Having decided to defy 95 years of tradition, President Ernesto Perez Balladares is encountering widespread opposition to his effort to amend the Panamanian Constitution so he can seek a second five-year term.
The outcome of the struggle, which a Latin American diplomat here described as "getting nastier by the day," is of vital importance to the United States. Whoever wins the election, scheduled for next May, will administer the Panama Canal when the United States yields control of the waterway and the remaining military bases around it on Dec. 31, 1999. 
 The Democratic Revolutionary Party, which Mr. Perez Balladares leads, has a long history of anti-Americanism.
But as President, Mr. Perez Balladares has sought to ingratiate himself with Washington. He has tried to curb money laundering and reform the banking system, offered to accept Cuban and Haitian refugees when the Clinton Administration sought havens for them and is now trying to negotiate an agreement for an anti-narcotics center that would permit 2,000 American troops to remain here well into the next century.
To Panamanians, though, the future of the canal overshadows everything, and it is on that front that much of the opposition to the President has coalesced. Mr. Perez Balladares has said his decision to seek re-election stems from a desire to "finish the job we've begun." But opposition groups say his real aim is to convert the canal into an asset of the governing party.
Those suspicions have been prevalent since the fall, when the President announced his nominees to the Panama Canal Authority, which will run the canal beginning in 2000. Instead of the broad-based nonpartisan board that had been expected, Mr. Perez Balladares appointed relatives, business partners and party loyalists.
Not long after, one appointee, Moises Mizrachi, a former campaign fund-raiser who is a member of the Panama Canal Commission, suggested that some canal functions could be privatized after it had passed into Panamanian hands. That set off a huge furor, with opposition figures accusing Mr. Perez Balladares of intending to raffle off pieces of the canal to his cronies.
As required by the Panama Canal Treaties of 1977, some parts of the former Panama Canal Zone have already been turned over to the Panamanian Government and are being made into industrial parks, shopping malls, hotels and other projects. But as the United States Trade Representative's office pointed out in a report last month, "Rumors of corruption are fueled by public bids which lack transparency," most notably in a recent effort to privatize a port area.
In addition, early in the next century the new canal administration will have to decide whether to modernize the waterway by building an additional set of locks. The estimated cost of the new locks is at least $5 billion, and officials expect, if approved, that the work will generate a bonanza of contracts and a host of new concerns about Government bidding procedures.
"During the next five years a tremendous number of opportunities will be emerging in the reverted areas," Ricardo Arias Calderon, a former Vice President and a leader of the Christian Democratic Party, said. "This explains to me the reason the President is breaking with a longstanding national consensus against re-election. He wants to concentrate economic power around himself and those who support him to a degree never before seen in Panama."
In an interview here, Jorge Ritter, the Panamanian Government's Minister of Canal Affairs and the chairman-designate of the body that is to run the waterway, said Mr. Mizrachi's comments had been misconstrued. There is no Spanish equivalent for the word "outsourcing," Mr. Ritter said, which is what Mr. Mizrachi really meant.
"I don't want to tell you that all operations relating to the maintenance and operation of the canal will not be subject to outsourcing," Mr. Ritter said. "Not everything the Canal Commission does is in house, even today. That was the misunderstanding that could have caused a certain concern that has now dissipated. But the canal will never be subject to privatization."
The National Assembly, which Mr. Perez Balladares's party controls, has approved an amendment to the Constitution that would allow him to seek a second term. But that decision is subject to ratification in a referendum. On May 21 the Government announced that the vote would be held on Aug. 30. In a recent poll, 57 percent of those surveyed said they opposed allowing the President to run for a second term.
Mr. Perez Balladares was able to win office in 1994 with barely one-third of the vote, as the opposition split among several candidates. Though opposition parties, which are united in their dislike of the re-election proposal, talk of running a single coalition candidate to prevent that from recurring, they seem unable to agree who that candidate should be.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin to Ask Western Help for Ruble as Markets Steady

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 28

 BODY:
As Russian financial markets steadied slightly after this week's record plunge, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would call on Western leaders to help defend Russia's embattled ruble.
His appeal was later echoed by a top finance official who said Russia would need a hefty rescue package from the West -- more generous than a $700 million loan already expected from the International Monetary Fund -- if it is to stem the panic that has threatened Russia's economic and political stability. 
 Speaking at a televised meeting of Government officials hastily summoned to his country house, Mr. Yeltsin said he would call foreign leaders, including President Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, asking them to support Russia as it proceeds with a plan for a new round of spending cuts and more vigorous tax collecting measures.
"Foreign investors should feel confident there will be no collapse of financial markets in Russia," Mr. Yeltsin said, tapping the table for emphasis. "The Central Bank and Finance Ministry today possess enough reserve funds to stay afloat. That's what is important."
For now, the Yeltsin strategy seemed to work. The ruble was stable for the second consecutive day, and Moscow stock indexes rose.
According to the latest report from the Russian Central Bank, Russia's gold and currency reserves now stand at $14.5 billion -- down from the $23 billion levels declared in October. Maintaining the stability of the ruble has been a key achievement of Mr. Yeltsin's reform-minded Government over the last few years, and as its desperate actions this week demonstrated, a stable ruble remains its top priority for keeping the shaky Russian economy on track.
The arrival in Moscow tonight of a top emissary from the International Monetary Fund is seen here as a sign that some help is already on the way. John Odling-Smee, the fund's official in charge of Russia and the former Soviet Union, is expected to confirm approval of a $700 million installment of a $10 billion loan to Russia, delivering a seal of approval that has been closely watched by financial markets here and abroad.
Meanwhile, Anatoly B. Chubais, a former top Kremlin aide and the head of Russia's electrical monopoly, was headed for Washington. Mr. Chubais maintains close ties to Mr. Yeltsin, and it is believed that he will consult with American officials about possible economic help for Russia.
Sergei Vasilyev, a senior Kremlin aide, was also on the trip. The Kremlin declined comment about it.
At a news conference held today in Kazakhstan, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the fund, said Russia's latest efforts had convinced the I.M.F that it was serious about tackling its budget deficit. "These are important enough that we believe we can release the next tranche of support," he told reporters, adding that an announcement would come in the "in the next few days."
But Deputy Finance Minister Oleg V. Vyugin said today that Russia needed the psychological boost of more foreign credits -- even if those credits turn out to be unnecessary.
"Judging from the current situation, I can tell you that in principle there is a chance that we can resolve this situation without additional assistance," he said. But he added that further credits "would play a psychological role because panic is a psychological phenomenon." The amount Russia seeks, he said, would be "a different order of figure."
"Such a credit would show everybody that there are considerable resources and that there won't be problems in the future," he said. "I don't see how such a decision would hurt."
Financial analysts here said today that Western institutions and banks were unlikely to come forward with a currency-stabilization package for Russia anytime soon, preferring to see if financial markets will be convinced by the endorsements given Russia's fiscal program this week by the I.M.F. and Western governments, including Washington.
In trading today on the Moscow stock exchange, the benchmark Russian RTS index rose 6.2 percent, winning back most of Wednesday's losses. The ruble, which was pegged at 6.17 to the dollar on Wednesday, rose slightly to 6.14.
The fiscal crisis, which has dominated the news for days now, has for the most part floated over the heads of most Russians, who are more preoccupied with making ends meet than with the values of currencies and stocks.
A key test of the markets' response will come Wednesday at a regular auction of Russia's Government-backed bonds, known as G.K.O.'s. The bonds will carry an interest rate of 150 percent as rates were tripled on Wednesday to save lure investors to hold bonds and the ruble.
"Supportive statements by the I.M.F. and the U.S. Treasury are useful to show the markets that the support is there," said Christopher Granville, chief strategist at Fleming UCB, a London-based investment group. "For the moment, the panic seems to have stopped. Then, the bluff will be called."
Russian finance officials are exploring the possibility of a sovereign syndicated loan, which would be pulled together by Western banks, financial analysts said today. "If they did get the money, the thing to do would be to restructure their loans, and buy back the G.K.O.'s, and cut their domestic debt," said Mr. Granville.
At the emergency meeting held this morning, Mr. Yeltsin called on Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko to focus efforts on shoring up the ruble. Mr. Yeltsin said he would press Russia's tax authorities to improve their dismal tax collection record, an indicator that has been under close scrutiny by Western advisers.
"Heads will roll," Mr. Yeltsin said, noting that he will meet on Friday with the law enforcement and fiscal authorities. "They have been working poorly. They must be stricter."
Mr. Kiriyenko said later that Mr. Yeltsin would sign a decree authorizing the tax police to confiscate property belonging to tax dodgers, with a list of major delinquents now being drawn up. Other measures under consideration would call for the forced bankruptcy of companies that have not paid their tax bills, and court proceedings against the managers of delinquent state-owned companies.
At a Cabinet meeting today, Mr. Kiriyenko said the principal cause of the Russian crisis was that "we have not learned to live within our means," a failure that he said had cost the Russian Government credibility here and abroad.
Mr. Kiriyenko, 35, who became Prime Minister just a month ago, also met on Wednesday last night with four influential Russian bankers at their request. According to reports, the bankers were reassured by his pledge to stick to the Government's announced austerity plan.
In public statements, several top Russian finance officials have blamed foreign investors -- who hold $20 billion in Russian Government securities -- for triggering the panic on the markets this week.
"The market was rocked by a small circle of market players," Mr. Vyugin said today. "We know them. We know about their operations. Judging from these operations, we can say with certainty that their purpose was to push the prices down."
At a news conference on Wednesday Mark Mobius, president of the Templeton Russia Fund, outlined the difference between the Asian and Russian financial crises.
"In the case of Russia, the crisis is a Government debt crisis, a Government cash-flow crisis," he said. "In the case of Asia, the government was rich, and the private sector was in debt. In the case of Russia, the Government is in trouble, and the private sector is very rich. In both cases, the capital markets, stock markets, bond markets have become extremely volatile."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Gain Slightly as Wary Buyers Return to Blue Chips

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market rebounded modestly yesterday, ending a four-day slump as investors crept back into some of their favorite blue-chip stocks as well as a broad variety of smaller issues.
 Even so, investors remained jittery over the sharp global selloff that erupted on Tuesday and Wednesday, resulting in losses for most of the major indexes amid fears about slowing profit growth and renewed concerns about a global economic crisis reverberating out of Asia.
 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, after falling in four consecutive sessions, rose 33.63 points, or four-tenths of a percent, yesterday, to close at 8,970.20. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.37 points, or half of a percent, to 1,097.60, and the Russell 2000 index of smaller company issues climbed more than 1.2 percent.
 Still, Wall Street analysts say that after a sharp run-up in prices in the early part of the year, the market appears to be correcting, adding that share prices may continue to sag on concerns about corporate profits.
 "The market, in retrospect, did a bit more than it should have," said A. Marshall Acuff, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "We're in for a reality check after a feel-better rally in the first quarter."
 That early-year rally saw the Dow soar 21.5 percent from early January to its peak of 9,211.84 on May 13, even though profit growth slowed significantly in the first quarter. Investors, ever confident if not euphoric, were cheered by falling interest rates, declining fears about economic turmoil in Asia, a global wave of corporate merger activity and the prospect of a sharp profit recovery in the second half of the year.
 But with share prices at record levels, analysts say a slowdown was inevitable, and perhaps necessary. "When the Dow reached 9,200 the market was very high, about 20 percent overvalued," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Investor optimism was at or near historic levels. Now, though, people are getting worried about another wave of problems in the emerging markets and the prospect of disappointing profits in the second quarter."
 Indeed, the Asian crisis that helped sink share prices around the globe in October appears to be bubbling up again. In Japan, a decade-long economic decline is deepening, and yesterday, the Japanese yen fell to a seven-year low against the dollar.
And, in addition to the global turmoil, analysts say that corporate profits are being squeezed in the United States by rising wage costs and an inability to raise prices. In the first quarter, for instance, corporate profits rose just 2.5 percent, even though the nation's gross domestic product expanded at an annual rate of 4.8 percent, making it one of the strongest quarters in a decade. A year ago, profits were up about 10 percent. In other words, the economy is strong, but profit growth is weak. "That shows there's a margin squeeze going on," Mr. Wien said.
In the future, profits could also be hit by the strong dollar, which continues to rise against the Japanese yen, as well as a soaring trade deficit -- factors that worry investors who have paid high share prices in recent years.
 "Some people felt Asia was a one-quarter affair and it isn't," said Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company. "There's going to be a continuing trickle of bad news out of Asia. And so our stock market is clearly on hold for some time."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Strong Dollar and Woes Abroad Drop Long Bond Yield to 5.82%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rose yesterday, pushing long-term yields to nearly two-month lows, in a rally propelled by financial turmoil in Russia and much of Asia and the rising value of the dollar.
In buying Treasury bonds, investors ignored news that in other circumstances might have been interpreted as negative for the market, notably new signs of a robust American economy and a new supply of debt issues from a Treasury auction. 
 The benchmark 30-year bond rose 11/32, to a price of 104 9/32. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, dropped to 5.82 percent from 5.84 percent, the lowest since April 6.
Early gains were brought on by instability in Asian markets, resulting in part from Pakistan's announcement that it had carried out five nuclear tests. This helped bring foreign investors into the United States market. Anxiety from the financial crisis in Russia also helped support demand for Treasury instruments, which are an investment of refuge at times of turmoil.
The market was further aided by a gain in the dollar's value against the Japanese yen and other currencies; a rising dollar makes dollar-denominated assets more valuable.
That partly explained the strong demand for $11 billion in five-year Treasury notes sold yesterday. Market analysts said the weakness in Asia played a role in the muted reaction to data that showed unexpectedly strong economic growth in the January-March quarter and a sharp rise in April factory orders. "While the data today were on the strong side," said Donald Fine of Chase Asset Management, "there was also growing evidence that some of the strength in the first quarter is likely to be balanced by some softness during the second quarter."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE REACTION;
Wealthy Nations Cut Aid to Pakistan Over Nuclear Tests

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 28

 BODY:
In reactions that followed the relatively mild pattern of responses to nuclear tests conducted by India two weeks ago, Japan, Germany, Canada and Australia joined the United States today in taking action against Pakistan for going ahead with tests of its own.
Other Pakistani trading partners, like France and Russia, expressed "disappointment" and "concern" at word of the tests but stopped short of recommending any sanctions. 
 Japan, the biggest aid donor to both Pakistan and India, said it would adopt the same position toward Pakistan as it did to India two weeks ago when New Delhi also set off underground nuclear blasts.
"We will consider what we should do in parallel with what we did with India," a Japanese Government official told reporters in Tokyo, but he declined to say exactly what steps Tokyo could take.
Freezing aid to Pakistan could be a severe blow to the Pakistan economy because Japan provided $235 million in loans and $42 million in aid last year. Japan has decided to halt new loans and grants, effectively cutting its official assistance to Pakistan by two-thirds. That will have a large effect on Pakistan, because Japan provides more than half of the total world assistance to that nation.
After the Indian tests, Tokyo froze $30 million in grants to New Delhi and said it would make cuts in its annual $1 billion loan program. It also withdrew its offer to be the host of a June 30 World Bank meeting at which donors of aid to India were to discuss development assistance. Japan's annual program of low-cost loans and aid to Pakistan totals $485 million. Kanezo Muraoka, the Government spokesman, said "we cannot condone" the tests.
The German Government said it was canceling planned discussions in June with Pakistani officials about new development aid worth about $45 million. Otto Hauser, the Government spokesman, said Bonn "sharply condemns this action," which he described as unacceptable.
Klaus Kinkel, the German Foreign Minister, joined a number of officials around the world in saying it was "unfortunate" that Pakistan had disregarded the international calls for restraint and responded to the Indian tests "with the same coin."
In Ottawa, Prime Minister Jean Chretien said that relations with Pakistan would "now be placed on hold" and that further measures would be announced. Canada recalled its Ambassador to India earlier this month and canceled some joint talks as well as military exports to New Delhi. "Canada is deeply disappointed the Pakistani Government did not heed the international call for restraint but chose to act in a manner contrary to international norms," Mr. Chretien said.
Australia, which suspended military links with New Delhi and all assistance except relief aid after the Indian tests, condemned the Pakistani actions and said it was withdrawing an offer made Wednesday to double its existing $1.5 million annual aid to Islamabad.
Britain, which believes that cuts in aid unfairly hurt the poor, does not plan any reductions in its $41 million assistance to Pakistan, just as it did not trim its $165 million to India. Saying he was "dismayed," the British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, said, "We condemn this action, which runs counter to the will expressed by 149 signatories to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to cease nuclear testing and to efforts to strengthen the global nonproliferation regime."
In Paris, a Foreign Ministry statement said that France "deplores and condemns these tests which run counter to world efforts to prevent proliferation and testing." The Russian Foreign Ministry said "it was regrettable that the Pakistani leadership failed to overcome its emotions and show prudence and good sense at an extremely responsible time."
Javier Solana, the Secretary General of NATO, said he condemned Pakistan's action, and the European Union said it would hold urgent meetings to consider taking the same action against Pakistan that it took Monday in the case of India. The European Union barred payments by international and financial institutions to India and called into question trade preferences.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called on the allies to join in slapping sanctions on countries that test nuclear weapons. "Only by acting together can we deter others from pursuing the nuclear option," she said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 894 words

HEADLINE: Economy Brisk, But Data Offer Some Cautions

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
In the midst of fresh crises in Asia and Russia, the Commerce Department announced yesterday that the American economy in the first quarter was even stronger than originally thought, but there was a suggestion in the new figures of slower growth ahead.
The good news came in the overall number. The gross domestic product, the value of all the goods and services produced in the United States, rose from January through March at a torrid annual rate of 4.8 percent. The first estimate for the quarter, issued last month, had been 4.2 percent, itself a surprisingly powerful performance, even for an economy that has been expanding rapidly for more than two years. 
 The worry was in the details. Corporate profits in the first quarter, reported yesterday for the first time, fell by 2.2 percent, after taxes. It was the second quarterly decline -- profits fell 1.1 percent in the fourth quarter -- after more than three years of steadily rising profits. What is more, a significant portion of the economic growth came from accumulating inventories. Factories hummed along, but a big chunk of what they produced stayed on the shelf, unsold. Without this overrun, the G.D.P. would have grown by 3.4 percent.
The stock market, which thrives on expectations of rising profits, took the news calmly enough. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.63 points to 8,970.20. But after having shot up 21 percent during the first quarter, the Dow average has hovered at its present level since early April.
"We are heading for slower growth," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, a consulting firm, offering a view widely shared by forecasters. "We are pretty sure you cannot continue to accumulate inventories at such a rapid rate without a slowdown. But economic growth is still likely to be quite respectable this year."
The latest numbers produced an unusual amount of uncertainty among forecasters about what might happen next. Profits, for example, may be falling, but they are still high, equaling a healthy 9.9 percent of total output -- enough perhaps to sustain the current strong level of spending by business for new investment.
Inventories are another matter. Nearly every forecaster agrees they cannot accumulate at an annual level of $100 billion, roughly 30 percent greater than most of last year -- and a surprising 25 percent higher than first thought. Last month's estimate for the first quarter was $77 billion in stockpiled merchandise.
Production -- and with it, the economy -- has to slow down while these stockpiles are depleted, most economists agree. "Every time inventory growth has risen faster than economic growth, the economy has slowed," said Nancy Lazar, a vice president and economist at ISI Group Inc., a Wall Street firm.
But by how much might production drop? Falling exports to Asia accounted for some of the inventory buildup. So did Federal Government purchases, which fell at a rather sharp annual rate of 9.8 percent in the first quarter. Not much improvement is likely soon in these areas. But personal consumption expenditure -- the spending of American consumers -- rose at a very strong annual rate of 6.1 percent. Not surprisingly, savings edged down.
That willingness to spend might encourage companies to maintain fairly high inventory levels, although not at the first quarter's levels.
"Normally one attributes inventory building to optimism among business people that sales will keep rising," said Robert Parker, chief statistician at the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, which issues the G.D.P. numbers. "As long as they remain optimistic about domestic spending, they are likely to be comfortable about stockpiling goods."
A dark spot is trade. While exports fell in the first quarter, imports rose sharply, and whatever consumers spend on imports, they cannot spend on domestically made goods and services. What is more, falling import prices have made it harder to raise prices on domestically made goods.
Reflecting this pressure, the implicit price deflator, a measure of inflation issued along with the G.D.P. report, rose in the first quarter at an annual rate of just 1 percent, the smallest increase since the second quarter of 1964.
The pricing problem helps to explain the downturn in profits, economists said. Gradually rising labor costs and a stronger dollar also squeezed profits. The stronger dollar means American companies earn less abroad because foreign currencies translate into fewer dollars on their balance sheets.
For nearly two and a half years, the gross domestic product has been expanding at an average annual rate of more than 3 percent. In four different quarters during this period economic growth exceeded 4 percent, and in last year's fourth quarter, it reached 3.7 percent.
Many forecasters expect growth to slow in the months ahead to an annual rate of less than 3 percent, which would be more in line with average growth over the seven years of expansion since the last recession. The average growth rate through this period has been 2.86 percent.
In another report, the Commerce Department said new orders for costly durable goods jumped 2.6 percent, to $191.2 billion in April, after a slight increase in March. But analysts discounted the increase, noting much of it reflected aircraft orders, which can fluctuate.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: IN WASHINGTON;
After an Anguished Phone Call, Clinton Penalizes the Pakistanis

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
After a futile midnight effort to stop Pakistan's nuclear tests, President Clinton grimly denounced them today as dangerously destabilizing and imposed penalties that could cost the Pakistanis billions.
 "I deplore the decision" by Pakistan to test its nuclear arsenal in reaction to India's five tests two weeks ago, the President said. He said the two nations were now embarked on a "dangerous arms race." 
 The Deputy Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott, one of several senior officials who traveled to Pakistan to try to prevent the tests, called the rising nuclear tensions in South Asia "an extraordinarily serious situation," one of "immense importance, complexity and, I would say, danger."
The tests came less than seven hours after Mr. Clinton telephoned Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, and all but begged him not to detonate a weapon. Administration officials described their half-hour conversation, which ended around midnight, as anguished and impassioned.
The talk, the fourth between the President and the Prime Minister since the first Indian tests on May 11, began with Mr. Clinton offering "a changed relationship" with Pakistan if Mr. Sharif canceled the nuclear tests, an Administration official said.
Mr. Clinton pledged to try to deliver 28 F-16 fighter jets that Pakistan has paid for, but never received, and to try "to cut through the knot" of laws blocking military and economic aid to Pakistan, said the official, who insisted on anonymity.
"The President said he unilaterally would keep trying to get closer in security terms," the official said. "It was a promise of a changed relationship. He said, 'If you do this, we can do great things together, we can work on your economy, we can give you the tools you need to help defend your country.' "
Pakistan received $500 million to $600 million a year in cash and high-tech weapons from the United States during the 1980's, when it provided invaluable help to the Central Intelligence Agency by smuggling billions of dollars worth of weapons to guerrillas fighting off Soviet invaders in Afghanistan. But when that cold war battle ended in 1989, so did the aid. In 1990 the United States openly declared what it had known for a decade: Pakistan was building a nuclear bomb, and was thus ineligible for American assistance.
After hearing Mr. Clinton out, Mr. Sharif replied, "You have said all the right things, but the rest of the world is filing its fingernails," the official said. Mr. Sharif said the failure of most of the world to punish India for its tests made it impossible for him not to follow suit. "There was anguish in Sharif," the official said. "This was a man between a nuclear rock and a hard place. He was saying: 'I wish I did not have these forces acting on me, but people are demonstrating in the streets, the editorialists and the opposition are demanding I test. You have to understand my position.' He as much as said this was out of his hands."
Mr. Clinton said the tests would force him to impose sanctions that could cost Pakistan billions and cripple its economy. "He said, If you do this, Nawaz, I have to do this, and it'll hurt you a lot more than it'll hurt India,' " the official said. " 'If your hands are tied, mine are too.' "
The two leaders, resigned to take political acts against their personal wishes, signed off. While Mr. Clinton slept, Mr. Sharif gave the go-ahead for the nuclear explosions.
This morning, three hours after the tests, Mr. Clinton said they had cost Pakistan "a truly priceless opportunity to strengthen its own security, to improve its political standing in the eyes of the world." Because of the tests, the United States will try to delay any future loans to Pakistan by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and will cut off loans by private United States banks to the Pakistani Government. Similar measures were taken against India after its tests.
Announcing the economic sanctions against Pakistan that he was required to impose under law, Mr. Clinton said, "I cannot believe that we are about to start the 21st century by having the Indian subcontinent repeat the worst mistakes of the 20th century."
The dangers of the tests were underscored by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat and a former Ambassador to India. He said he feared that the Islamic republic of Pakistan might share its nuclear technology with Middle East nations hostile to Israel. "We now have an Islamic bomb," he said.
United States intelligence officials said today that Pakistan had probably not exploded five nuclear weapons, as Mr. Sharif announced, but as few as two, both in the range of 5 to 10 kilotons, according to preliminary estimates. The bomb that destroyed Hiroshima in 1945 was 12 kiloton.
Mr. Sharif's announcement of "five successful nuclear explosions," leveling the score with India, was probably propaganda intended for domestic consumption, the officials said. They said the same was true of his warning that Pakistan was already mounting nuclear warheads on its new medium-range Ghauri missiles, which can strike India's biggest cities. And so were statements by Pakistani officials that India was threatening to attack Pakistan's nuclear test site hours before the detonations, they said.
They also said more tests by Pakistan were possible.
United States officials were well aware of what Secretary of State Madeline K. Albright today called the "overwhelming domestic pressures and regional dynamics" forcing Mr. Sharif's hand. The pressures were so intense that Mr. Sharif's Government might have fallen had he not tested, said Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, who spoke with the Prime Minister twice in the last 10 days.
That pressure might have been relieved had the United States given Pakistan its F-16's and addressed its security concerns, said Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican and a Foreign Relations subcommittee chairman. But now, he said, "this chain reaction is spiraling out of control, and this is very scary."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE RIVALRY;
South Asian Arms Race: Reviving Dormant Fears of Nuclear War

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 28

 BODY:
In a matter of weeks, covert nuclear programs in India and Pakistan, rivals who have three times gone to war, have turned into an open nuclear arms race, raising alarms about what comes next -- and where.
Diplomats and arms control experts see this arms race as particularly dangerous because Pakistan and India, unlike the United States and Russia during the cold war, have not held serious negotiations over outstanding problems for decades or concluded agreements that reduced the number of weapons aimed at each other. 
 These experts now fear that Pakistan and India could be drawn into a nuclear war over Kashmir, a territory that has been in dispute since the two countries gained independence in 1947. They also worry that nuclear testing by India and Pakistan could encourage other nations that have long sought nuclear arms to acquire these weapons.
"We are at perhaps the most dangerous period since the beginning of the nuclear age -- with the exception of the Cuban missile crisis," said Thomas Graham, a former negotiator for the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency who is now president of the independent Lawyers' Alliance for World Security.
The United Nations, and the nuclear powers who hold Security Council seats, are left standing by helplessly. Since the end of the Cold War, few nations have much leverage with either India or Pakistan.
"They don't want outside help, at least the Indians don't," said Mr. Graham. "They think it's too much like colonialism. The Indians have probably not been very interested in confidence-building measures because in their heart of hearts they probably thought they would one day eliminate Pakistan."
Michael Krepon, president of the Henry L. Stimson Center, in Washington, an independent military research organization, said that years of watching the two nations sign agreements and then ignore or circumvent them led him to conclude that these pacts were used for little more than scoring points off one another.
Furthermore, neither India nor Pakistan has signed the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons or the nuclear test-ban treaty.
Pakistani officials and several former American diplomats said today that public outrage at threats by Lal Krishna Advani, India's Home Minister and policy maker on Kashmir, that India might attack Pakistan along the Kashmir border, overwhelmed cautious civilian politicians in Islamabad and made the tests inevitable.
The United States, which had been surprised by India's nuclear explosions, did not offer Pakistan, a country that feels friendless and surrounded by dangers in a tumultuous region, any real incentives not to test, said Stephen P. Cohen, an expert on India-Pakistan military affairs who is joining the Brookings Institution in Washington as its first South Asian policy scholar in the fall.
"Two things didn't happen," Mr. Cohen said today. "The price we offered was not close to what we offered North Korea." Pyongyang got $4 billion in American assistance to cap its nuclear program; Pakistan was given vague promises that it might finally be given the 28 F-16 aircraft it bought and paid for almost a decade ago.
"And we and the Chinese were unwilling to offer the Pakistanis security guarantees that would have made them feel comfortable," Mr. Cohen said.
Furthermore, said Robert Oakley, Ambassador to Pakistan in 1990, Pakistan thought its national security was compromised by Washington, because a legal provision known as the Pressler Amendment cut off economic and military assistance to Pakistan because of its nuclear program, but did not similarly punish India, which had already set off a nuclear explosion in 1974.
"For eight years Pakistan has been deprived of everything, and therefore we severely weakened their conventional military capability, which was predicated on the use of American equipment," Mr. Oakley said today. "We certainly weakened their confidence in the United States."
"At the same time, India was getting stronger," he said. "So what could the Pakistanis rely upon? Missiles and nuclear capability."
The decision to test not only brings down crippling economic sanctions on the country, but has also prompted India's Prime Minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, to assert that Indian explosions were now fully justified, since Pakistan had proved how dangerous it is. Furthermore, the Pakistani military, which has only recently been pushed back from the center of political power, now has the bomb.
From Pakistan's perspective, pleas from around the world -- and several long telephone appeals from President Clinton -- were not enough to overcome visceral fears of India, a country of nearly a billion people that looms large over the border.
"Pakistan is a profoundly insecure state," Mr. Cohen said. "It is a state that feels itself surrounded by enemies, beginning with Iran, a security problem. Afghanistan has turned out to be a terrible disaster for them. The Indians are as troublesome as ever. Their friends are not really friends. The U.S. has moved out of the region, and the Chinese are cool. Add to that the domestic troubles."
India, better armed by virtually every measure, has kept Pakistan off balance since they were created from the partition of British India in 1947.
It was the Indian Army that seized a large part of Kashmir in 1947, when raiders from Pakistan entered the territory, then still under a Hindu Maharaja, who called for help. In 1971, the Indian Army came to the rescue of a nationalist Bengali movement and severed East Pakistan -- now Bangladesh -- from the rest of the country.
"Pakistan refuses to accept Indian primacy and India refuses to accept anything else," Richard H. Haass, a former member of the National Security Council in the Bush Administration, wrote in 1990. That core problem was often at the heart of the two nations' disputes.
Richard Murphy, senior fellow for the Mideast at the Council on Foreign Relations and a former Assistant Secretary of State for the region, said today that policy makers cannot now rule out the possibility that Iran will react to the Pakistani tests.
"The Pakistan-Iranian relationship is edgy -- totally hostile no, but really quite edgy -- and there have been a number of incidents of terrorism, assassination in Pakistan that they have blamed on Iranian instigation," Mr. Murphy said. "Don't rule out the chain reaction -- that this will add to the motivation of Iranians to go for a nuclear weapons program, although they have said in various U.N. forums that they stand for a nuclear-free zone in the Persian Gulf."
In India as in Pakistan, the decision to test was also explained by fears of neighbors' weapons and intentions. India singled out China, but many diplomats and experts on the South Asian region and on China rule this out as a serious consideration.
"There hasn't been any increased threat to India's security at all from China or Pakistan," said Mr. Oakley, the former Ambassador who is now at the National Defense University on Washington.
Several experts said that they believe that the Indians, now under a new Hindu nationalist leadership also seeking to broaden its political support, were determined to acquire a world-power image they believe has been unfairly denied them.
That point was made clear in a statement on nuclear policy presented to India's Parliament on Wednesday by Prime Minister Vajpayee. The bomb, he said, "is India's due, the right of one-sixth of mankind."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE OVERVIEW;
PAKISTAN, ANSWERING INDIA, CARRIES OUT NUCLEAR TESTS; CLINTON'S APPEAL REJECTED

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Friday, May 29

 BODY:
Pakistan responded to India's nuclear tests on Thursday with underground nuclear tests of its own. Within hours, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif declared his country a "nuclear power," fulfilling a secret plan made by a predecessor nearly 30 years ago that Pakistan would build an "Islamic bomb."
In announcing that it had conducted five underground nuclear tests, Pakistan's first, the Islamabad Government simultaneously said it was already fitting nuclear warheads on a type of missile said to be able to strike targets across most of north and central India. 
 The news set off pandemonium in the Indian Parliament, which had been hotly debating India's recent nuclear tests. The announcement raised the specter of retaliation by India, Pakistan's archrival, which said after it conducted five tests of its own two weeks ago that it would begin fitting nuclear warheads on a range of missiles, including several developed specifically for targets in Pakistan.
"Today, we have evened the score with India," Mr. Sharif announced in a solemn television address about three hours after the tests, which were carried out at 3:30 P.M. Thursday (6:30 A.M. Thursday, Eastern time) at a testing range in the Chagai Hills, a desert region in the remote southwest, close to the borders with Afghanistan and Iran.
As he spoke, Pakistanis poured into the streets to dance and fire guns in the air, and crowds jammed mosques to offer prayers.
Early today, Mr. Sharif's Government declared a national state of emergency, further heightening the sense of crisis that has gripped the subcontinent since the first Indian nuclear tests on May 11. The statement was issued shortly after midnight by the titular President, Mohammed Rafiq Tarar, acting under constitutional provisions that may be invoked when Pakistan's security falls "under threat of external aggression."
It was not clear whether Mr. Sharif intended to go further, by curbing civil rights, suspending Parliament or taking other measures that Pakistan has often resorted to in its 50 years as a nation. Officials in Pakistan said privately that they did not expect such moves, but noted that Mr. Sharif would need emergency powers to respond quickly if India reacted to the Pakistan tests by actions that push the two countries closer to a military confrontation.
Tremors from Pakistan's tests registered at seismic centers as far away as Australia, Sweden and the United States, although American intelligence officials said Pakistan had probably tested only two weapons rather than the five announced.
Pakistan described its tests as "a complete success," but offered no details about the types of weapons involved or their explosive power. But a separate Government statement said the Ghauri missile, test-fired on April 6, was "already being capped with nuclear warheads to give a befitting reply to any misadventure by the enemy," meaning India.
Some Indian officials have said it was the Ghauri test that touched off the tests ordered by India's Hindu nationalist-led Government.
President Clinton, who had made the last of five telephone calls appealing for restraint from Mr. Sharif only hours before the tests, quickly announced that the United States would impose the same package of economic sanctions on Pakistan that it applied to India after its tests. The sanctions include a suspension of American economic aid, a ban on American bank loans to government institutions and pressure for a cutoff of aid from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, which have propped up Pakistan's debt-laden, enfeebled economy for years.
"I cannot believe," Mr. Clinton said. "that we are about to start the 21st century by having the Indian subcontinent repeat the worst mistakes of the 20th century, when we know it is not necessary to peace, to security, to prosperity, to national greatness, or to personal fulfillment."
When the first shouted word of Pakistan's tests has heard in the Indian Parliament, a Communist leader, Somnath Chatterjee, interrupted a speech condemning India's tests and addressed himself directly to Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, the Hindu nationalist leader who approved the Indian tests. "You have started a nuclear arms race in this region," he said.
Mr. Vajpayee left the chamber to check with other officials, returning quickly to make a statement. "If this is true, then India's policy has been vindicated," he said.
Later, Mr. Vajpayee rejected suggestions that India had set off a nuclear spiral, saying it had acted only because of concern about Pakistan's covert nuclear program. "In fact, Pakistan forced us to take the path of nuclear deterrence," he said.
He did not rule out retaliation. "India is ready to meet any challenge," he said.
Asked if India might set aside the moratorium on nuclear testing it declared after its tests, Mr. Vajpayee replied, "A new situation has been created, and it will be taken into account in formulating our policy."
The tests set off widespread alarm around the world, with statements of condemnation from Russia, China, Britain and a score of other nations, some of which, including Japan, Australia, Germany and Sweden, announced economic sanctions of their own against Pakistan. Many economists predicted that the sanctions, especially if they include a cutoff in emergency loans from the International Monetary Fund that have repeatedly staved off bankruptcy for Pakistan, could be a body blow to an economy that has staggered from crisis to crisis for decades.
The hours before the tests were marked by extreme tensions in Islamabad and New Delhi after Pakistan summoned India's diplomatic envoy to a meeting at 1:30 A.M. on Thursday and accused India of planning a pre-emptive military strike "before dawn" on the Chagai Hills testing center.
Simultaneously, Pakistan's representative to the United Nations, Ahmad Kamal, met Secretary General Kofi Annan in New York, and asked him to intervene with the United States and India to halt any Indian attack.
Pakistan issued a statement saying any Indian attack on the nuclear installations would "receive a swift and massive retaliation with unforeseen consequences."
India, which signed a pact with Pakistan in 1988 under which both nations undertook not to attack each other's nuclear installations, responded with a statement describing Pakistan's allegation as "vicious propaganda" and pledging to abide by India's obligation under the pact.
American intelligence officials expressed skepticism about Mr. Sharif's assertion that Pakistan was already mounting nuclear warheads on its missiles, as well as about Pakistani officials' assertions that India had threatened to attack the nuclear test site hours before the detonations.
Unlike India, which undertook elaborate deceptive measures ahead of its tests, catching even the Central Intelligence Agency off guard, Pakistan made its preparations under close scrutiny from Western intelligence agencies. About 24 hours before the tests, officials in Washington said American spy satellites had detected last-minute steps at the Chagai Hills site, including the pouring of concrete into the shafts prepared for the tests, and said the blasts could come at any time.
By going ahead with the tests, Mr. Sharif turned his back on a broad package of American military and economic assistance Mr. Clinton had offered if Pakistan held off.
Many economists, in Pakistan and elsewhere, have said Pakistan's $32 billion in foreign debt and more than $30 billion in domestic debt made it far more vulnerable to the sanctions imposed by Mr. Clinton than India is. A similar point has been made by Indian politicians who have supported New Delhi's tests, some of whom have said India's deeper pockets will enable it to outspend and eventually ruin Pakistan if a nuclear arms race develops.
In rejecting the American overtures, Mr. Sharif said he was bowing to overwhelming domestic political pressures, from military chiefs, opposition leaders like former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and powerful Muslim clerics. Ms. Bhutto had vowed to "take to the streets" at the head of mass demonstrations in a bid to force Mr. Sharif from office if he did not go ahead with the tests, and she had even urged Western powers to mount a "pre-emptive" strike on India's nuclear installations to help Pakistan.
It was Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who as Pakistan's President committed the country to a covert nuclear weapons program in the early 1970's, telling associates that the world needed an "Islamaic bomb" to match those under the control of Christians, Communists and, once India's secret nuclear weapons program matured, Hindus. After Mr. Bhutto was overthrown by the Pakistani Army in 1977 and hanged in 1979, there were reports that some of the financing for the Pakistani program came from other Muslim countries, including Libya.
But according to Western intelligence reports and court records, an equally important role was played, in most cases inadvertently, by Western countries. Since the 1970's, Pakistani scientists and intelligence agents have illicitly obtained much of the know-how needed to build nuclear weapons, as well as many of the components. Abdul Qadeer Khan, the physicist who oversaw the tests, is said to have played a key role by photocopying classified documents while he was working in a laboratory in the Netherlands in the 1970's.
In his television address, Mr. Sharif, a 48-year-old industrialist who has alternated in office with Ms. Bhutto since the end of military rule in 1988, spoke of the nuclear tests as a national rite of passage as well as an "inevitable" defensive measure after India's nuclear tests.
"Today, we have made history," he said, speaking in Urdu, the national language. "Today, God has given us the opportunity to take critical steps for the country's defense. We have become a nuclear power."
The Pakistani leader described India as "an expansionist power" and claimed that New Delhi had "started" all three wars between the two countries in 1947, 1965 and 1971.
But he reserved some of his strongest language for Western powers, saying they had ignored repeated pleas from Pakistan. "The big powers have never taken us seriously, and have accepted India's falsehoods instead," he said. "So what happened today must be seen as a natural reaction on our part."
But Mr. Sharif devoted most of his address to the economic challenge facing Pakistan. He said he had ordered all Government ministers to move out of their official residences, and announced that he would leave what he described as the "palatial" Prime Minister's residence, a $50 million mansion. He said the residences would be turned into schools, clinics and welfare centers.
He said sanctions would give Pakistan an opportunity to abandon decades of profligacy and corruption, especially by a small minority of rich Pakistanis, who he said had "mortgaged" the country's future. He announced an immediate end to the import of foreign luxury goods like cars and television sets, a crackdown on rampant tax evasion and a drive against smuggling, which has cut into the customs duties that are the Government's largest revenue source.
"By imposing sanctions, the Western powers will have done us a favor," he said. "They will have given us a chance to effect a revolution in our way of life, to learn to live within our means and to stop this cynical wastage of our national resources. We must conserve every penny of foreign exchange, and treat it like oxygen, essential to our country's survival. We will have to be disciplined, at all times, in all places."
In another decree today, Mr. Sharif imposed "temporary restrictions" on all foreign exchange transactions in Pakistan and a mandatory "holiday" for all banks. The moves appeared to be an effort to halt a flight of foreign investment and a run on the hard-currency bank accounts held by many wealthy Pakistanis.
For many Pakistanis, belt-tightening is likely to be superfluous, since tens of millions live in conditions of extreme deprivation, with menial jobs or none at all, no access to safe drinking water and little in the way of education or medical care. By most estimates, Pakistan is one of the 10 poorest countries in the world.
But as was the case in India after its nuclear tests, the streets of Islamabad, Lahore and Karachi, as well as scores of other cities and towns, were filled with celebrations by Pakistanis from every rung on the economic ladder.
"I'm very glad we've done it -- it was the right thing to do," said Raisuddin, a butcher in Karachi, a city of 15 million people that was virtually paralyzed by traffic jams as people headed for the city center to join in the festivities, according to an Associated Press report.
An Agence France-Presse report from Lahore, 15 miles from the Indian border in east-central Pakistan, described crowds burning effigies of Mr. Vajpayee, the Indian leader, and chanting slogans in praise of Mr. Sharif, Gen. Jehangir Karamat, Pakistan's army chief, and Dr. Khan, the physicist. The report quoted a university student as saying, "We are ready to pay any price and make any sacrifice to live as a self-respecting nation."

Chart: "CHRONOLOGY: The Birth of Two Nuclear Powers"
Some of the important events as Pakistan and India developed their nuclear weapon capabilities.
 
1940's
 
1948 -- India establishes an Atomic Energy Commission for exploration for uranium ore.
 
1950's
 
1955 -- The Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission is established.
 
1958 -- India begins designing and acquiring equipment that could lead to atomic weapons.
 
1960's
 
1965 -- A Pakistani nuclear research reactor reportedly starts functioning. Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto announces: If India builds the bomb, we will eat grass or leaves, even go hungry. But we will get one of our own.
 
1968 The Non-Proliferation Treaty is completed. India and Pakistan refuse to sign.
 
1970's
 
1974 -- India tests a device of up to 15 kilotons and calls the test a "peaceful nuclear explosion." Pakistan's Prime Minister Bhutto reportedly tells a secret meeting of Pakistan's top scientists of the intention to develop nuclear arms.
 
1980's
 
1987 -- Leading Pakistani nuclear scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan says Pakistan has a nuclear bomb.
 
1990's
 
1990 -- President Bush imposes military sanctions on Pakistan for pursuing a nuclear weapons program.
 
1992 -- Pakistan says it has the components and know-how to make at least one nuclear explosive device.
 
1997 -- India announces development of supercomputer technology that can be used to test nuclear weapon designs.
 
May 11-13, 1998 -- India conducts five underground nuclear tests; declares itself a nuclear state.
 
Yesterday -- Pakistan detonates nuclear devices.

MCI to Sell Internet Unit Amid Chill in Merger Review
MCI Communications agreed to sell its wholesale Internet business to Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for $625 million. While the deal is widely seen as a move to appease regulators reviewing MCI's acquisition by Worldcom, it also illustrates the increasingly testy relations between MCI and the Justice Department. 
 Executives said MCI had earlier sought an indication from the Justice Department whether the sale would allay its antitrust concerns, but that the department would not so indicate. MCI has appeared to grow increasingly frustrated with the department's handling of the merger. Page D4.
 
Stocks End Four-Day Losing Streak
Stocks rebounded as investors bought some of their favorite blue-chip stocks as well as smaller issues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.63 points, to 8,970.20. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.37 points, to 1,097.60, and the Russell 2000 index climbed more than 1.2 percent, to 455.81. Even so, analysts say that after a sharp runup in prices in the early part of the year, the market appears to be correcting. D6.

Pakistan, Answering India, Conducts Nuclear Tests
Pakistan responded to India's nuclear tests with underground nuclear tests of its own. Within hours, Pakistan's Prime Minister declared his country a "nuclear power," fulfilling a secret plan made by a predecessor nearly 30 years ago that it would build an "Islamic bomb." A1 

U.S. Penalizes Pakistan
President Clinton denounced Pakistan's nuclear tests as dangerously destabilizing and imposed penalties that could cost the Islamic nation billions of dollars. A1
 
Pakistan has long depended on the World Bank, and more recently the International Monetary Fund, to prop up a failing banking system and a debt-ridden economy. A9
 
Japan, Germany, Canada and Australia joined the United States in taking action against Pakistan. France, Russia and Britain condemned the testing but did not back sanctions. A10
 
China expressed "deep regret" over Pakistan's decision to conduct nuclear tests, but denounced India for provoking the crisis. A10

Catalytic Devices Found To Add to Global Warming
The catalytic converter, which has sharply reduced smog from cars, is now a significant and growing cause of global warming, the E.P.A. says. Researchers have long suspected that the converters sometimes rearrange nitrogen-oxygen compounds from exhaust to form nitrous oxide, a powerful greenhouse gas that is more than 300 times more potent than carbon dioxide, the most common of the gases, experts say. A1

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE ECONOMY;
Sanctions Could Badly Bruise Fragile Pakistan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
Fear of economic sanctions from the United States did not stop India from testing five nuclear devices two weeks ago, nor did it stop Pakistan from retaliating. Now, having promised to punish both nations, the Clinton Administration is uncertain how much pain it can inflict.
Administration officials said today that they would try to delay World Bank loans to Pakistan, as they did earlier this week on loans to India. Pakistan has long depended on the World Bank, and more recently the International Monetary Fund, to prop up a failing banking system and a debt-ridden economy. 
 Because Pakistan is more heavily dependent on the World Bank and the I.M.F. than India is, the threat of delays should give the United States some leverage.
But World Bank officials say Pakistan has already received all of the $808 million in aid promised in the bank's current fiscal year, which ends on June 30.
That means that the soonest the United States could intervene to delay next year's loans and credits, which are expected to total about $750 million, is this fall, when the first projects come up for approval.
At the I.M.F., which began a three-year, $1.52 billion program in Pakistan last October, the United States could intercede to block development funds as soon as next month. Fund officials just returned from Islamabad, the capital, and they are preparing a report to pave the way for what a spokesman called "a small disbursement of funds" in June. But the next large chunk of cash is not likely to come up for approval until later this year or next.
That time span could prove important. American officials say that with backing from Japan and Canada, they can delay loans for both countries for a few months. But most board members at both the World Bank and the I.M.F. oppose the American sanctions policy, so if the issue comes to a vote, both India and Pakistan are likely to see the aid resume.
"This has started off as an issue between the U.S. and India and Pakistan," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of the investment bank Goldman Sachs & Company and a top economic official in the Carter Administration.
"But it is headed toward becoming an issue between the U.S. and its closest allies: There is a philosophical difference on sanctions, and a commercial competitiveness that is likely to make most of our major trading partners unwilling to go along."
The aid is particularly important for Pakistan because that country, unlike India, receives little foreign investment. The aid received from the World Bank, the I.M.F. and other international agencies accounts for about 1.4 percent of the country's gross national product, a figure that significantly understates the importance of the money in Pakistan's beleaguered economy.
The World Bank, for example, approved $250 million in late March for a program that focuses on elementary school education, primary health care, family planning, rural water supplies and sanitation for women and children. While the bank's contribution is a small part of a $10 billion program, its involvement is critical to persuading other donors to join, and to keeping Pakistan's contributions from being diverted.
The bank maintains that a pilot version of the program has improved school enrollment in a country where only 55 percent of children attend school, compared with more than 90 percent in India and Bangladesh. Pakistan's adult literacy rate is estimated at 37 percent.
"Obviously, this is not the kind of program you would want to cut off, especially in a country where we are trying to convince people that the West is not the enemy," one senior Administration official said. "That's the problem with automatic sanctions: they don't let you differentiate very much between aid that is in America's interest and aid that is not."
In fact, while Administration officials were publicly declaring that the sanctions would be put in place as soon as possible, several expressed reservations, saying it was a poor moment to cut off economic interaction with both countries.
"It's not as if we can unexplode the nukes," the senior official noted. "We have to work with the new situation we're faced with."
There is another complication: the sanctions amendments to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Act, which President Clinton signed into law, do not end automatically at some point in the future. That means Congress would have to vote to end the economic isolation.
Some Administration officials fear that could greatly complicate diplomatic efforts to work out a package deal under which both countries might agree not to mount their nuclear devices on missiles, then sign nonproliferation treaties or allow inspections of their nuclear facilities.
Another part of the automatic sanctions law calls for a end to American bank loans to the Pakistan Government, but those amounts appear to be minimal. Today the Pakistan Government, apparently fearing that the country's few investors would flee, froze all foreign-currency accounts to keep hard currency in the country.

HEADLINE: United Health To Acquire Humana Inc.

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The United Healthcare Corporation, one of the nation's largest health insurers, agreed yesterday to buy Humana Inc. for $5.5 billion, further shrinking the number of competitors in the industry and narrowing the choices of managed-care plans for consumers.
The combination of the health plans, with more than 10 million members across the country, would dominate the South Florida market. It would be the strongest insurer in Chicago and some other Midwestern cities. 
 Both companies said the agreement would strengthen their ability to offer services that patients want and provide nationwide coverage for big employers. But some health-benefits consultants called such a combination part of a consolidation trend that was unsettling for many Americans in managed-care arrangements.
"Humana was a very aggressive player," said John Erb, a consultant in Boca Raton, Fla., with Arthur J. Gallagher & Company. "They gave the Blue Cross and United a run for their money. Now, that competition will dry up. There will be diminished choices for employers and consumers."
Both United and Humana recently reported strong financial results, after their success in raising this year's premiums. But like other health insurers, they are under more pressure to produce profits as consumers demand fewer restrictive rules, governments propose tighter regulations, and hospitals and physicians balk at some economizing.
Managed-care companies also face a squeeze on Government payments for Medicare for the elderly and disabled, and Medicaid for low-income people. United Healthcare, based in Minnetonka, Minn., outside Minneapolis, and Humana, of Louisville, Ky., have a combined 902,000 Medicare members and 1.2 million Medicaid members.
Under the terms of the all-stock deal announced yesterday, United Healthcare would exchange one of its shares for two shares of Humana and assume $850 million of Humana's debt. On the basis of United's closing share price Wednesday of $64.125, before the deal was announced, the value of the stock swap is $5.5 billion.
United Healthcare shares fell $1.625 yesterday, to $62.50, while Humana's jumped $3.625, to $29.875.
The agreement is the latest in a series of huge-scale mergers and acquisitions in the health insurance industry. In March, Aetna Inc., which bought U.S. Healthcare for $8.8 billion in 1996, agreed to add the Nylcare health care unit of the New York Life Insurance Company in a $1.35 billion deal.
Both United and Humana have grown through acquisitions, notably the 1995 purchase by United of Metra Health, itself a combination of units of Metropolitan Life and the Travelers Insurance Company.
David Jones, a Kentucky entrepreneur, founded Humana with a partner in 1961. They owned nursing homes and later, hospitals. Humana spun off the hospitals in 1993 as a separate company, Galen Health Care Inc., which was later acquired by the chain that became the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation.
Mr. Jones, chairman of Humana, and Dr. William W. McGuire, chairman of United, said the combined company would promote United's "open access" health plans, which permit members to consult any specialist from a list approved by United, without approval in advance by their primary doctor.
Mr. Jones said it would have cost "hundreds of millions of dollars" for Humana to duplicate the computerized information systems that United has developed, which make it possible to allow more flexible choices of doctors for consumers while keeping track of physicians' activity, an important cost-control device for managed-care plans.
Doctors whose costs for patients are deemed excessive "can be identified and counseled," Mr. Jones said.
Dr. McGuire said profit margins were narrow in health insurance, while the demand for more capital was increasing. "You've got to have strong organizations," he said.
The two companies combined would have 602,000 members in health maintenance organizations in Miami, or 48 percent of that market, according to Interstudy, a nonprofit managed-care research center in Minneapolis. Dr. McGuire said United and Humana would have 1.4 million customers in all types of health care in Florida, or less than 10 percent of the state's estimated 14.7 million people.
In the Chicago market for health maintenance organizations, United and Humana would have a 28 percent share, ahead of H.M.O. Illinois, the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plan, with 24 percent, Interstudy said.
Under the deal, Mr. Jones would have 4.5 million shares of United Healthcare and a seat on the United board. No new positions were immediately announced for Gregory H. Wolf, chief executive of Humana, or other Humana executives.
Security analysts said the lesser role for Humana officials could mean less of the clash of cultures that has hampered many deals. "The track record for mergers in this sector is less than stellar," said Rob Maines, an analyst with Advest Inc. Analysts said it had taken a year to 18 months for several health care companies to get back on their feet after big merger deals.
Dr. McGuire said the Humana acquisition would bring eventual savings of $100 million to $250 million by eliminating overlapping administrative costs and "a couple hundred million" through efficiencies in medical care, including $100 million from lower payments to hospitals.
The combined company, with headquarters near Minneapolis, would start with 50,000 employees before shedding an unspecified number.
In the transaction, Goldman, Sachs & Company and the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell advised United Healthcare. Humana was advised by Lehman Brothers and Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.
