HEADLINE: Autos' Converters Cut Smog But Add to Global Warming

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
The catalytic converter, an invention that has sharply reduced smog from cars, has now become a significant and growing cause of global warming, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.
Hailed as a miracle by Detroit auto makers even today, catalytic converters have been reducing smog for 20 years. The converters break down compounds of nitrogen and oxygen from car exhaust that can combine with hydrocarbons, also from cars, and be cooked by sunlight into smog. 
 But researchers have suspected for years that the converters sometimes rearrange the nitrogen-oxygen compounds to form nitrous oxide, known as laughing gas. And nitrous oxide is more than 300 times more potent than carbon dioxide, the most common of the gases that trap heat and warm the atmosphere like in a greenhouse, experts say.
This spring, the E.P.A. published a study estimating that nitrous oxide now accounts for about 7.2 percent of the gases that cause global warming. Cars and trucks, most fitted with catalytic converters, produce nearly half of that nitrous oxide, the study said.
The E.P.A. has not proposed a solution at this point.
Other sources of nitrous oxide include everything from nitrogen-based fertilizer to manure from farm animals.
The E.P.A.'s study also showed that nitrous oxide is one of a few gases for which emissions are increasing rapidly. The gases are collectively known as greenhouse gases.
The increase in nitrous oxide, the study notes, stems from the growth in the number of miles traveled by cars that have catalytic converters. And the problem has worsened as improvements in the converters, changes that have eliminated more of the nitrogen-oxygen compounds that cause smog, have conversely produced more nitrous oxide.
Wylie J. Barbour, an E.P.A. official who worked on the recently published study, said the problem created by the converter was classic: "You've got people trying to solve one problem, and as is not uncommon, they've created another."
Nitrous oxide, or N2 O, is not regulated because the Clean Air Act was written in 1970 to control smog, not global warming. And no regulations exist to control greenhouse gases.
The United States and the other industrialized nations agreed in Kyoto, Japan, last December to lower emissions of greenhouse gases to 5 percent below 1990 levels, over the next 10 to 15 years, but the agreement has not been approved by the Senate and no implementing rules have been written.
"This hadn't really been on people's radar screen until climate change started becoming an issue," said one E.P.A. official involved in reducing pollution from cars, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Auto industry experts say they can solve the problem by tinkering with the catalytic converter, but some environmentalists suggest that the growing production of nitrous oxide is yet another reason to move away from gasoline-powered cars. The E.P.A.'s study estimated that nitrous oxide may represent about one-sixth of the global warming effect that results from gasoline use.
Precisely how much nitrous oxide the converters produce remains an issue. A report used by the E.P.A. in preparing its greenhouse gas study calculated that a car with a fuel economy of about 19 miles a gallon would produce 0.27 grams of nitrous oxide per mile. That represents an amount that is about one-third the emissions for nitrogen oxide, the chemicals causing smog.
Steven H. Cadle, a research scientist at General Motors, said, "it's a huge number." In contrast, an older car without a catalytic converter produces much larger amounts of nitrogen oxides, but only about a tenth as much nitrous oxide, the greenhouse gas.
The E.P.A. calculated that production of nitrous oxide from vehicles rose by nearly 50 percent between 1990 and 1996 as older cars without converters have neared extinction. Using a standard unit of measure for global-warming gases, millions of metric tons of carbon equivalent, nitrous oxide emissions rose to 54.7 million tons from 36.7 million during those years, the study said.
The contradictory impact of the converter has not been lost on environmental officials or industry experts, who continue to debate the extent of the growing problem as well as how to reduce the emissions in future years.
Ned Sullivan, head of the Maine Department of Environmental Protection, said the converter problem requires a "comprehensive" response. "This specific issue fits into a broader context that our regulatory system has tended to deal with pollutants on an individual, rather than a comprehensive, basis," he said.
Mr. Sullivan and others favor moving away from today's typical car design, a big gasoline engine driving the wheels, to electric cars. Another solution is hybrid cars, which use small, efficient engines running on gasoline to help turn the wheels and to charge batteries for electric motors that also run the wheels. Those have much higher fuel economy, and thus lower greenhouse gas emissions.
But car industry experts favor less drastic changes. They propose cutting nitrous oxide production by adjusting catalytic converters. They believe that redesigning the converters to reach optimum temperature faster would solve the problem and would also help them destroy other pollutants better.
 
 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page headline on Friday about the contribution of automobiles' catalytic converters to global warming misstated the amount of nitrous oxide that the Environmental Protection Agency believes comes from the devices. A draft study by the E.P.A. said that about 3 percent comes from cars and trucks, out of a total contribution of 7 percent from all manmade sources. Cars and trucks alone do not account for 7 percent. In a statement issued yesterday in response to the article, the E.P.A. said the production of the gas by converters "could be closer to 2 percent or less."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Giants Ready to Unload Miller in Payroll Purge

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON 

 BODY:
Monday marks the beginning of the National Football League's annual roster-shaping and payroll-trimming festival. After June 1, salary cap regulations make it advantageous for some teams to dump high-salaried players, and many teams do.
What ensues is an unusually open market for veteran players -- many of whom are valuable and suddenly free agents. 
 For the Giants, the notable departure will be center Brian Williams, who will retire. Williams, 31, was on the verge of his first All-Pro season a year ago when he injured his eye seriously at the team's training camp. He was sidelined for the entire 1997 season with double vision that has not abated sufficiently for him to continue his football career.
Except for that somber announcement, the Giants -- initially at least -- will not be busy. But they will be closely watching the other teams, eager to find a gem in the pool of players cast aside in this grand payroll purge.
And should a quality defensive tackle or defensive end become available, the Giants will not let him stay unemployed for long. In the transaction that would follow, Corey Miller, a starting linebacker last year and, with seven pro seasons, one of the Giants' most experienced players, would be cut.
Miller's departure would save the Giants $1.5 million in salary -- money the team would use to sign its new defensive lineman.
Miller is in a salary squabble with the Giants, who want to cut Miller's $1.5 million salary by $600,000. The Giants now view Miller as a likely backup to Marcus Buckley, whom the team re-signed as a free agent this winter.
The Giants do not want to pay a backup $1.5 million, though the restructured contract they have proposed to Miller is laden with incentives that would return the $600,000 lost in salary if Miller were to regain his starting job.
Miller and the Giants haven't been able to come to a new salary arrangement. The Giants may need Miller next season, and they know it. Buckley is unproven as a strongside linebacker and, at 236 pounds, is considered undersized for the position.
But it is risky for Miller to try to call the Giants' bluff. If a reliable defensive lineman becomes a free agent this week, the Giants will not hesitate to jettison Miller and hand over at least part of his salary to the new player. Because as much as Miller adds depth, the Giants are thin and inexperienced on the defensive front line.
The front line's starting foursome -- defensive ends Michael Strahan and Chad Bratzke and tackles Robert Harris and Keith Hamilton -- had superb seasons last year, but this winter, the Giants lost the backup defensive tackle Ray Agnew to free agency. Harris recently had shoulder surgery. The team has said that Harris will be recovered by training camp, but there are always questions following surgery and Harris is not the only Giant defender attempting that kind of comeback.
Bratzke is returning from knee surgery, even if he looked nimble and fit during the team's minicamp earlier this month. Cedric Jones, the defensive end and 1996 first-round pick still in search of his first N.F.L. sack, also had an injury-riddled season as Bratzke's backup last year. Christian Peter, another backup at tackle, played sparingly as a rookie.
Williams's vision has not improved in a substantial way -- as far as his football capabilities -- for months despite a series of surgeries. His retirement has been timed to allow the Giants the most salary-cap relief for this season. Williams's $1.55 million base pay will not be charged to the Giants' cap. The Giants are expected to use this money to sign the players selected in April's league draft.

HEADLINE: Sanctuary Lost: Hong Kong Can't Hide From Asia's Woes

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 29

 BODY:
For the last year, as one thriving Asian economy after another caught a chill, this former British colony has seemed like the region's healthiest outpost. Today, though, Hong Kong acknowledged that it had come down with a full-blown case of the Asian economic flu.
The Hong Kong Government announced that its economy contracted by about 2 percent in the first quarter of 1998. It was the first time the economy shrank since the middle of 1985, and it raised the prospect that Hong Kong was entering its most severe recession since World War II. 
 "We are facing an unprecedented economic upheaval," said Sir Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's top financial official, as he announced the much-anticipated economic statistics just after the close of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. "There is no panacea that will take immediate effect," he added.
In keeping with its role as the trading post for Asia, Hong Kong has not just shown isolated signs of economic distress -- say, a troubled banking system or a loss of investor confidence. It has caught a little of everything from its Asian neighbors: depressed consumer demand, declining export growth, tight credit and a plummeting real estate market.
"The uniqueness of Hong Kong is its open economy," said Ian K. Perkin, chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "It's like being a boxer in the ring, trying to throw off punches from many opponents. But now we're starting to get punched by the referee as well."
Hong Kong was able to put off its day of reckoning because -- unlike Indonesia, South Korea or Thailand -- it did not have suffocating foreign debt or an insolvent banking system. Indeed, it managed to keep its dollar pegged to the United States dollar even as speculators were on the attack and its Asian neighbors were slashing the value of their currencies.
But in the end, Hong Kong's dependence on trade with the rest of Asia guaranteed that it would suffer, too. "However strong our system is, we can't insulate ourselves from the storm elsewhere," said Richard Margolis, regional strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, tried to prepare the public for the dismal results in a speech on Tuesday. But even pessimists were taken aback by the 2 percent decline. And Mr. Perkin said second-quarter results were likely to be just as bad, predicting that Hong Kong would suffer its first full year of contraction since it began keeping statistics in 1961.
Mr. Tung has so far declined to say that Hong Kong is entering a recession. But by the generally accepted definition -- two straight quarters of contraction -- it may already be here.
Sir Donald acknowledged that Hong Kong would not attain the Government's official forecast of 3.5 percent growth this year, but he declined to give a revised forecast, saying the continued turmoil in neighboring countries made it all but impossible to predict when Hong Kong would hit bottom.
Meanwhile, he appealed to people not to despair. "As soon as the situation stabilizes, especially in Indonesia and Japan, I'm quite sure that Hong Kong will be the first economy to turn around," he said.
But people here already seem to be looking on the dark side. The Hang Seng Index plunged a total of more than 6 percent on Wednesday and Thursday, before rebounding slightly today on rumors that the Government would announce measures to ease the effects of the downturn. Sir Donald did disclose a modest package of steps to increase tourism and help homeowners finance mortgages.
But at the upscale Landmark mall in central Hong Kong, where tourists and locals used to emerge with arm loads of designer clothing and accessories, people were browsing rather than buying on a recent afternoon.
"We're being more frugal these days," said Lau Kit Yee, a 32-year-old Hong Kong native who owns a garment-trading company. "I'm more careful of what I buy, and I only buy things that I need." Ms. Lau said many of her competitors in the garment business had been forced to shut down in the last year -- contributing to an unemployment rate of 3.9 percent, the highest in 14 years.
Tourists, meanwhile, are becoming a rare species. The number of visitors to Hong Kong dropped 24 percent in the first quarter. In an effort to drum up business, the Government said it would relax visa requirements for Taiwan residents and raise the weekly quota of mainland Chinese allowed entry.
Among the most revealing numbers, retail sales dropped 14 percent in the first quarter. Consumers have been spending less in part because the value of their primary assets -- their homes -- has been hit by a stomach-churning decline. Residential real estate prices have dropped more than 40 percent since last year, while commercial real estate has fallen about 30 percent.
Of course, the decline comes after years of frenzied speculation, when Hong Kong became famous as the city of the $20,000-a-month apartment and the $100 million private home. But those who bought homes when the prices were rising now face huge potential losses.
"It's fine for people who are going to buy, but don't forget that half of Hong Kong's people own their own homes," said Nicholas Brooke, chairman of Brooke Hillier Parker, a real estate brokerage firm.
The slack demand has, in turn, kicked off a price war among Hong Kong's usually cozy developers. Last week, in a rare mutiny against the Government, several of Hong Kong's most prominent developers demanded that Mr. Tung back off from his most cherished policy goal: building 85,000 apartments a year over five years to bring affordable housing to low-income people.
The developers said the Government was flooding Hong Kong with apartments, further depressing the market. Mr. Tung has not abandoned his policy, but the Government said today that it would scrap other regulations that it adopted during the heyday of Hong Kong real estate to curb speculation.
The property market is a home-grown problem. But Hong Kong's other woes have been made worse by its neighbors. Japan's economic woes, for example, have dire implications here because big Japanese banks are pulling credit lines to small and midsize businesses.
"It's the old story about the good borrower and the bad borrower," said Gary L. Greenberg, managing director of Van Eck Global Asset Management. "The bank will take the money back from the good borrower. Hong Kong is the good borrower, while the rest of the region is the bad."
Economic misery in Japan, Korea, and Indonesia has also slowed Hong Kong's exports to those countries. Exports grew 1 percent in the first quarter, a pittance compared with the 20 percent annual gains typical of the early 1990's. And the poor performance comes despite continued strong demand from the United States, Europe and China.
If China's growth slows -- as many analysts expect -- exports could tumble further. A few contend that China may also devalue its currency, the renminbi, which would put enormous pressure on Hong Kong to uncouple its dollar from the United States dollar. But that remains a minority view, and most experts still see Hong Kong's dollar as the bedrock of its economy.
Despite all the dark clouds, a few observers found a silver lining. Hong Kong's pro-democracy politicians said public dissatisfaction with the state of the economy brought people out in record numbers to vote in Sunday's legislative elections. The pro-democracy candidates won a sweeping victory and are already gearing up to battle the Government on economic issues.
And Victor Fung, chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, said the troubled Asian economies would use exports to climb out of recession. As the largest trading and shipping center in the region, he said, Hong Kong would benefit as these countries began exporting again.
"I think you'll look back on this period and say, 'Yes, Hong Kong was hard hit, but the market did its job,' " Mr. Fung said.

HEADLINE: Income and Spending Were Up in April

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Growth in personal income accelerated in April and consumer spending continued to increase, signs that domestic demand was helping to offset the effect of the Asian crisis on the economy.
The Commerce Department said today that incomes rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, faster than March's gain of three-tenths of 1 percent. Spending rose half a percent, unchanged from March. 
 Trends in income can portend future business activity because they indicate how much consumers will be able to spend. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's output of goods and services.
Still, the outlook is uncertain. Government figures released on Thursday showed that the economy grew at a 4.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter, faster than previously estimated. But a significant portion of the growth came from an accumulation of inventories, suggesting the economy could slow in the second quarter. With inventories higher, businesses will probably draw down existing stocks for a while.
Also, if turbulence in the stock market continues, consumers may become nervous and refrain from making big-ticket purchases.
In today's report, the Commerce Department also said that disposable income, the money left after taxes, increased four-tenths of 1 percent in April after having risen three-tenths of 1 percent in March.

HEADLINE: Pakistan's Catch-22

BYLINE: By Robert C. McFarlane; Robert C. McFarlane was national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan from 1983 to 1985.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Ten days ago, in a long session with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, I found him sobered and deeply anguished by the choices before him.
In addition to the obvious nuclear catastrophe that could occur if Pakistan's armed confrontation with India in Kashmir got out of control, he understood quite well the ruinous economic impact that a nuclear arms race with India could have on his country, which already spends 70 percent of the national budget on defense and debt service. Worse, however, would be for Pakistan to be subjugated and ultimately dismembered by the nationalist-led, fanatically anti-Muslim Government in India, which with each day's rhetoric has seemed devoted to that very course. 
 Mr. Sharif wanted desperately to find a way to deter India. Yet unless he received concrete security assurances from the United States and/or China -- a firm commitment to respond jointly to any Indian attack upon Pakistan -- he would have no choice but to respond in kind to India's nuclear tests. The only way he could compensate for India's lopsided advantage in conventional forces would be by relying on nuclear weapons -- as the NATO alliance did vis-a-vis the Soviet Union for 40 years in Europe.
Not wanting to embarrass his American guest, Mr. Sharif asked obliquely, "Do you think China would give us a security guarantee?" I replied that I doubted it, and, going on to answer his implied question, I said that for the United States to do so would require a far greater understanding among Americans and in the Congress of the stakes involved.
I added that about as much as he could hope for in the short term would be a commitment from President Clinton to begin working immediately with him on a joint security policy that could lead to the kind of assurance he was seeking. In his exchanges with President Clinton since then, he sought that kind of commitment. Apparently he didn't believe he received it.
Yes, this crisis could have been avoided, with outside intervention. To be fair, however, the failure to prevent it lies with leaders of both of our political parties, who have never wanted to invest the time and energy required to mediate the well-known disagreements between India and Pakistan. Instead, by default, American policy has been forged by the Congress, which has put in place a nonsensical framework of sanctions -- of "sticks" alone -- while offering no incentives for restraint or intellectual solutions to Pakistan's problems.
Ask yourself what you would do as Prime Minister of Pakistan, faced with an imbalance of at least 2-to-1 with India in every measure of conventional power? You would seek a security guarantee from the United States or China that, however ambiguous, might at least complicate Indian thinking before an attack. And if you couldn't get that, you would "go nuclear."
Where do we go from here? First, looking to the wider audience of nuclear wannabes, we must make it clear that India's prideful boasting of having joined the club of great powers is false and that there will be no rewards -- but instead, severe pain -- for its unwarranted decision. We must make clear to the Indian Government that it is today what it was two weeks ago, an arrogant, overreaching cabal that, by its devotion to the caste system, the political and economic disenfranchisement of its people and its religious intolerance, is unworthy of membership in any club. Concurrently, we should make clear that we welcome into the real club those nations, like Brazil and Argentina, that have had the courage and good sense to forgo nuclear weapons and instead to focus on providing for their people.
Second, we should show some active, visible leadership. President Clinton should commit himself to a sustained period of intense political, economic and security diplomacy with both sides.
It must focus first on a serious analysis of the precarious security situation in South Asia and the most volatile source of current tension, the Kashmir dispute. In addition to offering to mediate that disagreement, the President must focus on the root causes of poverty and unrest in both countries. That analysis could provide a basis for convening an international donors group, including Japan, Germany, Britain, the World Bank and others, to begin -- finally -- to think seriously about the human misery in South Asia.
In parallel, we must put forward and lead a serious agenda of arms control. Separate, but related, is the enduring need to assure the security of the weakest member in the region, Pakistan. But it is not beyond the wit of sensible people who understand both the stakes and the awful history of the region to do so.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
My China For Your Congress

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Let's get straight to the point: President Clinton has no business, no business whatsoever, going to China now. The Republicans are right. President Clinton is wrong, wrong, wrong. He should stay home. This trip to China is an outrage. A sham. An embarrassment. It should be canceled. Today. Now. Immediately.
On one condition. 
 That if the President agrees not to go to China, the Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich agree not to go home. That's right. Mr. Clinton cancels his trip to Beijing and the Republicans cancel all Congressional recesses and agree to keep everyone at work until they pass the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill.
Why not? That's the only thing worth the President staying home for. Because that's the only thing that's going to begin to solve this problem of candidates selling themselves and legislation to the highest bidder -- including foreigners. You can't buy something that's not for sale, and until we have a campaign finance system in this country that makes it much more difficult for Democrats and Republicans to put themselves up for sale, then this problem will never go away.
Of course we still need to investigate whether the Clintonites sold out America's national security interests to China for campaign cash. If so, they should be drawn and quartered. But let's get real. Lott, Gingrich & Company want to investigate the President for campaign finance improprieties, but when they had a chance to pass the McCain-Feingold bill to prevent future such improprieties they killed it. And why did they kill it? Because the Republicans are historically better at exploiting the soft-money loophole than the Democrats, and they assume that if they can keep that loophole in place, they can cement their hold over Congress and buy back the White House.
If this situation is not addressed now it is only going to get worse, because the more we move toward an open, globalized economy, the more foreigners will try to take advantage of our lack of campaign finance laws to penetrate our system and pervert it to their ends.
It is already ridiculously easy: A Chinese People's Liberation Army general writes a check to his daughter. His daughter, a lieutenant colonel, writes a check to her American friend Johnny Chung. Her American friend writes checks to the Democratic Party for $100,000. Bingo. The President makes a decision that potentially benefits the Chinese general's company. The head of Loral Space & Communications, Bernard Schwartz, contributes $600,000 in soft money to the Democratic Party and the President decides to allow Loral to export a communications satellite to China for launch on a Chinese rocket -- despite a pending criminal investigation of Loral for providing China with missile-launch technology.
Both of these foul-smelling deals would be much less likely if the McCain-Feingold bill were passed, with its hard limits on how much any single individual or corporation can give to any candidate in one election, and with its elimination of the soft-money loophole, which allows unlimited contributions to political parties to buy political advertising -- a license for politicians to beg for money from corporate donors.
Trent Lott says just follow the existing campaign finance laws. But, as Senator Feingold remarked to me: "That is very misleading because the laws themselves are inadequate. The current law allows for the sorts of enormous campaign contributions that led to the sale of the Lincoln Bedroom. But the Republican leaders don't want to make those laws adequate because they are benefiting from them even more than the Democrats. This is about who has the money and who has the power, and Lott & Company are ready to stand in the face of scandals and corruption and public disgust to hold onto the cash."
The support for McCain-Feingold is clearly growing. The President has endorsed it, and the bill now has 52 senators backing it, including 7 courageous Republicans. So if Republicans want the President to show some leadership and stay home from China, then their leaders should show some leadership and stay at the office. It's time both parties stopped serving Chinese generals and U.S. fat cats and started serving the American people with some real campaign finance reform that actually confronts the problem.
Mr. Lott, Mr. Gingrich, remember that old Chinese proverb: Put up or shut up.

HEADLINE: BRIDGE;
A Non-Pro Wins the Trophy For Master Points in a Year

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott 

 BODY:
In the early days of the game there were two national organizations, William McKenney's American Bridge League, with roots in auction bridge, and Ely Culbertson's United States Bridge Association. They were merged in 1937, with McKenney in command, and Charles Goren was named the first winner of the McKenney Trophy for winning the most master points in a year. He won seven more times, a record.
Second best with six victories was Barry Crane, and after his death in 1985 the name was changed to the Barry Crane Top 500. Since then there have been many different winners, nearly all of them professionals who play weekly on the tournament circuit with clients who can afford their fees. 
 The 1997 winner did not fit the mold. Randy Pettit of Marietta, Ga., is a 54-year-old semiretired financial planner who is neither a professional nor a client. His bridge planning is perhaps less effective, for he sometimes arrives at a tournament without partners and teammates and relies on happenstance. His skill is such that the professionals are happy to recruit him as a team member or play with him when they are unemployed.
In 1997, he attended all three national championships, 18 regional tournaments and three sectionals, far less than most of the professionals. But by the end of the year he had accumulated 2,117 master points. A perennial contender, Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., took second place. This was a remarkable performance by Pettit, who has battled attention deficit disorder all his life.
Pettit's favorite bridge memory concerns the diagramed deal, played long ago in a Grand National Team match against strong opponents. His partner, Bill Lohmann of Atlanta, opened the West hand with one no-trump. The partnership was using the superweak notrump, showing 10 to 13 high card points, as many experts do when the vulnerability is in their favor.
His opponents reached the normal four-spade contract, but en route North made a splinter bid. His jump to four clubs was an optimistic slam suggestion showing a spade fit with club shortness. Pettit, East, doubled this to show length and strength in clubs.
The idea was to suggest a club lead rather than a diamond, advice that Lohmann did not happen to need. But guided by the double he made an imaginative move: He underled his ace-king of clubs.
East won with the queen and shifted to the diamond ten. South finessed, losing to the king, and a diamond was returned.
South was a puzzled man. The normal reason for East to win the first trick with the club queen is that he has all the top honors. But West had shown 10-13, so something funny was going on.
The declarer was the central character in that old Hitchcock thriller, "The Man Who Knew Too Much." Searching for West's high-card points, he finessed the spade jack. That did not work, for East produced the queen and returned a trump. South won and could not now ruff two clubs in the dummy. Still convinced that West had high cards outside clubs, he finessed the heart queen and was discomfited to see Pettit produce the king, another card he was not supposed to have.
In the replay South had no useful information and had no trouble making an overtrick. The result was 13 imps for Pettit, Lohmann and their teammates.

HEADLINE: In Buying We Trust;
The Foundation of U.S. Consumerism Was Laid in the 18th Century

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
"A penny saved is a penny earned" and Benjamin Franklin's other homespun exhortations may stir nostalgia for an earlier age when habits of frugality and thrift are thought to have been more deeply ingrained in the American character.
Yet some scholars have questioned whether those early colonial Americans wouldn't have been almost as devoted to, say, the Home Shopping Network as their modern counterparts are. 
 "Recent scholarship has convincingly demolished the notion of a sudden and late revolution that transformed America into a nation of consumers," writes Daniel Horowitz in "The Morality of Spending," a 1992 history of consumer attitudes. Carole Shammas, a historian at the University of California at Riverside, agrees: "The foundations of American consumerism were laid in the 18th century," when large quantities of imported manufactured goods from England started to circulate in the 13 colonies.
Indeed, the origins of colonial America's relationship with thrift and consumerism are complicated. While there was certainly a reverence for the values associated with thrift, there was also a vital and active consumerism.
Yet until recently, only the thrift side of the equation was emphasized. It was assumed that thrift was an article of faith for America's early Protestant dissenters, Puritans, Baptists, Methodists, Quakers and the like. And indeed, they believed that God had called man to occupy a particular place in this world, and therefore he must fulfill the obligations imposed on him by his "calling." This implied careful husbandry of possessions because they came from God.
As David Fischer, a historian at Brandeis University, points out, as late as 1775 no less than three-quarters of the churches in the colonies belonged to dissenting Protestant faiths that believed every man had such a sacred calling.
Many colonial Americans also harbored a visceral suspicion of wealth, luxury and self-indulgence, believing they threatened social cohesion. When James Oglethorpe was planning the settlement of Georgia, for instance, he envisioned a utopian society in which each family would be limited to 500 acres and trade in land would be prohibited.
But the picture of the self-sufficient early settler carving a home out of the wilderness in a pre-capitalist environment is only part of the story. Historians now argue that thrift was imposed on the early colonists by the natural rigors of the world they found and for many reflected not so much a monkish wish to live simply as the desire to grow richer.
As John Wesley, the 18th-century founder of Methodism, wrote, "We ought not to prevent people from being diligent and frugal; we must exhort all Christians to gain all they can, and to save all they can; that is, in effect, to grow rich."
And Alexis de Tocqueville, the celebrated French observer of the New World, noted in 1831 that "Love of money is either the chief or a secondary motive at the bottom of everything the Americans do."
Max Weber put another dent in the thrift myth more than 50 years ago in his famous work "The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism." He showed how belief in salvation through hard work at one's "calling" laid the foundations of capitalism by encouraging men to accumulate riches. Such accumulation was fine in the eyes of the early American Protestants as long as men resisted the temptations that the riches created. Thus what Weber termed the "worldly asceticism" of America's Puritan founders also contained the seeds of that rip-roaring modern consumer capitalism that was eventually to devour it.
These days many historians believe early American colonists were even more involved in a market economy than previously thought, importing goods from England and trading with each other rather than fighting what one historian has termed "a desperate rear-guard action against the spread of capitalism."
In a paper titled "An Empire of Goods," the historian T. H. Green said that Staffordshire china was the 18th-century equivalent of Coca-Cola.
And in "Wealth of a Nation to Be: The American Colonies on the Eve of the Revolution," Alice H. Jones writes of "the substantial size and character of wealth in consumer goods" among colonists.
In fact, historians such as Shammas, Jones and Horowitz argue that the continual exhortations to be thrifty and practice self-restraint were prompted by the growth of consumerism, not the lack of it. Americans throughout the 18th century and even more in the 19th were faced with a growing array of consumer goods such as glass and china, pots and pans and decorative objects, making frugality a difficult virtue to embrace.
From 1828 to 1878, Sarah Hale, a famously prolific journalist, preached the virtues of thrift to American housewives in women's journals and tirelessly inveighed against consumption. These years saw the establishment of over 600 savings banks in the Eastern states by philanthropic bodies such as the New York Society for the Prevention of Pauperism and The Christian Disciple, a Boston religious paper, with the express aim of encouraging thrift among the working poor as well as savings institutions in public schools to teach children thrifty habits.
At around the turn of the century the intellectual climate shifted with the emergence of three thinkers who predicted an age of economic abundance in which the need to preach thriftiness would no longer be appropriate.
In "The New Basis of Civilization," published in 1907, Simon N. Patten saw the United States moving from "a pain or deficit economy" to a "pleasure or surplus economy." His conclusion, eerily similar to that reached by John Kenneth Galbraith 50 years later in "The Affluent Society," was that the country's surplus should be used to help the poor and to improve public services, not on conspicuous consumption by the rich.
Thorstein Veblen, who coined the phrase "conspicuous consumption" in 1899, also understood modern industry's potential for raising living standards across the board but carped at the rich for diverting its product to their own extravagant uses. The lesser-known George Gunton, a British immigrant, preached that shorter working hours and high wages stimulated mass consumption, profiting worker and capitalist alike.
With the American entry into World War I, the Federal Government threw its weight behind a national thrift campaign to pay for the conflict, selling $17 billion worth of Liberty Bonds and collecting $1 billion in War Savings. So successful was this campaign that Treasury Secretary Andrew Mellon tried to continue it after the peace but ran into significant opposition from business, which, with industrial productivity rising, wanted people to spend.
In New York, store windows were plastered with posters of Uncle Sam at the controls of a locomotive saying: "Full speed ahead. Clear the track for prosperity. Buy what you need now." Even The New York Times called the Government's thrift campaign irritating and wearisome. In 1924 the United States Treasury threw in the towel. Officially sanctioned consumerism had won.
Only after the World War I did the golden age of mass consumption first envisaged by Patten, Veblen and Gunton finally dawn.
In "Buy Now, Pay Later" published in 1991, Martha L. Olney says the 1920's saw a revolution in consumer taste as Americans not only increased their purchases of consumer durables but also switched from buying china, furniture, books and jewelry to newly mass-produced items such as cars, radios and household appliances.
The average American household spent $79 a year between 1889 and 1908 on consumer durables; that rose to to $267 a year from 1919 to 1928, helped by the invention of consumer credit and an explosion of advertising spending that was deductible from the excess-profits tax imposed on business in 1917.
Since then thrift has taken a backseat to American consumerism. Some intellectuals have seen the shift as an encouraging sign: In 1954 David M. Potter argued in "People of Plenty" that the country's economy of abundance had shaped its view of democracy, freedom and equality by encouraging leveling up instead of leveling down.
Today thrift and mass consumption appear incompatible. Big-spending America has long had one of the lowest rates of savings in the industrial world and last year it fell further, to 3.8 percent of average household income from 4.3 percent the year before.
In classical economic theory, low savings leads to less investment and industrial weakness. But now a revisionist school of economists led by Martin Feldstein at Harvard and Paul David at Stanford argue that buying a car or a home is like an investment because it brings long-term benefits over time, just as spending on education should be considered an investment because it increases earning power. If such spending is included, then the country's savings rate has been running at over 25 percent throughout the century, Professor David calculates.
It may be that thrift and consumerism are compatible after all.

B7); Thorstein Veblen predicted the 20th century would usher in "conspicuous consumption." Americans became caught up in a culture of buying mass-produced goods. (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: Clinton Meets Delegation From Kosovo Seeking Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
President Clinton met today with ethnic Albanian leaders from the Serbian province of Kosovo who favor a negotiated solution to their conflict with the Serbian Government in Belgrade.
The attention from Mr. Clinton was intended to display American interest and involvement in Kosovo, as well as support for Ibrahim Rugova, the president of the self-declared Republic of Kosovo, in an attempt to bolster his position both with his people and with Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President. 
 To that end, the Agency for International Development announced an increase in aid to Kosovo of $6 million, nearly doubling the original allocation.
Mr. Rugova said he urged Mr. Clinton to act swiftly to halt the growing violence between Government forces and the ethnic Albanians who make up about 90 percent of Kosovo's population.
"We urged an increased U.S. presence in Kosovo and for more protection on the part of the United States for the people of Kosovo," Mr. Rugova said after the meeting. In particular, he asked Mr. Clinton to increase the pressure on Mr. Milosevic to negotiate seriously with the Albanians in Kosovo and to stop the violence against them.
Another member of the delegation, Veton Surroi, a journalist, said Mr. Clinton assured the visitors of American support and told them that "Bosnia should not be repeated and will not be repeated." Mr. Surroi said later that he understood Mr. Clinton to mean that the West would not stand idly by and would act before it was too late.
But Mr. Surroi, in an interview, said that Kosovo was already in the first stage of war, with fighting between Serbian forces and the growing Kosovo Liberation Army, which American officials say is getting aid from Albania.
But American officials also acknowledge that the ethnic Albanian rebel group, in its fight for independence, is undermining the political credibility of Mr. Rugova and his hastily assembled negotiating team. Some members of the team, like Bujar Bukoshi, who holds the title of prime minister of the unofficial Kosovo government, live in exile and are considered close to the rebel group.
Without rapid international pressure on Mr. Milosevic to negotiate, Mr. Bukoshi said, "I'm afraid we will lose very quickly our credibility."
Pressed by the Americans, Mr. Milosevic met Mr. Rugova on May 15 with the United States Ambassador to Macedonia, Christopher Hill. In return for Mr. Milosevic's compliance, Washington pressed the Europeans to suspend the introduction of tough economic sanctions against Mr. Milosevic, including a ban on foreign investment in Serbia.
While that sanction is only suspended, Mr. Surroi says there is not enough pressure on Mr. Milosevic to stop the violence or to turn the negotiations into productive talks.
While Washington is pressing the delegations to continue the talks on Monday, Mr. Surroi said that was unlikely. "It doesn't make sense to have talks while the Serbs are continuing the fighting," Mr. Surroi said.
Washington and its allies also oppose independence for Kosovo, fearing that a redrawing of boundaries could restart a wider war in the Balkans. But even Mr. Rugova says that autonomy within Serbia is no longer an option, and that Kosovo must eventually become sovereign.
Today in Luxembourg, foreign ministers of NATO members and partner countries, including Russia, committed themselves to drafting quick contingency plans to deploy troops on Kosovo's borders if the fighting threatens to spill over. But preventive deployments, requiring a large number of troops, would not stop the fighting in Kosovo, and would probably fail to prevent the infiltration of military supplies from Albania, American officials say.
NATO also approved military exercises in Albania, a NATO partner, and other activities intended to "contribute to the stability of the neighbors," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today.

HEADLINE: Risky Business;
A Set Fee for Each Patient Gives Doctors More Control and More of a Financial Stake

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Even as a new Government-financed study raises questions about an increasingly popular way of paying for health services, many doctors and hospitals in New York City and a number of other big cities are embracing it. And while this form of managed care -- known as capitation -- gives health care providers more control, it also carries with it more financial risk.
Some doctors love it, and some hate it. Few patients have heard of it. But after catching on in many parts of California and some other states, capitation is now rapidly rolling into networks of doctors and hospitals not only in New York City and the area around it -- notoriously one of the last places to adopt changes in health care delivery -- but also in places like Philadelphia, Boston and Atlanta. 
 The new Government-financed study, however, raises some questions about the trend. It found that patients served by doctors receiving per capita payments were less satisfied with important aspects of their care than people in the same type of health maintenance organization whose doctors were reimbursed for the specific services they provided.
In the prevailing system of managed care in most of the country, health maintenance organizations typically pay doctors a fee for each medical service, though less than traditional insurers pay. The H.M.O. uses various ways to keep down costs, such as leaning on doctors deemed to be ordering too many tests, referrals to specialists and hospital stays. If at the end of the year money from the premiums paid by employees and their employers is left over, the H.M.O. keeps it; if expenses have exceeded premiums, the H.M.O. is stuck with the loss.
Under capitation, the H.M.O. pays groups of doctors -- both primary care doctors and specialists -- one lump sum per enrollee. The amount reflects an estimated cost of caring for every person who enrolled for care with those doctors and goes beyond earlier experiments in which primary care doctors received much smaller sums for providing basic care to patients. If at the end of the year, money is left, the doctors, not the H.M.O., keep it; if no money is left, the doctors absorb the loss. So, the doctors themselves have a financial stake in holding down costs.
That means the H.M.O. no longer has to play the bad-cop role of denying patients tests and other procedures. Rather, they let the doctors figure out how to rein in costs.
Many doctors and hospitals -- where capitation works in similar ways -- are jumping at the opportunity to reclaim some of the decision-making that insurers have taken from them in recent years. They are betting that they can manage the care of patients better, and at lower cost, than an H.M.O.'s staff. And they hope to keep more of the health care dollar for themselves or to spend on their patients, instead of rewarding an H.M.O.'s executives and shareholders.
"In an ideal world, there will be more white coats and fewer suits making decisions about what patients get," said Dr. Leonard Fromer, a board member of the Prairie Medical Group, a physicians group in Santa Monica, Calif., that is largely paid on a per capita basis.
For one thing, capitation gives doctors a stronger incentive to provide preventive care. "We spend money up front to improve the health care of a given population," said Dr. Ken Brin, medical director of the Summit Medical Group of 85 doctors in Summit, N.J., which gets per capita payments for one patient in five. "A capitation payments program will provide a better type of medical care."
But some doctors are resisting the trend, saying that they do not want to get into the insurance business and risk the losses that a lot of big insurers have suffered from underestimating costs. Other doctors fear they might be tempted to cut corners to maintain their incomes.
Their protests have not stopped the capitation movement, which has been in use by doctors at Kaiser Permanente in California for decades, was later adopted by other health plans in Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco, and has dominated health maintenance organizations in those cities since the early 1990's. It is also strong in Chicago and Denver, among other cities. Nationally, the number of doctors with at least one capitation contract surged almost 50 percent, to 174,000, between 1994 and 1997, according to the American Medical Association. Just over one-third of the nation's 483,000 doctors now have capitation contracts, although these represent only about one-fourth of their revenues.
Much of the recent growth has been in the East. In New York, a stronghold of traditional medicine, almost all hospitals are either experimenting with capitation or studying how to deal with it, said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. His organization is promoting the concept and "trying to help our hospitals do it," he said.
The doctor-hospital network of Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx and Westchester County provides services under a per-capita system for 60,000 members of nine health plans, including Aetna U.S. Healthcare, NylCare, United Healthcare, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, an Oxford Medicare plan, and Health First, a Medicaid plan, said Dr. Spencer Foreman, president of Montefiore. The system covers 50,000 more for hospital care only.
In Manhattan, Beth Israel Medical Center and several hundred affiliated doctors provide per capita coverage for 43,000 people under Aetna, Nylcare and Health First plans. Beth Israel and its partner, Roosevelt-St. Luke's, expect to double that roster in the next year. Others have smaller programs.
Oxford Health Plans, a troubled giant among New York insurers, said in March that it was pursuing capitation contracts that would transfer to medical providers "a significant portion of the medical cost risk" for Medicare and Medicaid patients. Empire has a few per capita contracts with physician groups.
In Boston, Partners Health Care System covers 200,000 members with per capita contracts. In Philadelphia, the University of Pennsylvania Health System covers 160,000 that way. In the Penn hospital system, 25 percent of the patients are covered under capitation contracts for both doctors and hospitals, compared with less than 5 percent five years ago, said Dr. Alan Hillman, director of the center for health policy at the University of Pennsylvania.
Most patients will not know if their doctor is in a capitation plan or not, said Ruth Levin, a vice president of the Beth Israel-Roosevelt-St. Luke's partnership. Either way, they will pay the same fees and premiums and, if they do not have a referral from their primary doctor, the same added charges for using a specialist.
Advocates of capitation contend that it delivers better care at lower cost, in large part because it shifts decision-making away from bureaucrats to medical professionals.
"Our doctors are not going to call an insurance company's '800' number to get permission to do an M.R.I. scan," said Ellen Zane, president of a physician network in the Partners Healthcare System in Boston. "We're taking the risk; we want control."
Hospitals and doctors groups also have an added inducement to take measures to prevent illnesses. For example, Dr. Brin at Summit Medical said, "We may spend more money up front for a nurse case manager to teach a patient with congestive heart failure how to take his weight every day and check his ankles for swelling." His group uses such strategies "to keep the patients healthy, so they don't end up in the emergency room," he said.
The system is credited with helping rein in costs in the tightfisted Los Angeles health care market. After leaning on H.M.O.'s for several years, employers paid an average of $99 in monthly premiums for each member, sick or well, in 1997. That was well below the $130 national average and two-thirds of premiums in New York and Boston.
Capitation is not without its flaws. Many consumer groups and doctors say that by forcing doctors to fixate on costs, the system threatens to undermine the physician-patient relationship and encourage the denial of necessary care.
"That's where the public has to be careful, why they need to look for quality physicians and a commitment historically to provide the best of care," said Dr. Bruce Spivey, president of Columbia-Cornell Care, a group of 1,700 physicians affiliated with the recently merged New York and Presbyterian Hospital.
He said the vast majority of his doctors had agreed to accept capitation contracts eventually, but a "substantial vocal minority" were holding back and some specialists would always reject the idea.
In the Government-financed study of 2,748 Massachusetts state employees, which has not been published, patients whose primary doctors were paid on a per capita basis rated them lower on their level of concern, familiarity with individual problems and providing answers to all questions, said Dana Gelb Safran, a senior policy analyst with the Health Institute at the New England Medical Center in Boston who led the study.
Out-of-pocket costs were significantly lower for patients in the per capita group, however. Under both payment systems, doctors rated about the same on referrals, thoroughness of exams and counseling on staying well.
The reluctance of some doctors to become involved is understandable. Those in smaller practices often lack the experience and expensive information systems to forecast costs accurately. Accepting a low-ball offer by an aggressive health plan could ruin them.
Joseph Newhouse, a Harvard University economist who advises Congress on Medicare issues, said forcing a solo practitioner to weigh medical costs patient by patient "should be outlawed."
A number of physicians find the whole idea of capitation repugnant. Dr. Richard Daum, a cardiologist and internist in Concord, Mass., said his four-doctor group planned to drop its contract with an H.M.O. that recently announced a switch to per capita payments, even though the doctors might lose 200 patients from their roster of 14,000. "I won't work under capitation," Dr. Daum said. "It's against my religion."
Yet, even where opposition is strong, capitation continues to make inroads. "Most physicians do not want to get into these arrangements," said Dr. Martin Edelstein, a family practice doctor in Great Neck, N.Y., who is president of the North Shore Independent Physicians Association. But his local hospitals, the North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System, already have per capita contracts for 15,000 people and are preparing for more.
"The insurance companies tell us, 'This is what the future is,' " Dr. Edelstein said. "We figure you've got to prepare for this eventuality."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Says Unemployment Has Reached Record High

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 29

 BODY:
Japan's economic distress deepened today as the Government reported the highest unemployment rate on record, bond yields tumbled to new lows and the yen hit a seven-year low, partly on fears that regional instability could send the world's second-largest economy into a tailspin.
The combination of rising joblessness and a falling currency intensified worries that Japan is not only stuck in a recession, but is also verging on a deflationary spiral. The fear is of a vicious cycle of declining prices, weakening profits, unemployment and falling demand that could ripple through other troubled economies of Asia and the United States economy. 
 "I think we are in the early stage of a deflationary spiral," said Haruo Shimada, an economics professor at Keio University. "It may very well come this year."
The yen's slide reflected selling by traders who turned to the dollar for safety after Pakistan conducted five nuclear tests Thursday, raising fears of a new arms race with India and worsening instability in Asia.
The Japanese currency slipped further after the Government said today that unemployment had hit a record 4.1 percent in April, up from 3.9 percent in March. The yen hit 139.20 in the morning here and ended trading in New York today at 138.90 yen to the dollar. The yen has fallen more than 16 percent compared with its level a year earlier.
American officials have been deeply worried about the economic problems in Japan. Concern is also growing that Japanese Government officials have few tools left to revive the economy. The Bank of Japan, the central bank, has been pursuing an easy monetary policy for years and its benchmark lending rate to banks is at half a percent, so there is little room for the bank to drop rates further to help fuel the economy.
"It's quite scary," said Andrew Shipley, an economist at Schroders Japan Ltd. Referring to the Bank of Japan, he said, "Japan's economy is sliding into recession without the B.O.J. able to cushion the blow."
Parliament finally passed long-awaited legislation today that will relax the fiscal austerity law and allow the Government to spend more on the economy and cut taxes to aid growth, part of a $120 billion invigoration package that will start trickling into the economy this summer. But there are already murmurings about the need for more stimulants.
Koji Omi, chief of the Economic Planning Agency, acknowledged today that the economic troubles are becoming increasingly severe, particularly in employment and production. The April unemployment data showed that the jobless rate for males was 4.2 percent and that only 55 jobs exist for every 100 applicants, the worst readings in two decades.
Those statistics make Japan's unemployment rate nearly the same as that in the United States, where joblessness historically has been far higher. But anyone in Japan who has worked for even one hour in the final week of the month is considered fully employed. Some economists say unemployment could double if calculated by American methods.
After the unemployment report was released, yields on the benchmark 10-year bond, a barometer of economic weakness, fell to an all-time low of 1.19 percent. By contrast, 10-year Treasury bonds in the United States yield about 5.55 percent.
The Economic Planning Agency also may finally acknowledge, possibly next month, that the economy is in a "downward phase," said a report in the Yomiuri Shimbun, a leading national Japanese daily. Economists have been saying for months that the economy is in a recession, but until now the Government has been describing the economy as simply "sluggish" with the "severity getting worse." Officials at the Economic Planning Agency refused to comment on the report.
Some economists are particularly worried about further weakness in the yen beyond the level of 139 to the dollar because that would escalate the risk of currency devaluations by other Asian nations trying to help keep their exports competitively priced.
"It certainly could get to 150," said Peter Morgan, an economist at HSBC Securities Japan Ltd. "The fundamentals don't look close to a reversal."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE OVERVIEW;
LEADERS IN INDIA AND IN PAKISTAN TONE DOWN CRISIS

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 29

 BODY:
A day after Pakistan matched India by setting off its own underground nuclear tests, both nations began talking of new arrangements that would stabilize their rivalry and minimize the risk of war.
But neither seems ready to consider an agreement not to deploy nuclear weapons, especially missiles. And it is too soon to say whether the day's tone was merely a respite after turbulent events of this month. 
 In Washington, officials expressed skepticism that a calmer reality had set in. American intelligence reported that Pakistan may be preparing new tests, and the State Department called the situation grave. Page A5.
Even as officials in India and Pakistan were speaking as though they wanted to step back from the brink of military confrontation, there were many signs that the situation remains volatile. Among these was a statement by the scientist overseeing Pakistan's test, who described the devices as warheads that were being prepared for mounting on a medium-range missile that Pakistan tested last month.
In the Indian Parliament, several prominent opposition leaders, including I. K. Gujral, a former Prime Minister, appealed to Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee not to transfer India's nuclear weapons to the armed forces immediately, a step that Defense Minister George Fernandes has said was already approved.
"If that has been done, God help us," Mr. Gujral said.
Mr. Vajpayee tried to soothe opposition leaders and offered to reopen broad-based diplomatic negotiations with Pakistan to discuss a nonaggression pact. Such talks were proposed on Thursday by Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, after he announced that Pakistan had set off five nuclear tests at a remote site in the southwestern desert.
"I welcome the statement of Pakistan's Prime Minister that Islamabad is prepared for negotiations," Mr. Vajpayee said in Parliament. "It is very good and we should have dialogue."
As for the suggestion of a nonaggression pact, a longstanding Pakistani proposal that has always bogged down in the bitter differences over the divided territory of Kashmir, Mr. Vajpayee added, "If a new offer is made, we are prepared to probe it."
In Islamabad, Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan suggested that both nations sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty of 1994.
But the proposal is fraught with difficulty because India has said it will consider accepting "some provisions" of the treaty only if the global pact is revised to include India as an established nuclear power, along with the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France, and only if the other powers pledge the eventual elimination of all nuclear weapons, something they all have refused to do.
Mr. Vajpayee also repeated an offer made before Pakistan's tests, for India to promise not to be the first to use nuclear weapons. But India is certain to demand a similar pledge from Pakistan, and Pakistan has shown a reluctance to make such a promise, fearing that in case of attack by India's far more powerful conventional forces, it would need nuclear arms to defend itself.
Mr. Sharif spent the day in discussions with his Cabinet that focused on using the emergency powers that he declared during the night to shore up Pakistan's battered economy, an economy that is sure to be weakened by the sanctions imposed by the United States, Japan and others in retaliation for the nuclear tests.
On Friday the emergency powers were extended to include severe restrictions on access to the courts in civil cases, a step intended to prevent legal challenges to a harsh crackdown on tax evaders, smugglers and profiteers that Mr. Sharif has promised.
On the military side, Mr. Ayub Khan said Pakistan felt it had established an equilibrium that would discourage war. Since Pakistan and India were carved out of the British-ruled subcontinent in 1947, they have fought three wars; Kashmir was a factor in each one. Since India detonated its nuclear devices on May 11 and 13, at a site near the Pakistan border, there have been widespread fears of war in both countries.
"We have restored the military and strategic balance," Mr. Ayub Khan said in an interview with the BBC. A former army officer and son of Pakistan's first military dictator, the Foreign Minister said Pakistan had been increasingly vulnerable to conventional military attack since 1990, when the United States, saying Pakistan was secretly developing nuclear weapons, cut off military sales. American materiel had sustained Pakistan's armed forces since the 1950's.
"Since then, Pakistan has been at a tremendous conventional military disadvantage," Mr. Ayub Khan said.
While many opposition and military analysts in India and Pakistan have been shocked by the nuclear tests and the ensuing polemics, fearing they would trigger a war that might involve nuclear weapons, the view that open possession of nuclear weapons could eventually be a stabilizing factor has been gaining ground.
One who appears to share the Pakistan Foreign Minister's view is India's army chief, Gen. V. P. Malik, who told reporters after Pakistan's tests, "It is better this way."
"If there was any ambiguity earlier about Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, it no longer exists," General Malik said.
While cautioning that Indian generals have never sought to make Government policy, General Malik said India had no plans to attack Pakistan, and had not mobilized any troops except those confronting Pakistani forces across the cease-fire line in Kashmir.
"I don't see a war scenario on either side," he said. "I don't see a warlike situation."
Another sign that tension is diminishing came from India's Interior Minister, Lal Krishna Advani, who was accused of warmongering after warning Pakistan last week that India's tests had shifted the balance of power in India's favor.
Mr. Advani, one of the most hawkish of the Hindu nationalists who control the Government, also said India intended to adopt a "pro-active" military policy in Kashmir, including "hot pursuit" of Pakistan-backed insurgents operating across the cease-fire line.
But in a speech in Parliament on Thursday, at about the time Pakistan was detonating its tests, Mr. Advani said his reference to "hot pursuit" had not been intended as a threat to send troops into Pakistani-ruled areas in Kashmir. He also pulled back from his assertions about India's enhanced military power, saying India viewed nuclear weapons solely as a "deterrent" and had tested them only to match Pakistan's nuclear program.
"We do not want to be subjected to diplomatic coercion," he said.
The scientist who oversaw Pakistan's tests, Dr. Abdul Qadeer Khan, described the devices tested as "ready-to-fire warheads" that had been miniaturized so they could fit onto Ghauri missiles, which Pakistan tested in early April at a range it put at about 900 miles.
In a telephone interview today with the Voice of Germany radio network, Dr. Qadeer Khan also said Pakistan was "ready to cap" Ghauri missiles with the warheads.
Mr. Ayub Khan made a similar claim in the BBC interview, saying Pakistan would "naturally be serially producing nuclear warheads and missiles."
But a later BBC report quoted other officials in Islamabad as saying there had been no decision to arm and deploy the Ghauri, a missile built with technology that Pakistan got from China and North Korea.
Western arms experts have questioned whether either India or Pakistan could move quickly toward deployment. Pakistan has test-fired the Ghauri only once and India's counterpart, the Agni, has been test-fired only three times, twice unsuccessfully, and not since 1994.
Jack Mendelsohn, an analyst with the Arms Control Association in Washington, told the BBC on Thursday that the lack of missile testing and a shortage of fuel for nuclear weapons would cause lengthy delays. In the meantime, he said, "hopefully we can walk them back" from deployment.
Similar hopes were expressed by several prominent Indian parliamentarians during a debate today. Mr. Gujral, who stepped down as Prime Minister after a defeat in the general election in March, said he learned during his 11 months in office that even then India had a reliable "nuclear deterrent," even though nuclear arms were not deployed.
For years Western intelligence reports have said India had a small stockpile of nuclear weapons, stored away from front-line forces and probably in disassembled form.
Mr. Gujral urged Prime Minister Vajpayee to open negotiations with China, Pakistan and the Western powers to draw up security arrangements that would make deployment unnecessary, and to think carefully about matters that he said Mr. Vajpayee and his ministers had ignored.
He said these included issues that the United States and the Soviet Union had tussled with for decades during the cold war -- the costs of building and maintaining a large nuclear arsenal, command and control systems to make the arms safe and an appropriate political and military strategy for their use.
"Jingoism and warmongering by a nation of India's size is an extremely dangerous thing," he said. "You can create an atmosphere of war without intending to, so for God's sake, be careful."

HEADLINE: Ending an Era, ABC News Chief Relinquishes Control

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
An era ended yesterday, when Roone Arledge, who has reigned over ABC News for 21 years -- longer than any other news executive in television history -- announced he would turn over leadership to the division's president, David Westin, starting on Monday.
Mr. Arledge, who will be 67 next month, will remain chairman of ABC News and will be a consultant to Mr. Westin. Mr. Westin, 45, will remain president. 
 In March 1997, Mr. Arledge named Mr. Westin to succeed him, without saying when. Now Mr. Westin will wield the decision-making power alone, concluding 15 months of power sharing with Mr. Arledge that left clouds of uncertainty over some ABC News ventures.
Although Mr. Westin, a lawyer and former president of the ABC Television Network, has had limited experience in journalism, Mr. Arledge praised him for having "integrity and a strong vision for ABC News," and said he was confident Mr. Westin would "do a terrific job."
Mr. Westin, who has worked for ABC seven years, is taking over when ABC News faces several major concerns. The Walt Disney Company, its parent, has demanded trimmer budgets; the ABC network has been in a slump, often delivering smaller audiences to the news division's programs, and "World News Tonight," the evening news program with Peter Jennings as anchor, has slipped to second place in the Nielsen ratings behind the "NBC Nightly News." The biggest problem is "Good Morning America," which has seen viewers leave in droves, and now ranks far behind the top-ranked morning show, NBC's "Today."
"Following a legend is always a challenge," Mr. Westin said of Mr. Arledge, adding that a greater challenge will be determining the role of television news in the future. "In a new world where there is almost unlimited access to information, what is our role? How do we make sure we have a special place with our viewers?"
In 1977, when Mr. Arledge, then president of ABC Sports, became president of ABC News, he, too, was criticized for not having sufficient news experience. Yet he had revolutionized sports television, and not just in production techniques. He was the first to refuse to allow event sponsors or league presidents to dictate which announcers would cover an event. He pushed ABC Sports to cover social and economic issues in sports, and gave free rein to the opinionated commentator Howard Cosell.
"Roone will go down in history as one of the true visionaries of our business," the president of ABC Inc., Robert A. Iger, said in a statement.
Starting in a production truck at an Alabama-Georgia college football game in 1960, Mr. Arledge became the most innovative producer in sports history. He created "up close and personal" coverage of the Olympic Games, and invented "Wide World of Sports" and "Monday Night Football," as well as most of the now-commonplace enhancements like instant replays, slow-motion replays, underwater cameras and on-screen graphics.
He translated some of those techniques to news. When he took over, ABC News was the least well-regarded network news division, and the lowest-rated. He raided other networks for young, talented producers and collected as many high-profile on-camera journalists as he could. He started the news magazine programs "20/20" and "Prime Time Live," expanded the Sunday morning program "This Week" and invented the late-night program "Nightline."
Sometimes criticized for creating a star system, Mr. Arledge believed that such stars as Barbara Walters, Diane Sawyer, Peter Jennings, Hugh Downs, Sam Donaldson and Ted Koppel gave ABC News a distinct identity.
Within a decade, ABC's news programs had the best ratings and were widely considered to be of the best quality. In 1995, ABC News was the first network news division to be given a Gold Baton for overall excellence from the Alfred I. Dupont-Columbia University Awards.
Mr. Arledge has also been criticized for being disdainful of administrative duties, yet slow to delegate authority or to make decisions. Some journalists complained that he was remote, and seemed most interested in talking to the highly paid star journalists.
Asked about his legacy, Mr. Arledge said yesterday: "ABC Sports hardly existed when I first started, and I built it into the greatest sports television organization there has ever been, at its peak. ABC News had very little respect or sense of importance, and one reason I took that job when I could have taken other jobs was I felt it was a resource this country needed, and I built that into the No. 1 news division in television."
But Mr. Arledge has also presided during the recent ratings decline of "World News Tonight," and some say he paid too little attention to "Good Morning America" when, already in trouble, it was shifted from the entertainment division to the news division two years ago.
Still, he insisted that ABC News remained the strongest of the three network news divisions.
"NBC has some ratings," he said. "But if you look at its staff of people and correspondents, I'd love to match them up one-on-one and see who's the better.
"We're a little like today's Yankees -- star after star after star."
