HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Wake-Up Call: Truisms Of U.S. Policy Totter

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Several of the hopes and assumptions of the post-cold-war era have been shaken by this month's momentous events in Asia. The collapse of President Suharto's rule in Indonesia and the detonation of nuclear devices by India and Pakistan has forced the rethinking in Washington and other Western capitals of ideas that had come to be policy truisms.
As a member of President Clinton's Cabinet said today, "the motto for this month in this town has turned out to be, 'Back to the drawing board.' " 
 For one thing, the widely acknowledged ascendancy of United States commercial and economic interests over strategic and other goals, which led to the subordination of human-rights considerations in the region, for instance, is likely to be questioned much more sharply than previously.
Even before Indonesia was gripped by turmoil, it was evident that United States policy there, based on trade and tacit backing for Mr. Suharto, had reached a dead end. And even before the nuclear tests, Congress had acted to ban satellite exports to China, in part because of fears that Chinese missile expertise may have already made its way to Pakistan.
The prospect of nuclear war is once again real, and that is likely to shake official Washington and at least part of the American public out of the easy assumption that foreign policy does not matter much any more. Sketchy foreign-policy reports on the network television newscasts are suddenly longer and far more substantive.
Mr. Clinton's visit to China next month was to have promoted trade between the two countries, as part of the Administration's efforts to help American companies expand their overseas markets; the subtext of that strategy has been the conviction that trade helps sell democratic ideas.
At least for the moment, wider trade with China seems dubious. Social conservatives and political liberals will find more of an audience for their moral agendas in the months to come, and dollar diplomacy will suffer.
Mr. Clinton had planned a trip later in the year to India and Pakistan, also with trade promotion as a major component. Having imposed sanctions against both countries, the President is rethinking the whole trip.
The month's events have also reinforced the impression that religious fundamentalism and religion-based nationalism are the most disruptive forces facing Western policy makers. The exchange of nuclear demonstrations was set off by a minority Indian Government dominated by a hard-line Hindu nationalist movement. Islamic fundamentalism is a political threat or a governmental reality in much of the Middle East, and the situation in Israel is complicated by the influence of a rigorously Orthodox Jewish minority upon the Government.
For the Hindus who danced in the streets of New Delhi, for the Pakistani leaders who boasted of becoming the first Islamic nuclear power and for Iraq and Libya, both of which have worked on nuclear bombs, the acquisition of weapons of mass destruction is not only a means of achieving policy goals but also an act of defiance of the rest of the world -- especially the nuclear powers. India has long been a nuclear power, and has been known as such by everyone. But it has never been an officially declared nuclear power.
It has long been deeply unhappy at its exclusion from the nuclear "club," as defined by the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty of 1968, which divides the world into haves -- the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France -- and have-nots. India is permanently excluded under the terms of the treaty because it exploded its first nuclear device after the treaty was signed.
"They want status, and they want it desperately," said Michael Krepon of the Henry L. Stimson Center in Washington, who is an authority on military and nuclear affairs in the region. "They want those at the high table to acknowledge them as an equal. But that would require the amendment of the treaty, which involves 180 countries or so, and it isn't going to happen."
Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee all but said as much on Wednesday, telling the Indian Parliament that the bomb was "India's due, the right of one-sixth of mankind."
While the United States and the Soviet Union managed to survive for almost half a century as mutually antagonistic nuclear powers, with each deterring the other from making use of its nuclear arsenal, the prospects of India and Pakistan's doing likewise are not encouraging, for a number of reasons.
Moscow and Washington had decades to feel each other out, and at the beginning of that period each had only a few bombs and no missiles. When the missiles came along, the two countries narrowly averted a war in the Cuban missile crisis of 1962. Pakistan and India will have the benefit of no such grace period now that both have bombs and the means to deliver them.
Although the point is open to debate, the religious animosity between India and Pakistan seems even more intense than the ideological rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union. At any rate, the United States and the Soviet Union had never fought against each other; India and Pakistan have already fought three wars.
Finally, there is the matter of geography. The main population centers of the United States and the Soviet Union are separated by thousands of miles of land and sea, while India and Pakistan are contiguous, their troops face each other in Kashmir, and New Delhi is a mere 250 miles from Lahore, Pakistan.
Even if India and Pakistan had sophisticated early-warning systems, which they do not, there would be virtually no margin for error.
The experts are deeply pessimistic. Thomas Graham Jr., a retired arms negotiator who now heads the Lawyers' Alliance for World Security, said it was fanciful to think that India and Pakistan would restrain themselves, and he also suggested that other countries would now be emboldened to push ahead with nuclear weapons development.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Sending Russia $670 Million to Help Stabilize Ruble

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 29

 BODY:
Russia received a boost today when the International Monetary Fund said it would disburse $670 million by the end of June. That, along with conditions the I.M.F. placed on the Government, should be enough to stabilize the Russian financial markets, fund officials said.
"The Government's economic policies are wholly coherent, and there is no reason for devaluation," said John Odling-Smee, the I.M.F.'s chief expert on Russia. 
 But Russian Government officials and investment bankers remain worried that the assistance may be a case of too little, too late. And Russian officials have begun to explore the establishment of a multi-billion-dollar fund to help stabilize the ruble.
Such a fund could be organized by the I.M.F. or by the seven leading industrialized nations. The idea would be to create a line of credit that the Central Bank could draw on if its reserves were depleted.
Russian officials stress that the money in the proposed fund, which they project should amount to about $10 billion, would not necessarily be used, but that foreign investors would find it comforting to know that it was available.
Mr. Odling-Smee acknowledged today that the Russians had been inquiring about the possibility of additional financing. Both the I.M.F. and the Clinton Administration, however, said the Kremlin had not formally asked for more money.
So far, Russia's financial markets remained under siege. Stocks fell today after the Moody's investment service downgraded its ratings for Russian bonds.
Reflecting continued anxiety over the stability of the ruble, the Kremlin has sent a high-level delegation to Washington. Anatoly B. Chubais, the pro-reform former Kremlin aide, and Sergei Vasilyev, a senior Kremlin aide, met today with Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers.
The mission was authorized by President Boris N. Yeltsin, who has appealed to Western leaders for "moral support." One aim was to persuade Washington to support Mr. Yeltsin's program to cope with the financial crisis in the hope that this would help calm jittery investors.
Today, President Clinton praised Mr. Yeltsin's efforts. But he did not say whether the United States would be willing to help organize a currency stabilization fund or offer other assistance if it was needed.
"Russia's new economic plan puts in place a solid strategy for fiscal reform," Mr. Clinton said in a statement.
Much of the Yeltsin Government's plan was required by the I.M.F. as a condition for receiving the latest loan disbursement. The broad aim of many of the measures is to reduce Russia's budget deficit to 5 percent of its gross domestic product.
Its large budget deficit has made Russia particularly vulnerable to the effects of global economic turmoil. Moscow finances much of its deficit by selling treasury bills to foreign investors. As concerns over emerging markets has spread, many investors have been dumping the treasury bills and converting the proceeds to dollars, putting enormous pressure on the ruble.
Announcing its deficit-reduction program, the Yeltsin Government today named a tough-minded former Finance Minister to head the State Tax Service. The new minister, Boris Fyodorov, 40, will replace Aleksandr Pochinok as Russia's top tax collector. Russia's episodic efforts to crack down on tax cheats have been generally ineffective, and Mr. Fyodorov has long argued for stronger action.
The Kremlin has also promised to take swift action to collect back taxes. At least 5 billion rubles -- about $830 million -- in tax arrears is to be collected in June.
At least 20 major companies that owe taxes will be targeted. The Government has promised to declare companies bankrupt if they refuse or cannot pay.
To expedite the collection of tax arrears from Russia's oil companies, tax payments will be taken from their export earnings. By July, the payment of taxes will be required if an oil company wants to ship its crude on export pipelines.
The Government is also reversing its earlier decision to help Russia's oil companies deal with the downturn in world oil prices by reducing excise taxes.
The Kremlin has also promised to raise $2.5 billion by speeding up the auctions of state property after the financial situation stabilizes.
Still, Moscow has pledged to take action against tax delinquents before, only to retreat in the face of political pressure.
And even if the Russians begin to carry out their plan, it may not be enough to reassure nervous investors who believe Russia's Central Bank simply does not have enough funds to defend the ruble.
The Central Bank's reserves for stabilizing the ruble have dropped to $14.5 billion from $23 billion in October.
If the I.M.F. or the Group of Seven nations will not provide funds for a currency stabilization fund, the Russians have another option. They could take loans from private banks and use the money to restructure their short-term debt.
Russian Finance Ministry officials say they have already received proposals for loans from several major banks. But the I.M.F. has cautioned against this approach, saying the interest rates would be far too high during the current financial crisis.
"I would not advise the Russian Government to do it until it is clear that it really does have control over the fiscal situation and until stability has returned to the financial markets," Mr. Odling-Smee said.
In general, the I.M.F. predicts that investors will be heartened by the Russian program and that further financing will not be needed.
"I would expect stability in the financial markets to be established fairly soon," Mr. Odling-Smee said.
One leading investment banker, however, disagreed.
"The markets want to see more money," he said. "They want to know that the Central Bank would be able to tap additional funds if its reserves ran low."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Slump, Ending Worst Month Since October
Stocks retreated from early gains to end lower, hurt by weakness in computing issues and growing concern that political and economic turmoil in Asia could damage United States corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell for a fifth time in six sessions, losing 70.25 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,899.95, its first close below 8,900 since April 28. Broader gauges also fell. 
 The declines made May the worst month for the market since October, when Asia's troubles first damaged stock prices. For the month, the Dow lost 1.8 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500 lost 1.9 percent and the Nasdaq composite index lost 4.8 percent. Page D3.
 
Bond prices strengthened. The 30-year Treasury yield fell to 5.80 percent from 5.82, extending a trend that has pushed yields to the lowest levels in nearly two months. D3.
 
Russia Getting I.M.F. Money Soon
The International Monetary Fund said it would disburse $670 million to Russia by the end of June. The I.M.F. said the disbursement should help stabilize Russian financial markets. But Russian Government officials and investment bankers remain worried that the assistance may be too little, too late. A3.
 
April Incomes and Spending Rose
The Government said personal income growth accelerated in April and consumer spending increased, signs that domestic demand was helping to offset the effect of the Asian crisis on the United States economy. D2.
 
Japan's Malaise Worsens
Japanese economic distress deepened as the Government reported the highest unemployment rate on record and the yen weakened to another seven-year low against the dollar. Fears intensified that the world's second-largest economy is not only mired in a recession but may be verging on a deflationary spiral that could hurt other countries. D2.
 
CBS Wins Help From Stations
CBS announced an agreement with affiliated stations to share in the cost of rights to National Football League games this fall. The agreement represents the first instance of a network's receiving direct financial help from affiliates to pay for programming. A1.
 
End of an Era at ABC News
Roone Arledge will surrender leadership of ABC News on Monday, ending a 21-year reign that made him the longest-running news executive in television history. Although Mr. Arledge, 67, left, will keep the title of chairman, the decision-making power will rest with the president, David Westin, 45. The transfer comes at a time when the parent company, Disney, is demanding smaller news budgets and ABC's evening news show has yielded the No. 1 rating to NBC News. A6.
 
Robertson Stephens Is Sold
BankBoston, as expected, announced that it would acquire BankAmerica Corporation's securities unit, Robertson Stephens. BankBoston, the second-largest bank in New England, will pay $400 million in cash to BankAmerica and put $400 million in a pool to persuade the firm's partners and key employees to remain after the sale. D3.
 
Suharto Pressed to Return Riches
Indonesia's new Government annnounced several measures aimed at curbing the economic favoritism that had permitted the Suharto family's fortunes to flourish. The measures came as popular support intensified for a return of an estimated $40 billion that the former leader and his relatives amassed during his four decades in power. A1.
 
Clinical Trials of Drugs Criticized
Federal investigators said patients who participated in clinical trials of new drugs were often exposed to unsafe and unethical practices because no one policed the research to protect their interests. A8.

HEADLINE: Fed's No. 2 Chosen to Lead District of Columbia's Financial Board

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
More than seven years after she headed a panel that warned of a looming fiscal crisis in the District of Columbia, Alice M. Rivlin was selected by President Clinton today as the chairwoman of the District's financial control board.
Ms. Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve Board, will replace Andrew F. Brimmer. 
 Mr. Brimmer, an economist, was appointed the control board's first chairman in 1995, when Washington was already suffering from the troubles Ms. Rivlin's panel had predicted. He announced in March that he did not intend to serve another term.
The White House said in a statement that Ms. Rivlin would retain her position with the Federal Reserve and would assume her new duties after a 90-day transition during which Mr. Brimmer and two of his colleagues, Stephen D. Harlan and Constance B. Newman, will remain beyond the expiration next week of their three-year terms.
The two other members of the control board, Edward Singletary and Joyce Ladner, are stepping down next week.
The appointment of Ms. Rivlin comes at a time of major change in the capital's political landscape. Last week, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., a vocal critic of the control board and of Mr. Brimmer in particular, announced that he would not seek a fifth four-year term.
Mr. Barry's decision was hailed by Republican lawmakers. The control board has been praised by Republicans for turning Washington's fortunes around despite its sometimes cantankerous relationship with the mayor.
Hostility grew as the control board steadily shifted power from Mr. Barry to itself and its surrogates, leaving the mayor to supervise only a few marginal agencies.
District officials are now projecting budget surpluses for the 1998 and 1999 fiscal years. By law, the control board will be shut down after four consecutive balanced budgets.
An Administration official said that the White House did not anticipate any problems with Ms. Rivlin's serving dual roles, but added that the Administration might propose legislation that would remove any potential obstacle.
In a statement, Ms. Rivlin, 67, said, "I am delighted with the chance to serve the city as we build the foundation to return decision-making powers to the elected officials of the District."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Market Falls Again, Ending Worst Month Since October

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated from early gains and ended lower yesterday, dragged down by weakness in technology issues. The selloff came as concern grew that continued turmoil in Asia could damage corporate profits in the United States.
"Things have to calm down in Asia before investors become more aggressive," said Joseph E. Stocke, a money manager at the Meridian Investment Company. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the fifth time in six sessions. It dropped 70.25 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,899.95. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.78 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,090.82. The Nasdaq composite index fell 15.75 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,778.87.
For all of May, the Dow lost 1.8 percent, the S.& P. 500 fell 1.9 percent and the Nasdaq lost 4.8 percent. It was the worst month for the market since October, when Asia's financial troubles first rattled the United States stock market. In October, the Dow tumbled 6.3 percent, the S.& P. fell 3.4 percent and the Nasdaq slumped 5.5 percent.
Computer companies led the decline yesterday. I.B.M. fell 2 9/16 , to 117 1/2; Dell Computer dropped 2 7/32 , to 82 13/32 , and Hewlett-Packard declined 1 9/16 , to 62 5/16 .
Semiconductor companies were also lower. Intel was down 2 1/16 , to 71 7/16 ; Applied Materials fell 1 3/4, to 32; Linear Technology was off 1 1/2, to 69 15/16 , and Advanced Micro Devices dropped 9/16 , to 19 9/16 .
Analysts said concern was mounting over the earnings of technology companies.
"Technology has driven the market for the past seven years, and my sense is it won't lead this year," said John Rutledge, an analyst with the Keystone Investment Management Company. "Clearly the economic problems in Asia aren't over yet, and all of Asia accounts for about 25 percent of end-demand for technology products."
In other sectors, financial stocks rose as bond yields fell. Declining bond yields prompt more households to buy homes and take out mortgages. Fannie Mae, the world's largest buyer of single-family mortgages, rose 15/16 , to 59 13/16 .
Electric power companies like the Southern Company also gained. Those stocks tend to rise with bond prices because the value of their dividends increases as yields fall. Southern rose 7/8, to 26 9/16 .
Union Pacific declined 1 1/4, to 48 3/8, after the company, the nation's largest railroad surprised analysts yesterday by saying that it would report a second-quarter loss as congestion on its tracks persists. The company did not say how big the loss from continuing operations would be.
Shares of Centocor, which rallied on Thursday, fell 2 3/8, to 39, after the Food and Drug Administration recommended approving the company's Avakine drug to treat Crohn's disease but investors reacted to conflicting reports about the company's prospects, including concerns about competition for its heart drug, Reopro, and future earnings.
Treasury Prices Increase
By Bridge News
Treasury prices rose yesterday as investors bought to adjust their portfolios at the end of the month.
A weaker-than-expected manufacturing survey also bolstered prices. And financial and political uncertainty in Asia continued to drive buyers into the relative safety of the Treasury market.
The price of the 30-year Treasury edged up 10/32 , to 104 19/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.80 percent, from 5.82 percent.
Prices were helped after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index of manufacturing activity in the Chicago region, seen as a bellwether for the economy, fell to 56.3 in May, from 58.6 in April, a steeper decline than expected.
And while some investors took profits in the afternoon, the report and the effect of end-of-the-month positioning supported prices. Typically, portfolio managers who try to keep the duration of their holdings in line with bond indexes buy securities on the last day of the month.

HEADLINE: Race Track a Victim of Competition From Casinos

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: MAYS LANDING, N.J., May 27

 BODY:
After the second race today at the Atlantic City Race Course, the noisiest creatures in the grandstand were some sparrows chirping in the rafters. Jack Klein, a 71-year-old carpenter and loyal track patron for a half century, sat alone in the mezzanine, a solitary figure in a sea of orange and yellow seats.
"It's depressing to come out here now," Mr. Klein said. "It's too quiet." 
 And so went the final days of thoroughbred racing at the track, which is closing Saturday after 53 years. Long known in racing circles for its handsome one-mile turf course, some fabled races and, years ago, faithful crowds of 20,000 and 25,000, the track has finally succumbed after a 20-year struggle with the slot machines, blackjack tables and off-track betting parlors in the casinos just 10 miles down the road.
It probably should come as no surprise that a race track virtually in the shadows of Atlantic City would fail. For years, tracks across the country have been steadily losing fans. Industry officials say that from 1985 to 1995, attendance at all thoroughbred tracks in the country declined to 34.4 million from 51.1 million. Other tracks have fallen victim, too. Outside Chicago, Arlington Park, once a top-flight track, no longer offers racing. A track in Omaha, Ak-Sar-Ben, closed two years ago, and the Detroit Race Course plans to close later this year.
In New Jersey, competition for the gambling dollar has been particularly acute. Attendance at the tracks fell to 2.9 million last year from 6.1 million in 1988, and betting fell with it. The losses at Atlantic City Race Course have been greater than at the three other New Jersey tracks offering thoroughbred racing, the Meadowlands, Monmouth Park in Oceanport and Garden State Park in Cherry Hill.
Yet even as race tracks in the state stumbled, gamblers were pumping more and more into slot machines -- $32.45 billion in 1997, roughly double the amount bet in 1988 in constant dollars. In same period, lottery sales, also adjusted for inflation, held steady at more than $1.5 billion.
Richard Thalheimer, a professor at the University of Louisville, said his studies of New Jersey's tracks in the late 1980's and early 1990's found that if the casinos and lottery did not exist, total betting at the tracks would be 52 percent greater than it is today.
Horse players, Dr. Thalheimer said, become heavy players at the casinos. He said the action at casinos, particularly at slot machines, is fast. "They're not a game of skill," he said of the slots. "And they give a much higher rate of return for each dollar put in than for each dollar bet at the tracks." Casinos also entice players with free drinks, free parking and admission, and reasonably priced food in pleasant restaurants.
"Without getting some kind of gaming at the tracks, it's going to be a very tough road for the future," he said.
Indeed, slot machines at Delaware Park in Stanton, Del., once a lowly competitor of the Atlantic City track, produced a $90 million bonanza last year for its operations and purses, and helped the course lure better horses, trainers and jockeys. The administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has shown little interest in counterattacking by allowing the state's tracks to install slots. A few months ago, a slot-machine proposal was killed by coalition of Whitman cabinet officials and casino representatives serving on a commission that the Governor created to study the future of the state's tracks.
Philadelphia Park, another competitor, provides its fans with upscale off-track betting parlors, as well as the convenience of telephone betting. New Jersey officials are thinking about such amenities for the state's horse players. But first, state voters would need to agree in a special referendum to give the Legislature the green light to permit them.
"We just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time," said James J. Murphy, the president of the Atlantic City Race Course. "There's just no magic trick we can come up with now."
So, even though the track calls its closing meet Five Days of Fury, its mood is one of melancholy and reminiscence.
Katie Seifried, the switchboard operator for 30 years, will be the last of her family to work at the track. The track was founded after World War II by John B. Kelly -- a prominent Philadelphia contractor and Olympic gold medalist, and the father of Grace Kelly -- working with his friends in show business, including Bob Hope, Frank Sinatra, Harry James and Sammy Kaye. Ms. Seifried's father, Thomas McGrath, was the track's first superintendent. Her husband, George, and brothers, Bob and Tom Jr., worked as carpenters.
"All we knew in the family was the race track," she said. "When I get into my car, it just comes automatically to the track. It's going to be very sad to leave."
Down by the finish line, Walter Sibson, 85, was sitting alone, like Mr. Klein up in the mezzanine. Earlier this spring, he said, he visited Churchill Downs and some horse farms in Kentucky. "I don't think Churchill Downs is as nice as this," he said. "Horses get in the back stretch there and you can't see them. I'm just watching one race today and leaving. I just wanted to roam around the place for a last time."
Loretta and John Dreyer, summer regulars for 25 years, were in the clubhouse dining room, with its tables draped in white linens, its pink napkins and a $9.95 buffet of pasta salads and sliced beef, turkey and salmon. Mrs. Dreyer said she would take one image away from her years at the track; of Grace Kelly, in a blue and white pinstripe suit on a Saturday night long ago.
The Dreyers, unlike many horse players, dislike simulcasting betting parlors. Watching live racing in the future, they said, will mean drives to Pennsylvania or Delaware.
"You know, people say casinos killed this track," Mr. Dreyer said. "But if people really liked live horse racing, they'd come to the track."
That sentiment has bedeviled the racing industry for years: how to win back horse players who have taken their gambling dollars to casinos or elsewhere, and how to attract a younger generation of fans.
Industry officials outside New Jersey say the best way to revive interest in racing nationally is improved marketing and fresh appeals to young families. Recently, the industry started a $20 million advertising campaign to capture new fans and lure back old ones.
Thomas Merritt, executive director of Thoroughbred Racing Communications, a Manhattan-based media-relations company for the industry, said New Jersey's Monmouth Park offers several attractions to entice families, including pony rides, playgrounds, face painting, a petting zoo and a jazz combo.
"All this introduces the track as a pleasant place to go," Mr. Merritt said. "Kids will think positively about that."
Mr. Murphy, the Atlantic City track president, said the Whitman commission's rejection of the slots was what persuaded track stockholders to close the track. During the racecourse's long struggle, it sold about 80 percent of its land for a mall and two big housing developments, and plowed the $12 million in proceeds back into operations and purses, Mr. Murphy said. Earlier this decade, it hoped to stay alive by having a developer build a 105,000-seat stock-car racing stadium around the track. But that idea foundered.
Two weeks ago, officials announced the sale of the track and its remaining 280 acres to a Michigan builder, Samuel Sobel. The land is zoned for commercial and recreational development, but plans for the site have not been drafted, Mr. Murphy said.
The sales contract sets aside a four-acre parcel for the track company to build an upscale simulcasting parlor that will offer wagering on races beamed in from the other tracks throughout North America. New Jersey law now permits such parlors only at tracks offering live racing and at the casinos. Exceptions to this law would have to be approved by the Legislature and by the voters in a special referendum.
In 1983, the Atlantic City Race Course became the first track in North America to provide simulcast races, Mr. Murphy said.
"That's our only bet left," he said of the proposed simulcast parlor. "If anybody has fought the good fight against the longest odds possible, it has been the principals of the Atlantic City Race Course."

HEADLINE: Taxi Vote's Aftermath

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

 BODY:
After seven hours of impassioned complaints from cabdrivers and owners on Thursday, the Taxi and Limousine Commission retreated into secret session to decide its vote on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new safety rules.
When the six commissioners emerged an hour later, they offered little comment as they rolled through a series of votes approving most of the Mayor's plans. Asked later why the discussion was not held in public, the commission's chairwoman, Diane McGrath-McKechnie, shot back, "There's no reason for that." 
 For the owners and drivers, this was a final bitter moment in a month of hostilities with Mr. Giuliani, the first Mayor in decades to make a determined assault on the industry's safety practices and finances. Even after the votes, contention remained, with legal experts saying the commission had probably violated state law by holding the private session.
Whatever the emotions that were aroused, safety experts say that most of the 15 new rules -- from higher insurance to probationary periods for new drivers -- could tame the worst drivers and help injury victims win more compensation.
Still, the measures would not solve all the problems. In one of the most important changes, taxi and livery companies would have to increase their liability insurance to $100,000 for each accident victim, from the current minimum of $25,000. But while that would help most victims collect more than they do now, it would not enable people with the most devastating injuries to crack through the industry's tough series of legal defenses and collect much larger judgments.
Taxi owners often split up their holdings into a series of smaller companies to minimize liability and borrow against the value of their lucrative licenses, leaving little for accident victims to collect.
Industry officials also warn that the regulations could change the economics of the industry, strangling some smaller operators and ultimately forcing a fare increase.
But polls showed that no matter how much the Mayor baited and pushed the cabbies, the public stood behind his efforts to transform the historically powerful industry, which has experienced a surge in accidents during the last several years.
"The fact is that what we're trying to do is reasonable, it's sensible, it's rational," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday. "It should have been done a long time ago in New York City.
"New York City allowed the taxi industry, because of reasons of political pressure, to dominate in ways that other cities had not allowed to happen, so we're making that change. Yesterday's change was a historic change of great proportion. And three or four years from now, people will appreciate it."
The new rules, to take effect in 30 to 60 days, would sharply increase fines and insurance requirements and make it much easier for the taxi commission to suspend drivers' licenses.
Ms. McGrath-McKechnie and Randy M. Mastro, a Deputy Mayor, both said yesterday that they also expected the commission to pass two hotly contested measures that were tabled Thursday because some commissioners opposed them. Two members of the commission were absent from the voting, and Mr. Mastro said that he was confident that when the full board voted the measures would pass.
One proposal dealt with how quickly drivers could be suspended for traffic violations. The other would require taxi owners to put up a $100,000 bond to guarantee that some accident victims could receive more than just an insurance settlement.
Given the huge cost of some of the proposals, it was natural that the drivers and owners would have fought them no matter how the Mayor brought them forward.
But as more than 50 industry representatives spoke at Thursday's hearing, it was clear that most thought Mr. Giuliani had been much more contentious than he needed to be and that he had given them the back of his hand.
After yellow-cab drivers held a one-day strike earlier this month, city officials blocked efforts by cabbies to stage caravan protests through city streets, saying they should go to Thursday's hearing if they wanted to speak out. Yet dozens of people who signed up to speak were turned away at the crowded proceeding, and even those who spoke with the greatest anguish felt their comments made no difference.
"Did you see how the vote went?" said Johan Nijman, an immigrant from Surinam who paid $250,000 for his taxi medallion two months ago and said he could be forced out of business by the additional costs.
"I thought these people had an agenda to push this thing through no matter what," he said. "And this was a very sad day in the history of American democracy. Tears came from my eyes, sir."
Industry leaders fared no better in complaining that the commission had rushed out the proposals without consulting them and without providing much in the way of statistics to support them.
At one point, Mel Miller, the former State Assembly Speaker who now lobbies for the taxi industry, said that to have a public hearing on the same day the commission was expecting to vote on the measures was unfair. "That's not input," he said. "That's like telling you to comment on a bill after the Governor has signed it."
Some legal experts said the commission's closed-door discussion may have violated the state's open meetings law. "A discussion regarding policy or rule changes would not fall within any of the grounds for entry into executive session," said Robert J. Freeman, executive director of the State Committee on Open Government. "This is the public's business that we're talking about.'
Allan J. Fromberg, the commission's spokesman, maintained yesterday that the board "did not meet in executive session."
He added: "The commissioners took two breaks and had discussions with their counsel, which is entirely appropriate. End of story."
But one commissioner, Marvin Greenberg, disputed Mr. Fromberg's account. "Everybody was talking to each other," Mr. Greenberg said. "We went over line by line to see what we could agree on and where the differences were and where we couldn't find agreement."
Out on the street, the controversy over the proposals seems far from over.
Some drivers thought they got a break when the commission tabled one proposed sanction -- a plan to suspend a cabbie's license after only 6 Division of Motor Vehicle points, rather than the current 11 -- because at least one commissioner questioned whether it was too harsh.
But what few drivers realize is that another measure that did pass will create a separate disciplinary system being set up by the commission itself that is even harsher. It could lead to a 30-day suspension for any driver who got one moving violation -- say, for following another car too closely -- coupled with an administrative infraction during an 18-month period.
Industry officials said they were likely to ask the City Council to review the new rules or file suit to try to block them. And while Ms. McGrath-McKechnie has said she sees no need for a fare increase, industry leaders said that they will push hard for one if they fail to change the new rules.

HEADLINE: A Spelling Champion for All Jamaicans;
12-Year-Old From Kingston Is a Hero for Winning in Washington

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Suddenly, Jamaica has a new hero: a 12-year-old girl from Kingston with a winsome smile and steely determination whose David vs. Goliath victory at the National Spelling Bee has enthralled Jamaicans both on the island and in the large immigrant community in New York City.
Jody-Anne Maxwell, with precise diction flavored by her lilting accent, spelled "chiaroscurist" before a packed hall in Washington on Thursday, becoming the Bee's first foreign champion in its 71 years. She defeated 248 other finalists, including a handful from the Bahamas and Mexico, the only other foreign nations represented. 
 At that moment, driving his delivery van in Queens, William Barnes was listening on his radio and could not believe what he was hearing -- an island girl had come to the capital of this vast and intimidating land and beaten America's best.
"I just feel overwhelmed," Mr. Barnes said yesterday. "My little country came through."
Watching an account of the Bee on the evening news, Troy Armstrong, a 13-year-old sixth grader from Queens, was stunned both at Jody-Anne's victory and his mother's sudden belting out of the Jamaican national anthem. She hugged him and said, "I hope you grow up to be just like that."
Troy, one of about 148,000 people of Jamaican ancestry who live in New York City, primarily in Brooklyn and Queens, said, "It makes me feel proud to be Jamaican for once."
Although Jamaican immigrants have a median income higher than the city average, pop culture, he and others said, has exaggerated the group's problems with gangs and drugs.
"They make it seem like the only jobs Jamaicans can get is selling drugs and being in gangs," Troy said.
And Una Clarke, a City Councilwoman from Brooklyn who was born and reared in Jamaica, said she was working with the Jamaican Embassy to try to bring Jody-Anne to New York to inspire Jamaican students who she said often struggle in school here because of cultural conflicts and differences in American and Jamaican dialects.
"This flies in the face of all the negative stereotypes about Caribbean students," Ms. Clarke said.
Jody-Anne, a polite, confident girl who wants to be a corporate lawyer and attends one of the top public schools in Jamaica, attributed her victory to God and to her coach, the religion teacher from her school. But many others -- from the vice principal at her school to high school students in Brooklyn and Queens -- said it exemplified what they consider the overlooked esteem of the island's education system.
Among Jamaican immigrants, island schools have a reputation for stronger discipline -- including corporal punishment in some cases -- and greater academic rigor than New York City's. A few have even sent their children back to the island to be educated, though neither the city's Board of Education nor Jamaica's Ministry of Education keeps statistics.
John Davis, 29, who came to Queens 10 years ago, said he was considering sending his daughter back to the island when she is ready for elementary school in three years.
"In Jamaica, they tend to concentrate more on what they are learning than what they look like and if their pants are baggy," said Mr. Davis, a real estate agent.
But Jamaica has its disadvantages, too, he said. "Although the school system is good, the economic conditions are hard," he said. "That is the biggest deterrent as to why most Jamaican parents won't send their kids home."
Jamaica's Minister of Education, Burchell Whiteman, said the nation's top schools send the majority of their graduates to colleges abroad (Jamaica has only two colleges). He acknowledged that school programs were uneven and that the country had a literacy rate of about 80 percent, well below that of the United States, at 96 percent. What he calls the "effective" literacy rate, those who read at or above their grade level, is an even lower 65 percent.
"In our schools that perform above normal, generally speaking they put you at an advantage when you enter schools in New York," Mr. Whiteman said. "But I concede at the same time that too many schools are not at the level where they need to be if we're talking about a 65 percent literacy rate."
Jody-Anne is in the seventh grade at Ardenne High School, which has produced the country's top speller for the last eight years, Mr. Whiteman said. In Jamaica, high school begins in the seventh grade.
Only last year did Jamaica begin testing its best against the Americans in the National Spelling Bee in Washington, which is open to English speakers 15 or under; contest rules bar anyone beyond the eighth grade.
"This shows the world -- especially you people, in the United States of America -- that Jamaica, although it is very small, is on top in areas other than sports," said Erma Hutton, vice principal at Ardenne High.
Jody-Anne, who won a $10,000 cash prize, a set of encyclopedias and two round-trip tickets from US Airways, spent yesterday hopping among television studios for a series of interviews so time-consuming she had to cancel a planned visit to see the White House, said her father, Lloyd Maxwell. Mr. Maxwell, a real estate consultant, and his wife, Shirley, a data processor, have four daughters, ages 8 to 30.
Jody-Anne's older sister Janice won Jamaica's national championship a few years ago, and Jody-Anne, a straight-A student who wants to emulate an aunt who is a lawyer, characteristically devoted herself to it, eventually winning the Jamaican spelling bee and heading for Washington on a mission.
"I came here along with my compatriots with the intention to win," she said, in the same firm but polite tone with which she entranced the audience when asking the moderator to repeat words or put them in sentences. "We decided from the beginning that this was not pleasure."
When the runner-up, Prem Murthy Trivedi of Lakewood Preparatory School in Howell, N.J., faltered on "prairillon" (he spelled it "prerillon"), Jody-Anne was given "chiaroscurist," meaning a painter whose style emphasizes the use of light and shadow to simulate depth. She knew how to spell it right away -- a slight smile showed this -- but asked the moderator to repeat it anyhow and put it in a sentence "because I wanted to make absolutely sure."
Yesterday afternoon, as the throng of students filed out of the halls of George W. Wingate High School in Brooklyn to soak up the bright sun outside, a group of students from Jamaica leaned against a fence, excitedly discussing Jody-Anne's achievement.
"She showed me that I can do it too," said Sarah Childs, an 18-year-old junior. "I can go in front of the whole world and excel. She can have a positive influence on a lot of kids."
The students' enthusiasm and pride were echoed across Crown Heights, the heart of the West Indian community, where other people from the Caribbean also were elated at Jody-Anne's achievements.
Kevin Jack, 20, who was born in Trinidad, said: "A lot of people from other countries tend to look down on us, thinking we can't reach such heights. She proved a lot of them wrong. They didn't expect it."

PUB-DATE: May 30, 1998,

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2191 words

HEADLINE: Bilingual Education Is Facing Push Toward Abandonment

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif.

 BODY:
Bilingual education, once widely hailed as a humane and sound method of immigrant assimilation, has fallen into disfavor, disparaged as a bureaucratic boondoggle, even by many of the people it was primarily designed to serve: the nation's increasing Hispanic minority.
On June 2, California voters are expected to endorse Proposition 227, which will eliminate the hundreds of bilingual programs in a state that is home to nearly half of the pupils in the United States with limited English proficiency, setting the stage for similar attacks on such programs nationwide. 
 If it passes, Proposition 227, which essentially limits help for non-native speakers to a year of intensive English instruction, will mark an extraordinary intervention by voters into classrooms to mandate teaching methods, a sign of the growing importance of education in the nation's political debate.
The shift in the fortunes of the nation's bilingual education system has been pronounced, the result of flagging support among its main constituents, Hispanic Americans, a growing political resistance to education bureaucracies, and the sense that, despite many studies, there was no conclusive evidence that it worked. Behind that erosion of support is a stubborn statistic: the high dropout rate of Hispanic youths.
According to the National Center for Educational Statistics, the school dropout rate recorded in 1995 for Hispanic students born in the United States remained at 17.9 percent, but that of Hispanic immigrants was 46.2 percent. This compares with a drop-out rate of 12.2 percent of blacks and 8.6 percent of whites. Foreign-born blacks and whites had lower drop-out rates than those who were born in the United States.
Because three-quarters of schoolchildren nationwide who speak limited English are Hispanic, and because bilingual education is often made to stand for the whole question of educating foreign-language children, the failure of the schools to educate Hispanic youths is often discussed interchangeably with bilingual education as if they were the same thing. But in fact, most Hispanic students do not study in bilingual classes because there are simply not enough classes to accommodate their rapidly growing numbers.
Moreover, most bilingual classes take place in underfunded school districts, adding to the difficulty of assessing their effectiveness. In California, only 30 percent of the students with limited English ability are in bilingual classes because there is a shortage of about 20,000 bilingual teachers in the state. And there is no known difference in dropout rates between those in bilingual classes and those of similar background studying only in English.
 
Crucial Division On Supporting Plan
While the California initiative is the work of a white Republican Silicon Valley millionaire named Ronald K. Unz, it is backed, according to repeated opinion polls, by at least half of the state's Hispanic voters.
In fact, Mr. Unz said his interest was prompted by a strike in 1996 by Mexican-American parents who protested that their children were forced into bilingual education classes.
Another Hispanic American against the initiative is Virginia Martinez, a former bilingual education teacher in Santa Ana, a town an hour south of downtown Los Angeles with the largest concentration of Hispanic immigrants and their offspring in the country, according to national census data.
Here, where the issues of immigrant absorption and bilingual education are particularly pronounced, Ms. Martinez tests for English competency at Taft Elementary School, which has foregone bilingual education for the past 13 years, favoring English immersion, the aim of Proposition 227.
"I kept seeing kids doing poorly in the upper grades after they had gone through bilingual education," Ms. Martinez said. "There was no transition to English. I felt that bilingual education was holding them back."
In the school, Hispanic and Asian children learn in English from the first day, with the occasional translation help of teacher aides. High scores reflect clear success, although Taft serves a more middle-class and ethnically mixed population than many other schools with bilingual programs.
At the same time, Pio Pico Elementary School, just a few miles away, is a reminder of what bilingual education was supposed to be. Built on a lot once overrun by gangs, now an oasis of learning and community involvement, Pio Pico serves a uniform population of low-income Mexican and Central American immigrants who believe deeply in bilingual education.
"With bilingual education, I am involved with my daughter's schooling," said Martha Leon, a housekeeper whose daughter, Lizeth, is in fourth grade. "My daughter is learning English, but because of the Spanish, I feel the school is mine."
 
Limits Were Enacted In Some Other States
 This issue is not confined to California. Backed by a broad range of politicians, including then-Gov. Ronald Reagan, today's bilingual education emerged from the civil rights era and was supported by its own Supreme Court decision, the 1974 Lau v. Nichols ruling. The court ordered states to give special help to students who did not speak English, but did not specify what remedy the states should use.
Aside from California, 10 states mandate bilingual education and most others permit it. Since 1968, when Congress first passed the Bilingual Education Act, the Federal Government has helped fund it. And while not one of those programs yet faces a broad initiative like that in California, all are under debate if not outright attack and curtailment.
In Chicago and Denver, school boards have recently limited bilingual classes to three years; in Arizona, the legislature has voted to limit funding for them to four years. In Albuquerque, N.M., parents are suing the school system, asserting that bilingual classes segregate their children, an accusation that had been leveled at New York State by Brooklyn parents three years ago. This followed a Board of Education report asserting that bilingual programs had failed to teach children as effectively as those in English-only classes.
 
Extra Factors Skew Statistics, Some Say
Supporters of bilingual education contend that the programs have never been adequately supported or implemented, and are thus unfairly blamed for the shortcomings of Hispanic education in this country. What is clear is that demographics will only add urgency to the debate. In California alone, 100,000 Mexicans arrive legally each year, a vast immigration from a single country that is slowing the Mexicans' assimilation. Within half a century, Hispanic Americans are expected to constitute 25 percent of the United States' population, making their education an issue of enormous long-term consequence.
Among scholars, views on bilingual education remain largely positive but even there, disillusion can be felt over the sloppiness of research and the difficulty of drawing conclusions. The programs' failings are acknowledged though they are not attributed to any theoretical weaknesses.
"I am fairly certain that if you control for all other factors -- rates of poverty, teacher training, school climate -- and just study the process of language acquisition, you have a slight edge for bilingual education. But that edge is extremely small," said Kenji Hakuta, professor of education at Stanford University and chairman of a panel that produced a recent National Research Council report on educating children with limited English.
"People are genuinely and appropriately dissatisfied, but they are misdiagnosing the problem," Professor Hakuta said. "The kids are learning English. The problem is that they are not progressing in school subject matters."
Professor Hakuta, like other opponents of Proposition 227, say that because it forbids bilingual education except under exceptional circumstances and requires all children to fit into one unproven method of educational transition, it is poorly conceived and dangerous.
Mr. Unz and his supporters counter that their plan is based on European models that do work.
 
Too Little Progress In Too Much Time
One problem in the debate is the varying definition of bilingual education and the many programs that come under its rubric, from English as a second language to so-called structured immersion, which is mostly English instruction with some subject content thrown in -- to true bilingual teaching.
In its most widely understood form, bilingual education teaches academic subjects to immigrant children in their native languages while, at the same time, gradually instructing them in English so that after a few years they join regular classes.
The idea is that instead of losing time learning English before entering school or having to struggle in English before they are ready, these children can keep up with their grade levels while gradually transferring into mainstream classes.
Important elements of the theory behind this plan were provided in the last quarter-century by Jim Cummins, a professor of education at the University of Toronto. He argued that learning to read in one's native language makes it easier to read in a second language and that the more children master in their first language, the more they will be able to master in the second.
Practical experience backed these theories in part. When children arrived in the United States well-schooled, they made the transition to English classes easily. They understood how a language worked and were able to transfer their skills.
The problems occurred mostly with children who were either born in the United States to Spanish-speaking households or had received inadequate schooling before immigrating. Teaching those children for years in their native language before allowing the transition to English seems to have done them little good.
As Charles L. Glenn, professor of education policy at Boston University, put it:
"Someone who plays soccer will learn to play American football faster than someone else who has never played a sport. But that does not make it efficient to teach soccer first if the goal is football. We should build on academic skills if a child already has them in another language but we should not make developing new ones in that language a priority."
Still, the research on bilingual education is notoriously inconclusive, and studies often seem to be done by scholars seeking to bolster their own views. The original theory of bilingual education was that students would move out of their native languages as rapidly as possible into English, normally in one to three years. But that approach has lagged, with many students staying six to seven years in primary language classes both because they were not yet fluent enough in English and because of more complex reasons.
Some Spanish-language teachers felt protective of students and feared that they would be mistreated in mainstream classes. Others simply found it easier to instruct pupils in Spanish and thus made insufficient effort to teach in English.
Still others believed that the longer native speakers were taught in their language, the more easily they would learn subjects in English.
For the backers of Proposition 227, the dragging transition to English is what is wrong with bilingual education. They also say it has developed its own bureaucracy and budgets -- replete with extra money for schools with students who stay in bilingual education and salary bonuses for bilingual teachers. They say it has lost sight of the children's welfare and that the country has historically, and successfully, relied on quick assimilation through English.
The truth is more complicated. Richard Rothstein, a researcher at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington has written a book called "The Way We Were?" (Century Foundation Press, 1998) in which he demonstrates how poorly immigrants from Italy, Poland and Russia did in school in the early part of the century without bilingual education. For example, in 1931, only 11 percent of the Italian students who entered high school graduated compared with 40 percent for all students.
When bilingual education was established in the 1960's, it was boosted partly by the assertion that the American economy depended on its citizens' ability to do business abroad.
Today, English is the international language, far more dominant than it was 30 years ago. Parents across the globe are demanding more and earlier English instruction for their children and many foreign-born parents here consider mastery of English to be fundamental for their children. This, too, has weakened the case for bilingual education and driven voters toward Proposition 227.
But at Pio Pico, there is a feeling that all they have worked toward is endangered. When asked what they would do if the initiative passed, Judith Magsaysay, the principal, half joked that she would go to jail rather than stop using Spanish to help her pupils. When the parents around the table heard her, they said in chorus, "Don't worry. We'll bring you tortillas in prison."

HEADLINE: Taxi Reform Is Just a Band-Aid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to curb taxi accidents through increased insurance coverage (front page, May 29) is merely a Band-Aid. As long as drivers have to work long hours for little pay -- and medallion owners operate as financial middlemen disconnected from day-to-day taxi service -- they will work fast and aggressively. 
 The Mayor should consider a radical plan to alter the medallion system that is forcing the economic costs to drivers higher, or start fining owners for the actions of uncontrolled drivers.
 
GLENN KULBAKO
Boston, May 29, 1998
 
The writer is the taxi industry coordinator for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
India and Pakistan Officials Speak of Avoiding War
Both India and Pakistan began talking of new arrangements that would stabilize their rivalry and minimize the risk of war, a day after Pakistan conducted nuclear tests. A1 

Clinton Administration officials said they were skeptical of conciliatorystatements made by India and Pakistan as American intelligence reports indicate Pakistan may be preparing for more weapons tests. United States intelligence officials say that Pakistan could test another nuclear weapon within days and that Pakistan was preparing to test a missile. A5
 
I.M.F. Announces Aid to Russia
The International Monetary Fund said it would disburse $670 million by the end of June to help stabilize the Russian financial markets. Russian Government officials and investment bankers expressed concern that the assistance would come too late, and Russian officials have begun to explore the establishment of a multibillion-dollar fund to help stabilize the ruble. A3
 
Pressure on Suharto Fortune
The new Government in Indonesia announced several measures aimed at curbing the economic favoritism that allowed the Suharto family fortune to grow as high as $40 billion. Public pressure led to the resignation of Mr. Suharto's son as president-director of one of the country's largest companies as support continued to grow for the return of the money that Mr. Suharto and his family siphoned from the economy. A1
 
Credit Gains in Central Europe
Consumers in Central Europe have discovered the joys of buying items on credit, an option long denied under Communism. Retail credit grew by 50 percent in Poland last year and both the Czech Republic and Hungary recorded steady growth in consumer debt, fueling trade imbalances as a flood of imports swamps exports. A3
 
Support for Ethnic Albanians
President Clinton met with ethnic Albanian leaders from the Serbian province of Kosovo in an attempt to display American interest and involvement in Kosovo, as well as support for Ibrahim Rugova, the president of the republic of Kosovo. The Agency for International Development announced a $6 million increase in aid to Kosovo, seeking to bolster Mr. Rugova's position both with his people and with the Serbian Government. A4
 
France Recognizes 'Genocide'
The French National Assembly voted unanimously to formally recognize the killings of ethnic Armenians in Turkey from 1915 to 1923 as genocide -- a move that drew sharp protests from Turkey. If the motion passes the Senate, France would become the first major European country to use the term "genocide" to describe the deaths of one million or more Armenians in Ottoman Turkey in the years during and immediately after World War I. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A6-9, 14
 
House G.O.P. to Press Religious Right Agenda
House Republicans are beginning a major effort next week to show a commitment to the religious right, with floor votes set on proposals favoring school prayer and against the "marriage penalty" in the Federal income tax. The votes were promised by the Republicans this month after meeting with representatives of a dozen religious groups, who warned that if Congress did not aggressively pursue their causes, conservative voters could stay home in November and threaten the party's narrow House majority. But both proposals face difficulties. A7
 
Quandary of Life Sentence
Michael Rene Pardue, imprisoned in 1973, is serving a life sentence in Alabama because he escaped three times from a life sentence that the State Supreme Court has ruled he never should have been serving because of a coerced confession. The case has drawn attention from around the world as legal experts and others whose consciences have been pricked by the state's handling of it wonder how state officials can justify his new sentence. A1
 
Shift at Helm of ABC News
David Westin, left, president of ABC News, is to take over its leadership from Roone Arledge, who has led ABC News for 21 years, longer than any other news executive in TV history. Mr. Arledge, 66, will remain chairman of ABC News. Westin. Mr. Westin, 45, will remain president. A6
 
Testing of Drugs Is Faulted
Federal investigators said patients who took part in clinical trials of new drugs were often exposed to unsafe and unethical practices because no one policed the research to protect their interests. A9
 
Monday Deadline for Clinton
The Supreme Court ordered the White House to respond by Monday afternoon to a request by the Whitewater independent counsel to speed consideration of privilege claims by President Clinton. A7

New Rules for Taxis Bring Hopes and Doubts
Safety experts say most of the new rules for taxis in New York City could tame the worst drivers and help injury victims win more compensation. But the regulations could also change the economics of the industry, strangling some smaller operators and ultimately forcing a fare increase. News Analysis. A1
 
Rival Bill on Sentencing
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, who has introduced legislation that would require all violent offenders to serve full prison terms, says passage of the bill is a top priority. But Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver is planning a less stringent bill that would allow judges the discretion of eliminating parole for first-time violent offender. B1
 
Spelling Jamaican Pride
Residents of the large Jamaican immigrant community in New York City and of Jamaica are enthralled by a 12-year-old Kingston girl's victory at the National Spelling Bee. The girl, Jody-Anne Maxwell, became the Bee's first foreign champion in its 71 years in defeating 249 other finalists. B1

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Cone Keeps Cool And Runs Follow For the Yankees

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
David Cone allowed a titanic 406-foot homer to Reggie Jefferson on his fourth pitch of the game last night. So what? Cone stayed calm. He knew, just as everyone else at soggy Yankee Stadium knew, that his pitching opponent, Derek Lowe, would have a difficult time suppressing the Yankees. Every other pitcher does. Why should Lowe be any different?
Besides, the Yankees have treated David like a king on the mound this season by scoring for him as if this this were Little League, not the major leagues. The relentless Yankees continued that offensive trend last night by beating Lowe and the Red Sox, 6-2, before a paying crowd of 47,160, most of whom waited 2 hours 13 minutes while the first pitch was delayed by a steady rain. 
 Once the game finally started, the Yankees quickly exhibited just how sizable the disparity is between them and the second-place team in the soon-to-be decided American League East. Well, maybe not that soon, but does anyone really think the Yankees will mishandle a whopping nine-and-a-half-game cushion? The Red Sox are fading fast and have lost six games in a row, including four straight to the Yankees.
The always-tinkering Cone incorporated a new wrinkle into his delivery last night by placing his right, or pushoff foot, on the extreme right side of the rubber instead of on the extreme left side. Cone said he felt that his fastballs and sliders were sailing too far outside to right-handed hitters and hoped the adjustment would enable those pitches to move toward the middle of the plate. It worked as Cone struck out seven and gave up only two earned runs and one walk in seven innings, his longest outing of the season. He tossed an economical 84 pitches.
Jefferson, a left-handed batter, homered off a hanging slider in the first inning and blasted a fastball into the right-field seats in the fifth. John Valentin doubled off the center-field fence in the second, missing a homer by a foot. But that was the only serious damage off Cone, who permitted only two other base runners in winning his seventh straight decision.
The Yankees have scored 88 runs in Cone's 10 starts, an average of 8.8 a game.
"He keeps telling me to not give up on him," Manager Joe Torre said. "I'm not about to give up on him."
Of course not. Cone is 7-1, but his earned run average is an uncharacteristic 5.59. But if Cone keeps getting stronger and pitching the way he did last night, the Yanks will be even more formidable -- if that is possible for a team whose 37-11 start is tied for the fifth best in American League history.
The 24-year-old Lowe had a decent beginning by retiring seven of the first eight Yankees he faced, but Lowe walked Joe Girardi, the worst hitter in the lineup with a .244 average, in the third and immediately rued the free pass. Chuck Knoblauch singled in a run to tie the score, 1-1, and after Derek Jeter singled to fill the bases, Paul O'Neill cued a double to shallow left to knock in two more for a 3-1 edge.
More misery awaited Lowe in the fourth. His legs quivered whenever New York had runners on, which happened quickly because Bernie Williams singled. Chad Curtis walked, Scott Brosius singled and, after a visit from Manager Jimy Williams, Lowe gave up a bloop single to Girardi that pushed home two more runs.Knoblauch finished Lowe's evening with a run-scoring single to make it 6-1.
How abysmal was Lowe with runners on base? He yielded six hits in nine at-bats in that situation and also walked two. No wonder Lowe pulled his cap down tight over his eyes after being removed. He is 0-4 with an 8.24 e.r.a. as a starter.
Cone was the antithesis of Lowe as he retired five of six batters who hit with men on base and breezed to his second victory in six days against Boston.
"I expect to be better," Cone said. "I expect to return to the form I had last year. I haven't gotten there yet, but I'm still trying."
 
INSIDE PITCH
Sweating and smiling, finally, TINO MARTINEZ stood near the bat rack after batting practice and pronounced himself ready to start. It was the first time the first baseman was in the lineup since last Friday in Boston. "It's definitely sore and there's pain there, but I can definitely play," said Martinez, who has been throttled by swelling between his right shoulder blades. "Yesterday, I couldn't play. Today, I feel like I can play, even with pain." Martinez, who was injured when ARMANDO BENITEZ of the Baltimore Orioles plunked him with a pitch on May 19, went 0 for 4. . . . The Yankees made a nice gesture to those fans who waited over two hours for the game to start by announcing they could exchange last night's ticket stub for a ticket to one of six games against Minnesota (Aug. 10 and 11) or Anaheim (Aug. 24, 25 or one of two games on Aug. 26). Fans must make exchanges by mail and must enclose a self-addressed, stamped envelope. Today's game with Boston is a sellout.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 54; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1114 words

HEADLINE: Econ-Icons

BYLINE: By David Brooks; David Brooks is a senior editor at The Weekly Standard.

 BODY:

Two Lucky People Memoirs.
 By Milton Friedman and Rose D. Friedman.
 Illustrated. 660 pp. Chicago:
 The University of Chicago Press. $35. 
 The air is sweet up in the hills of New Hampshire, so it's no surprise that Milton Friedman should so fondly remember his younger days in a remote cottage: "I can recall many a pleasant summer evening discussing consumption data and theory in front of a blazing fire." Long chats on consumption data might not stir the souls of some, but as Milton and Rose D. Friedman reveal in their joint memoir, "Two Lucky People," they are econ-nerds through and through. They linger over memories of intense technical discussions. They describe friendships built on arcane talk of curves and functions and theorems. And while their public fame rests on books like "Capitalism and Freedom" and "Free to Choose," and their enormous influence on politicians like Ronald Reagan, Margaret Thatcher and the free-market leaders of Eastern Europe, they insist that this aspect of their careers is just a sidelight. It's the science of economics that has been central to their lives.
So while they do describe public crusades and the Nobel Prize ceremonies, their memoir is most moving when it evokes life in the community of scholars. "We reflected again on the wonderful dividend from graduate teaching of having intellectual children throughout the world . . . and on the emotional hold which the University of Chicago has on those who have been there," they declare in a characteristic passage. Milton insists he will be remembered more for his technical work than for his political activism, and he seems slightly aloof from the intense public controversies that have raged around him. The Friedmans come across as the last Enlightenment thinkers in a post-modern world, putting their faith in Science and Reason and exuding a happy confidence that truth will triumph. Their memoir reads like one of those Christmas letters you sometimes get from modest but superachieving friends: Met some wonderful people in Japan this past summer, found mice living in the vacation house, transformed the nature of economic thought.
Milton and Rose Friedman grew up in observant Jewish homes at opposite ends of America, Milton in New Jersey and Rose in Oregon. Those who are familiar with Milton's tendency to pursue arguments to their logical end will not be surprised to learn that until the age of 12 he "fanatically" adhered to the Orthodox dietary and other requirements. But he suddenly gave up religion, discovered mathematics and after college at Rutgers found himself at the University of Chicago studying economics along with another student, Rose Director. He calls his first year of graduate school the most intellectually stimulating of his life, but he is characteristically reticent about his emotional life. We do learn that after a day at the 1933 Century of Progress world's fair, Milton tried to plant a good-night kiss on Rose and she refused him. It's hard to know which is more amazing, that he didn't immediately formulate an argument on why she should kiss him, or that Rose didn't see that this was the guy for her. In the succeeding 65 years they have become a famously complementary pair.
Milton's talent as an economist is the invisible driving force of the book, taking them off to unlikely locations. He was recruited to Washington to do research for the New Deal. During World War II he worked in the Treasury Department to create the tax-withholding system that ever since has been the bete noire of free marketeers like himself. Later in the war he went to work at Columbia University's Statistical Research Group, figuring out, for example, how many pellets a shrapnel shell should burst into to create maximum damage. And then for the rest of his life, his ability took him to a series of ever more prestigious appointments, visiting fellowships and worldwide lecture tours.
Friedman entered an economics profession that was dominated by Keynesian thinking, but that now, thanks largely to him, recognizes the centrality of monetary policy. His public teachings in Newsweek, on PBS and in books like "Capitalism and Freedom," which has sold more than 400,000 copies even though, he says, it was not reviewed in any major national publication, have altered the political framework. And the policy ideas he invented or championed, including school vouchers, the negative income tax, the volunteer Army, the balanced budget amendment and drug legalization, continue to define political debate.
Yet his equipoise is as striking as his brainpower. We're used to flamboyant geniuses, but Friedman is relentlessly normal. It's hard now to capture how extreme his libertarian ideas seemed when they were propounded 50 years ago. In 1947, a small band of free-market economists met in Mont Pelerin, Switzerland. Many great thinkers were there -- F. A. Hayek, Karl Popper, Friedman -- but, as befits a fringe group, also a lot who were eccentric and temperamental. At the first meeting Ludwig von Mises stood up and shouted, "You're all a bunch of socialists," and stamped out of the room.
Friedman has been so persuasive because he expounds radical ideas with a sweet smile of reason. He charms and disarms his debating partners, and as the Friedmans boast -- the one boast in the book -- they have many professional foes but no personal enemies. Friedman doesn't seem to get downhearted when his views are unpopular, or elated when he is honored. When he was informed that he had won the Nobel Prize, he responded quite rationally that the award seemed to lead many laureates to expound on subjects outside their expertise.
In truth, "Two Lucky People" probably would have been a more exciting book if the Friedmans were a little more histrionic. Their narrative is clear, but it is artless. They do not draw detailed portraits of their friends (they truncate their descriptions of Nixon, Reagan, Thatcher and the other leaders they have known). They tell us next to nothing about what they think about beyond economics. Milton says that he regretfully has no taste for music, and they do not even say which novelists move them, or what historians or philosophers have been important in their lives.
In the end, however, this is a book that restores your faith in reasoned discourse. Amid all the wonks vying to get intimate with the powerful, and all the academic theorizing about how language is an ever-shifting deception, there really are people who believe in scholarly exchange as a way to discover truth. The Friedmans pursued their ideas. Influence -- in this case world-shaking influence -- just sort of followed.
