LENGTH: 1244 words

HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
Several television specials this year have commemorated the 50th anniversary of Nascar, the stock-car racing organization created in Daytona Beach, Fla., to bring order to what was up to then a chaotic, formless sport. Two of the latest will be shown tonight on TBS, one of a number of channels that now show Nascar's brand of stock-car racing.
The first, a segment of "National Geographic Explorer," beginning at 7 P.M., is a superficial look at the sport. That is followed at 9 by "Nascar at 50: Good to Go," which offers a closer examination of some of the struggles in a sport trying to retain its aw-shucks charm while striving to scrape the blood off its knuckles and the grease from its fingernails. 
 That's no small image rehab for a sport that began in the rural Southeast, on small dirt tracks usually bulldozed out of someone's farmland. One of the goals of William H. G. France Sr. in establishing Nascar (the acronym for National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing) in December 1947 was to make sure that the drivers of the postwar era -- many of whom had to be quick to deliver carloads of home-brew whiskey and still win the race against Federal agents to stay out of jail -- did not have to use fists or guns to collect their prize money before race-track owners could abscond with it.
Nowadays, as the TBS program points out, drivers like Jeff Gordon, the 26-year-old star who is already a two-time Nascar champion, need only outrun all the fans wanting autographs on the millions of dollars' worth of souvenirs bearing the drivers' likenesses. "They're accessible, they're open, they're modest, and they come out of a Southern culture that's respectful," said Neal Pilson, a former president of CBS Sports, in describing the stock-car racers' personality traits that attract many Americans who think that too many other pro athletes have lost the common touch.
At a time when most sports leagues are experiencing flat or declining television ratings, Nascar racing has produced steadily increasing viewership. Last year, for example, CBS had an average rating of 5.7 for the six major races it broadcast, an increase of 16 percent from 1996. (Each rating point represents 980,000 homes.)
The races are now shown on a total of five broadcast and cable networks -- one more than National Football League games. And on July 4, Nascar will reach another milestone: the first live network broadcast of a race in prime time, the Firecracker 400 on CBS.
The one-hour TBS show, by Turner Original Productions, illustrates the delicate balancing act that has brought Nascar to where it now is: operating a multimillion-dollar sport while maintaining the veneer of small-town charm. Charlotte Motor Speedway, in North Carolina, whose Winston Cup race last October is the setting for "Nascar at 50," is the perfect symbol: a glittering track whose infield was once a landfill. One of the main subjects of the program is H. A. (Humpy) Wheeler, who, as president and general manager of Charlotte Motor Speedway, has turned it into what he terms the "Taj Mahal of racing." Don't laugh. The condominiums overlooking the track went on the market in 1984 for $95,000, and 10 years later were selling for $375,000.
At one point in the program, Mr. Wheeler sits in his plush office and holds up a jar of 140-proof moonshine, a reminder, he says, of where the sport has come from. "This place has got to have a space for the person who works in the mill and the person who owns the mill," Mr. Wheeler says of his track.
Mr. Pilson, who now works as a broadcast consultant for several Nascar tracks, said the average Nascar fan was more affluent than a typical mill worker. "He's not at the highest level economically, like golf, but he is higher than the baseball and basketball fan," he said in a recent telephone interview from his Manhattan office.
Some of those fans are also nomadic, traveling hundreds of miles several times a year to attend races. Roaming the countryside in motor homes, beat-up vans and resurrected school buses, they watch the same performers over and over: kind of like Grateful Dead fans without the marijuana.
But what really attracts sponsors, Mr. Pilson said, is the Nascar fan's unique understanding that loyalty to a particular driver means allegiance to that driver's corporate sponsor. "What's most important is that the fans are buying the sponsors' products," Mr. Pilson said.
Excluding extravaganzas like the Olympics, the only sports programs that regularly deliver higher ratings than Nascar's Winston Cup Series (stock-car racing's big league) are professional football and the post-season playoffs in major league baseball and professional basketball, Mr. Pilson said. "College football is about equal to Nascar, in terms of ratings," he said, "and everything else is below Nascar."
Strong ratings are especially crucial to stock-car racing. For years, the sport has thrived by skirting the ban on televised tobacco advertising, and R. J. Reynolds has spent tens of millions of dollars to see and hear the name Winston on all those broadcasts. If, as expected, any major liability settlement with the tobacco industry brings an end to cigarette sponsorship in racing, Nascar's big television audience will make it much easier to find a replacement sponsor.
That sponsor will be buying the sort of viewer loyalty that is hard to find in an era of free-agent athletes who are million-dollar migrant workers. But it's a loyalty that may not be hard to understand after watching the "Nascar at 50" segment on Dale Earnhardt.
Mr. Earnhardt, a seven-time Winston Cup champion, distills the Nascar driver's charm down to its 140-proof essence. When he was 17, he found his father, a talented driver as well, slumped over dead after suffering a heart attack while working on a carburetor. That seemed to toughen his resolve, and Mr. Earnhardt soon got to the top of his sport with the nickname the Intimidator for his willingness to knock aside any opponent who would not get out of his way.
The segment begins with hundreds of fans lined up outside his car dealership waiting for him to autograph shirts, caps and even a windshield from one of his race cars. One female fan explains the attraction: Mr. Earnhardt commits the kind of mayhem on a race track that frustrated motorists like her can only dream about. "Plus, he's an attractive man,' she adds.
After a quick look at the horses, chickens and fish that live on his farm (with millions of dollars annually in souvenir sales, Mr. Earnhardt can afford to keep the fish in his pond well-fed, and they welcome his arrival as hungrily as his fans do), he displays almost two dozens bins of mail from fans seeking autographs. He will oblige all of them, apparently. Through it all, he comes across as a simple man aware of a simple truth: his wealth is derived directly from the deep emotional connection his fans feel for him.
That connection includes television executives, too. Mr. Pilson likes to tell a story about the time he was introduced to race drivers at a trackside chapel service as the man who first put the Daytona 500 on CBS, a decision made in 1979 that has greatly benefited Nascar and the network. "The drivers got up and gave me a standing ovation, and they came up to me one by one and shook my hand," he recalled. "Could you imagine that introduction getting that kind of a reaction someplace like an N.B.A. locker room?"

PUB-DATE: May 31, 1998,

SECTION: Section 5; Page 13; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2690 words

HEADLINE: The Soul and Spirit of Hilo

BYLINE: By JOCELYN FUJII; JOCELYN FUJII, author of "Under the Hula Moon" (Crown), lives in Honolulu.

 BODY:
I THINK of Hilo, rain or shine, as the unsung hero of the Hawaiian Islands. Residents of the town in eastern Hawaii, known for its abundant rainfall, have retained their spirit through the devastating tsunamis of 1946 and 1960 and the more recent economic struggles of sugar plantation closings. The engines of tourism and economic development raced past Hilo, creating, in a sense, a kipuka -- an oasis of green in a sea of lava. Modest plantation-style homes have yards full of gingers, orchids and other riotous blooms, as well as litchi trees that bulge with fruit during summer. If economic hardship has taken its toll, you won't see evidence of it in downtown Hilo, where the parking meters (once 10 cents an hour and now free) are covered with jaunty flowered cotton covers made by volunteers.
There is a Hawaiian saying: "Hana mao 'ole ka ua o Hilo" -- Endlessly pours the rain of Hilo. When I wake up in a Hilo waterfront hotel, the first thing I do is listen for rain and the gurgling of Hilo Bay, and the second thing I do is look out the window to see if the summit of Mauna Kea (Hawaii's highest mountain) is visible. 
 Yet during a recent visit to Hilo, which averages nearly 11 feet of rain a year, the skies were clear and the view unobstructed. I sat in a light-filled breakfast room at the Shipman House Inn, five or six blocks inland from the Hilo bayfront. The view was pleasantly altered by the ripple effect of the inn's 100-year-old hand-rolled windows. Outside, the palette of greens and blues was enhanced by an unexpected splash of crimson from a ti plant that leaned over the sill. Hilo Bay shimmered beyond.
My boyfriend, Brad, and I had stayed in Auntie Carrie's Room upstairs, which cost $140 and featured a private bath, an ornate antique four-poster bed made of koa (a native hardwood) and a 12-foot ceiling. We had just finished our breakfast of sweet starfruit, homemade papaya bread, still-warm corn bread, macadamia-nut granola and juicy orange-red Sunrise papaya when the proprietor of this year-old inn, Barbara-Ann Andersen, unveiled another marvel.
A friend had just dropped off some cuttings taken from the first vanda orchid plant brought to the Big Island, she told us, producing a tangle of roots and leaves. Vanda orchids are often used in leis and in fact were introduced to Hawaii in the 1800's by Ms. Andersen's ancestors.
Having worn countless vanda leis in my lifetime, and sitting in the heart of what is today known as the Orchid Island, I was having, as islanders would say, a "chicken-skin" (goosebump) experience. In the living room next to us sat a gleaming 1912 Steinway grand piano that Queen Liliuokalani, Hawaii's last monarch, played on her visits to Shipman House.
"She was a friend of my great-grandmother's and would visit for poi luncheons," Ms. Andersen said. Family lore has it that the queen enjoyed smoking a cigar while giggling Shipman children fanned her, competing to see who could get closest to the queen without touching her.
OUTDOORS, on the five and a half acres surrounding the inn, a light breeze wafted through the 20 varieties of fruit trees that had produced most of the food on our plates. Soon after breakfast, Ms. Andersen found a home for the vanda cutting in the shade of a furry tree fern. She placed the orchid within easy reach of a hose until the drought that had been generated by El Nino was over.
Hilo, which in 1990, its wettest year on record, received nearly 18 feet of rain, had seen only 6.2 inches in the first three months of this year. (Nearly 9 inches more fell in April, but that month usually brings more than 15 inches.) Hawaiians have some 40 terms for rain, and Hilo residents know most of them.
Although the decrease in rain has devastated farmers, El Nino has been good for surfers and visitors. Hilo Bay waves are crisp, the parks dry and welcoming, and the snorkeling in the spring-fed shoreline along James Kealoha and Leleiwi beach parks, near Richardson Ocean Center, the best on the eastern side of the island. The main recreational area for Hilo beachgoers, Kealoha and Leleiwi are on a stretch of shoreline east of downtown Hilo and the bayfront, bordered on one side by vast acres of ponds and on the other by reef-protected ocean.
The weekend we visited, there was no rain and Mauna Kea's summit, 13,796 feet high, was always visible. As our plane approached Hilo on Thursday I saw waterfalls, arched bridges and the corrugated iron roofs of plantation homes, painted yellow, red, green and turquoise. From the air, the rock gardens and prim stone bridges of the 30-acre Liliuokalani Park looked like minimalist sculpture.
On Saturday morning, the Farmers Market downtown on Kamehameha Avenue teemed with elbow-to-elbow shoppers who scooped up fresh, inexpensive anthuriums, proteas, orchids, lettuce, herbs, homemade vegetable and chicken tamales, gourmet macadamia nuts, fruit breads and fleshy, ruby-hued tomatoes. While I reluctantly pay $3.50 apiece for green anthuriums in Honolulu, at the Hilo Farmers Market they cost $6 for a bunch, and the more common red ones, $3.50 to $5 a bunch.
The most popular greenmarket in the state, it is loved as much for its local color as for the quality and freshness of its produce, grown from sea level and up on the flanks of the island's five volcanoes. A leisurely whirl through the market is like a journey through the many ecosystems and ethnic traditions of the island.
Kamehameha Avenue also is lined with shops and restaurants in historic buildings such as the S. Hata Building, a 1912 structure in the Renaissance Revival style, and the S. H. Kress Building, a 1932 Art Deco structure that temporarily houses an exhibit from the Pacific Tsunami Museum. Photos show the extensive damage to Hilo from the 1946 and 1960 tsunamis. In June, the museum will move down the street to a larger space in the First Hawaiian Bank building, which was designed by C. W. Dickey and built in 1930.
I ducked into Sig Zane Designs a few doors away. Some islanders fly to Hilo just to buy the shop's aloha wear and Haiwaiian collectibles. The store's cotton shirts, dresses and home accessories depict the bold graphic designs of culturally significant Hawaiian plants like koa, breadfruit, taro and lehua blossoms. Aloha shirts cost $45 to $59 and the new long-sleeved linen shirts with koa patterns, $75. The store's salespeople are generous with their time and will explain the plants' meanings and uses.
Every year during the week after Easter, Hilo erupts in the cultural explosion known as the Merrie Monarch Hula Festival. Hotels that line Banyan Drive along the shore are sold out for the week. Employees and owners of businesses like Zane's, who are serious students of hula, get involved in creating costumes and rehearsing.
"Because we live on a volcano, we have a natural energy all around us, always percolating," said Mr. Zane, a dancer who is married to Nalani Kanaka'ole, a revered hula master and one of two sisters who lead Halau O Kekuhi, a local hula school. "The island itself is one of our biggest sources of inspiration. For Merrie Monarch, we're learning a chant about the creation of the islands. We are talking about land giving birth. Here, on this island of volcanoes, it's ongoing, it's real, it's tangible. Here it's a living culture, not one that's just spoken or read about."
Down the street from Sig Zane's, Hana Hou is a vintage buff's nirvana, awash in the tropical prints of retro clothing and custom-made quilts made from Hawaiian fabrics of the 30's and 40's. The mango wood bench in the dressing room, carved from the same tree as the desk near the entrance, is as distinctive as the $150 neckties that Michele Zane-Faridi, the shop's owner (and Sig Zane's sister), recently designed out of vintage aloha-shirt fabrics.
The kimonos at Dragon Mama Natural Fiber Futon Shop, a few feet away from Hana Hou, are vintage as well, but mostly the store sells fabrics. Bolts of extraordinary silks and cottons line one wall for those who prefer their clothing custom made. (When the Dalai Lama visited the island, Dragon Mama sewed his futon and bedding.) No kitsch in this store: The pillows, clothing, obi, futons and home accessories, of natural fibers, express a strong, quiet Japanese esthetic. Items range from a $12 pillow to $32-a-yard silk fabrics.
One block inland, or mauka (which means "toward the mountain") from Kamehameha Avenue, Mauna Kea Galleries on Keawe Street offers hand-colored lithographs, early Hawaiian maps, vintage Hawaiian china and paintings by Hawaii masters.
It is worth a jaunt a few blocks inland to visit the intimate Lyman House Memorial Museum, where you can learn everything from the geology of Hilo to its plantation past, Hawaiian gods and architecture.
Hilo also generates a lion's share of the cookies, candies and snacks given as omiyage in the local custom of gift-giving when flying between islands. In addition to the Puna papayas and macadamia nuts that are Big Island trademarks, there are renowned chocolate-dipped shortbread cookies made by Big Island Candies in Hilo.
Seafood lovers can't miss in Hilo. At the southern end of Hilo Bay, where Lihiwai Street meets Kamehameha Avenue, Suisan Fish Market's early-morning fish auction draws throngs of wholesalers who bid in pidgin, the local patois, for supplies of ahi and mahi-mahi that will soon appear on menus. Those who arrive earlier than 7:30 A.M., when the auction begins, can watch the fishermen unload their catch on the pier.
Ocean Sushi Deli, a year-old sushi bar with zero ambience that specializes in local hybrids like lomi salmon, opihi (limpet), and ahi poke (seasoned raw fish), was so crowded that it took us three tries to get in. The ahi poke sushi, and the lomi salmon with its flavors of salt, onions and tomato, made it well worth the wait -- at $2 an order. We also took advantage of the deli's catering services to order a platter of sushi for takeout -- something to consider on a sunny Hilo day, when the picnic tables on Hilo Bay or at Liliuokalani Park beckon.
Not all the fish in Hilo, however, comes from the sea. Two or three miles down the road from Suisan, past the Onekahakaha Beach Park, a Hilo institution called Seaside Restaurant serves fresh fish straight from aquaculture pond to plate. Because the dining room can get noisy, I like to go before dark and be served on the deck, where I can take in the view of the surrounding natural ponds, glassy and serene. The water reflects clouds and moonlight as clearly as the colors of sunset.
Inside, the restaurant is casual, with large windows and memorabilia from the 1946 tsunami. The room can get noisy when full. I had the aholehole, the silvery, bony fish in the perch family savored by island fish lovers, crisped to perfection and moist inside. Mullet and opakapaka (pink snapper) steamed in ti leaves are also signature items on a menu that also remains attentive to those not favoring seafood, with chicken and steak.
My favorite place for lunch is a simple lunch wagon on Hilo Bay called Island Grinds, north of the bridge. The wooden-sided lunch wagon is the quintessence of Hilo style. It sits under a willowy ironwood tree, with a table and chairs on the beach.
Lisa Werner and her partner, Norina Page, keep the wagon open from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. weekdays except Tuesday. They also run a thriving delivery and catering business. The food -- kalua style (slow-roasted, shredded) turkey, fresh fish, cajun taro burgers, black-bean-and-tempeh burrito, lilikoi (passion fruit) and macadamia nut cole slaw, taro potato salad and daily specials -- is health-conscious, and the servings are generous. And the fresh fish -- delectable every time I've ordered it -- always costs $5.50 with salad, regardless of market price.
Parked on the sand a few feet from shore, the tiny lunch wagon is stronger than it looks, having survived an eight-foot wave two years ago. The wagon and Ford truck were dredged out of the bay. Ms. Werner, who thought all had been lost, said, "When I gingerly opened the door, the inside was pristine, as peaceful and in order as day one."
What do you do when it rains? I asked.
"We stay," she said without hesitation. "We stay."
 
Staying in a historic mansion, sampling taro burgers
 
Getting There
There are no direct flights from the mainland to Hilo, but several carriers, including Aloha Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines, fly into Hilo International Airport in eastern Hawaii from Honolulu and elsewhere in the islands.
On the other side of the island, there is nonstop service from the mainland from Los Angeles and San Francisco on United Airlines into Keahole International Airport in North Kona. The drive across the island can take three to four hours.
 
Where to Stay
Shipman House Bed and Breakfast Inn, 131 Kaiulani Street, Hilo; (800) 627-8447; fax (808) 934-8002. This is Hilo's most impressive inn, a Victorian mansion on a ridge a few blocks from the waterfront in a residential area. There are three rooms in the main house and a guest cottage with two units, each having a queen-size bed and a separate entrance; all have private baths, high ceilings and restored original furnishings. Rates are $130 to $150 a night, single or double; $25 for an extra person, breakfast included. Shipman House is on the National Register of Historic Places and the State Historic Register. On the Web: www.hilo-hawaii.com.
Hawaii Naniloa Resort, 93 Banyan Drive, Hilo; (800) 367-5360; fax (808) 969-6622. This high-rise 325-room hotel on the ocean is close to Coconut Island, a reefy islet where Hilo children love to fish. Double rooms, $100 to $140. The hotel has two outdoor swimming pools and an indoor spa, with whirlpool and sauna and fitness equipment. A nine-hole golf course across the street belongs to the hotel.
Hilo Bay Hotel, 87 Banyan Drive, Hilo; (800) 367-5102; fax (808) 935-7903. This is an affordable no-frills hotel with 143 modest rooms, ranging from $59 to $114 for doubles.
 
Where to Eat
Hilo's bayfront area along Kamehameha Avenue is the town's restaurant row, with cafes serving everything from pizza (Cafe Pesto), fancy sandwiches (Canoe Cafe) and Mexican fare (Reuben's). Away from the avenue, other dining choices include:
Seaside Restaurant, 1790 Kalanianaole Street; (808) 935-8825. This is just past James Kealoha Beach Park, across from what residents call Four-Mile Beach. The furnishings are formica-style casual, but there are stellar views. Dinner entrees start at $10; a complete dinner of fresh steamed opakapaka or pan-fried aholehole, is about $23.95. Dinner only Tuesday through Sunday.
Ocean Sushi Deli, 239 Keawe Street; (808) 961-6625. Sushi, traditional and unconventional, sells briskly at this tiny Japanese diner for $1.50 to $2 an order. Good food, takeout, no credit cards; family platters $16.95 and up. Open 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily.
Island Grinds, on Hilo Bay, under the ironwoods. Heading north from the Hilo airport with the ocean on your right, take the first driveway over the bridge, past the Suisan Fish Market on Kamehameha Highway. A lunch of fresh fish is $5.50, Cajun taro burgers are $3.50, and the lilikoi-macadamia nut cole slaw is $1. Open Monday and Wednesday to Friday, 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Closed Tuesday.
 
Sightseeing
Anyone can take a free self-directed tour of downtown Hilo by following a map and leaflet with historical information available in some hotels, shops, the Hilo Main Street office at 252 Kamehameha Avenue, and at the information kiosk across from the Main Street office, on Bayfront. The walking tour covers eight square blocks of the 12 blocks that make up downtown Hilo.
The Lyman House Memorial Museum, 276 Haili Street, (808) 935-5021, is Hilo's cultural center. The museum is open Monday through Saturday, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission is $5 for adults, $2.50 for children 5 and under, $3 for seniors 60 and over. On exhibit are Hawaiian artifacts, implements, a thatched home, a Taoist shrine, Japanese stoneware and a large mineral collection.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: What Happened On Horton Road

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves; Evelyn Nieves is a columnist for The Times

 BODY:
 Kelly ann tinyes's ninth annual 14th-birthday ceremony turned out much like the others.
It was another gusty March 5, the sky a cardboard gray. At 4 p.m., with rush-hour traffic starting to clog the tightly packed streets of Valley Stream, doors up and down Horton Road opened and neighbors began the walk to the Tinyes house. Outside their red Cape Cod, Kelly's parents, Richard and Victoria, and their son, Richie Jr., 17, waited on the square lawn with several of Victoria's relatives and about 50 pink and white balloons. 
 When 30 people had gathered in the street in front of the driveway, the balloons were handed out, and Victoria Tinyes, standing in the middle of the group, called out to the assembled crowd, "Is everyone ready?" Everyone was.
"Happy Birthday, Kelly!" they all shouted, letting their balloons go. They watched, heads tilted upward, as the balloons disappeared in the clouds. "This is the first year none of them got stuck in that tree," Mrs. Tinyes said, scanning the arching branches of a mature oak in front of the house. Everyone agreed. Then, with the quickest of goodbyes, the crowd was gone.
That was it. The one event of the year on Horton Road was over in 10 minutes.
It was very different here nine years ago, before Kelly was lured into a neighbor's house and beaten, stabbed and strangled to death on March 3, 1989, by one of Horton Road's own sons. This tract of post-World War II starter houses on Long Island -- where blue-collar families from Brooklyn and Queens settled down for the long haul, grateful to have landed in the suburban dream of Nassau County -- used to be a happy place. There were block parties and pool parties and garage-sale barbecues. The 19 families who lived on the street knew one another's in-laws and watched one another's kids; the 27 school-age children acted like cousins. It was like a working-class commune.
No one has moved (except an elderly woman, to a nursing home, and an elderly man, who died). Yet Horton Road now seems like any other street where neighbors say hello when their eyes meet but don't bother when they don't. It would be better if it were that way -- if it could be explained as just another neighborhood where people are too busy for one another. Instead, Horton Road is a neighborhood wrecked by a murder, where children grew up too soon because of it and lingering questions still surround the crime.
Even the brief ritual for Kelly's birthday, which comes two days after the anniversary of her death, causes consternation and division. There are those who think that the best way for Horton Road to get past what happened is to stop bringing it up, especially in public. Then there are those who are simply not welcome. They include the neighbors who have remained cordial to John and Elizabeth Golub, those who think that even though the Golubs' son Robert was convicted of murdering the Tinyes girl, the parents are still deserving of sympathy. And least welcome of all are the Golubs themselves.
This is no secret. In fact, while neighbors were gathering in front of the Tinyes house for the annual ritual in March, the Golub house, five doors away, was dark, as though no one was home -- despite the Toyota in the driveway.
At least half the children on Horton Road stopped playing outside after what everyone here refers to simply as the Murder. The Golub house, the first Tudor house in a row divided between that style and similar Cape Cods, has become the Murder House. Kelly, pretty and popular, a favorite baby sitter for many younger children on the street, has become the symbol of lost innocence. Friends still keep the presents they planned to give her at a surprise birthday party the day after she disappeared.
Almost since that day, people on Horton Road have been saying that the Golubs should move. (Shortly after the murder, nine families issued a news release stating, "The Golubs are not welcome back to Horton Road.") Neighbors still say that they don't know why the Golubs have stubbornly resisted the idea of leaving.
Others also wonder why the Tinyeses haven't moved. That way the hatred that has fueled the two families, sparking more than 50 harassment complaints to the police, and ruling the neighborhood for nine long years, might end.
"They should be the ones to move," Mrs. Tinyes said between answering phones at Victoria Collision, the auto-body shop the Tinyeses own by the Queens border and Kennedy Airport, just a few miles from home. Mrs. Tinyes has broad shoulders and, at 43, an open, unlined face, with big hazel eyes and a short mass of blond-highlighted curls. She works as a medical assistant in a doctor's office when she is not answering phones here. Above her, on a shelf, sits Kelly's final school photo, reproduced more than a hundred times in the newspapers. The girl in the photo has dark blue eyes, long dark hair and a spray of freckles across the nose. She is slightly smiling.
"The Golubs should've moved a long time ago," Mrs. Tinyes said. "In the beginning, they said they would."
Richard Tinyes, a burly 44-year-old with blond hair and a beard, sat at his desk a few yards away from his wife. "We would've moved a long time ago if we could afford it," he said. "But we couldn't. When Kelly died, for more than a year, I couldn't focus on the business. There was the tremendous emotional upheaval. I can't even calculate how much business we lost. Kelly's murder hurt us mentally, physically and financially."
The Golubs say much the same. They moved to Horton Road in 1967, when their first child, Adele, was 2 years old and Mrs. Golub was pregnant with Robert, the first of two sons. For the most part, the family stayed on the fringes of the neighborhood's social fabric. They spent much of their spare time at the nearby Keystone Yacht Club, where they kept a fishing boat. Neighbors say they began spending more and more time at the club after becoming pariahs on Horton Road. The Golubs haven't moved from the street, they say, because the house is about all they have left. They can't afford to sell.
Mrs. Golub, who is 56 and does clerical work in a Valley Stream office, is a short woman with a raspy, smoker's voice and jangly, nervous movements. She said her husband, who is 66 and runs a Getty service station in nearby Hewlett, has a heart condition worsened by stress. She will not say much more. "It is true that not just one family was affected by what happened," she said. "Publicity just makes it worse. So while we're still here, we'd rather not talk. Hopefully, one day when we're able, we'll leave."
Neither family wants to admit that they are locked in a battle of wills. The Tinyeses refuse to move because they believe that justice was only partly served in the case; they are hoping one day to see it through. They, and many others, remain convinced that Robert Golub, then 21, did not commit the murder alone. They think he had an accomplice: Robert's brother, John J., who was 14 then and who the police say was with friends in another part of the Golub house at the time of Kelly's death.
The Golubs have held tight to a position diametrically opposed to the Tinyeses': neither son had anything to do with the murder. Robert was framed, they say. He was given an inadequate defense in a trial marked by scant circumstantial evidence, frequent prejudicial outbursts from the Tinyeses, sensational media coverage and a jury swept away by the emotion of it all. John J., they claim, has been viciously maligned, his life ruined by innuendo. He was driven out of Horton Road, where he has not been seen since Thanksgiving 1989, and forced to use aliases to avoid harassment from people in the neighborhood. (Speaking for him, Mrs. Golub said that John J., who has never publicly discussed the murder since the day after, when he waved to reporters from his bedroom window and said he didn't do it, was "definitely not" interested in being interviewed now.)
The saga of Horton Road has just about exhausted the patience of the Nassau County Police Department. What so many in the neighborhood call a murder mystery, the police call a closed case. At his desk in police headquarters in Mineola, Sgt. Robert Edwards, who commanded the Tinyes case, sighed a long, deep sigh before he began what has become a frequent defense of the investigation.
"The facts, he said, "don't bear out the theories. We know the Tinyeses think John J. had something to do with the crime. We don't have a single shred of evidence to support that, and you can quote me on that. There was nothing tying John J. to the crime. There was evidence tying Robert to the crime. Blood evidence, a bite mark, a print. And he was the only one in the house who had the time to commit the crime."
Kelly Tinyes was last seen entering the Golub home at about 3:15 p.m. on March 3, 1989, after receiving a phone call from someone in that house. As far as anyone knew, she had never been there before. Her 8-year-old brother, for whom she was baby-sitting, had answered the phone and said the caller identified himself as "John." Both Robert and John J. denied making the call.
Four people were in the Golub house at the time Kelly entered: Robert, an unemployed bodybuilder; John J., a freshman at Hewlett High School, and two of John J.'s friends. Both friends passed lie detector tests ("with flying colors," Sergeant Edwards said), supporting their contention that they never saw Kelly. They described how they and John J. smoked pot together in a spare bedroom, had a snack in the kitchen and then left to go play basketball at about 3:45 p.m. John J., according to the boys, left them only a few times, to turn up the stereo in another room.
Everyone in the Golub house at the time Kelly entered, the police said, was a suspect at the beginning of the investigation. "We've been through this a hundred times," Sergeant Edwards said. "We've even had the Tinyeses come in and speak to the Chief." (The lead detectives in the case, Richard Wells and George Pierce, both retired, as well as the Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, declined to be interviewed.)
But it is impossible to talk to people on Horton Road without hearing the stories suggesting there is more to Kelly's death than the police will say.
Jaclyn DeLuca, 15, is haunted by her belief, widely known on Horton Road, that as a 6-year-old she watched Kelly being assaulted in the Golub basement through a jalousied window. She believes she saw more than one person doing it, perhaps even more than two.
Plagued by insomnia and depression, she has been in therapy since shortly after the murder. "I looked in and I saw things going on," she said, standing with her mother, grandmother and 17-year-old sister in front of her house, across from the Tinyeses', after Kelly's birthday ceremony. "I know what I saw."
Laura Panarelli, Jaclyn's grandmother, remembers Jaclyn coming home the afternoon of the murder and seeming distressed by something she had seen. "This was before we knew Kelly was missing," she said. "We didn't know what she was talking about."
Two days later, the police interviewed Jaclyn. Her mother, Pam, a close friend of the Tinyeses, said that while the police later discredited her account, they believed Jaclyn at first. "She told them things that blew them away," she said. "She said Kelly's hair was being pulled out. They had her draw pictures of the murder room and the cuts on Kelly's body. She knew things."
The police ultimately discounted Jaclyn's story as the product of a young child's imagination. They claim that her story was unpersuasive, and that other children contradicted her account of what she was doing that afternoon.
"The police are liars," Pam DeLuca said.
Jaclyn nodded solemnly. "They're all liars."
The DeLucas were among several families compelled to turn to long-term therapy to help their children cope with the murder. They include the Callahans, who have lived next door to the Golubs for 31 years. Carole Callahan said that her daughter Donna, 12 years old when Kelly was murdered, has spent years trying to overcome her shock and guilt over the crime.
Donna Callahan, along with Jimmy Walsh, a 6-year-old who lived two doors down, watched as Kelly entered the Golubs' house the afternoon she disappeared. Five minutes later, when Richie Tinyes came outside looking for his sister, Donna told him that Kelly was in the Golubs' house. Richie and Jimmy, who told the police he saw John J. open the door for Kelly, knocked repeatedly, but there was no answer. (Sergeant Edwards said Jimmy Walsh was "very young," and thus could have been mistaken about who let Kelly in.)
The police conducted a search of the Golub house the next day, where the body was found around noon. For years, Donna was racked with guilt for sitting on her stoop yards from the murder scene and being unable to help Kelly. "For a long time afterward, she wouldn't speak at all," Mrs. Callahan said. "We had to keep the blinds on the side of the house that faced the Golub house closed. She wouldn't go upstairs. We wanted to move, but she didn't want to, and her therapist said it would be better if we didn't."
It has been a while since the police have had to mediate a fight between the Tinyeses and Golubs. For four years, the two families were fighting each other's charges of harassment and menacing in court. But the last run-in between the two families was more than a year ago, when John J. Golub was arrested in Hicksville on drug charges. The Tinyeses went to his arraignment in Hempstead. Not a word was exchanged between the two families, but afterward, John Golub Sr. blamed the persecution on Horton Road for driving his son to drugs.
The Tinyeses live with the idea that someday they could perhaps get the case reopened. "We try to lead normal lives," Mr. Tinyes said, showing off his son's stock-car race trophies in his office. "But it doesn't make the pain go away."
"It's not getting any easier," Mrs. Tinyes said. "If anything, it's getting worse."
A copy of their daughter's official police file, obtained through a Freedom of Information request, is dogeared from readings. For years, they've been looking for some detail that will convince authorities to reopen the case.
Mr. Tinyes held up his daughter's autopsy report. "This could be a key," he said. Kelly was a big girl, five-nine and an athletic 120 pounds, and would have fought her attacker, he said. "Yet she had no defensive wounds. In an attack that lasted 20 to 30 minutes, how could that be?" He suggested that that could help prove someone was holding her while the other beat and slashed her.
But two experts consulted to examine the autopsy report for this article, Dr. Michael Baden, a former New York City Medical Examiner, and Lawrence Kobilinsky, a forensics expert at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, each said that the report does not provide any proof that two people committed the grisly crime.
"The bottom line is you can't tell," Dr. Baden said. "She had many, many wounds. Some of them could have been defensive."
On Horton Road, it is becoming clear that the questions about how -- and why -- Kelly Tinyes was lured into the Golub house and killed may never be answered. "The only way is for Robert Golub to talk," said Pam DeLuca.
He never has. From the time the body was found, he has sworn his innocence. After the trial, he expressed frustration that he had followed his court-appointed lawyer's advice not to take the stand. At his sentencing, he gave a jumbled, barely audible statement. He made cryptic remarks suggesting that someone from the Golub home made the call, but that it wasn't he. "Who called Kelly up on March 3 from our home?" he said. "Who met Kelly in our home? Who knew her birthday was the next day?"
Behind the massive stone walls of Attica Correctional Facility, where he is serving 25 years to life, Robert Golub has little to add.
"I don't see the point," he said during a brief and awkward interview. Small and soft-spoken, he no longer looks like the bewildered, baby-faced bodybuilder whom people saw at his trial. At 30, he wears his hair combed back, with a neatly trimmed beard and wire-rimmed glasses.
His appeal denied, his request for a transfer to a prison closer to home postponed, he spends his days working in the kitchen and his evenings reading and working out.
He hasn't seen his parents in more than a year, his sister, who is married, in three or four years, and his brother in "the whole time" he has been in prison, he said. For his parents and sister, he said, the drive from Long Island to this forlorn patch of upstate New York -- about seven hours each way -- is too long to make frequent trips. As for his brother, he said, "We don't really get along."
"I'm not really comfortable talking about this," he said. He tapped his fingers on the scarred little square table in the visiting room, politely waiting to be dismissed from his visit, clearly anxious to go back to the relative comfort of his cell.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1553 words

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dannel Malloy;
Stamford Offers Prekindergarten at Age 4

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
AS Mayor Dannel Malloy of Stamford sat through the lengthy meetings of the School Improvement Panel at the State Capitol he had an idea. Listening to the data about the importance of early education, he decided to create an opportunity for all 4-year-olds in Stamford to attend prekindergarten. By September, 360 children will be enrolled in the new school readiness program. Every 4-year-old child who lives in Stamford will be eligible, with fees charged on a sliding scale from $5 to $135 a week. According to the Mayor, Stamford will be the first city in the nation to offer a prekindergarten program to all its children. "What we want to do is guarantee all 4-year-old children in the City of Stamford a prekindergarten experience regardless of their financial circumstances," Mr. Malloy said. "It's the single largest step we can take to resolve disparity with other towns."
Stamford is a diverse city where the extremes of wealth and poverty co-exist. Stamford, which has many immigrants, has schools reporting 41 languages spoken by students. "Primarily for socio-economic reasons some of our children start at a lower level than other children and we want to address that," Mr. Malloy said. 
 The Mayor pointed out that in Connecticut the law does not require school attendance until the age of 7,
Mr. Malloy recently discussed school readiness in an interview. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Do you think that the preschool experience will have long lasting results?
A. We are cognizant of all the scientific research that the mind develops at a much quicker pace than once thought. The early development of the human brain is extremely important for setting the table, if you will, for potential future accomplishment.
If you wait until age 5 you are missing a huge opportunity to impact and to grow people's minds. In essence what I am trying to do is start kindergarten at age 4. For the time being we are looking at a combination of public and private providers with the private providers filling the gap for people who can't afford it. I would not be surprised if 10, 15 years from now school starts at age 4. I hope it does.
Q. What kind of numbers are we talking about?
A. We estimate there are 1,200 to 1,350 4-year-olds in the city. We are planning for 360 children full time to start.
We understand that some parents want a full-year program because it has a work component, or welfare to work. Some parents will only want a school year and some parents will want a part-time program. We'll design a program to accommodate those interests.
We'll come to understand better over the first year of operation how many slots will be devoted to part time versus full time. We do have more capacity in a number of buildings. We'll be able to meet the needs as we identify them.
We've estimated that 450 children will come to school in September without a prekindergarten experience. It's very bad for those children to not have that experience. It is also very difficult for the children in the class who have had the preschool experience. The teacher has to spend a disproportionate amount of time on covering ground that otherwise would be covered in a prekindergarten experience.
Middle class families pay for private providers. They are ready to go. They are ready to hit the ground running but they are slowed by the one third of the class who aren't ready. So this kind of program has a positive impact for those children who otherwise wouldn't have the access to prekindergarten and it is also very important to children who do have but would otherwise be held back.
Q. What about funding and organization?
A. The state will help us operate this program with two and half million dollars next year. We've also set up a very unique way of running this program. It is a partnership between the city itself, the Board of Education and the Child Care Center of Stamford, a private provider. The private provider will really be running the program. The Stamford Board of Education will supply eight master teachers who will be supervising the program. Otherwise, the private provider will be the operator.
Special education has been one focus of what were trying to do to make sure that special education children are thought about first and foremost in this context.
Q. Which children are you expecting to enroll?
A. We want a mix of children so the program has a certain quality, flavor, mix. Really we are trying to address the needs of children who otherwise would not find themselves a seat elsewhere. Either they can't afford it or the parents may not know enough to enroll their children in prekindergarten.
We also have some cultural divides to overcome. We found that Central Americans and Hispanics are somewhat reluctant to send their children off to school as early as Anglo-Americans born in this country. There are some cultural differences. We'll chip away at that over the next few years. We expect racial and economic diversity in the prekindergarten classes.
Q. What will the children learn?
A. First of all, they don't learn eight hours a day. We've come to understand that there's an educational need in a portion of each day but that much of the full day activities are socialization and child care.
On the other hand some portion of each day should be devoted to learning, so our program is designed to accommodate that. They will have art and drawing, their letters, the precursors to kindergarten that exist in every prekindergarten. My children learned colors, shapes, letters. They were exposed to gymnastics and music and dance. Those are the types of things that you want to make sure children are exposed to.
What we're doing is building children's potential for learning later in life. We are making those connections for them at a stage where their minds can evolve to a higher degree than if those connections are made later in life.
There's a difference between expanding someone's potential and expanding their actual performance. Performance may measure other things, whether one's culture supports education, other socio-economic factors. Some of those factors will be overcome later in life.
If you have not expanded that person's mind, if you've not created a better brain at a younger age, then their performance potential becomes limited. I think it's important to measure performance in grades. I think that scientific evidence is so clear that the mind's development needs to take place early and if it doesn't it's never going to. So you're missing opportunities. That's really what this is about.
Q. As Mayor why are you so concerned with educational matters?
A. Historically, mayors have not been involved in education. It is only a recent phenomenon over the last few years. I'm an advocate of mayors becoming more involved in education systems and improving education.
We created a very destructive model in the United States, this separation of education government from general government. Perhaps it made sense at one period in time, maybe it was a protection against cronyism or political payoffs. I don't know the exact history. But what has happened is its turned the system on its head.
Here in Stamford I want the city to maintain school buildings and provide custodial and maintenance operations for it. To put it in perspective. I have 10 engineers working for me in maintaining infrastructure. The Board of Education has none and yet they are maintaining 18 buildings that represent the bulk of our capital, with the exception of roads and sidewalks.
I think that looking at this divide between general government and education I see that American education had a period of time when it was not as successful as it should have been. The American people tolerated that because the system was not set up to hold anyone accountable. That's very different from general city government.
There's been a tremendous amount of pressure on general city government throughout the United States to reform and address modernization to a higher degree than has been applied to education. I would like to help the educational systems accommodate that change.
Q. Do you think schools should be funded in a different way?
A. Our reliance in the Northeast on property taxes to fund education is a bad system. Reliance on property taxes is one of the things that's killed some cities in the United States. In Connecticut I think Bridgeport, New Haven, Hartford and Waterbury were damaged by the reliance on property taxes. It caused the taxes to rise in those communities beyond the ability of the middle class to afford thus driving the middle class out.
In Stamford, for instance, 7 percent of our money comes from state and Federal government. We're paying 93 percent, probably a higher percentage than any other city in the United States. Our source of funds is property tax and personal property tax.
New Haven, Hartford and Bridgeport rely on other systems. The irony is that if the state had contributed historically to those systems at levels that they are now contributing, the cities would be much more successful today. So you have killed the golden goose, the goose that provided the jobs, the culture and education. Now the burden of supporting them is much greater.

LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Downtown;
At the World Trade Center, Things Are Looking Up

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE leases were signed, one after another. Bankers Trust took 274,000 square feet, Aon Risk Services 396,000, Oppenheimer Funds 181,000, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield 461,000 and, finally, J&H Marsh & McLennan committed to 361,000 square feet earlier this month.
All the space is at one building complex, the World Trade Center, whose twin 110-story towers and other buildings have 10.5 million square feet of office space and an additional 300,000 square feet of retail space. 
 As the market for office space in midtown has tightened and rental rates increased, tenants have been looking to downtown as a cheaper alternative. Over the last year, those seeking large blocks of space have been finding them at the trade center, which had many vacancies as a result of the 1993 terrorist bombing and the shrinkage of the financial industry in the early part of the decade.
"In January 1997 we had about an 80 percent occupancy rate," said Cherrie Nanninga, director of real estate for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the complex. Twenty percent of 10.5 million square feet of space is 2.1 million, which would be a substantial building by itself.
But as a result of the last year's work, Ms. Nanninga, said the complex is over 90 percent occupied and expects to it reach the 95 percent mark by the end of the year. That, she said, would be about as full as the center is likely to get, since there is almost always someone moving in or out. "Ninety-seven percent occupancy would be full," said Ms. Nanninga, whose name is pronounced NAN-in-gay.
In all, the trade center reached agreements to lease 2.2 million square feet of office space in 1997, or almost a quarter of the 9.6 million square feet leased in the downtown district.
Real estate executives and brokers say the trade center has benefited from both the general resurgence of the downtown office market -- which was so depressed just a few years ago that the city offered a financial incentive program to lure prospective tenants -- and the Port Authority's newfound willingness to be more flexible than in the past.
Mary Ann Tighe, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG, who helped broker many of the recent deals at the center, said Port Authority officials had become less bureaucratic and more entrepreneurial in recent years. "Now they are willing to give us things that could not have been discussed in the past," she said.
She said the deal with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was an example of that new thinking. "Empire always had a subsidized cafeteria for its employees, which is very expensive," she said. "You have the cost of the real estate, plus the manpower and the subsidy and the economics were not working within the confines of the Port's standard proposal for leasing the space.."
To get around the problem, Port Authority officials agreed to expand the cafeteria it already had in the complex for its own employees to accommodate those from Empire. "That is showing immense flexibility for a government agency," Ms. Tighe said. "They were going to renovate it anyway, so adding the capacity was not that big a deal."
Bradley Gerla, a downtown specialist for Jones Lang Wootton, agreed that there was a new attitude at the Port, as the authority is usually called. "They have streamlined the entire process," he said. "I'm doing a deal for 10,000 square feet that would have been impossible five or six years ago. By the time they got finished negotiating terms, the tenant would have signed someplace else."
THE cafeteria expansion is just a small part of the renovations going on at the trade center, where all 240 elevators and 70 escalators will be modernized with new controls for better service and shorter waiting times. The Port Authority has already spent $325 million on the 25-year-old center and expects to spend $400 million more before the upgrade is finished.
The improvements include added communications capacity and increased electrical capacity to power the personal computers and fax machines that were laboratory projects when the trade center was designed.
Mindful that the bombing knocked out power to the buildings, redundant sources of power have been added, including a cable through the PATH tube to New Jersey in the building in case the power flow in New York somehow fails.
Security overall has been tightened, with guards checking employee passes at the elevators. There is still underground parking, but it is available only to tenants who have an electronic card to open the garage door.
Port officials have been upgrading the 300,000 square feet of retail space in the center, to make it more of a destination for shoppers, not just a service for tenants. A long-closed Alexander's is being converted into a Marche, a European-style market/restaurant; a Warner Brothers Studio Store has been installed in the underground plaza that unites the complex, and a Banana Republic store is going into a space vacated after to the merger of Chase and Chemical banks.
The center is a natural retail destination, Ms. Nanninga said. "We have 1.8 million visitors to our observation deck a year," she said. In addition, largely because of the conversion of nearby downtown office buildings to residences, there are 20,000 people who now live in lower Manhattan who add to the retail base.
Some brokers say the aggressive leasing campaign and renovation of the center are part of an effort to prepare for sale to a private investor, possibly a real estate investment trust. REIT's typically prefer to buy fully leased properties, so their income is predictable.
The Port Authority has been studying the possibility of a sale, but officials say no decision has been made. "The Port Authority has been doing all this work in leasing and retail to enhance the value of the center," said James S. Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a tenant's broker. "They used to be 9 to 5 people, but now they are pushing through things they have never done before. I believe they will test the market at some point, and a REIT like Vornado or Mack-Cali would be logical candidates to buy."
Downtown locations are an alternative for companies unwilling to pay the higher rents of midtown, real estate executives say. "For a B building in midtown you are talking rents in the mid $30's" a square foot annually, said Barry Gosin, chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate. "Downtown, it is more like the mid to upper 20's."
He said the residential conversion program had helped make downtown a more attractive location than in the early 1990's, when the streets were all but deserted on weekends and after business hours. "There are 3,000 to 4,000 residential units and a few new restaurants," he said. "There is a need for more, but the fact is there are people on the street."
As a result of the demand that is shifting from midtown, the vacancy rate in the downtown area has dropped sharply. According to John V. Wheeler, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, the overall vacancy rate is 12 percent, with Class A space in single digits at 8 percent. The overall vacancy rate compares to 20.2 percent in 1995.
But Michael Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate, said that a word of caution was in order when thinking about the trade center and the downtown office market. "A lot of what we are seeing is growth in financial services," he said. "The firms are adding salesmen and staff as the Dow rises. That is very ephemeral absorption, because Wall Street sheds staff and space when the tide turns."
But for now investors appear to believe the good times will last, because they are paying prices unheard of less than a year ago, according to Howard Michael, chairman of the Carlton Group, a real estate investment banking firm.
"The guys who were paying $50 a foot to buy buildings six to nine months ago are paying $110 to $120 a foot now," he said. "Downtown is still the cheapest real estate in Manhattan, and it's the best opportunity for further growth."

It now has more than 90 percent occupancy, she says, adding that she expects 95 percent by year's end. That, she says, is about as full as it is likely to get since there is always an ebb an flow of tenants. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)
