LENGTH: 1477 words

HEADLINE: ART;
The Animated Mind Behind the Mannequin

BYLINE: By STEVEN HENRY MADOFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CHARLES RAY is watching. His gaze may be following you from the big photographic self-portrait called "Yes," from 1990, in which his slightly zoned-out eyes (he was on LSD at the time) seem to wander after you. Maybe it is the "Self-Portrait" mannequin of the same year, in which a very stiff Ray likeness wears the artist's favorite sailing outfit (he loves to sail his 40-foot fiberglass sloop out of his home port in Oxnard, Calif.), the eyes just a little wall-eyed, following you across the room. Or maybe it is the eyes of one of the eight naked Ray-like figures that stare out from the onanistic proceedings in his most talked-about sculpture, the 1992 "Oh! Charley, Charley, Charley . . ."
But Mr. Ray is definitely watching. What interests him may not be you exactly. In the puzzlelike way that the artist thinks, his interest is perhaps more about the idea of what it is like to be looking at a piece of art that seems to be looking back, and what that does, not only for the viewer but for the disorienting force of the work. 
 Formal power and psychological power constitute the two elements in the equation of Mr. Ray's quirky art. That math has added up, with the artist's growing international reputation, a tenured professorship in studio art at U.C.L.A., prices for his sculpture climbing to more than $400,000, and now a retrospective of his sculpture, photographic and film works that opens Thursday and remains on view until Aug. 30 at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York.
It is slightly disconcerting to meet Mr. Ray in front of the peeling one-story white house that he shares with the artist Jennifer Pastor in the working-class Marvista section of Los Angeles. To a stranger he looks like one of his self-portrait mannequins, only animate. But then "disconcerting" is a strategic element in his repertory. Slender, with tousled brown hair, his shirt untucked, his jeans wanting a few more fly buttons buttoned, Mr. Ray, 45, pushes past a bramble of bougainvillea that fairly blocks his front door and strides through to the sparsely furnished living room.
Sitting at a simple table, staring through thick tortoise-shell glasses, he says: "The thing about my work is that I try to keep it a little distant, a little stiff, in a sense, so that it doesn't give off too much specific meaning. Like with the mannequins, I wanted to make something sort of abstract but also real. Something almost invisible. So I thought if I lopped off the head of a mannequin and put a kind of generalized copy of my own on, the effect would oscillate between abstract and real, to startle, to get into your head.
"You know, I like the equation of the work to go both ways. Like in 'Oh! Charley, Charley, Charley . . . ,' it looks like I'm really vulnerable, revealing everything, but in the end I reveal nothing. The figures of me are so self-involved that it's a closed system, no expression, almost sad rather than erotic. On one level, I was dealing with the fear of AIDS, contamination -- the subjects of the day.
"But what I was thinking about was Rodin's 'Burghers of Calais,' the forms, the figures turning in space, wondering how do you make a figurative group sculpture today? It's not like I could do the City Council of L.A. The repetitiveness of my identity was a way to tie the piece together. The kinkiness of the sex was another way to do that with subject matter, with a patina of sensationalism."
That patina of the sensational and theatrical has been carefully applied by Mr. Ray since his student days at the University of Iowa and Rutgers University, where he first married performance art to a string of movements: minimalism, process art, conceptualism. He photographed himself in a wall-length series of deadpan pictures in which he dons all the clothes he owns, piece by piece. He folded himself over a plank leaning against his studio wall, playing up the threat of Richard Serra's propped sculptures of the time, but with a sense of the body as sculpture that was reminiscent of Bruce Nauman's art.
In Mr. Ray's work of the late 70's and into the 80's, he lay unclothed and seemingly squashed under metal slabs; shoved himself inside minimalist metal boxes, his arms and legs protruding; stood naked against a wall, with his head stuck through a shelf to seem disconcertingly -- in the spirit of the mannequins to come -- like another still-life object.
From the 80's on, Mr. Ray's art has only pushed harder at his practice of weird displacement and sculptural economy, with an increasingly trippy sense of what a little disorientation can do.
Consider "Ink Box" of 1986, in which a black minimalist cube brimming with ink tricks viewers into thinking its top is solid. (Viewers beware.) Or "Rotating Circle," from 1988, which is installed flush in a gallery wall and spins so fast that it seems to be still. (The motor's high-pitched sound is the giveaway.) Or "Tabletop," from the same year, whose six nondescript objects are rotated so slowly by hidden motors that the viewer who looks away and then back will find everything moved just enough to induce instant head scratching. Or Mr. Ray's "Firetruck," done for the 1993 Whitney Biennial: a toy red hook-and-ladder blown up spectacularly to life size, double parked in front of the museum to bring on double takes.
And then there is last year's "Unpainted Sculpture," a fatally wrecked Pontiac Grand Am whose every part was recast in fiberglass, put back together and painted a soft gray. As Richard Flood, chief curator of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, the institution that bought the work, says: "It's all about disaster, and yet it looks like Bernini's 'Ecstasy of St. Teresa,' with all this shattered material like luxurious folds of cloth; so Baroque and so modern; so full of death and yet so abstract, the way the gray turns detail into a kind of haze. It almost floats." Trippy indeed.
FOR Mr. Ray, formalism and conceptualism, interior and exterior, physical and mental have become fluid properties. What goes on in the work is what Paul Schimmel, chief curator of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and the organizer of Mr. Ray's traveling retrospective, calls "Charley sculpting his own psyche." Then he puts Mr. Ray into context.
"When you think about the prominent art of the late 80's and the 90's -- the work of Jeff Koons, Bob Gober, Damien Hirst, Katarina Fritsch, of Charley -- you see that it's a generation investigating their psyches and projecting them onto a broader cultural landscape. They do it through work that is disorienting, dreamlike and open-ended. There is a kind of end-of-the-century symbolism about it, where the artists are asking, as Gauguin did 100 years ago in the title of a painting, 'Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?' "
For three hours Mr. Ray has been explaining his work, getting up to point out titles from his living-room bookshelves -- "The Puzzling World of Polyhedral Dissections," "What Computers Still Can't Do: A Critique of Artificial Reason," "Shapes, Space and Symmetry." He's awkward and intent, encouraging, his voice emphatic, then trailing off. He talks about his love of science's disinterested cool in observing the world. He speaks of his childhood in Chicago, and of the brutality and discipline of his high school years at Marmion Military School, in Aurora, Ill. If Mr. Schimmel is right, then how does all this disorienting, distant, funny, disturbing art reflect the artist's psyche?
Looking around for a while, hesitating, starting, then starting again, Mr. Ray isn't sure what to say. "It's so slippery, what a work is really about, I don't want to sound like an idiot. You know, the sensational part, shocking Mom and Dad, that's a real boring little issue. It's easy. I use the topical like engineers use the sun's gravity to whip a space probe further into space with the extra momentum. That allows me to get the viewer in, but what's hard is to get the work to sit right, to get the syntax of a piece exactly, as Anthony Caro would say. It's a squishy, vibrant equation -- something where all the parts intersect perfectly, something that breathes psychologically."
"In all of it," Mr. Ray says, "I'm dealing with myself in relation to the institutions that define me. You know, my mother and father, school, the Catholic Church -- so that I don't accept those negative things that label me, don't follow those arrows into myself. That distance in my work, I suppose you could say it's to stay out on the porch instead of going into the house, psychologically."
He laughs uncomfortably and gets up. On the way to the door, he points out another book, one he admires for its subversiveness. Among all of his science and math books, it's by another doctor, Dr. Seuss. Its title is "Oh, the Thinks You Can Think!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: OH! CHARLEY Charles Ray in his studio with a muffler, par for the artist whose retrospective opens Thursday at the Whitney. (Ann Summa for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (91%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (91%); NEW YORK, USA (77%); 

CITY: LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (91%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (53%); 

COMPANY: WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART (NYC) UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA (LOS ANGELES) (54%); 

ORGANIZATION: WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART (NYC) UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA (LOS ANGELES) (54%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (91%); CALIFORNIA, USA (91%); NEW YORK, USA (77%); LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (91%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (53%); 

SUBJECT: ART; PHOTOGRAPHY ARTISTS & PERFORMERS (90%); SCULPTURE (89%); PHOTOGRAPHY (78%); VISUAL ARTS (78%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (71%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (64%); 

PERSON: MADOFF, STEVEN HENRY; RAY, CHARLES

LOAD-DATE: May 31, 1998



705 of 755 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1998 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: May 31, 1998,

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2592 words

HEADLINE: Classical Radio Plays Only To Sweet Tooths

BYLINE: By DAVID SCHIFF; David Schiff is a composer on the faculty of Reed College in Portland, Ore.

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
CLASSICAL-MUSIC radio stations in the United States were once chock-full of nutty professors, eccentrics whose quirky opinions served to educate and inspire generations of listeners. In the 1950's and 60's in New York, for example, the obsessive Fleetwood, on WNCN, might play a selection four times in a row if he liked, and the outrageous Seymour DeKoven, on WFUV, proselytized fanatically for "barococo" music. Far more than purveyors of musical appreciation, they were models of musical devotion.
Today there are just a few strong personalities left on the air, like the durable and majestically ponderous Robert J. Lurtsema on WGBH in Boston, and their futures are imperiled by a bland format that has become the norm on commercial and public stations alike. (Mr. Lurtsema himself has been cut back to weekend mornings.) Station managers justify the new, smooth approach as "welcoming," but it is hard to imagine how it could ever instill a passionate concern for music in a new generation. 
 Across the country, station managers and programmers seem to believe that their audiences want a continuous and homogeneous flow of background music, interrupted as little as possible by announcements, let alone idiosyncratic bursts of opinion. Shows like Jim Svejda's "Record Shelf" and Peter Schickele's "Schickele Mix," both syndicated by Public Radio International, and "Performance Today," produced by National Public Radio, find themselves caught between, on one hand, a news and information culture with little interest in classical music and, on the other, classical-station executives for whom "education" has become a dirty word.
"The educational approach only leads to the graveyard," said Fred Child, the music director of WNYC in New York. But classical stations like WNCN and KFAC in Los Angeles have died in other ways, pursuing "lite" or crossover formats.
Station executives base their formats as much on the evolving function of radio as on musical concerns. Many people, they claim, listen only when in cars, and others leave a radio on as background music in the office. Choosing a specific program and listening to it from beginning to end -- "foreground listening," as those in the business call it -- is rare, and near-universal wisdom in the field holds that to demand concentrated attention is to risk alienating listeners.
Oddly, though, these same people who are said to listen without intention seem to care a great deal about their classical stations. Any change in format provokes angry protests and letters to the editor. Such outbursts, station executives argue, say more about demographics than about musical taste.
The loyalty classical-music lovers show to their stations, executives suggest, may be little different from that displayed by followers of political talk-show hosts or on-the-air psychologists. The station becomes an emblem of the listener's identity, and the identity of classical-radio listeners is distinctive. They are well educated, wealthy and, above all, older than other listening groups. The audience for "Performance Today," for example, averages about 50: not ancient but a decade older than the one that tunes in to "All Things Considered," also on NPR. No wonder station managers often describe their approaches to programming with words suited to a retirement community.
IN recent conversations with station directors and music programmers, two buzzwords kept recurring: "shelter" and "gateway." Suzanne White, the general manager of KBPS here in Portland, said that her listeners, 52 years old on average, were seeking a "haven of sanity"; Mark Kausch, the manager of music programming for Public Radio International, the main syndicator of classical programming in the country, said that listeners wanted a "warm blanket." When the radio blares with the political bile of Rush Limbaugh, the adolescent stunts of Don Imus and Howard Stern, and the quick psychological fixes of Dr. Laura Schlessinger, let alone pop music aimed at 12-year-olds and golden-oldies from the 80's for aging Gen-X-ers, a peaceful harbor of classical music certainly has its attractions for people over, say, 45, and the more peaceful the better.
But first you have to get listeners into the safety zone. The term "gateway" stems from the notion that as people get older, there is less radio programming addressed to them, so they may drift toward a classical station. This is the fringe audience. These listeners will stay, it is said, only if they are made to feel welcome.
"You can't be snooty" several station directors insisted, as if repeating a mantra. Mr. Child, of WNYC, formerly the municipal station in New York but now run by a foundation, demands that announcers be "smart and sassy and know their stuff," and not to be didactic, he said. "You don't have to announce the key and opus number when you play Beethoven's Fifth." Mr. Child proudly noted that WNYC's 900,000 listeners were, on average, eight years younger than the audience for its lone remaining commercial rival, WQXR, which is owned by The New York Times.
The metaphor of the safe haven and the desire to be "welcoming" have had powerful effects on programming. The station's identity must be kept consistent throughout the day, so the desired demilitarized zone will appear no matter when a listener turns on the set. Chat must be kept to a minimum: just a smoothly intoned mention of composer, title and performers between selections. And the selections themselves must never rock the boat. Contemporary music -- apart from movie music and, for some reason, works of Alan Hovhaness -- is almost universally banned from play, though it may survive if it pops up in concerts recorded live. Second-string composers like Telemann, Boccherini and Glazunov are played as often as the three B's.
Just as programmers express horror at the thought of educating the fringe audience, they tend to dismiss the idea of reaching out to the young. "We feel that the audience will come to us as they get older," said Ms. White, of Portland. This strategy may seem complacent, but with baby-boomers swelling the ranks of the elderly and living for decades past the average classical listening age of 50, passive receptivity and a welcoming tone may be all that is needed to double or triple the classical audience.
Mr. Kausch, of Public Radio International in Minneapolis, said that the defensive stance of classical stations is a result of the evaporation of support from the National Endowment for the Arts and the shift by many NPR stations, like WBUR in Boston, to an all-news format. Both KBPS and WNYC, as stand-alone public stations, must pay their own way. In many markets, the desire for an impersonal round-the-clock "haven" and economic pressures have led stations to use programming services offered by PRI (Classical 24) and WFMT in Chicago (Beethoven Service) to fill their schedules without having to staff the station during the night and on weekends.
Although these services usually provide as respectable a mix of less familiar pieces and well-known classics (though little opera or 20th-century music) as is heard on most in-house shows, their specific musical offerings rarely appear in station program guides or newspaper listings. These services also seem indifferent to performers. They play recent releases or older recordings by familiar or obscure players with no clear reasons given for the choice.
This haphazard approach, though, serves the desire for a continuous flow of classic music on demand. Listeners caught in traffic or fighting insomnia, industry wisdom suggests, just want to be able to hear some classical music: almost any will do. Like the dairy product "soft-serve," the music flows out in easily digestible form even if you are not quite sure of its ingredients.
On a recent morning, I realized just how much I had come to expect only "smooth" classics on the air. After dropping my daughter off at school, I switched the radio from the local Howard Stern wannabe back to KBPS. A noisy torrent of orchestral colors flooded the car. After a few seconds I realized that it was Sibelius, the suitably stormy music for "The Tempest": not exactly new music but a nice jolt of musical energy. When it abated, the announcer quickly apologized for playing such music during the "morning rush" and promised a swift reversion to Baroque music. A Bach concerto soon followed: smooth Bach.
At the same time that stations plan formats to avoid alienating fringe listeners, they know that their strongest supporters are the hard-core music lovers. Most stations provide for the essential needs of these listeners: Metropolitan Opera broadcasts and live recordings of orchestral concerts. These programs are typically the most interesting ones on a station, the only time you might encounter Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes" or John Adams's "Harmonium."
But these features usually appear in fixed time slots, like Saturday afternoon or 10 at night, when the fringe listeners are otherwise engaged. And the kind of quirky, personal programming that once turned listeners into devoted advocates is hard to find. Shows that could ignite a lifelong passion for music, like "The Record Shelf," "Schickele Mix" and "Performance Today," often find themselves at odds with their surroundings.
Mr. Svejda, of "The Record Shelf," and Mr. Schickele are the two great eccentrics on classical-music radio today. Mr. Svejda, whose show is produced by KUSC in Los Angeles, is perhaps best known for his use, or overuse, of dramatic pauses. You may learn the real subject of a show only several minutes in, after being teased and tantalized by musical excerpts and Mr. Svejda's portentously dropped hints. Still, no one on the air treats both composers and performers with such personal devotion or has such a fine ear for differences in inflections and interpretations. His show on the legendary Hollywood String Quartet sent me running to my local record store only to find that several speedier Svejda listeners had beaten me to the bin.
If you tune in to your classical station and hear a bagpipe band playing "Send in the Clowns" you have probably happened on "Schickele Mix." Mr. Schickele's radio persona seems a distant but equally deranged relation to his more familiar incarnation as P. D. Q. Bach, spawned by a freak collision of musicology and vaudeville. The show, designed for people with a lively interest in music, usually pursues a single musical concept, like the contrapuntal device of the ground bass or the rhythmic phenomenon known as hemiola, and tracks it down in an odd assortment of musical examples that may jump from Haydn to Bulgarian folk singing to heavy metal.
Although "Schickele Mix" is often more technical in its musical discussion than anything else on the radio, its mood is a throwback to classic radio comedy. Mr. Schickele, who was born in 1935, grew up in Fargo, N.D., where WDAY, like many other stations of the time, had a full-time staff of professional musicians. "Peggy Lee got her start on the station," he said. Mr. Schickele and his brother went to the studio before school to hear the musicians, who would play big-band swing during one program, switch to polkas in the next, then turn to country and western.
BUT diversity, which may be a plus in academic and political circles, gets Mr. Schickele into trouble on radio stations that are sensitive to image and format. In addition to worrying that potential listeners may not recognize their stations, managers fault the show for its thematic approach. "If you don't tune in at the beginning you don't know what he is talking about," Ms. White, of Portland, complained.
"Schickele Mix" does demand "foreground listening." Each show has a carefully constructed shape, for all the appearance of improvisation. Yet in the larger classical mix, that strength becomes a weakness. And despite its comic mayhem the show raises the specter of the E-word, education. Mr. Schickele has found that the show succeeds best when it is sold as an informational program rather than a musical one, and over the years he has increased the amount of talk and shortened musical examples.
"Performance Today," NPR's main musical offering, is similarly caught between musical and informational formats. It comes on between news programs like "All Things Considered" and talk shows like "Fresh Air" or "Talk of the Nation," but it attracts a different audience: notably older, smaller and more female.
In programming philosophy the show seems torn between its desire to attract the younger people who listen to Terry Gross's interviews with Gladys Knight or Mel Brooks and its need to retain its core listeners, many of whom see the show as their one connection to classical music. Benjamin Roe, the senior producer of "Performance Today," said that some of its strongest support comes from rural listeners for whom it functions as a surrogate concert hall. It has cemented its provincial support by broadcasting live recordings of concerts from halls around the country. Regional festivals and ensembles have come to count on the show for national exposure.
The essential element in the programming of "Performance Today" is live performance. Even though the show often broadcasts performances of standard repertory that can easily be found on CD, the live format offers not only a rush of adrenalin but also the presence of audience applause. In effect, "Performance Today" puts its listeners on the air, a tactic that has earned it a loyal following. Yet the program's strengths in the heartland may have hurt it in larger markets. It is not played in Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, San Francisco or Seattle. In New York and Washington, "Performance Today" follows "All Things Considered" in the evening but has not been able to grab the news audience.
Perhaps responding to pressure from NPR, "Performance Today" has taken a more active role in generating live concerts of an unusual and newsy nature. "We want to make classical music special," Mr. Roe explained. The program presented a live performance of Bach's B minor Mass conducted by Robert Shaw on Easter Sunday in Atlanta, and a benefit concert featuring four maestros, Pierre Boulez, Christoph von Dohnanyi, Kurt Masur and Seiji Ozawa the next day from Symphony Hall in Boston.
More problematic, at least for the core audience of "Performance Today," the program has strongly endorsed crossover endeavors, presenting concerts by Billy Joel and Paul McCartney. Martin Goldsmith, the show's host, interviewed the pop stars on the show with the same pious tone he accords the Emerson String Quartet, but it is not clear that the audience shared his respect for their symphonic efforts. Mr. Roe, a true believer in crossover, criticizes the siege mentality of stations that stick to the classics but admits that so far, "Performance Today" has had only small success in trying to woo a younger audience.
The average "Performance Today" listener -- to get back to age, as one always does in these discussions -- is 48 to 50, which puts Sir Paul, for one, over the average. Perhaps his arrival as a classical musician, rather than making a case for crossover, just confirms Suzanne White's prediction that the future of classical radio is just a matter of the coming of age. In any case, if Sir Paul ever had the time and inclination to share his enthusiasm for the classics with radio listeners, he might make a most engagingly nutty professor.

HEADLINE: POP/JAZZ;
A Welcome Truce For Jazz Festivals

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous 

 BODY:
EVER since the Newport Jazz Festival moved to New York in 1972, the idea of a jazz festival in the city has been a sore spot for everybody involved, from the producers to the musicians to the fans. The oldest and best known of these gatherings in New York, George Wein's JVC Jazz Festival, successor to Newport, has traditionally elicited a storm of questions and doubts.
The most obvious question involves the advisability of mounting a festival in a city that is by definition a festival, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. The second most obvious one concerns the possibility of putting on a festival in a city that is so utterly urban and opposed, bureaucratically and logistically, to bringing together large groups of people for a festival. Festivals here have always seemed compromised, and one needs only look at other festivals worldwide, whether the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, the Montreal Jazz Festival or the Umbria Jazz Festival in Italy, for a telling contrast. 
 The recent announcement that Michael Dorf, the owner of the Knitting Factory, would open the upstart Texaco Jazz Festival tomorrow, several weeks earlier than usual so that it does not overlap with JVC, was a good sign. Until Mr. Dorf began his What Is Jazz festival, precursor to the Texaco Jazz Festival, in 1988, the only festival game in town was Mr. Wein's JVC Jazz Festival. Ever since, Mr. Wein and Mr. Dorf have been scrapping over bragging rights, and paying customers. Moving the Texaco Jazz Festival can be seen as an attempt to diffuse tensions between Mr. Dorf and Mr. Wein, whose JVC festival opens on June 15.
So the change in schedule comes as a relief. One can now spend the month grazing the best the two festivals can offer without being driven mad by conflicting possibilities. And to create a sense of a festival, Mr. Dorf is setting up a 1,500-seat concert tent by the Hudson River. The schedule change and the additional marketing potential created by the June Is Jazz Month concept, being promoted by Mr. Wein and Mr. Dorf, are further pluses, especially in light of the limited resources that the city spends promoting jazz internationally. Unlike New Orleans, which spends money in pursuit of tourists who are jazz fans, New York's clubs and festivals are virtually on their own with little governmental help or support.
And tourist dollars are extraordinarily important for the health of the club and festival scene in New York, with some clubs claiming that upwards of 90 percent of their business comes from tourists. A full club means that clubs will survive and musicians will be paid, and that, ultimately, is what is crucial to sustaining the music.
Like a reef attracting fish, the two festivals are already having a wider impact on the local music scene. The Cuban pianist Chucho Valdez will be performing a rare two-week stand at the Village Vanguard. The assumption is that he'll do well because of the increased level of tourism during the month. And the saxophonist John Zorn has already set up a festival at Tonic, a Manhattan club, running from June 24 through Aug. 16.
What else can tourists expect to find during the month? They'll find a jazz scene in flux, with the older generation of headliners vanishing and few new ones to replace them. They'll find plenty of promise and plenty of synthesizing going on, from both the musicians associated with the Knitting Factory and those who were once labeled the young mainstream. There's an explosion of activity by musicians who are hitting their 30's and beginning to try new approaches, things that have not yet been tested with time.
And they'll find a jazz scene in New York that probably more now than ever views festivals as mostly irrelevant to jazz musicians, outside of the paycheck. The sad fact is that Mr. Wein's festival no longer has the power or credibility to make stars. And Mr. Dorf's sprawling, bigger-than-ever festival throws so many people together that the concerts become a gray mass of events, with few distinguishing figures. Finally, they'll find that New York, with or without the jazz festivals, is so deep in jazz talent, that almost any conclusion about the state of jazz can be supported by the evidence -- that jazz is dead or that jazz is in better health than it has ever been. Regardless, the festivals will have been responsible for bringing people here, and that, ultimately, is good for the state of the music and its economic health, and for that Mr. Wein and Mr. Dorf deserve thanks.
And for those of us here who have to live with all the festivals' faults, we can only dream of the possibilities. We can imagine better concert programming on the model of Montreal, with its stars playing long stands with a revolving cast of musicians. Or better political support, on the model of Umbria, which turns over to the festival the town of Perugia and all its various concert spaces. We can also imagine audiences that are less narrow-minded, more willing to embrace a broader range of musics and styles. We can imagine turning Central Park into the home of the jazz festivals in the way that New Orleans uses a race track for its festival site, or a city with better concert halls, or a jazz scene with bigger names that can fill the larger spaces. But first things first, and June Is Jazz Month is a good start.

HEADLINE: The View From/New Haven;
The Abused Urban Tree Finally Gets Some Help

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
IN the absence of human activity, 90 percent of Connecticut would be forest. "We have inserted ourselves into this forest ecosystem," says Fred Borman, Connecticut's Urban Forestry Coordinator. "People do not give the trees the attention they deserve."
But some Connecticut communities are paying more attention to their trees, as was evident on a recent Sunday, when volunteers spent the day mapping and assessing trees in the initial outing of the New Haven Street Tree Inventory, which will be used to develop a tree care plan for the city. 
 For many years, the city's tree program has simply reacted to requests and complaints, said Pamela Kressmann of the New Haven Department of Parks, Recreation and Trees. "We just don't know how many street trees there are in New Haven," she said. No database had been created for planning preventive maintenance or for determining where new trees were most needed.
The street tree inventory, which is being conducted by the city in cooperation with the Urban Resources Initiative of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, relies on volunteers said Dr. David Bloniarz, director of the Northeast Center for Urban and Community Forestry. The volunteers participated in an all-day training session in late April.
Street trees, about 10 percent of urban trees, are in the strip between the curb and the sidewalk, in pits within the sidewalk corridor and on traffic islands and median strips. On streets that do not have sidewalks, they are the trees within 10 feet of the curb or pavement edge.
Dr. Bloniarz, who helped conduct the training, explained that street trees need special care because they are under considerable stress. They are planted in a constricted space, pruned away from utility wires into unnatural shapes, struck by vehicles, vandalized, exposed to toxic exhaust and road salt, and damaged by construction such as sidewalk repairs.
Yet trees provide a host of benefits, said Jonathan Wagar, also one of the trainers. In addition to their beauty, trees provide shade, help cool homes, protect against storm water runoff, control erosion, attract wildlife, reduce noise, filter air pollutants, and form windbreaks.
Mr. Borman, the urban forester, said that Middletown, which inventoried 4,000 trees in its downtown business district and surrounding residential areas, determined that the trees were worth more than $4 million.
But most communities do not know the value of their street trees, either in dollars or in esthetics. A decade ago only five Connecticut communities had tree inventories, Mr. Borman said. "Two of those were computerized, two were on index cards, and one was in the head of the tree warden in Stamford." Since then, about 35 communities have conducted partial or complete inventories, including Middletown, Stamford, Hartford, Danbury, Madison and Southbury. Though Greenwich does not have an inventory, it spends more than a million dollars a year on its tree program.
The Washington-based organization, American Forest, determined the optimum tree canopy for a community to be 40 percent of the overhead space. Mr. Borman estimates that most communities in Connecticut range between 15 and 20 percent.
That percentage will be difficult to increase, explains Mr. Borman. A large portion of Connecticut's street trees are between 60 and 90 years old. "For street trees, you're pretty much at the point where the urban forest is going downhill," he says. "Tree removals still outnumber tree plantings two or three to one." In New Haven, the tree division is attempting to turn those numbers around. The division's capital budget, which includes money to buy and plant street trees, increased to $375,000 in fiscal year 1998 from $50,000 in 1997. About 150 street trees were planted in 1997, and plans are in place to plant 600 more in 1998. A new contract soon will go out for bid for 1,000 additional street trees to be planted in the fall of this year as well as next spring.
The New Haven street tree inventory was started in the city's Newhallville neighborhood. Volunteers spread across the neighborhood carrying clipboards, data sheets, block plan maps, measuring tapes and tree identification books.
Each tree was assigned an identification number. Volunteers recorded the location, species, size, condition, and pruning needs of each tree. Species identification when a group first encountered a new species was occasionally time-consuming; then the pace quickened as many subsequent trees turned out to be the same species.
Size was determined using a measuring tape placed around the circumference of each tree at a point four and a half feet above the ground. The condition of each tree was rated as good, fair, poor or dead. Some of the factors indicating that a tree was in less than good condition were the presence of cavities, wounds, dead or dying branches, vertical cracks and insect infestations.
Trees that appeared to pose a threat to public health and safety or to property were flagged. These included dead or dying trees, those with dead limbs that were likely to fall onto the street or sidewalk, and trees blocking the view of traffic signs or signals.
The preliminary findings of this first outing were encouraging, said Leigh Shemitz, executive director of the Urban Resources Initiative. Only 7 percent of the 427 trees catalogued were found to be trees with problems. There was a good mixture of young and old trees, as expected from the neighborhood's history; in the early 1990's, the city did a major planting in the neighborhood to replace the trees struck down by a 1989 tornado.
Among the 15 species identified were several types of oaks and maples, sycamores, honey locusts, Japanese zelkovas and Bradford pears. A given block tended to be planted with one or a few species, with the species varying across the neighborhood.
This is the preferred layout for tree management, said Ms. Shemitz. Species uniformity by block is favored for esthetic reasons, while species diversity in a neighborhood prevents an insect or disease infestation from wiping out the neighborhood's entire forest. Uniformity by block, though, also helps because it is easier to spray an entire block for an infestation than to spray individual trees, one by one.
This summer, the data collected in the Newhallville neighborhood will be entered into a computerized geographic information system for more detailed analysis. And additional volunteers will be trained in the fall, when the inventory continues. It will take several years to complete.

HEADLINE: Public Relations Firm Helps the Disabled

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
IS helping people with disabilities any way to build a public relations company? Susan and Robert Cole think so. When the Coles started Cole Communications, they did it with the understanding that they would devote a third of their practice to working with organizations serving people with disabilities.
"Our interest in people with disabilities goes back years to the time when we became the parents of a daughter who was born deaf," Mr. Cole, a former journalist and banking executive, said. "Debra was 6 months old when we noticed she was not reacting to sounds. And then the testing and the search for help began. At one point I took a year's leave from Chase Manhattan bank, where I was in public relations, to raise funds for the Deafness Research Foundation." He is also the author of "The Practical Handbook of Public Relations" (Prentice Hall). 
 Susan Cole, who formerly worked as a researcher at the Hudson Institute, left her job so she could to teach a class in sign language to her daughter's playmates. "Bob and I and our son, Peter, learned sign," she said. "Debbie was being taught total communication, which is simultaneous speech and sign, but we realized that lack of communication with other children would isolate her, which is why I gave the classes. And the children in the neighborhood were very good about coming. Learning sign was exciting to them."
Eventually, Mrs. Cole went back to work, first as an editor of a research journal for a nonprofit scientific group, then for a bank and finally as managing director and corporate affairs group head for the Ogilvy & Mather public relations agency in Manhattan where her clients included a number of nonprofit organizations. Four years ago, she set up an office in her Bronxville home and started her own public relations firm, Cole Communications.
"Not-for-profits have been an interest of mine, which dates back to my being a researcher for Herman Kahn at the Hudson Institute, which was a major think tank of its day," she said. "Handling not-for-profit accounts is a challenge, especially since most of them operate on a limited public relations budget, yet they need top-quality professional help. I decided to divide my practice in thirds: corporate, nonprofit and organizations serving people with disabilities."
Today the client mix is just that. Last year, when Mrs. Cole landed the American Express Financial Advisers account, Mr. Cole left his job as vice president and manager of external relations for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce to become his wife's partner.
True to their plan, the Coles are handling public relations for the C.W.I. Workshops in Glens Falls, N.Y., and the Westchester Association for Retarded Citizens in White Plains.
"Both are organizations that train people with disabilities for the work force," Mr. Cole said. "Unfortunately, in most corporate programs that support diversity in the workplace, one minority, the disabled, are still overlooked. Ironically, since the passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act in the early 90's, the percentage of physically and mentally disabled people with jobs has declined. In 1990 it was a pitiful 35 percent. Now its down to 33 percent. Yet there are 53 million disabled people in this country who should be getting some attention from those who claim to care about broadening entry into the economic mainstream."
As public relations advisers, the Coles hope to make the business community aware of the poor job it has done in tapping the disabled market for employees and customers. "Do good, be smart: that's our message to business," Mr. Cole said. "The disabled make up a huge market. They have $175 billion in disposable income, triple the spending power of teen-agers, yet they are ignored by most of the corporate sector."
Speaking from experience, Mrs. Cole added that the parents of the disabled are also a factor, since they are often the ones who influence buying decisions. "This is a group that knows who are the good guys and the bad guys," she said. "Take television commercials: in our house we always tune into the ABC channel because it provided captions for the deaf, as do all families who have a family member who is deaf. And 66 percent of them buy the products advertised on that station. Another 53 percent look for that product, and 35 percent will switch brands to the product advertised with captions. This is an economically powerful market, and the companies that are aware of it are thriving."
Embassy Suites, for one, Mrs. Cole said. Embassy Suites' Open Doors program -- rooms specially fitted for disabled guests -- earned the company an additional $13 million in gross revenues. "And when McDonald's ran a commercial showing two young people signing, they won a lot of new business," she added.
The Marriott Foundation, based in Washington, is another one of the good guys. "They have a work-bridge program, which offers disabled people on-the-job training and internships," Mr. Cole said. "And 85 percent of those who have gone through the program have received permanent job offers from a variety of companies."
Debra Cole, who is now an adviser to students at Arizona State University in Tempe, was formerly a recruiter for her alma mater Gallaudet University in Washington. "She found that most hotels and motels had a one-size-fits-all philosophy," Mr. Cole said. "Often when she was told that she was being given a room that could accommodate those with disabilities, the only thing she found it had was railings in the bathroom."
The Coles, who have conducted seminars in reaching out to people with disabilities for many businesses, would like to become corporate consultants. "There's still a lot of misinformation about hiring people with disabilities," Mr. Cole said. "Too many people still experience a kind of discomfort when dealing with the issue. The reality is that hiring those with disabilities makes good business sense, and this large group -- one out of six Americans -- makes up a largely untapped source of talent and a largely ignored market for goods and services.
"We have to separate the myths from the realities, the most damaging being that people with disabilities are not normal. The reality is that they are just like everybody else in terms of differing likes, dislikes, personality traits, emotions, strengths and weaknesses."

The company is a client of Cole Communications, a public relations company that had its beginning in a Bronxville home four years ago. (Photographs by Richard Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
REIT's the Big Buyers in a Strong Industrial Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
BOLSTERED by a strong economy, New Jersey's industrial sector showed signs of steady improvement over the last year and the forecast is for more of the same through the rest of 1998.
"The market," said David T. Houston, of Colliers Houston & Company, a commercial brokerage in Teaneck, "is on a firm course of consistent, if unspectacular, growth." 
 Leasing activity in the northern and central New Jersey marketplace has whittled down the supply of available space over the last year by 20.5 percent, or some 13 million square feet, to 50 million square feet, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage.
The conversion of buildings to alternative uses like office space or housing also contributed to the decrease. In turn, the vacancy rate dropped to 7 percent from 8.9 percent a year ago.
Sales activity was also strong. The big buyers are real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, including First Industrial Trust of Chicago and Security Capital Industrial Trust of Aurora, Colo. And with more capital flowing into the market other REIT's are expected to follow.
At the same time more speculative and build-to-suit construction, by developers as well as REIT's, is expected to sprout as growing companies continue to consolidate scattered distribution centers under one roof. There will also be new construction to meet needs for modern space, said Stan B. Danzig, a senior director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield.
Mr. Houston said there would be "a strong landlord's market for the next 12 months" with "resistance to rent increases in some markets."
Tenants' flight from the old to the new is what developers with sites along such traditional magnets as the New Jersey Turnpike corridor are banking on. At Exit 10 in Edison and around Exit 8A in Cranbury, Monroe and South Brunswick Townships, a crop of big boxy distribution centers, together totaling some 4.2 million square feet are under construction or about to begin and more are planned. Brokers said the competition in the turnpike corridor -- particularly at Exit 8A where many of the new buildings are rising -- will keep the lid on rents, now averaging $4.38 a square foot.
Meanwhile, in the Meadowlands, where land for new development is scarce, rents are creeping up as existing space is filling with companies that want to be close to Manhattan. As a result that market, as has traditionally been the case, is achieving the highest average rental rate -- $5.24 a square foot, according to Cushman & Wakefield.
"After eight lackluster years the available inventory is now being absorbed," said Emanuel Stern, president of the real estate division of Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus. Of the 12 million square feet of space his company controls in the Meadowlands less than 5 percent is vacant, Mr. Stern said.
Still, renovations and limited new construction are occurring. A case in point is the former 581,000-square-foot New York Times printing plant at in Carlstadt, which was updated by Security Capital Industrial Trust, a REIT that has acquired some 3.5 million square feet of industrial space since it entered the state just over two years ago.
Security Capital reduced the old plant to 489,000 square feet and spent $4 million to renovate it into warehouse space, which was then leased to Allied Beverage Group, said Michael Nachmankin, vice president of the New York metropolitan region for the company, which has offices in Edison. Security Capital will start construction this summer on a 175,000-square-foot speculative distribution center on the rest of the 30-acre site "because the demand is there," Mr. Nachmankin said.
Early this month, Coca-Cola purchased 41 acres of the 50-acre former Englehardt Metals research and development center refinery plant on Delancey Street in Newark, not far from Route 1 & 9 and the New Jersey Turnpike, where it plans to build a bottling and distribution center. The company, which is also seeking to buy the remaining land of the mostly vacant plant site, has not yet determined how big the center will be or when construction will start.
W HILE the focus is on warehouse distribution centers, a smattering of high technology, or flex, buildings are also planned. Next month Kessel Associates of Bergenfield will begin two speculative flex buildings, each with 12,800 square feet, in Sparta in Sussex County. And by this summer First Industrial Trust, which has acquired 3.5 million square feet of industrial space since it entered the state in January 1997, will construct two buildings, each with 40,000 square feet, in Franklin Township in Somerset County.
"In some markets it is more prudent to develop than to buy," said Jan A. Burman, senior regional director of the northeast region for the company, which has offices in Syosset, L.I.
Dan Frankel, a principal at the Woodbridge-based brokerage of Jacobson, Goldfarb & Tanzman who specializes in the industrial market, said the pressure for new construction would continue for the next nine to 12 months and then slow by mid-1999 so the additional space can be absorbed. Though all the major developers and REIT's are optimistic, they are still cautious, he said.
Until then construction continues. At Exit 10 in Edison, Heller Industrial Parks is constructing a three-building, 1.3 million-square-foot speculative warehouse, distribution and office center on 57 acres within the company's 410-acre park at the foot of Mill Road.
"The market is healthy," said Jeffrey J. Milananik, the company's president. "We maintain the philosophy that if we build it and people see it the space will lease."
The first 250,000-square-foot building will be completed by October and the other two larger buildings will come on line by next year. The company, as it has done before, will offer its new space at a below-market price -- an annual rate of about $4 a square foot, said Mr. Milananik.
Elsewhere in Edison Reckson/Morris Industrial Trust, a joint venture of the Morris Companies of Secaucus and Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a REIT based in Melville, L.I., expects to begin construction next month on an 830,000-square-foot distribution center.
The partners also are building an 845,000-square-foot center on Cranbury South River Road in Cranbury, within the Exit 8A region. More than half of the center, to be completed in October, was preleased to two tenants -- Cosmetics Essence, a fragrance company that has taken 485,000 square feet, and Setco, a division of the McCormick Spice Company, which has leased about 120,000 square feet.
T HERE is some possibility of overbuilding at 8A," said Ron Schram, senior vice president at the partnership. "But right now the buildings are coming onto the market in a seesaw fashion so developers are not stepping on each other's feet."
Mr. Nachmankin of Security Capital agrees with that assessment. His company has two buildings, together totaling 616,000 square feet, under way on Cranbury South River Road. They are part of a 150-acre industrial park the company is developing, which eventually will contain 2.2 million square feet of space.
And the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury, with partners, is developing 900,000 square feet of new speculative space in the region in two projects. One is a 260,000-square-foot building now rising at 1 Matrix Drive in Monroe Township. The other, a 650,000-square-foot existing building that the company reduced by 100,000 square feet, renovated and then expanded by 650,000 square feet, is on Docks Corner Road in South Brunswick.
About three-quarters of the 1.2 million-square-foot distribution center has been leased, 268,000 of it to Cooper Tire, which is consolidating its scattered locations into the site. The center is scheduled for completion in July.
"There are many contenders and some pretenders in this location," said Alexander B. Taylor, a partner at Matrix, referring to the competition. "But the fundamental tenets of the market are still strong, and for the time being there are more users than good space available."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Re-using an Industrial Area on Stamford's Fringe

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
FOR three decades, businesses of all sorts have sought out the prestige of tenancy in the imposing office buildings in the heart of this city.
Now, with first-class commercial space extremely tight, Stamford's dormant and underutilized industrial buildings in fringe areas of the city are being salvaged for re-use as nontraditional locations for offices, shops, health clubs, art galleries and even a trading floor. 
 Edward Tonnessen, a broker in the Stamford office of Albert B. Ashforth, commercial realtors, has arranged a deal that ratchets up by several notches the level of use to which old industrial buildings can be converted.
Sempra Energy Trading Corporation, which deals in contracts in oil, natural gas and electric power in the United States, Canada, Mexico and parts of Europe and Asia, has taken a 10-year lease on a 35,000-square-foot warehouse in Stamford's 30-acre Commerce Park, a former industrial complex at the Greenwich border, off Exit 6 of I-95. It will spend $5 million on converting the building into a trading floor, offices, conference rooms, a fitness center, cafeteria and library.
"When rents get very high in prime space there is a niche created for gentrifying these older forsaken locations," said Mr. Tonnessen, "and they take on a higher use. In reverse, when rents drop below $25 a square foot you can't move this kind of space."
Warehouses are easily transformed into trading floors because they possess three essential components: high ceilings, unbroken open space and a heavy-duty supply of power.
"Trading and high-tech companies have tremendous power requirements for satellite dish communications and backup generators," said Mr. Tonnessen. Ceiling heights of 12 to 16 feet allow room for the vast amounts of communications apparatus that must be installed under a false trading floor elevated two feet above the actual floor.
Warehouses are also desirable because they are exempt from zoning restrictions on numbers of employees. Trading companies have more employees per square foot than other businesses. Because the number of employees allowed by zoning is based on the number of parking spaces per square foot of building, most office buildings could only accommodate a portion of the staff needed on a trading floor, said Mr. Tonnessen. The rest, he added, "would have to scramble around the neighborhood for parking spaces."
As a former division of AIG Trading Corporation in Greenwich, where a trading floor was installed with some difficulty in a traditional office building at 1 Greenwich Plaza, Sempra will continue to lease its existing space from AIG until the Stamford renovation is completed at the end of this year.
Then Sempra will join some 20 tenants in a variety of converted industrial buildings at Commerce Park who have gradually replaced such former manufacturing users as Barnes Engineering, Pitney-Bowes and Ronson Lighters.
About six years ago the half-century-old park began emerging from a long period of vacancies and short-term leases on its way to nearly complete gentrification. Among its occupants are the New York Sports Club, formerly Gold's Gym; Fine Art 2000, an art studio and gallery; Michael Kessler Antiques; Osborne & Little, an English fabric and wallpaper showroom; Cablevision's new phone service division; Syed Sports Medicine Clinic, Prime Time Limousine, an Ethan Allen furniture store and design center and, soon to be added, a new 70,000-square-foot Shop Rite supermarket.
"This animal has formed itself," said Matthew Tenney, president of Stampar Associates, L.L.C., owners of Commerce Park. "The mix of tenants has realized lower rents in the $10 to $15 a square foot range, in a neighborhood close to Greenwich and downtown Stamford, with turnpike access to New York City only seconds away."
"The city likes this," said Irene Korin, Stamford's business recruitment manager. "It doesn't want to be wall-to-wall office towers. Some people would never look at anything but Class A space, but others want something nontraditional. Traders and high-tech firms often work all night. Their people are young, make a lot of money, but they don't wear suits and they can stick out like sore thumbs in a formal office setting."
Most Sempra traders are 35 or younger, said David Messer, president of Sempra. "We are very excited about having a building that is conducive to the type of creativity that's required in the trading business," he said. "Our desire is to create a space that's airy and open, but very comfortable, because our people spend long hours sitting at their trading desks. There will be very few private offices. Everyone sits out in the open, in what we call the bullpen."
Unlike the majestic new $145 million SBC Warburg Dillon Read trading floor and offices formerly known as Swiss Bank, located so conveniently across from the Stamford railroad station, Sempra is about a mile from the station. So it will have to run shuttle buses for many of its 150 employees.
"I think Swiss Bank opened the door for other trading floors to feel comfortable out of New York," said Cindy Zuckerbrod, broker with RAND Real Estate Services in Westport. "Sempra looked for a year and found nothing in the traditional office market. I approached them with the idea of converting a warehouse -- something they had never thought about. They loved the concept and they found something -- too bad it wasn't with me."
Roger Ferris, head of Roger Ferris & Partners of Westport, is designing the Sempra project, as he did the AIG trading floor.
T HERE has been a definite uptick in reusing old buildings," he said. "These sites are real opportunities. They're immediately available because nobody knows what to do with them. They don't serve a warehouse purpose, and they're not going to work for lawyers. With minimum columns and 15-foot ceilings, you couldn't build anything better if you started from scratch."
His company has designed half a dozen trading floors in London, Manhattan, Tokyo and Greenwich and it has contracts for two more.
"The need for trading floors is expanding rapidly," he said, "and not just for trading companies. Trading today is so instantaneous -- businesses want to be in communication with their investment people, they are part of the deal and need to be on the line."
Other tenants in the park have been quite sanguine about exchanging a chic address for other perquisites. Mr. Kessler's antiques gallery was in downtown Greenwich until last fall, when he moved it to a 5,000-square-foot building in Commerce Park, a structure he characterized as "a rundown disaster."
"But," he said, "the landlord was willing to renovate to suit and I had had enough of parking problems in Greenwich." The landlord gutted the interior, installed picture windows and, after fencing off one side of the lot for garden furniture and fountains, still left plenty of parking space.
"I'm happy I made the move," said Mr. Kessler, "and it was good for the landlord having me create a classy business for other people to follow suit."
R. C. Johann is vice president of United States operations for the British firm of Osborne & Little, overseeing showrooms in the Designers & Decorators Building in Manhattan, the Merchandise Mart in Chicago and the Design Center in Washington, D.C., as well as in its Commerce Park space. "At one point we had offers to move to White Plains or Long Island City for less rent," he said, "but the city and state made it financially very attractive to stay here with tax abatements. And the landlord has invested a lot of money in upgrading the place with new roadways, brick pillars flanking the driveways, painting and landscaping."
Mr. Ferris's plans for turning Sempra's ugly duckling into a swan include removing the west wall and replacing it with a 150-foot expanse of glass containing a new entrance approached through a broad area of plantings. The roof will be raised on the same side in a shed configuration, and the space below the new roof line will be faced with glass and merged with the new glass wall.
A vista of landscaping seen through the glass and extending into the new entrance "will give the traders something to look at," said Mr. Ferris.
"People in this industry get burned out," he said. "They sit all day in close proximity, so they are inclined to like working in an imaginative space."
The remaining exterior brick walls will be cleaned and repointed, the existing entrance on Commerce Road will be closed and bricked over and parking will be provided on both sides of the building. "We want to keep the aesthetic of the place," said Mr. Ferris, "not mask it. It's not a Park Avenue corporate environment."
"Stamford has an opportunity to create a different kind of space. Software companies, new media, cable TV production operations want a more soft-collar type of environment, said Kip Bergstrom, the recently resigned director of economic development for Stamford, who has a similar job in Providence, R.I.
"If Stamford doesn't do it, it will wind up with a one-dimensional economic base. You can't do better than what Sempra is doing, and it isn't that these companies are just looking for something cheap. Sempra, with renovations, will end up with Class A space."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rendering, above (Drawing by Roger Ferris and Partners), of Sempra's building with trading floor after conversion of warehouse, at left. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A/Dr. Stuart A. Newman;
Drawing a Line in Genetic Engineering

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
DR. STUART A. NEWMAN, a professor of cell biology and anatomy at New York Medical College, wanted to do something controversial to evoke public and scientific debate on the morality of genetic engineering. So Dr. Newman and a colleague filed a patent for a process to make "chimeras," creatures that are part human, part animal.
A resident of Pleasantville, Dr. Newman and his colleague, Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington, do not want to make the creatures. In fact, Dr. Newman does not think anyone should be allowed to make them and thinks these kinds of patents should be rejected. But he wants people to talk more about the issues so laws and ethics can be established before science delivers a done deal. 
 Dr. Newman has a doctorate in chemistry and has done research in development biology. He is a founding member of the Council for Responsible Genetics, based in Cambridge, Mass. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. How did you get involved with Jeremy Rifkin and the patent for "chimeras"?
A. Jeremy Rifkin has been involved in a critique of biotechnology and genetic determinism, and so on. So I've been interacting with him over the years. About five years ago, he approached me with the idea of thinking about something that would be patentable within the current patent law but would be shocking enough to the general public so that it would raise some questions in a very vivid way: What should be patented? Is it not the case that living systems are being turned into commodities? And is human biology being commodified?
We were both concerned about the notion of perfectibility of humans -- the use of technology to basically turn people into something superior to what they are now. So I thought about it for a while and came up with the idea of a chimeric organism -- basically a composite between human and animal tissues.
Such chimeras have been made before using nonhuman animals, like sheep and goats. There was one called a "geep" that was reported on back in the 1980's. And these have been studied as experimental models. So the novelty here was introducing a human component into the mix.
Q. These animals could not breed together on their own? Does it take biology to make a geep?
A. Different species can mate. You have mules arising from the mating of a donkey and a horse, for example. But this is something different. You can take even more distant species. And it was found that by taking the cells of early embryos and mixing them together you wind up in certain cases getting cooperation between the cells of the different species. So you wind up with an organism whose tissues are a mixture of cells of the two species. It's not the genetic material that mixes, as it would be in a hybrid. The tissues of the body are a mosaic of cells from the different species.
Q. Please explain the distinction.
A. The tissues of a geep, for example, are partly sheep cells and partly goat cells. Each tissue of the body is a mixture. In a hybrid, since the genetic material mixes in the fertilized egg, then all the tissues in the body consist of cells that are hybrid cells. The thing is that in the chimera, you retain the identity of the cells of the originating species.
So a chimera between a human and a chimpanzee, for example, could have a brain that would contain some human cells and some chimpanzee cells. And the heart could contain some human cells and some chimpanzee cells. So, of course, this organism could not breed true, because its reproductive cells would be either one type or the other. You're not creating a new species; you're creating an organism that is a mixture or a composite.
Q. What's so bad about that?
A. Well, let me present a hypothetical. By this method it would be possible to make an organism that would be 90 percent human and 10 percent ape. I think this would be disquieting to some people, particularly if you were using such an organism to do experiments on. If I were to present to you something that was 40 percent human and 60 percent gorilla or chimpanzee, how would you feel about that? There's certainly a point where I think everybody would say a line has to be drawn.
Now, already, people have obtained patents for organisms that contain some human genes, say a pig in which all the pig cells have some human genes in them. This is a step in that direction. Maybe most people wouldn't say the line should be drawn there, maybe that's not human enough. But there certainly comes a point where you can put many, many genes in or make organisms like the one we propose, which is a composite in which a certain percentage of the actual cells are human cells.
I think that the issue we're raising by doing this is that there must be limits to this kind of work, it can't be done in a completely unregulated fashion. It can't be driven only by scientific curiosity and commercial viability. There have to be some other values that are brought to bear on this kind of enterprise.
Q. You have a particular method, which is how you have something that can be patented?
A. Yes. According to the patent office it is, and this is something that many of us from the council and Jeremy Rifkin's organization and many other organizations around the world dispute -- the idea that organisms are inventions.
The Patent Office refers to genetically modified organisms as compositions of matter as if they were simply a modified chemical. By their definition, something that shows inventiveness and novelty and hasn't been described before and represents a new composition of matter is patentable.
We would like to see a situation where there is public discussion about this, and we would like to see the legislatures at the national and international levels saying that organisms, particularly those with human tissue, are not simply compositions of matter and are not inventions. They are really a part of nature or if they're not a part of nature they should not be patentable because of these other disquieting questions.
Q. So, ideally, you'd like to see your patent rejected because they've changed their policy?
A. Right.
Q. Does the decision from the United States Patent Office have any legal impact on the rest of the world?
A. In Europe already there are statutes that exclude things like cloned human beings from being patented. Not only is it dealt with at the level of patenting but it is considered to be just against the law.
Q. Where in your professional judgment is the line between acceptable biotechnology and the unacceptable?
A. I think there are many benefits to biotechnology. There has been a lot in the newspaper lately about the progress against cancer, and that was remarkable. And this sort of thing involves some sort of biological research.
Personally, I accept experimentation on transgenic animals -- that is, genetically modified animals. I think this advances research on health care, and so on.
I personally have great reservation and am against the genetic modification of humans in a prospective sense. What I mean by that is the idea of making genetically modified human embryos so the resulting individuals develop in some predetermined way.
I'm also against the idea of cloning humans because I think that producing people according to predetermined prototypes is really culturally a very negative thing.
On the other hand, if some already existing person is sick, has some life-threatening illness and can be helped by what's called somatic modification -- that is genetic modification of the body cells of an already-existing person -- I think that is fine.
I'm against what's called germ line modification -- the modification of an individual that does not yet exist so that the individual develops according to some predetermined design.
What medicine does traditionally is cure people who are ill, not make people according to some predetermined plan.
Q. Is the patent process long?
A. Yes. A normal, uncontroversial patent might take a year or a year and a half. I think there will be a long delay in this patent decision. The Patent Office will be scrutinizing this in a thorough fashion and will look for advice from other avenues.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Stuart A. Newman at New York Medical College. He aims to provoke debate on genetic engineering. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (93%); MASSACHUSETTS, USA (79%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (93%); NEW YORK, USA (93%); MASSACHUSETTS, USA (79%);
