HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Lower East Side;
Reinventing the First Stop for Immigrants

BYLINE: By JANICE FIORAVANTE 

 BODY:
THIS summer the Lower East Side, long the first home of immigrants, will mark the centennial of the consolidation of what is now New York City.
There will be live performances and other events in trendy clubs and restaurants and on its newly cobblestoned Orchard Street between Broome and Delancey Streets -- dubbed Centennial Block for the occasion and lined with old-fashioned street lights. In keeping with the anniversary, storefronts will have displays depicting the neighborhood's history. 
 The area is being rediscovered by new immigrants -- artists who are joining earlier homesteaders from the late 80's and are moving from the East Village or reeling from SoHo prices.
"The community keeps reinventing itself," said Susan Fleminger, director of visual arts and arts education at the Henry Street Settlement, whose main house is at 265 Henry Street, near Montgomery Street. "Just when you think it's over, it revives itself." Henry Street is one of six century- old settlement houses that continue to help new immigrants, providing day care and programs for the young and old, as well as cultural activities in Henry Street's Abrons Arts Center.
Another center for the arts is the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural and Educational Center at 107 Suffolk Street near Rivington Street in a century-old former school. It has four theaters and 45 artists' studios, according to Edgardo Vega Yunque, the center's director.
Tenements built in the 1860's to the early 1900's were boarded up in the mid-1930's when owners felt new requirements for renovations to bring in more light and air too costly to undertake during the Depression. Ground-floor stores remained opened.
"They couldn't rehabilitate them, they didn't have the money," said Matthew Bauer, executive director of the six-year-old Lower East Side Business Improvement District (BID).
Now the upper floors are being renovated, preserving such elements as window surrounds and cornices and bringing closer-to-market-rate prices to the neighborhood.
BUT what some people view as a renaissance others see as displacement of the poor. As the middle class moves in and prices rise, some locals fear gentrification is driving out poorer residents of the neighborhood, stretching from Houston Street to the Brooklyn Bridge and the Bowery to the East River and taking in a large part of Chinatown, including the 44-story Confucius Plaza, just south of the Manhattan Bridge ramp. "It's a very divisive issue," said Ann Bobco, a resident and a member of Community Board 3.
"People are screaming about gentrification," said Lyn Pentecost, chairwoman of the Lower East Side Coalition for Housing Development. But Ms. Pentecost, a 35-year resident who teaches metropolitan studies at New York University, said that for every market-rate apartment, there's low-income housing coming on line. "There's a strong nonprofit sector in the neighborhood keeping affordable housing here," she said.
On Ms. Bobco's Suffolk Street block, for example, the Asian Americans for Equality (AAFE), a community development organization, is building 12 four-story houses with 48 for-sale units. Their two- and three-bedroom units will sell for $125,000 to $140,000. The units will be limited to households earning $40,000 to $70,000.
AAFE, which builds low-income housing as well, acts as a tenant advocate, and refurbishes existing buildings. Forty percent of its tenants are Asians, 30 percent are Latinos and 30 percent are others.
O WNERSHIP gives residents a stake in the community," said Christopher Kui, executive director of AAFE. "Why should people have to move out to Queens to own a home?"
Originally, Irish and German immigrants came here, followed by Eastern Europeans and Southern Italians. "By the 1890's, the residents were mostly Eastern European Jews," said Sharon Seitz, during a tour of the Tenement Museum, at 97 Orchard Street, near Delancey Street, which occupies a building built in 1863. Today, Dominicans, Mexicans, Colombians, Bengalis and Chinese are among the residents.
Schools are a problem. In Community School District 1, five of nine schools have been cited for corrective action for poor performance. Sonia Diaz Salcedo, who became superintendent in August 1997, has removed three principals from troubled schools, instituted professional development programs for assistant principals and staff, and is focusing on improving the physical plants of schools.
But at the pre-k to 6 P.S. 20, the principal, Dr. Leonard Golubchick, said that 90 percent of his 1,010 pupils scored at or above the 90th percentile in state reading and math tests. Moreover, he said, grades 4, 5 and 6 are connected to the Internet; all classrooms have at least one computer, the technology lab has 34 Macintosh terminals, the library five computers and a multimedia center with computers is imminent.
Last spring the school received a $75,000 Annenberg grant for each of five years for arts programs, provided through the Henry Street Settlement.
Among the school's graduates are the Gershwin brothers, Louis J. Lefkowitz, a longtime New York State Attorney General; George Burns and Edward G. Robinson.
I.S. 131, one of six schools in District 2 that serve the community, is known as the Dr. Sun Yat-sen School. It enrolls 1,400 students of whom 85 percent are Chinese, said Alice Young, its principal.
"English is a second language for most kids here, even the native born, because they speak Chinese at home," she explained. The school offers a Saturday program to inspire literacy. Called "Walk, Talk, Think, Write," it exposes students to their community and beyond. A recent program included a tour of the uptown and SoHo Guggenheim Museums for children and parents.
The 2,300-student, 70-year-old Seward Park High School has long been regarded as a troubled school. In 1993, said Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, she attended the funeral of a student who had been knifed to death. But now, she added, there is an effort to turn the school around.
"Our printing and publishing program includes tours of printing presses and teaches word processing, computer graphics and desktop publishing," said Kenneth Harvey, assistant principal for guidance. And, he said, a medical technology program offers internships for seniors in labs at New York Downtown Hospital and Bellevue.
AMONG the private schools are Tifereth Jerusalem, a k-12 yeshiva with 150 students, where tuition is $3,900 a year, and the pre-k-8,210-student Roman Catholic St. James School, where tuition is $1,930 to $3,500, depending on the number of children in a family.
There are seven public housing projects in the neighborhood with a total of 9,465 apartments. And running along Grand Street from Essex Street to the river are 28 12- to 20-story co-ops with a total of 4,400 units, many with spectacular views. Celia Honig, assistant principal at I.S. 131, who grew up in the area, now lives in a one-bedroom co-op at East Broadway. "They were originally financed by garment industry unions," said Ms. Honig, referring the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers.
The co-ops were built from the 1930's to the late 1960's as affordable housing for the middle class, added Joel Kaplan of the United Jewish Council. "Co-ops could be bought for $3,000 a room and had to be sold back to the co-op," he said. "But in November 1996 co-op members voted to reconstitute the cap to $15,000 a room and allow sales to outsiders."
 BUT demand far outstrips supply, said Sion Misrahi, owner of a real estate firm by the same name. "One-bedroom co-ops cost from $45,000 to $57,000 but they're hard to come by," he said.
Heshey Jacob, general manager for three of the co-ops, Seward Park, Hillman and East River with 4,200 apartments, said that 150 apartments had sold in nine months "so you can see the turnover rate is not high." He cited sales of two-bedroom units for $60,000 and three-bedrooms for $85,000.
"Rentals of one-bedroom apartments in refurbished tenements are going for $1,100 to $1,500, while two bedrooms run from $1,500 to $2,000," noted Mr. Misrahi.
Mr. Misrahi's own life mirrors the neighborhood's. "I was a merchant on Orchard Street and my father also had a store here," he said. Then in August 1994, he opened his firm as its only employee and now has 17 people working with him. "My office played a role in pushing for renovations as buildings became valuable." He was the founding president of the BID.
Buildings being bought for renovation for market-rate rentals or co-ops are selling for $80 and $120 a square foot, Mr. Misrahi added. The stores themselves, which five years ago ran anywhere from $20 to $80 a square foot, now go for as much as $120 a square foot. "If on Orchard Street between Delancey and Rivington Streets or Essex and Delancey, there's more shopping traffic and the price is higher," he explained.
Three buildings on Hester Street presently on the market together are priced at $2 million.
The higher prices reflect the influx of designer clothing stores and trendy restaurants such as the Living Room Cafe, which features folk music. They join such institutions as Katz's Delicatessen, at 205 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, and Ratner's, the kosher dairy restaurant, at 138 Delancey Street, near Suffolk Street, that itself has become a part of the 90's Lower East Side by opening Lansky's Lounge, a hip night spot suggesting a speakeasy.

HEADLINE: Staying Put and Caring For the Neighborhood

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN 

 BODY:
IN a world full of fence-sitters, Evelyn Schatz is about as subdued as a whirling cannonball. Friend and foe alike in New Haven have labeled her irrepressible, tyrannical, bumptious, blunt and brassy. In short, she is considered a dogged persuader who gets things done.
Mrs. Schatz's tactics are simple and well-known: hound city officials and the police until they take action, badger slum landlords until they go elsewhere, convince residents to take action, nag business and property owners until they see beyond their own interests. 
 "Evelyn could pester anyone to death," said Tony Bialecki, economic development officer for the city of New Haven. "She never lets up."
For the most part, Mrs. Schatz said she has fueled her campaign on pure conviction. These days she earns a modest salary by heading the Chapel West Special Services District, one of three such organizations established by the city in the 1980's to improve conditions in the neighborhoods. With an annual budget of $120,000 and the help of an eight-member board, she oversees activities within a large swath of the city's downtown and surrounding business district, including the Hospital of St. Raphael and parts of Yale University.
Her work force consists of two people who tidy the district with a street sweeper, weed whackers, hedge clippers and lawn mowers. For her part, Mrs. Schatz works nearly round the clock maintaining a tight vigilance over everything from criminal activity to property acquisition.
Those interested in buying property in Mrs. Schatz's district had better think twice. "I make it clear to anybody who comes here, 'We don't want any nonsense'," she said. "So far," she added beaming, "it seems to be working." After years of battling crime and decay in a once-notorious area, Mrs. Schatz says she is finally seeing results. Granite-bricked sidewalks, old-fashioned street lamps and trash containers line many blocks; abandoned buildings once filled with crack dealers, have been demolished or refurbished by a new generation of community-minded homeowners or landlords.
One of the more recent arrivals is Arnie Lehrer, who owns rental properties in the neighborhood and serves as a board member for Chapel West, said he has seen "dramatic improvements" in recent years. "It used to be that you couldn't even count the number of johns cruising up and down these streets," he said. "Now most of my tenants say they feel safe."
Nevertheless, Mrs. Schatz said, it is no time to become complacent. More than ever, she said, she must keep a watchful eye over city officials and boards that for years have allowed poorly managed prison release and drug rehabilitation programs into the area, which she says contributed to its decline.
"I'm not one of these 'not in my backyard,' fanatics," she said. "Because I've already got enough in my backyard." She continued: "Instead of busing some of these programs to other parts of the city like Morris Cove, where I was raised, or Westville, they think we're mincemeat or something and always dump them here. As everyone knows, I've had enough already."
Though she has had enough already for years, unlike many residents who long ago fled the city for the suburbs or retirement communities, since 1958 Mrs. Schatz and her husband, Morris Schatz, have stayed and fought. For 20 years, the couple has lived above Schatz Furriers, a business started by Mr. Schatz's father at the turn of the century on the corner of Chapel and Howe streets. The building sits a few doors down from Chinese and Indian restaurants on one side and the Y.W.C.A. on the other, where the couple met at a dance in the early 50's. "He was standing by the coffee machine with a pipe in his mouth and looked so cute," Mrs. Schatz recalled.
But because of their backgrounds -- Mr. Schatz is Jewish and Mrs. Schatz is Italian -- the couple had to iron out family frictions before getting married nine years later. Later, Mrs. Schatz gave birth to a daughter who died soon after from a respiratory ailment. For several years following the child's death, Mrs. Schatz said she went to the cemetery three times a day to visit the grave. One day, she said, she received a revelation that the child was at peace and that she should get on with her life. "We did a lot of crying for many years," she said.
After that, she said she and her husband funneled their passions into their deteriorating neighborhood. One of the major problems was a series of social service programs housed in the Y.M.C.A. and adjoining Y.W.C.A., which drew much of the drug and prostitution traffic, she said. As a result, long-time residents moved out of the area, many leaving their properties neglected and abandoned. The escalating crime drove customers away from businesses like her husband's, and many of them failed.
"There used to be this joke," Mr. Schatz, a loquacious man with a wry sense of humor, said. He tells about a dead man who was put to rest in a casket at a nearby funeral home. When the man's relatives filed past him, they mentioned that the funeral home was near Chapel and Howe streets. "Suddenly the guy jumps up out of his casket and starts yelling, 'Get me outta here, I could get killed in this neighborhood!' "
Yet living under those circumstances was not a joke. For years, the couple said, Saturday nights surrounding their house looked like 42d Street, where prostitutes often walked naked from car to car and drug dealers conducted business out in the open. As the Schatzes and other residents pressured the police, one pimp threatened to bomb the house next door, she said, and prostitutes trailed her as she walked down the street. "I used to run outside screaming at them," she said. "They'd tell me that my days were numbered. Of course I was scared."
In 1970, the Schatzes along with other residents and merchants, formed the Upper Chapel Street Neighborhood Association, to help regain and improve the area and to strengthen their clout with the city.
The next 10 years, she said, were fraught with frustration but that she learned a powerful lesson.
"One thing you realize is that by the time you go in front of all these city board members, their minds are already made up," she said. "Sometimes if you bring in enough people it helps but not always.
"So I figured out long ago that the only way to deal with politicians is to threaten them."
One of Mrs. Schatz's targets was a local judge who, she said, "gave the prostitutes a slap on the wrists and they were out on the streets in no time."
One weekend he took a holiday in upstate New York. After tracking down the telephone number for the lodge where the judge was staying, Mrs. Schatz said she called him and said, "I invite you to stay in my house for two weeks so you can see what I have to deal with." She continued, "of course, he slammed the phone in my ear, but after that, he wasn't as lenient with the hookers."
In the late 70's, she made local headlines after buying a life-sized inflatable doll, dressing it up as a prostitute, then fastening it to the front of a bus filled with residents of the neighborhood. The bus and its occupants then went across town, to Mayor Frank Logue's home and confronted him in front of television cameras.
"I made it clear that if he didn't help us clean up our neighborhood we were going to load up the bus with prostitutes and all the other riffraff from our neighborhood and drop them off at his house."
After the incident, Mrs. Schatz said she began pouring her efforts into canvassing thousands of residents for the mayoral campaign of Biagio DiLieto, the city's police chief who had run several sting operations in her neighborhood. Mr. DiLieto, who went on to serve five terms as mayor from 1980 to 1990, said, "she drove me absolutely crazy. She was a constant bother and the only constituent who ever hung up on me."
The former mayor had worked as a police officer in New Haven since the late 1940's and described the upper Chapel Street district as a "persistent problem." He added, "but when Evelyn Schatz came on the scene she put up a tremendous battle and won."
Sgt. Ray Hassett runs the community police substation on Edgewood and Day streets, around the corner from Mrs. Schatz's home. As he leaned against his police car one day recently, he said the neighborhood is "not as dangerous as it used to be," because of community policing tactics and more involvement from residents no longer afraid to report criminal activity. Yet, he added, career criminals continue to linger. He said he too receives his share of calls from Mrs. Schatz, but he said their relationship has made parts of his job less complicated. "She has a tremendous history of relationships in this community," he said, "and if I need access or information, she can open doors." As for the Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A., the old managers have vacated and Mrs. Schatz's organization has lobbied hard to make certain the new clientele doesn't cause problems. Though the building still houses rehabilitation programs, she said she is working closely with the new management to maintain control over the destiny of her neighborhood.
"At first I fought them and fought them," she said. "Now I join them; that way, I can keep an eye on them." This summer, she added, the new management of the Y.W.C.A. plans to dedicate the ballroom of the building, where the Schatzes first met, to her and her husband.
Each morning, Mrs. Schatz will rise, eat a breakfast of one egg, toast and grapefruit, then trek to her paneled office where the windows face an old stone church and begin her 16-hour day. Most visitors, and there are many, can find her behind her desk with the telephone receiver suctioned to her ear, snapping away at city officials and fulfilling requests.
Within a half-hour span on a recent morning, someone called to find out where to get a birth certificate, another caller wanted to know how to get rid of an aggressive panhandler, another needed some house paint and someone else needed their street cleaned after revelers smashed bottles on the sidewalk.
"They call me for everything," she said. She then cut away and began dialing the phone. Mr. Schatz, who had been listening to Frank Sinatra in the next room, walked into the office to point out a collage of photographs from Democratic Party fund-raising and other events Mrs. Schatz has helped organize over the years. "There's Evelyn with Joe Lieberman, with Barbara Kennelly, with Bill O'Neill," Mr. Schatz said.
Most recently she organized a 75th birthday party for Mr. DiLieto that drew 500 people. Flipping through the photographs of the event, Mrs. Schatz -- who was on hold -- said matter-of-factly, "Yeah, Dodd, De Stefano, Blumenthal, they were all there."
In turn, a group of Mrs. Schatz's friends have organized a party to celebrate her 70th birthday on June 30. More than 350 people are expected to attend. That week, the city of New Haven will place banners along Chapel Street proclaiming it "Evelyn Schatz Way" ("they're calling it that because I always get my way," she said with a big smile.)
Mrs. Schatz is preparing for the party by working with a nutritionist to lose several pounds. Saddled to three telephone lines all day doesn't give her much of a chance to exercise. "Let's face it," she said. "If I exercised the rest of my body the way I do my mouth I'd be Twiggy!"
She took a deep breath and released it with a sigh. "I'm burned out," she said while dialing the phone. "But, oh, my God, I've got so much to complete."
Each day she goes through The New Haven Register looking for people in the newspaper that have even the slightest involvement in her district. She'll cut the piece out, laminate it and send it to the person or their family. "People like those kind of things," she says, showing her visitor a laminated obituary.
As for plans to run for political office, Mrs. Schatz simply shoos the question away.
"Are you kidding? I have absolutely no taste for politics."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1410 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
The Last Season for the Last Drive-In Picture Show

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: WESTBURY

 BODY:
TWO days ago the three giant screens of the Westbury Drive-in Theater on Brush Hollow Road, dark since last November, came alive for the theater's final season.
After 46 years of continuous operation by United Artists Theater Circuit, this last survivor of the dozens of drive-ins that once operated throughout the New York metropolitan area is scheduled to close its gates permanently sometime after Labor Day. 
 Replacing it on the 23.59-acre site will be a 14-screen, 3,000-seat multiplex, also to be operated by United Artists, and a 116,700-square-foot BJ's Wholesale Club.
A nearby Home Depot, a Staples and other large stores along Jericho Turnpike, along with motels, fast-food restaurants and gas stations, make this sprawling drive-in, which speaks more of rural countryside than built-up suburbia, a quirky anachronism.
The question long embroiling the surrounding community of quiet residential enclaves built on farmland in the 60's has not so much been if the drive-in would ever close, but when it would close and what would replace it.
The multiplex and warehouse store were first proposed almost a decade ago. But opposition by local residents who fear increased traffic and the consequent refusal in 1993 by the Oyster Bay Town Board to issue the necessary special-use permit to the developers kept the plan in limbo until now.
The two owners of the drive-in, Howard T. Hogan Jr. of Locust Valley and Eleanor Lerner of Delray Beach, Fla., sued the town. In a New York State Supreme Court decision handed down in 1996, which was upheld by the Appellate Division last year, the town was ordered to grant the construction permit. The final legal victory for the owners came May 12, when the Court of Appeals denied the town's motion for a further appeal, clearing the way for construction to begin in the fall.
Long Island once had drive-in theaters in Commack, Rocky Point, Melville, Bethpage and Bay Shore, among other locations. But one after the other fell victim to skyrocketing land values and property taxes, which have been the death knell for thousands of others.
The nation's first drive-in opened in Camden, N.J., in June 1933. By 1954, there were almost 4,000 drive-ins throughout the United States. But by the end of last year that number had dwindled to 577, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. None are left in New Jersey, where the last drive-in closed in 1991; there are six in Connecticut and 28 still exist in New York, all upstate except the Westbury theater.
"The reason drive-ins are closing is not for lack of business," said Frank Seeber, the owner and operator, along with his wife, Ann, and daughter, Beth Wilson, of three upstate drive-ins. They include the Middletown Twin, which opened in 1953, the same year as the Westbury; one in Newburgh and one in Maybrook. "The real estate they're on just becomes too valuable," Mr. Seeber said.
The Westbury is no exception. The site, which is bounded by Brush Hollow Road and Cantiague Rock Road, is one of the most desirable undeveloped real estate parcels in Nassau County, with the Long Island Expressway just to the north of it and the Northern State Parkway less than half a mile to the south.
Except for the ticket booth and concession stand and the three 35-foot-high and 75-foot-wide screens (which Mr. Seeber plans to purchase when the theater closes), the property is empty.
He said that the land was worth $1.1 Although there is parking for 950 cars, United Artists was losing $100,000 a year on the theater, said Kurt C. Hall, its president.
Mr. Hogan, whose family built the Westbury, said that the land was worth $1.1 million an acre, and that real estate taxes, which United Artists has been paying under its land lease, were $385,000 a year.
"A lot of people have nostalgic feelings about the drive-in, and I am one of them," said Mr. Hogan. "It has been part of my family, it was part of my youth, and I have very fond memories of it. But it's just not viable any more."
The new project will be a "state-of-the-art development costing $20 million," he said. "It's going to take what is now an eyesore and turn it into something that will be esthetically and economically an asset for the community." He said that the new development would generate $19 million annually in various tax revenues and that it would create 300 jobs.
Mr. Hogan, who was represented in the legal proceedings against the town by Jeffrey Forchelli of the Forchelli, Schwartz, Mineo & Carlino law firm in Mineola, said very careful planning went into his selection of the multiplex and BJ's Wholesale Club, since the 14 screens would have different show times and the store's peak hours would be different from peak traffic hours at nearby office buildings.
But residents buy none of that and have battled along with the town against the redevelopment plan fearing the traffic impact on an elementary school and firehouse substation on Cantiague Rock Road, and further degradation of air quality in their community. Their preference is light industry, for which the property is zoned, or housing.
THE proposed project "was a bad idea from Day One, and we really had right on our side including getting all kinds of expert testimony on the affect this project would have," said Leonard A. Gutterman, the past president of the West Birchwood Civic Assocation, a group representing the homeowners of a 828-home residential enclave just east of the drive-in property.
Other multiplexes on Long Island are all on major roads like Sunrise Highway and Route 110, not on secondary roads like Brush Hollow, Mr. Gutterman said. BJ's also usually builds its operations on major roadways, he said.
"Some terrible, terrible planning went into this from the very beginning, and for me the decision of the courts was justice at its worst," he said. "Neither the Appellate Court judges in New York City or the Albany court had any understanding of the issues out here."
John Venditto, the Oyster Bay Town Supervisor, and formerly the town attorney who litigated the case for the town, said that the State Supreme Court in Mineola had recognized there would be a traffic problem, but had reversed the town board's decision nevertheless, ordering the town to find solutions instead of leaving that up to the applicants.
"We were always unhappy over the fact that the burden was placed on us to prove our position and we were hopeful we would get the attention of the Court of Appeals with the issues we raised," said Mr. Venditto. "But unfortunately that wasn't the case."
Opposition to the demise of the drive-in also came from those who consider the last open-air movie theater on Long Island just as worthy of landmarking as original diners and other icons of what has come to be known as roadside culture.
"We felt the Westbury was special because of its historical significance to LongIsland," said John Giordano, the Farmingdale village clerk, who privately worked on the restoration of his village's Long Island Rail Road station and other historic preservation projects. "Uniqueness is one of the qualifying factors for landmark status, and this drive-in is unique."
But the Landmarks Commission of the town of Oyster Bay turned down the application earlier this year, voting 4 to 3 against the proposal.
"To qualify as a landmark something has to have some architectural significance, and a drive-in doesn't have that -- it's basically an empty field with a screen," said Edward J. Smits, the Nassau County historian, who spoke against the designation. "The other question would be what was the drive-in's impact on cultural history and as far as I can see the drive-in had no cultural significance in general and neither did this one specifically."
But the Westbury's imminent closing is a wrench for its patrons. Many are families on a budget who spend a relatively inexpensive night out without getting a baby-sitter.
Cindy Rubin, who was stringing balloons outside the West Birchwood home of her sister Tammy Cohen to celebrate the birth of her sister's baby, said she was sorry to see the drive-in go.
She and her husband, Glenn, live in Glen Head, but they go to the drive-in, Mrs. Rubin said. As a couple they went there on dates; now they pack some snacks and go there with their 3-year-old son, Ryan. "It's different, it's fun, it's a romantic place," Mrs. Rubin said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Westbury Drive-in Theater, left (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times), has just opened for its 46th and final season. It will be replaced on the 23.59-acre site by a 14-screen, 3,000-seat multiplex movie theater, shown in rendering, and a BJ's Wholesale Club. (Angelo Corva)

HEADLINE: Where the Bad Air Comes From

BYLINE: By JAY AXELBANK 

 BODY:
WHEN many new residents arrived in Connecticut they thought they were getting away from the noise and pollution of the Big City and that they would be enjoying rural landscapes and picturesque towns. One would be able to throw open a window to take in a deep breath of fresh air. Ah were it but true; unfortunately the state has some of the smoggiest, most unhealthful air in the entire country.
"There's so little pristine quality left here," lamented Dr. Thomas Godar, a doctor with the American Lung Association in Hartford who is bracing for a rash of warm-weather health alerts. "Until we clean up our air, we can't fully enjoy the outdoors in the summer." 
 As the state tracks ground-level ozone concentrations at its dozen monitoring stations scattered from Greenwich to Stafford, and long-suffering residents can expect far more health-warning announcements this summer than last. If weather and other conditions resemble 1997, there could be twice as many ozone alerts as last year's total of 12, according to Carmine DiBattista, head of the Bureau of Air Management of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
It's not that air quality is expected to be any worse, he explained. It's because the Federal Government, acting on a mass of new medical evidence, has just "raised the bar."
Starting in 1998, health standards for ozone, a lung irritant also known as smog, have been made more stringent than those in effect up to now. Since April 1 when the state began ozone monitoring, there had already been two smog-alert days as of last Wednesday. Unhealthful conditions were recorded in Greenwich, Westport, Danbury and Torrington on May 16, when the temperature reached 90 degrees, and in Torrington on May 20, when the temperature was in the low 80's. Under the less rigorous standards, smog alerts did not usually occur until mid-June.
The new ozone standards are at the center of a campaign at the Federal and state level almost 30 years after passage of the Clean Air Act. The drive, led by Connecticut and seven other Northeastern states, targets ozone-causing pollution, mainly from coal-burning power plants in the Midwest and South, that sweeps into this region. To help combat ozone, the Environmental Protection Agency disclosed in April that it is considering even tougher emission controls on new cars.
The E.P.A. has also embarked on a parallel anti-pollution drive, taking aim at fine particulate matter or soot -- which is considered as serious a health threat as ozone and is responsible for haze in the atmosphere. The E.P.A. last year announced first-time health-safety criteria for these microscopic particles and has begun setting up a nationwide monitoring system to measure the extent of the problem.
Connecticut, for its part, acted to curb power-plant pollution as part of the just-passed utility-deregulation bill, which was signed into law by Gov. John G. Rowland at the end of April. A future provision of the law will set strict emissions standards for out-of-state and Connecticut power plants selling electricity in the state.
Despite the multi-pronged clean-air campaign, there is a long way to go. It will take until 2007 to 2010, on the basis of E.P.A. projections, for Connecticut and the rest of the nation to breathe air that meets Federal ozone standards. And reducing airborne soot will take even longer, until 2015 at the earliest.
Even if Connecticut were to shut down all industry next week and halt all vehicular traffic within its borders, according to Mr. DiBattista, the state would still not comply with the new E.P.A. requirements. "The problem is power-plant pollution that comes mainly from the Midwest and South," he said.
Prevailing easterly wind patterns, he explained, not only push ozone components and soot across Connecticut's borders from New York and New Jersey, but also from Pennsylvania and states as far away as Ohio, Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia.
Even though Connecticut ozone levels have been reduced by approximately half since 1970, the state still officially ranks among the three or four most smog-ridden areas in the entire nation, behind such industrial regions as Los Angeles, New York and Houston. In the 1970's and 80's, health-warning advisories based on the older, less exacting ozone-danger standard, averaged above 35 days during the summer season, twice reaching 60 days. By the 1990's, the average had fallen to 12, but even this number reflects the fact that the state is still far out of E.P.A. ozone compliance.
Ozone exceedance figures for 1997, compiled by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, list the highest number of ozone "hits" in the state for Westport, Stratford and Madison, with six each. Danbury and Groton had four apiece, Greenwich three, and East Hartford, Middletown, New Haven, Bridgeport and Stafford, all had two. Torrington was the unofficial clean-air champion of monitoring sites, registering zero. Overlapping alerts in the various locations accounted for the state total of 12.
Ground-level ozone is the prime ingredient of smog. The term smog, which meant a combination of smoke and fog, is now used by environment officials to refer to ozone -- even though the gas is invisible. Ozone is formed when pollutants -- mainly from power plants, factories and automobiles -- combine in the presence of sunlight -- usually when temperatures reach the high 80's. (Ground-level ozone is distinct from the beneficial, stratospheric variety that shields the earth against ultra-violet rays.)
Scientists point out that ozone's invisibility can mislead people into thinking the air is pure just because the sky is sunny and blue. Only when accompanied by a pall of haze from heavy concentrations of fine particulate matter does ozone acquire a "marker." Beyond the pockets of haze over some of Connecticut's largest population centers, the entire state might resemble Los Angeles in the summer if mountains blocked the outward air flow as they do in California.
The smog buildup means that Connecticut residents such as Bridget and Monica Kelly -- 12-year-old twins who both have asthma -- feel acute discomfort when they shoot baskets on the driveway of their Stratford home during July and August. Barbara Wasko, 67, of Bridgeport, who has a lung disorder, complained, "I have trouble even walking on those smoggy days -- I have to stay inside."
For Renee Idone, 38, of Roxbury, who has competed in several Boston marathons, a 10-mile run is extra taxing on high-ozone days. "The air can seem so fresh and clean -- yet I know it's really not healthy to be outdoors," she said.
Richard Straub, of the American Lung Association of Connecticut, said those most vulnerable to elevated levels of ozone and particulate matter are children and elderly people, particularly those with asthma, emphysema or other cardio-pulmonary conditions. He added that there are an estimated 181,000 asthma sufferers in the state and the number is accelerating in the state and nationwide.
Even healthy individuals, including outdoor workers, swimmers and youngsters who spend a lot of time in the summer sun, can experience irritant effects from smog, according to Dr. Gary Ginsberg, a toxicologist with the state's Department of Public Health in Hartford. "If people inhale smog and soot they can temporarily diminish lung capacity and have trouble breathing properly. But prolonged exposure can permanently impair or prematurely age anybody's lungs," he added. High levels of ozone not only harm people but can also affect crops and vegetation, stunt trees and contribute to algae in lakes.
Hundreds of scientific studies since the 1980's, according to the E.P.A., have underscored the serious health impacts of polluted air in the United States and have given added momentum to the current anti-pollution campaign.
The national effort got underway last year when Connecticut and seven other Northeastern states took the lead after decades of being on the receiving end of upwind dirty air from the Midwest and South. They embarked on legal action under the 1990 Clean Air Act to curb dirty coal-burning electric power plants in Midwest and Southern states.
The E.P.A. was asked to mandate that these states order such plants to sharply reduce emissions that drift to the Northeast. These high-polluting utilities, many of them built decades ago in the Ohio River valley, were, in effect, grandfathered. They were not required under the 1970 Clean Air Act to adhere to the same emission limits as modern and cleaner electric utilities built after the 1970s.
"Up to now those states, ironically, have been in ozone compliance," observed Jason Grumet, director of the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, representing the environmental agencies of the New England states and New York and New Jersey. "Their pollution immediately gets dumped across their borders by the prevailing winds. And if your state had acceptable air quality, you were in compliance. You didn't have to worry about reducing your pollution."
But no more. The Northeast states' initiative resulted in an agreement with the E.P.A. -- announced in February -- that would require all 22 Eastern states, including Connecticut, to put controls in place by 2003 for reducing ozone-causing nitrogen oxide emissions. Each state would be assigned a pollution-reduction budget.
States such as Ohio and Kentucky, with many coal-burning power plants, would not be exempt from emission reductions even if their own air quality was considered in compliance.
Some of the nation's filthiest power plants and other pollution sources in the Midwest and South would be required to scale back up to 85 percent. Connecticut and the other Northeast states, however, which have already substantially cut smog-causing emissions in the last few years, would not have to make such severe reductions.
The significance of the E.P.A. proposal, Mr. DiBattista says, is that "it would give Connecticut a level playing field in fighting smog."
By 2010, in this scenario, the resultant air quality in Connecticut and other Northeast states would comply with the E.P.A.'s safe-ozone requirements -- based on the assumption that, besides the power-plant cleanup, the bulk of the nation's auto fleet would be phased out and replaced by cleaner-burning vehicles. If the timetables are met, Connecticut could say goodbye to summer ozone alerts.
Experts in the field of air-quality control say it has taken this long to clean up the nation's air because the bright hopes and resolve of the 1970 Clean Air Act kept colliding with economic and political realities. In addition to frequent resistance and repeated delays in meeting compliance dates, there was a period of indifference in Washington. Moreover, before 1990 the focus was on reducing sulphur dioxide emissions to fight acid rain.
Overarching all these hurdles were two other harsh realities. Even though dirty air respects no borders, the authority to implement federally mandated cleanup programs resides within each state, making cooperative regional efforts difficult. And dealing with air-quality issues poses significant technical challenges.
A few days ago, as Renee Idone left her Roxbury home for her usual l0-mile run, she said, "Why should we have to wait so many more years to clean up pollution. Doesn't everybody want to breathe clean air?"

HEADLINE: Making Technology Fit Easily in Schools

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY in the schools frequently resembles presents under a Christmas tree: shiny and bright. But once the new-toy stage passes, machines are all too often relegated to the back of the classroom.
Learning to make computers work as efficiently, effortlessly and automatically as, say, pencil sharpeners, has been a challenge for teachers and administrators who recognize that computers cannot be perceived as merely add-ons to the curriculum or game-playing rewards for students who have finished their regular work. 
 "The direction now is how to use technology as a way to advance your curriculum goals so it's of a piece," said Dr. Judith Fox, Superintendent of the Byram Hills school district in Armonk. "The idea is using technology for multidisciplinary problem solving."
In Mount Vernon, for example, some fifth- and sixth-grade students will be using laptop computers for classroom work and homework assignments instead of conventional notebooks starting in September. The change is part of the Anytime Anywhere Learning program developed by Microsoft and Toshiba and will be financed with district money and a grant from the Toshiba America Foundation.
In Irvington, the strategy behind the new technology initiative is to help students become more active learners who pursue their own research and solve problems.
And at the College of New Rochelle, four students studying Latin are doing so by way of the Internet, where they can converse with students around the world.
Such endeavors -- and how similar programs can be integrated in the schools -- was discussed at a conference here earlier this spring sponsored by the Westchester Education Coalition. Among the workshop topics were "Technology in Support of Instruction: A Bridge From the Classroom to the Real World," "Developing Skills to Thrive in the Information Economy," "Video Conferencing in the Classroom" and "New York State Standards: Technology Activities Database on the Web for Teachers and Students." They were designed to help teachers and administrators make technology work for the curriculum instead of the other way around.
"If we don't give benchmarks, we are depriving schools of the opportunity to succeed," said Robin Willner, director of corporate social policy and programs for International Business Machines. "If we accept the fact that standards will be higher, then we can't teach the same way. You can't prepare teachers the same way. It's not about the technology. It's about the teaching." MERRI ROSENBERG

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 3; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2998 words

HEADLINE: New Housing Favors Manhattan In Uneven Pattern

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
CITY COUNCILMAN ARCHIE SPIGNER wanders through the streets of southeast Queens these days and marvels at the scatterburst of new housing that has been or is being built -- even in neighborhoods that were struggling only a decade or so ago.
Over the last two or three years, said Mr. Spigner, a Democrat and chairman of the City Council's Housing Committee, "a lot of new construction has occurred" in neighborhoods like Jamaica, South Jamaica, St. Albans and Laurelton. 
 "Wherever there was space, a house has been constructed," Mr. Spigner said. "So much so that we've seen some unique architectural features to conform to oddly shaped lots -- long buildings, wide buildings, some with no side yards -- not the traditional 100-by-40 lot."
"Everything is going," he said.
Indeed, from 1990 through 1996, according to the New York City Department of Planning, 2,050 new housing units were completed in Queens Community District 12 -- a major portion of Mr. Spigner's constituency -- making it one of only 7 among the city's 59 Community Districts to pass the 2,000-unit mark in the first seven years of the 90's. And there's the rub.
While housing construction in the city is showing clear signs of revival, coming off the laggard years of the early 90's, increases in the numbers of completed units have been spotty, leaving many communities behind. The increases have been particularly evident in Manhattan below 96th Street.
And, significantly, they have not been enough to address the city's chronic housing shortage.
So far this decade, building permits for the construction of 48,000 new units, or 6,000 a year, have been issued by the city -- by one estimate, half as many as necessary to meet the rising need.
Although his community is among the favored few, Councilman Spigner sees the bigger picture.
"The deficit is still plain," he said. "There's a moderate-price housing shortage. It's probably better than three, four years ago. But if you put out an apartment for rent for $800, $900, you're going to get a long line of takers, a hot response. It's good if you're the landlord, but not if you're on the line.
"Short of being in the upper reaches of the middle class," Mr. Spigner said, "you have to make hard choices about your rent and where you live. And the poor people are hurting."
For Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law, "The real question is why, when the market is this tight and rents are increasing so rapidly, we are not seeing a burst of construction in the boroughs as well as in Manhattan.
"Normally, when vacancies are as low as they are in New York and market rents are as high," Professor Schill said, "we would expect to see developers fighting each other to bring new supply onto the market. Instead, what we see are rates of new construction that do not even keep us even with losses to the housing stock."
For the builders, the barrier to production is, simply put, that the market in the boroughs outside of Manhattan will not bear, they say, what it takes to cover construction and operating costs. "It gets down to marketability," said Jerome Belson, president of the 850-member Associated Builders and Owners of New York. "To meet the needs of the middle-income earner who cannot afford to pay $2,000 a month, you need subsidies. Without subsidies, you're not going to make up that deficit."
It is not as though the city will ever -- nor does it need to -- achieve the production peaks of the past.
In the 1920's, as subway branches reached through still-verdant boroughs and budding communities opened like leaves along the lines, the number of new housing units mounted at an unprecedented rate -- 76,000 a year. But in the Depression-era 1930's, production declined by almost 75 percent, to an annual average of 20,700 units.
During the first five years of the 40's, with the nation concentrating its resources on World War II, production further declined, to 16,500 units a year. But then, as the boys came home, construction steadily increased, reaching 34,413 new units in 1950. Potato farms along Queens Boulevard, for example, gave way to phalanxes of apartment buildings and the stately Tudors and Federals of Forest Hills.
Throughout the 1950's and 60's, an average of 31,700 units were completed each year, reaching a postwar peak of 60,031 in 1963. One reason for the increase was the large number of units built with subsidies under the public housing and Mitchell-Lama programs -- the latter specifically supporting middle-income projects. Subsidized housing accounted for 29 percent of the 634,375 units built during the 50's and 60's.
OVER the next two decades, however -- and even during the hot real estate market of the mid-80's -- production levels were less than half of what they were in the 50's and 60's, dropping to an average of 13,600 a year. One reason for that drop-off was the virtual cessation of construction under the government housing programs.
There has been no rebound.
As the city weathered a deep real estate recession during the first five years of this decade, average annual production plummeted to 7,100 units. Indeed, the 5,512 units built in 1993 constituted the lowest production since 1946, when 4,571 units were built.
But for the last three years there have been glimmers of resurgence.
"The numbers are rising," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "They have risen substantially in every borough, especially in Manhattan."
"One point to be kept in mind," Mr. Rose said, "is that the sites, the availability of land for development, is less than in previous eras." In fact, the city is now so built up that just about the only significant semirural remnant is the southern tier of Staten Island, which is under intense development pressure. "So the numbers are necessarily never going to be at the scale of the development peaks," Mr. Rose said.
There are two related indicators of housing production in the city. The more precise measure is the tally of completed units; the other is the number of units for which building permits have been issued for proposed construction. Data on the number of units completed in Manhattan -- and, hence, totals for the whole city -- were incomplete for 1996, Planning Department officials said.
The city has, however, tracked the number of units authorized by building permits. And those numbers indicate that, while authorized production levels started to rise during the last two years -- by 8,632 units in 1996 and 8,987 in 1997 -- they still lagged behind even the relatively low levels of the 1980's.
From those permit numbers, Professor Schill at N.Y.U. has calculated an estimate of the continuing housing shortage.
Although permits for construction of new housing approached 9,000 units last year, the city loses about 12,000 units annually because of abandonment, deterioration and the combining of apartments, according to the city's Housing and Vacancy Survey -- creating an annual deficit of about 3,000 units.
At the same time, according to the most recent Census Bureau estimates, the city's population is growing at a rate of about 7,800 people -- or 3,200 households -- each year. And so, despite the recent increases in construction, the combination of units lost and increased households leads to an annual deficit of about 6,000 units.
That estimate, however, is complicated by two counteracting factors, for which no comprehensive statistical data are available. One is the number of units that are completely rehabilitated each year -- "gut rehabbed" in the industry parlance. The other is the number of families -- hundreds, if not thousands -- living doubled up in the same unit. So Professor Schill's calculation of a 6,000-unit annual deficit is closer to a well-founded estimate than an absolute number.
The N.Y.U. real estate center, in conjunction with the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, will soon begin a study examining whether the cost of construction in New York "is one of the reasons why we have such a ridiculously low rate of new development," Professor Schill said.
"Although there is certainly a lot of anecdotal information about the high cost of building in New York City, and particularly Manhattan," he said, "there has been no careful analysis of the extent to which construction costs are out of line with other large cities.
"Nor, for that matter, do we know definitively whether government subsidies are absolutely necessary -- and how much those subsidies need to be, if they are needed -- to promote new construction."
There appear to be only shades of difference among parties to the debate over those questions -- whether it simply costs more to build in New York and whether construction in the boroughs outside of Manhattan is impossible without government subsidy. In general, the answers have been yes and yes.
The slivers of contention have been: Do the high construction costs of Manhattan inordinately inflate those costs for the other boroughs? And what is the proper balance between the necessary protections provided by New York's stringent land-use, environmental and building codes and the need to house people?
As far as Mr. Belson of the Associated Builders and Owners is concerned, Manhattan is not to blame for difficulties in the other boroughs. "Building is building," he said. "If you're putting up a 10-story in Manhattan, it is, in effect, the same cost to build it in Brooklyn or Queens. A porter in Manhattan costs the same as a porter in the outer boroughs.
"So, if construction costs are similar and operational costs are similar, where would you rather try to get that rent, in Manhattan or the outer boroughs?"
But for Joshua Muss, president of the Muss Development Company, there is a divide far wider than the rivers between Manhattan and the rest of the city. For four generations, Mr. Muss's family has been building in New York, but only outside of Manhattan. "As far as I'm concerned, the boroughs, unfortunately, always seem to be fighting against Manhattan's success," he said.
The regulatory codes, the environmental reviews, the labor contracts -- all skewed by a market-domineering Manhattan, in Mr. Muss's view -- make it increasingly prohibitive to build in the other boroughs.
AND so, "particularly for the middle-income New Yorker who makes $50,000 to $80,000, about enough to afford a two-bedroom at $1,800 a month, there is no new housing," he said. "It's not being built."
Mr. Muss sees three groups unable to find the kind of housing they want: "Young people getting married, trying to live in the neighborhood from which they came. Immigrants working for a year or five. Young people from all over America, seeking fame and fortune; they find themselves in a railroad flat in downtown Manhattan, the renovation district, three and four people in apartments that cost $2,500 a month."
Eventually, they get promoted, or want to get married. "They're moving right past the boroughs because there's nothing to attract them," Mr. Muss said, "and all of a sudden they become New York City's competition because they get jobs in the suburbs."
The preponderance of construction in Manhattan is borne out by the building-permit data, with the relatively open spaces of Staten Island running second. Although it has 20.9 percent of the city's population, Manhattan was issued 40.5 percent of all new building permits in 1996 and '97. With 5.5 percent of the population, Staten Island received 22.7 percent of the permits.
Queens, with 26.9 percent of the population, received 13.9 percent of the permits. And the Bronx, with 16.2 percent of the population, got 11.6 percent.
Brooklyn fared worst. With 30.5 percent of the population, it was issued only 11.4 percent of the permits.
It may be broadly true, as Mr. Belson points out, that building in the other boroughs is not essentially different from building in Manhattan. But it is also true that New York City has set regulatory standards -- often based on high-rise Manhattan requirements -- that are more stringent, and therefore more costly, than those in other cities. And that boosts costs in the other boroughs.
Building codes, for instance, mandate the use of certain materials and labor practices. "Construction must conform to complex rules of safety, which the city is properly unwilling to compromise," said Roger Starr, a housing specialist with the Manhattan Institute. "And the high-rise buildings in Manhattan require especially qualified workers as new techniques become available."
For example, Mr. Starr pointed out that the strength of concrete depends on the proper mix of cement and water. "The more water, the weaker the concrete," he said, "but the less water called for in the code, the more difficult it becomes to place the concrete where it's needed and to insure that it is packed solidly." And so, because of the greater complexity of design in Manhattan's towers, he said, "labor costs in Manhattan go up and pull labor costs outside of Manhattan along with them."
For Mr. Muss and his family, it was the city's arduous zoning process -- and the recession -- that had them yanking their hair while trying to develop Captain's Quarters, a 269-unit complex of town houses in the Prince's Bay section of Staten Island.
The land was purchased in 1963, with plans once calling for a project -- including an adjacent site -- of 1,200 units. "But we redesigned 26 times at the Planning Commission's insistence," Mr. Muss said. "Finally, we got into the ground in 1985."
Sales of the $225,000, three-bedroom homes started in 1986, Mr. Muss said, but came to a halt two years later because of the recession. "The last house was completed last year, and the last house was sold two months ago," he said.
"You're talking about an odyssey for 269 units that started 35 years ago."
Because of those kinds of obstacles, Frank Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a policy research organization, estimates that "to build unsubsidized housing, the rents have to come in at about $1,200 for a one-bedroom and $1,600 for a two-bedroom in order to cover your costs."
Mr. Braconi cited several other factors that add to construction costs. "Environmental cleanups, that's part of it," he said. "The legal difficulties in relocating tenants; they're greater than in nonregulated cities."
In Chicago, for example, Mr. Braconi said: "If a builder wants to redevelop a site with new or more housing, he lets the current leases expire, empties the building and builds. But in New York, you can't do that because of our rent regulations.
"I'm not a big critic of rent regulation," he said. "I think, overall, it's a good thing that people have protections. But that doesn't mean that the protections aren't an obstacle to new housing."
As far as Mr. Belson is concerned, there are currently only two ways to build in the other boroughs without subsidies. The first is to rehabilitate an existing site, "so that the construction costs would be 50 percent below new construction costs," he said.
The second is what Mr. Belson calls "creative compaction."
"It means that instead of having a 1,200-square-foot one-bedroom apartment, you'll now have 775 square feet," he said. "You're not going to get the old-fashioned foyer at the exterior door. You have to creatively compact to reduce the ultimate cost to the tenant." Mr. Belson agrees that, because of the constraints, "we're losing the middle class."
"Like when you squeeze a tube of toothpaste," he said, "people leave the five boroughs. You've got Jersey City, Hoboken; that portion of New Jersey will become the sixth borough."
To ease the squeeze on the middle class -- a bit -- the Department of Housing Preservation and Development has launched a Middle-Income Housing Initiative. Under the program, the city's Housing Development Corporation is issuing taxable bonds to provide subsidies of up to $20,000 a unit to help develop housing above 96th Street in Manhattan and in the other boroughs.
BUT it is just a start. And, to begin with, the initiative will subsidize only about 1,000 units. Still, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, Richard T. Roberts, is hopeful of a sustained impact. "It's the first concentrated effort the city has made to spur development of middle-income housing since the end of the Mitchell-Lama Program," he said. "Depending on its success, we hope to be able to pursue and expand the program."
Mr. Rose, the city's Planning Commissioner, is also optimistic.
Asked if housing can be built in the boroughs outside of Manhattan without subsidies, he said, "The answer is yes, it can and is being done."
"We're already seeing interest in the construction of new multifamily housing in the boroughs," Mr. Rose said. "Yes, market-rate stuff that's a function of the real estate market in those boroughs coming back to where it once was.
"It's not going to match Manhattan prices," Mr. Rose conceded, "but there is a great deal of interest" in building in Flushing, Staten Island, Williamsburg and southern Brooklyn.
Of the deficit in completed units, Mr. Rose said, "Clearly, we can and should be doing better than even our current improved numbers."
And asked what it would take to create a sustainable, healthy market that keeps that gap closed, he said: "We have to make significant reforms to the regulatory obstacles. We have to make available for residential use whatever unused land we do have, much of it now in abandoned manufacturing areas" -- an initiative that would have to address the fears of adjacent residents about high-rise development.
"And with a little bit of assistance through existing mechanisms, the market can achieve numbers that meet that test."
"Of course," Mr. Rose added, "the availability of financing is crucial."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
With Proposed Gas-Tax Boost, a New Push for Self-Service

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
New Jersey was not alone when it banned self-service gasoline in 1949. Many states decided that they did not want to encourage this oil-company innovation, citing safety issues. In 1968, 23 states still had bans; by 1977, with the development of safer pumps, all but New Jersey and Oregon had dropped their objections.
For the moment, New Jersey and Oregon are standing firm. A legislative assault on Oregon's ban withered last year. Trenton has decided to keep the ban several times in the last two decades, debating it usually when gas prices are increasing at the pump and consumers cast about for ways to save. 
 But even though gas prices have dipped below a dollar a gallon, the issue has started to simmer again because of Governor Whitman's request for a referendum on raising the state's gas tax by 7 cents per gallon. The increase would be used to improve the state's roads and bridges and to safeguard its dwindling open space.
Asked about the proposed tax increase, Jim Minugh, a Sayreville steel worker who was putting $10 worth of gas in his Toyota pickup at a New Jersey Turnpike rest stop last week, said: "I don't have a problem with that. But as far as self-serve, only if they cut the prices. If they don't they might as well keep service."
Mr. Minugh also said he was mystified about how gasoline prices were set now.
In fact, the price at the pump reflects several elements. Federal taxes of 18.5 cents per gallon are standard, but state gasoline taxes vary. New Jersey has one of the nation's lowest, at 10.5 cents per gallon, to which it adds a gross receipts tax of 4 cents a gallon, making the total state take 14.5 cents. The Governor's suggestion would bring the tax to 21.5 cents per gallon.
But taxes are not the only source of price differences. Gasoline companies charge varying prices depending on octane, additives, region, demand, and competition. Distributors and dealers do the same. None want to let the public entirely in on their costs and profits, so the picture of the system remains hazy in the corners. As a spokeswoman for Coastal, Vicky Gunnewig, put it: "We don't discuss any price-related issues. It's a very volatilely priced commodity."
The price starts with crude oil, which is cheap these days at less than $15 a barrel, compared with about $25 a barrel last year. The low price is a result of surpluses, according to James Van Alen, an oil analyst for the investment firm of Janny Montgomery Scott. Mild weather allowed stockpiles to increase, Mr. Van Alen said, and the Asian economic crisis depressed demand.
The wholesale price of refined gasoline, before state and Federal taxes, can vary significantly from region to region, which most analysts say is the result of differing transportation costs and competitive environments. William Dressler of the New Jersey Gasoline Retailers Association said a pre-tax gallon of regular Mobil gas is 54.10 cents for a dealer in Newark but 50.10 cents in Paulsboro, a Philadelphia suburb.
Gasoline companies, sometimes via a distributor, send their gasoline to one of three kinds of gas station: those that they operate directly, those that they contract managers for, and, most common, the independent franchisee. (There are also unbranded stations that buy daily or weekly from different distributors, sometimes directly from tankers in New York Harbor.)
Dealers pay the pre-tax price, additional markups, and Federal and state gas taxes. Buyers at the pump pay that price plus the dealer's markup, which can be as small as one or two cents a gallon up to a dime or more. That's where self-service is supposed to reduce prices: if the dealer doesn't have to hire attendants, the thinking goes, his overhead goes down.
That is the point of view of gasoline companies represented by the New Jersey Petroleum Council. The council says customers deserve a choice, and prices would drop by several cents per gallon. "It seems to work in 48 states," said John Maxwell, the council's associate director.
But the independent operators of gasoline franchises, represented by the Gasoline Retailers' Association, fear that self-serve would not reduce their costs as much as competition would require. Mr. Dressler also talks about "pretty ladies" who might spill gas on their "nice dresses," or who might get attacked at a self-serve pump "with no attendant around to protect them."
But he also has arguments that don't evoke images of an inept June Cleaver or "Nightmare on Elm Street." The association estimates that the state's 3,800 independently operated gas stations employ an average of four attendants each, a total of 15,200 jobs that would be jeopardized by self-service. Self-service adds physical barriers for elderly drivers and those with disabilities, and can add financial barriers, too, because the price differential escalates rapidly when full-service is just an option.
The average differential is 10 to 20 cents, according to a national study by Charles Romeo, an assistant professor of economics at Rutgers. But the range can be much greater. In Pennsylvania, according to Ross DiBono, the executive director of the Pennsylvania Gasoline Retailers Association, the difference runs from 8 cents to 40 or 50 cents per gallon.
In a measure of the complexity of the issue, the state's two large drivers' groups are split.
"We've never been able to get a commitment that the prices would actually drop," said Pamela Fischer, a spokeswoman for AAA New Jersey, which has fought to keep the ban. "And unless it's going to benefit the motorist's pocketbook, what good is it?"
The New Jersey branch of the the National Motorists Association wants to remove the ban. Steve Carrellas, an association spokesman, said speed and control are more important than price.
"I think people do want the choice," he said. "You can still have a law requiring the station to have someone there to handle the pump, which would be good for seniors and the handicapped. And you could make it that the dealer can only charge one price per grade of gasoline, and that price would reflect the cost of the station owner to maintain some level of full service."
One way or another, many people are convinced that New Jersey can't hold onto mandatory full-service forever. Even Anthony Smith, a third-generation station owner in Newark who makes sure his customers get their windshields washed and their oil checked, said he thought self-serve was inevitable.
"I don't think it's price," he said. "It's the option to serve yourself, or be served."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Jersey drivers have to leave the state to pump their own gas, as Michael Manchio did recently in Philadelphia. (Mary DiBiase Blaich for the New York Times)

PUB-DATE: May 31, 1998,

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 16; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1022 words

HEADLINE: FOOD;
Lamb, Succulent With Spices and Figs

BYLINE: By MOIRA HODGSON

 BODY:
WHEN I was growing up in England, the traditional dish for a spring Sunday lunch was roast lamb. It was, of course, served well done (the children always fought over who got the crispy bit at the end of the joint -- and very crisp it was, too). The meat was gray and rather dry, and with it fresh mint sauce, peas and new potatoes from the garden were handed around the table. It was one of my favorite meals.
But several years later, in a modest French bistro in New York City, I made the startling discovery of roast lamb served pink. The meat was not accompanied by potatoes but by flageolets, and instead of mint sauce, there was lamb just flavored with red wine. The whole plate reeked of garlic, and it was wonderful. 
 From then on, roast lamb entered the repertory of my no-fail dinner party dishes, and it was always larded with a good deal of garlic. Sometimes I wrap the leg in anchovies (which lose their sharp taste when cooked) or in a paste of mustard, yogurt and olive oil, sometimes both. Roast lamb was -- and still is -- both easy and economical (especially since a cheaper grade of meat like choice, which has less fat, can be used).
When the weather is warm enough for the outdoor grill, leg of lamb can be boned and cooked over the coals. It is especially good marinated in a mixture of Moroccan spices, which make a smoky crust, and served in slices on a bed of mint leaves.
Matthew Kenney, the chef and owner of Matthew's and Monzu Restaurants in Manhattan, also uses Moroccan spices with lamb, cooked in a tagine. He stews the shank with spices and figs and sprinkles it with cilantro, toasted almonds and sesame seeds. This is a great party dish, served on a bed of couscous with grilled vegetables or salad on the side.
 
Roast Marinated Leg of Lamb
Total Time: 1 1/2 hours cooking
plus overnight marinating
 
 1leg of lamb, about six pounds
 2tablespoons Dijon mustard
 1cup plain yogurt
 2tablespoons soy sauce
 1/4cup olive oil
 6cloves garlic, minced
 2tablespoons grated orange peel
 1/2cup fresh rosemary leaves
 Freshly ground pepper and coarse sea salt to taste.
1. The previous evening, wipe the lamb dry with paper towels and scrape off any blue markings and fat. In a small bowl, combine mustard, yogurt, soy sauce, olive oil, garlic, orange peel, rosemary and pepper. Spread mixture evenly over the lamb, then wrap it in foil in the refrigerator overnight.
2. Bring lamb to room temperature before cooking it. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Season lamb with salt and put on a rack. Roast it for 15 minutes. Turn heat down to 375 degrees and roast it for 9 to 11 minutes a pound for rare, 12 to 15 minutes a pound for medium.
Yield: 8 to 10 servings.
 
Butterflied Leg of Lamb Grilled Moroccan Style
Total Time: 30 minutes plus marinating
 
 16- to 7-pound leg of lamb, boned so that it lies flat
 1/2cup extra-virgin olive oil
 1tablespoon ground ginger
 1tablespoon ground coriander
 1tablespoon ground cumin
 1tablespoon Hungarian paprika
 3cloves garlic, minced
 Coarse sea salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 3cups fresh mint leaves, left whole but with stalks removed.
1. The previous evening or at least two hours before cooking the lamb, wipe it dry with paper towels and remove as much fat as possible. In a small bowl combine olive oil, ginger, coriander, cumin, paprika and garlic. Spread mixture evenly over lamb. If marinating overnight, wrap it in foil and refrigerate it, otherwise leave at room temperature.
2. Preheat grill or coals until they are very hot. Season the lamb with salt and pepper and put on rack to cook. Do not be alarmed if flames erupt, caused by lamb fat pouring off. Cook the lamb for seven to eight minutes on each side. The meat should be done then if you like your lamb on the rare side. If you like it more well done, cook it longer (about 12 minutes on each side). The lamb should be browned on the outside but remain pink in the middle. If you cook it too long, the meat will turn out gray and dry.
3. Let the lamb rest for five minutes, then cut it in thin slices with a sharp knife. Spread mint leaves over a serving platter and arrange the slices of lamb on top.
Yield: 8 to 10 servings.
 
Lamb Tagine With Dried Figs And Almonds
Total Time: 2 1/2 hours
 
 1/4cup sesame seeds
 1/2cup sliced almonds
 2tablespoons olive oil
 2 1/2pounds boned lamb shoulder, trimmed of excess fat and cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes
 Coarse sea salt and freshly
 ground black pepper
 2cloves garlic, minced
 1medium onion, chopped
 1teaspoon ground cumin
 1teaspoon ground cardamom
 1teaspoon turmeric
 1teaspoon ground chili pepper like Ancho, or chili powder
 1cup dried figs, quartered
 4tablespoons chopped cilantro plus 8 sprigs cilantro.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Put sesame seeds on a small sheet pan or pie plate and toast in oven for six minutes. Add almonds and toast another 8 to 10 minutes until golden brown. Set aside.
2. Put olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Season lamb with salt and pepper. Brown on all sides in two batches, about 10 to 12 minutes total. Add garlic, onion, cumin, cardamom, turmeric and chili powder to the lamb. Stir well and reduce heat to medium low. Cook for five minutes. Add two and two-thirds cups water and bring to boil. Reduce heat, cover and simmer for one and a half hours, or until meat is tender. It should be slightly springy but easy to pull apart with your fingers.
3. Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Strain liquid from the stew into small saucepan or bowl and skim fat. Adjust seasoning and keep warm. Mix meat and figs and spread in a single layer in an ovenproof serving dish. Pour sauce over meat and figs and sprinkle with almonds. Bake 12 minutes, or until crisp and golden. Sprinkle with sesame seeds and chopped cilantro and garnish with cilantro sprigs. Serve from hot dish.
Yield: 4 servings.
Note: This is adapted from Matthew Kenney's "Mediterranean Cooking" (Chronicle Books).

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Victoria Roberts)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (88%); ENGLAND (73%);

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (88%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (88%); ENGLAND (73%); NEW YORK, USA (88%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (88%);

PERSON: LAMB TOTAL TIME (81%);

 2 1/2pounds boned lamb shoulder, trimmed of excess fat and cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes
 Coarse sea salt and freshly
 ground black pepper
 2cloves garlic, minced
 1medium onion, chopped
 1teaspoon ground cumin
 1teaspoon ground cardamom
 1teaspoon turmeric
 1teaspoon ground chili pepper like Ancho, or chili powder
 1cup dried figs, quartered
 4tablespoons chopped cilantro plus 8 sprigs cilantro.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Put sesame seeds on a small sheet pan or pie plate and toast in oven for six minutes. Add almonds and toast another 8 to 10 minutes until golden brown. Set aside.
2. Put olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Season lamb with salt and pepper. Brown on all sides in two batches, about 10 to 12 minutes total. Add garlic, onion, cumin, cardamom, turmeric and chili powder to the lamb. Stir well and reduce heat to medium low. Cook for five minutes. Add two and two-thirds cups water and bring to boil. Reduce heat, cover and simmer for one and a half hours, or until meat is tender. It should be slightly springy but easy to pull apart with your fingers.
3. Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Strain liquid from the stew into small saucepan or bowl and skim fat. Adjust seasoning and keep warm. Mix meat and figs and spread in a single layer in an ovenproof serving dish. Pour sauce over meat and figs and sprinkle with almonds. Bake 12 minutes, or until crisp and golden. Sprinkle with sesame seeds and chopped cilantro and garnish with cilantro sprigs. Serve from hot dish.
Yield: 4 servings.
Note: This is adapted from Matthew Kenney's "Mediterranean Cooking" (Chronicle Books).
