HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Will a New Association Give Insurers a Kinder Face?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
WITH trumpets and drum flourishes, the life insurance industry has rolled out a new organization intended to burnish its soiled reputation and convince Americans that it really is safe to do business with its agents.
Most of the industry's leading companies have joined the group, called the Insurance Marketplace Standards Association. Members gain the right to include in their advertisements the organization's bull's-eye logo, which the group hopes will come to be regarded as a kind of Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval on policies. 
 But consumer advocates are skeptical that the group will change the way insurance agents operate or succeed in diminishing an image of scheming, cheating rascals that has haunted the industry with millions of unhappy policyholders seeking redress through lawsuits. "I'm afraid it's just going to be cosmetic," said J. Robert Hunter, a former Texas insurance commissioner who is now director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America.
There may be good reason for the skepticism. The guiding principles of the association boil down to these: treat customers fairly, don't criticize the competition and assign someone to make sure the company is following the rules. Most insurance companies always espoused these goals, even as some agents were selling policies that delivered considerably less than promised.
Moreover, while individual companies must establish written policies and assign people to monitor compliance, the association has no mechanism to discipline members that fail to live up to its standards. It relies on a company's self-assessment and a review by a team of outside examiners -- paid by the company -- to determine eligibility. And so far, it has not rejected any of the 170 companies that have applied.
"Given the recent history of the insurance industry," Mr. Hunter said, "if you're not saying some people don't meet our standards, something's wrong."
Some of the biggest life insurers have paid millions of dollars in settlements arising from customer complaints. Some customers said agents had disguised insurance as retirement plans; others said they were falsely promised that they could receive added coverage at no extra cost or that, in a few years, premiums would vanish and policies would pay for themselves. In the biggest case, the Prudential Insurance Company of America has paid more than $70 million in fines and expects to pay customers up to $2 billion in settlement claims.
Robert R. Googins, executive director of the association, acknowledged that its guiding principles were not new to insurance or commerce in general. But he said he thought that formally pledging honesty and service to customers, rather than assuming them as vague, historical virtues, would reassure the public and lead companies to re-examine whether they were practicing what their founders preached.
Some 170 companies -- representing 64 percent of the individual life insurance business and 54 percent of annuities -- have joined the group since it started in April. Mr. Googins said there were signs that attaining membership in the group had improved sales and service procedures.
To get started, companies have to work their way through a 191-page handbook, create or update policies, assign specific responsibility for the policies and ultimately be able to answer "yes" to 162 questions.
"When people started turning the pages of the assessment handbook, they found things that they weren't doing all the time or that they weren't doing at all," said Mr. Googins, a former insurance commissioner in Connecticut. "It was kind of an eye-opener in terms of, 'Gee, we just assumed we were doing these things.' But there were a lot of gaps."
The reviews have taken months, Mr. Googins said, and the independent assessments for each company have cost as much as several hundred thousand dollars. The group requires that both examinations be repeated every three years. But, he said, "the real cost of this program is all the effort and time required for the continued maintenance of the policies and procedures and the staffing."
Mr. Googins considers it a virtue that no one who has applied has been turned away. Under the association's rules, companies do not apply and then go through the examination. Instead, they see whether they measure up, then apply -- or not, if they don't. "But," he said, "if a company is serious, it would make the necessary changes and then apply."
In keeping with the glacial pace of the industry, it took four years to create the association and work out the guidelines.
The new standards apply exclusively to life insurance and annuity sales and do not include other products sold by the companies, like health or disability insurance. They also do not address the perennial complaint of customers that policy language is impenetrable.
Joseph M. Belth, a professor emeritus of insurance at Indiana University and the editor of The Insurance Forum, a monthly newsletter about the industry, said he doubted that the association would have much effect because it failed to address what he regards as fundamental shortcomings: companies' persistent unwillingness, for example, to disclose the annual cost of insurance for every $1,000 of coverage, or the extra cost of paying premiums monthly or quarterly instead of annually.
Even organizations that work closely with the industry are cautious in their assessment of the association. "It's a step in the right direction," said Larry Mayewski, a senior vice president at A. M. Best & Company, an insurance company rating agency. "But there is a difference between having a structure in place and making sure that structure is effective. Time will tell whether the structure and controls are effective."


GRAPHIC: Advocates of a trickle-down economy may have found a new reason to crow: Largely because of the booming financial markets, charitable giving rose 7.5 percent in 1997, the biggest increase this decade.
Chart: "Giving More, But Not Till It Hurts"
 According to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's Trust for Philanthropy, Americans contributed $143.5 billion to nonprofit organizations last year, up from a revised $133.5 billion in 1996. Moreover, giving rose in all four donor categories: individuals, up 6.8 percent; bequests, 10 percent; foundations, 11.4 percent, and corporations, 7.5 percent.
 Personal giving -- combining individual giving and bequests --constitutes 85 percent of the total.
But that is at the low end of the range for the last 30 years; in 1975, such donations peaked at 90.2 percent of total giving.
 Similarly, the $143.5 billion in total giving, while a record, represents 1.8 percent of the gross domestic product, below the top of the 30-year range: roughly 2.1 percent from 1967 through 1972. Had last year's giving equaled that rate, total giving would have neared $170 billion.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;
Revival Yes, Parking No

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
Late last year, the city opened a one-stop payment center for people to pay tax bills, parking fines and the like in a vacant factory on 94th Avenue. But there was limited space for parking -- only 50 spots for an estimated 251 employees and 1,200 daily visitors, many of them drivers headed to a Parking Violations Bureau hearing room.
"These people come to pay fines and they can't find parking, so you get a ticket while paying a ticket," said David Boord, co-chairman of the Coalition for Public Parking, a group formed six months ago to lobby for more parking lots and garages in downtown Jamaica. 
 Richard LoConte, a spokesman for the Department of Finance, said that he was aware of the parking problems but that the lot for 50 cars was the only space available there. Besides, he said, the area is a transportation hub, so people can get there by train or bus.
Mr. Boord and others say the government offices that have moved in, helping rejuvenate downtown Jamaica in the last five years, are competing for parking with businesses, an issue first reported in The Queens Tribune.
In the 56 square blocks of Jamaica's business district, there are a total of 41 city, state and Federal agencies, with more on the way. Yet many of these agencies have provided minimal or no parking for their workers and clients, forcing them to use the metered municipal lots that businesses rely on for customers.
A study last year done for the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, a nonprofit economic development group that oversees some parking lots, found that a shortfall of 221 parking spaces downtown. And in five years, the study said, the area will have a shortage of 1,500.
"It's a horrible situation for merchants," Chuck Wallace, the director of a Toys "R" Us on Jamaica Avenue, said. "With limited parking, you don't get that big-ticket item going out the door. It's kind of hard to take a bike or jungle gym on a bus."
Until Borough President Claire Shulman intervened this month, 86 of the 256 spaces in the municipal lot behind the toy store were used by police officers from the 103d Precinct. They now park their personal cars at a former tow pound nearby. But the municipal lot is still often full, especially on weekdays. Some 2,000 people either work at or visit the state offices that are in the same building as Toys "R" Us.
Two weeks ago, members of the Coalition for Public Parking met with people from the Mayor's office. Curt Ritter, a mayoral spokesman, said the city was working on a plan, but would not reveal details.
The coalition has also written to other government officials, urging them to consider the need for parking when agencies move into the area. The new Civil Court on Sutphin Boulevard, for example, resulted in a net loss of more than 238 parking spaces, the group said.
"I know people from Jamaica who travel out of the city to take advantage of the free parking," Mr. Boord said. "And jobs and tax money go with them." RICHARD WEIR

GRAPHIC: Photo: Parking spaces are scarce near the courthouse on Sutphin Boulevard. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Insider Sales Don't Always Burn Outsiders in I.P.O.'s

BYLINE: By RICK GLADSTONE 

 BODY:
IF the cockpit crew dons parachutes before the plane even leaves the gate, prudent passengers may want to avoid the flight. But such logic doesn't necessarily apply to investments in new stock offerings.
The rush of initial public offerings in recent years has included substantial amounts of insider selling -- sales of stock held by corporate executives and private shareholders who are bailing out or greatly reducing their stakes. Such sales are often taken as a sign that insiders know something horrible lurks ahead that could trounce the stock. 
 Yet a study of offerings since 1993, compiled by Commscan, an investment research firm in New York, shows that shares of these I.P.O.'s have, as a group, outperformed initial offerings in which all the stock offered was newly issued by the companies.
The effect is not limited to initial offerings. Subsequent stock offerings that included insider selling of shares also outperformed those that did not, the study shows.
Michael Kim, the Commscan analyst who conducted the study, said the results surprised him. "Contrary to everyone's assumptions, a deleterious effect from insider selling can't be assumed," he said.
The study's data base "doesn't point to any specific factors, nothing about the companies themselves" that could account for the surprising results, Mr. Kim said, and he was unwilling to speculate about causes. "There could be hundreds of different reasons," he said.
Analysts said they found the Commscan study's results intriguing and contrarian, especially given other studies showing that many initial offerings disappoint investors.
"Three out of four I.P.O.'s trade below their offering price within the first 12 months," said Michael Murphy, a technology-stock investor and money manager in Half Moon Bay, Calif., who publishes a newsletter on stocks he considers overvalued. "Performance from either the offering price or first trade has been pretty poor."
Others said the Commscan study might have unintentionally masked some important distinctions among insider sales in offerings.
Some spinoffs, for example, are counted as insider-included sales. When a company separates out a business and hands it over to shareholders, the main aim is to unlock or improve the value of the business, and some recent spinoffs have been huge successes.
And company executives or large shareholders who put their shares on the block in initial offerings could have many reasons for bailing out: portfolio diversification, personal cash needs, a child's tuition.
"Insider selling covers a whole lot of variables when talking about I.P.O.'s," said Robert Mescal, editor of New Issues, a monthly newsletter about new offerings published by the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield Beach, Fla. "It may be that the chief executive has agreed to leave with the I.P.O. That's insider selling, but it isn't done with malice."
NONETHELESS, Mr. Mescal said, prospective buyers should scrutinize insider selling. "My first question is, 'What do you know that I don't know?' " he said. "My thought always is that retail investors, the little guys like you and me, are at the mercy of everything. Read the prospectus if there's any doubt in your mind."
The prospectus will not specify why inside shareholders are selling, only whether the proceeds of the sale will go to the company. But the prospectus reveals other useful information about the insiders.
John Fitzgibbon, editor of IPO Reporter, a weekly newsletter based in New York that focuses on the new-offering market, said it is important to look for the number of shares that insiders keep after the offering, which can be a good indicator of their confidence in the company's future.
Perhaps more important, Mr. Fitzgibbon said, is the so-called lockup period, or how many days after the offering insiders are prohibited from further selling. That period is normally 180 days, but insiders can seek a waiver. "That's the big cautionary flag, if these insiders come back and say, 'I want to sell,' " he said. "It sets off the alarm bells, like that old gauge in the boiler room. You'd best look at it."
Dan Dykens, an analyst at the Renaissance Capital Corporation in Greenwich, Conn., which runs a mutual fund that invests in new offerings, said smart investors were likely to be wary of insider selling regardless of the reasons given.
"I think the classical or traditional outlook is, if they own the business, and they're confident it's such a great business, then why are they selling?" Mr. Dykens said.
These assertions were not disputed by Mr. Kim of Commscan, who said his study merely showed that insider selling wasn't necessarily a bad omen.
"Just because you hear that a large shareholder is selling, you can't assume the company's stock will do poorly because of that," he said. "I think that's the only reasonable conclusion you can draw."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Herald Square, Swing District

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
THE portly man struck the golf ball with a stiff swipe, and the sound of metal striking plastic brought to mind green fairways, wind in the trees and money. But the man was not on the seventh hole of some exclusive country club. He was at the New York Golf Center on 35th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway.
"I will buy this," the man, Ignacio Cruz, an insurance executive from Madrid, said as he pointed to the club he was using -- the Biggest Big Bertha, $290 from Callaway. "I'm a regular client of this store." 
 There are successful golf shops all over the city, but in recent years the Herald Square area has become a particular hotbed. There are five retailers between 32d and 35th Streets, all small oases of green carpeting for tourists from foreign countries where equipment is either scarce or extremely expensive, and for city dwellers marooned far from a regulation course.
Available in each store are shiny new clubs fanned out against the walls, stacks of brightly colored boxes of balls, small putting greens, and areas for taking practice swings. There are usually a few female shoppers, but it is men who use the stores as hangouts, hefting clubs and exaggerating their weekend exploits. Many prefer not to be identified, saying their bosses and wives might not understand.
But on Wednesday Peter Amoruso was happy to talk. "My golf clubs are my girlfriends," said Mr. Amoruso, who lives and works in midtown and pops into the Golf Center five days a week. "Coming here, it gives you a big-time fix. You see friends, you say hello and talk about equipment."
"They know I do this at the office," he went on. "It's therapy. If I don't do this, I'm pulling my hair out."
The West 30's wasn't always a golf neighborhood. The pioneer was Golf Trading, which opened in the 1960's on 35th Street west of Fifth Avenue. In the early 80's, the name was changed to Larry's Golf, after the owner at the time, Larry Zimmerman, who has since retired to Florida.
In the beginning, as now, the West Side's lure for owners was cheaper real estate than on the East Side, and the fact that the West 30's, also home to the Empire State Building and Macy's, is well traveled by two golf-loving constituencies: tourists and business people.
"It's because of the tourists," said Rangsima Naganidhi, whose husband, Nick, took over Larry's Golf in 1996 and changed the name to Nick's Golf. "Most of the customers we have are regulars from Asia and Europe."
After Larry's came the Golf Center, which opened in 1983. Golf Town followed in 1990, on 32d Street between Fifth Avenue and Broadway. Eagle Golf opened in 1992 on Avenue of the Americas between 36th and 37th Streets. Three years ago, Fifth Avenue Golf Trends opened, just east of the avenue on 32d Street. For the last year the neighborhood has even had a golf teacher, Mark Lozier, who works out of a studio on 32d Street.
Part of the explanation for this cluster of golf activity is cultural. The West 30's is often referred to as the city's Koreatown, and all five shops are owned by people of Korean, Japanese or Thai descent who said that about half their business comes from Asian and European customers.
Peter Choi, a Korean-American who owns Golf Town, said that the Asian ownership was no coincidence. "Koreans, Japanese and other Asians are crazy about golf," he explained. "When they come here they buy the house, then the car and then the golf clubs."
Spend a few hours at any of the stores and you will see customers spending $1,000 for a set of irons or $400 for a single driver, or both. Some of the owners estimated that they average about 150 transactions a day, with more during the summer and Christmas seasons.
But several owners complained that business had become more difficult in the last five years. And having so many stores so close together does not make it any easier.
"There is a lot of competition among the stores," said Herb Rhee, who with his brother, Charles, runs the Golf Center, which is owned by their father, Sam. "Then all the stores lower their prices and no one can make a profit from selling clubs. The stores are being stupid, and no one can make any money. It is getting saturated like the electronics business."
Ms. Naganidhi of Nick's Golf agreed. "People shop around, so you have to bargain, and the profit margins are very small," she said, adding that her store concentrated on selling used clubs, something that the others don't much do.
Asia's recent economic problems have made matters worse, reducing the number of customers throughout the West 30's golf hub, the store owners said. Although all said they were doing fine, no one would discuss sales figures. And Golf Town's owner, Mr. Choi, said of the five stores: "I think one or two may go. Or they may sell to someone else."
"People get into this because they love golf," Charles Rhee said. "Then they find out that this is a tough business."
But to the customers, the stores' bottom lines are beside the point. They visit to forget about business. "I'm thinking maybe I'll get my wife to buy me this putter," said Murray Sarway, a tan executive in a tan suit who was looking at a $399 club at the Golf Center. "I find that golf soothes my mind. It takes away the pressure."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
An Emerging-Markets Bog: Time to Wade In Again?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
MAY was a rough month for emerging markets, which are proving once again that they can turn sour on a dime.
The Russian RTS index fell 38.8 percent. In Indonesia, the Jakarta composite index was off 8.6 percent after dropping 15 percent the month before. The South Korean Kospi index dropped 20.5 percent. And the contagion spread to Latin America, where Mexico's Bolsa dropped 11.2 percent. 
 So what was Mark Mobius, the managing director of Templeton Asset Management, doing?
He was in Moscow last week, beginning to sift through the rubble of the stock market there to find bargains for his closed-end Templeton Russia fund, whose share price is off 32 percent this year after a 78 percent gain in 1997. He was also snapping up Russian GKO's, akin to Treasury bills, that were paying annual interest rates of 70 percent and more.
That is Mr. Mobius's job. He is supposed to make the best of a crisis. And he would be happy for investors to send money his way. But heed what he says about the values that he thinks he can find now, in Russia and in other emerging markets that have recently collapsed: "These returns may take a year or two to materialize."
And though he is sifting, he remains cautious about the outlook. Before Russia's market crashed, Mr. Mobius thought the market was overpriced, given the risk involved. So he had a third of his Russia fund's assets in cash, an unusually high percentage for a closed-end stock fund. He is usually fully invested in stocks.
In the big picture, it is not important that Russia appeared to set off the latest round of routs in emerging markets. Many face serious problems, and ripples from any one market are usually felt near and far.
But it was the Russian central bank's move to raise official interest rates to a staggering 150 percent that got the most attention last week. The bank made a bold effort to defend the country's currency, the ruble, and stave off economic chaos; the jury is still out on its effectiveness, and the outlook remained dicey at week's end.
Traders and strategists continued to debate whether the International Monetary Fund, the United States or others would come up with a new rescue package to avoid a crippling currency devaluation. Moody's Investors Service downgraded Russia's credit rating. Monetary fund officials released $670 million in previously promised cash but said they were not considering a separate new package of money for Russia.
Constance Hunter, a portfolio manager for Firebird Management L.L.C., which runs three hedge funds investing in equities and bonds in the countries of the former Soviet Union, said investors believed that "if the currency goes, it is going to go in the next two or three weeks," judging by the high levels that short-term interest rates have reached in recent days.
Ripples were coming from other markets, too. Thousands of workers went on strike to protest growing layoffs in South Korea. Indonesia's new president, B. J. Habibie, struggled to win confidence in his approach to reform. Pakistan set off five underground nuclear tests, heightening tensions with India and disapproving Western nations. The continued weakening of the Japanese yen cast more doubt on Japan's ability to lead Asia out of the economic doldrums.
But some investors may decide that caution is not the wisest course. Emerging markets have a habit of rebounding sharply.
Investors were warned away from the developing world after the Mexican peso was devalued and emerging markets collapsed at the end of 1994. The United States worked out a bailout package in March 1995, and by July the Bolsa recouped all it had lost since December. A cautious investor might have missed much of that rally.
Many bullish investors seem to be assuming the same will happen in Russia: The I.M.F. and the United States will not let the ruble be devalued, they say, and will do whatever is needed to sustain it.
"The market is leaning toward believing that the I.M.F. will come up with another bailout," said Richard Segal, the fixed-income strategist in the proprietary trading unit of Santander Investment Securities in London. He said investors, traders and strategists considered Russia so important that the United States and its allies would dare not let it fail, and the I.M.F. would have a hard time turning Russia down after making loans to Indonesia and South Korea.
But he said a Russian bailout would mean "more investors will invest in risky countries," a criticism leveled at other bailouts.
Mr. Mobius, not counting on such a bailout, said he was looking for stocks that would not be seriously hurt by a devaluation of the ruble. Such companies would include exporters that are paid in foreign currencies and domestic companies with little foreign-currency debt.
A bailout would probably lead to a quick rebound in Russia. But the other bailouts the I.M.F. undertook in Asia last year benefited markets only temporarily.
Since a bailout of Thailand was announced in August, the main stock index there has fallen almost 50 percent. In Indonesia, the stock market fell after the first outlines of a rescue plan emerged at the end of October. The market then rallied early in the year but is now down 24 percent from its February high. In South Korea, the Kospi index traveled a similar road, falling after a bailout was readied in December, then rallying strongly at the beginning of the year, only to sag 42 percent since March.
Desmond Lachman, the head of emerging-markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney, is more worried than many money managers. "My view on emerging markets is fairly bearish, but not because of Russia," he said.
"Russia gets bailed out," he predicted. "It is Asia that is the problem."
He said he expected the yen to keep sliding, making the stabilization of the rest of Asia more difficult because Japan would not be the buyer that helped lift the other countries out of their slumps.
Ms. Hunter of Firebird Management said investors should remember how quickly things can change in emerging markets.
At the beginning of the year, betting that the Russian market would decline, she made money selling some stocks short so she could buy them back later at lower prices. She had a 15 percent gain in the first quarter. But she started betting on a rally in March. "In retrospect, we should have waited," she said. "But in March things looked better."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Declarations of Independence;
The New American Spirit: Divided We Stand

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
MERGER mania may be running amok in the world of commerce, but in the world of civics the opposite seems to be happening. Cities and counties dotting the country are in the grip of secession fever.
In California, the San Fernando Valley has been brazenly unfaithful to the city of Los Angeles, doing all it can to get a divorce. 
 Last month in New York, the rural East End of Long Island filed suit, trying to force the State Legislature to allow it to secede from Suffolk County and form Peconic County.
In Maine, a legislator submitted a bill last year seeking to study the feasibility of making northern Maine the 51st state.
A Maryland lawmaker recently asked his Legislature to let Eastern Shore residents decide if they want to form their own state.
And in March, seeking attention over a nettlesome fishing dispute, people in a sliver of Minnesota called the Northwest Angle got their Congressman to propose a constitutional amendment allowing them to secede from the United States and join Canada.
Taking a cue, perhaps, from places like Scotland and Quebec, break-up talk is bleeding into legislatures and city halls. Some of it is intended to draw attention to neglected issues. But most of it stems from a serious desire for more local autonomy.
 
Breaking Away
Even so, as Staten Island learned in its failed secession battle five years ago, these movements have dim prospects because they usually must be approved by governing bodies of the very places they want to leave.
The only movement currently given a fighting chance is in the San Fernando Valley, the suburban sprawl of 1.4 million people that spawned the nasally hip Valley Girl. An organized campaign by constituents who believe they receive too few city services for their high taxes is seeking to create what would be the nation's sixth-largest city.
The effort gained ground in October with a law that bars city councils from vetoing secession initiatives, though there are still hurdles: petition signatures of 25 percent of registered voters, a viability study and a majority vote for secession in both the Valley and Los Angeles.
"People feel that they're not getting a fair shake in the existing arrangements," said Richard Briffault, a professor at Columbia University Law School who has written about legal issues in secession but is neutral on its desirability. "Usually, it's a group that's a population minority in the larger entity. They are also different in some significant way, whether it's based on ethnicity or based on politics or based on economics."
In Maryland, the conservative Eastern Shore has chafed under state laws on gun control and wetlands preservation, but "the straw that broke the camel's back," said State Senator Richard L. Colburn, a Republican, was the response when a toxic microbe killed thousands of fish in Chesapeake Bay last year.
 
The Backlash Factor
Tracing the problem to manure runoff at chicken farms, the major Eastern Shore industry, the Governor proposed stricter environmental regulations costly to the poultry industry.
"We feel we should control our own destiny," said Mr. Colburn, who introduced a bill this session that was buried in committee but may resurface. Mr. Colburn wants to call the new state Delmarva (after the peninsula shared by Delaware and Virginia), and said it would have no sales tax, loose environmental regulation and a blue flag with one star like the Bonnie Blue flown by some southern states in the Civil War.
Some activists and politicians see secession as a movement whose time has come, a welcome backlash to the consolidation that began earlier in the century, when most cities grew by annexing territory. A few cities, like Indianapolis and Nashville, have merged with their suburbs in recent years, but some experts say the pendulum is swinging the other way. In Los Angeles, which has always been a diffuse collection of neighborhoods, Venice, San Pedro and other communities are also talking secession.
"Fracturing cities might be the best way to form more efficient governments," said Howard Husock, director of case studies and public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. He also favors a "quasi-secession" movement in Dade County, Fla., where four unincorporated areas near Miami have voted to turn themselves into municipalities.
"Small municipalities can control things like schools, zoning and other functions, and form compacts with other communities for other services, like fire departments," Mr. Husock said.
 
Shock Therapy
Tom McClintock, a Republican Assemblyman who co-wrote the California law opening the door to secession movements, puts the argument in grander terms.
"Large, centralized command-and-control structures were very much a 20th-century phenomenon, actually a throwback to medieval governing modalities," he said. "We have been re-learning the lessons of the Enlightenment, that human institutions produce far more satisfactory results when powers are decentralized and disbursed."
Kevin Starr, a California historian who is the state librarian, fears that breaking up Los Angeles would leave behind a shell of a city. He said he saw some secession movements as "a kind of shock therapy."
"It's like a married couple when one person doesn't really want a divorce but moves out," he added. "Everybody starts rethinking the relationship."
Some proponents claim they reap benefits even if they don't gain independence because the media attention forces elected officials to take notice.
"Even without Peconic County being formed, we have seen a lot of attention," said Assemblyman Fred W. Thiele Jr., a Republican from Sag Harbor, N.Y., who twice introduced legislation asking for a binding referendum on forming a new county, to no avail. Mr. Thiele believes the threat of secession has prompted politicians to favor his constituents on issues like farmland preservation and real-estate transfer taxes.
In Maine, State Representative Henry Joy, a Republican who introduced the secession study bill, said forest and land regulations were restricting economic growth in northern Maine. He said the bill generated "hearings around the state to discuss the feasibility of economic development in rural areas."
It also convinced Mr. Joy to run for governor this year.
 
A Cry for Attention
Representative Collin Peterson, the Democrat who introduced the constitutional amendment in Minnesota, said the 100 residents of the Northwest Angle didn't really want to leave the country -- only to solve their problems with Ontario over regulation of the Lake of the Woods, which dips into Minnesota. He acknowledged that secession publicity got him a meeting with Canadian officials.
"The people in the Northwest Angle decided the only way to get something resolved was to create an international incident," Mr. Peterson said. "Initially, their idea was to blockade a train."

(Associated Press); Secession talk is popping up in a number of communities, though as advocates in Staten Island, N.Y., learned in their failed battle five years ago, even patriotic language can't help most of these long-shot campaigns. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Avoiding That Sinking Feeling

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Uncharted waters. That's where United States equity investors found themselves last week.
For more than three years, corporate profits have risen as the economy expanded. Those earnings gains, in turn, fueled stock prices. The rising tide lifted all boats. 
 But this week, the situation was very different: Profits were shrinking -- down 2.2 percent in the first quarter -- even as gross domestic product stormed ahead 4.8 percent. It was the second quarter in a row that profits fell. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 2.4 percent.
Then there was the distress in Russian, Latin American and Asian markets.
What's a nervous investor to do? Forget about retreating to the old investment havens. They ain't what they used to be.
In the not-so-distant past, defensive shares in electric utilities, telecommunications companies and tobacco companies were good bets for bleak times. No more.
Big tobacco is under siege from the government, and the stocks show it: Philip Morris is down 22 percent from its January high, and Loews, which owns Lorillard, is down 17 percent. Telecommunications companies and electric utilities were old standbys because their businesses and revenues were highly regulated and predictable. Deregulation has made investing in these stocks much more of a crapshoot.
So how can stock market investors act defensively today? Given the profit picture and the economy's continued punch, investors should look for companies that can raise their prices to consumers. As long as the economy remains strong and interest rates low, stocks with pricing power will do well. Only one thing would wreck that picture: an interest rate increase by the Fed.
Jason Trennert, economist and vice president at International Strategy and Investment, an economic consulting firm in New York, has identified the industries that will be able to raise prices in coming months, and there are just a few. "What's great for consumers -- high wages, low inflation and heated competition -- is not great for most companies," Mr. Trennert said.
In his view, only two industries can raise prices: airlines and home builders. Airline stocks have had a nice run this year, but are down 9 percent from their March highs. At 17 times earnings, the group trades at a big discount to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which has a multiple of 26.
Although home building stocks would seem vulnerable to a rate increase, Mr. Trennert said that even if rates blip up, they will remain low enough to keep mortgages attractive. The stocks are cheap; well off their highs of earlier this year, they trade at multiples roughly half that of the S.& P.
Heading the list of industries that cannot raise prices is the heavy-manufacturing group: makers of automobiles, technology equipment and other capital goods. According to ISI's survey, in which a score of 100 represents strong pricing power, manufacturers' ability to raise prices plunged from more than 60 four years ago to 12.5 this week.
The profit vise in which these companies are caught will only tighten as the Asia crisis deepens. That's because margins on their goods that are sold abroad are often higher than the margins on those sold domestically. Yet these stocks continue to trade at astonishingly rich premiums. The price-to-earnings ratio on the group, as measured by the S.& P. Capital Goods index, is 33. Go figure.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
When Overtime Doesn't Feel So Fine

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
WHEN a winter storm destroyed the Albertson's store where Debra Chard used to work as a deli manager, she called it divine justice. She was relieved to get away from managers who, she said, pushed her to work before and after shifts and demanded that she work long hours with no breaks.
"They'd say, 'Don't expect to have a job if you don't get it done,' " said Ms. Chard, of Bremerton, Wash., who has gone on to work for a different grocery store company. "If I said 'I haven't punched in yet,' they'd say, 'Well, I'll fix that.' " But, she said, they never did punch her in. 
 Ms. Chard, 33, is a plaintiff in one of eight lawsuits against Albertson's, the giant supermarket chain based in Boise, Idaho. The suits, all of which are seeking class-action status, assert that the company has cheated employees and managers of overtime pay, that it has not paid for off-the-clock work done before or after shifts or during breaks and that it has wrongly considered managers to be exempt from overtime pay.
An Albertson's spokesman, Michael Read, denied the allegations. "We are committed to treating our employees fairly, and we do and always have paid them in full for all the time they have worked," he said, adding that employees rarely work off the clock.
Albertson's is unusual in the number of lawsuits it is facing, but many companies are confronting worker complaints about the amount of time expected from them.
In pursuit of lower labor costs, many companies have pared staff in recent years. As a result, some labor experts say, overtime and uncompensated work have become the workplace conflict of the 1990's.
"There are more and more instances where the drive for increased profits results in a company's deliberately denying workers basic economic protections," said Michael Rubin, a partner at Altshuler, Berzon, Nussbaum, Berzon & Rubin, a law firm in San Francisco specializing in labor and employment issues. Mr. Rubin is representing workers for sewing contractors of Guess Inc., the Los Angeles apparel maker, in a suit contending violations of overtime law.
In the early years of the current economic boom, labor experts say, workers felt uncertain about pursuing lawsuits -- they feared for their jobs. But recently, in an increasingly robust labor market, employees have felt secure enough to press on overtime issues and to leave work they see as exploitative.
"In the old days, if you sued your employer, you wouldn't get another job," said Michael F. O'Malley, author of "Are You Paid What You're Worth?" (Broadway Books, 1998) and a compensation expert at William M. Mercer Inc., a consulting firm in New York. "But now you could still be hired the next day by somebody else. I think the fear of not being employable because you have sued an employer is probably not as strong right now."
IN lawsuit after lawsuit, corporations, particularly those that pay lower wages, have been accused of not paying overtime even as they make employees work beyond their shifts, and of keeping managers who spend most of their shifts in nonsupervisory roles from receiving overtime pay to which they are entitled.
The exact number of overtime-related lawsuits cannot be determined. In addition to class-action suits and those brought on behalf of employees by the Department of Labor, many other suits are brought individually. Still, from 1993 through 1997, the Department of Labor recovered roughly $450 million for nearly 900,000 workers. During the same period, more than 61,000 civil suits were filed in Federal courts concerning the Fair Labor Standards Act, though those could also have involved minimum-wage issues.
Amy Kohn, an employment law consultant at Hewitt Associates of Lincolnshire, Ill., said she expected the lawsuits to keep coming.
"There's nothing right now to indicate that they would slow down," she said. "With the labor market being what it is, there's little incentive for employees not to pursue claims if they think they're viable."
The 40-hour workweek was established six decades ago, as part of the Fair Labor Standards Act; under it, hourly employees whose duties are primarily nonsupervisory must receive one and a half times their regular wage for hours worked beyond 40. And some states have adopted even more stringent rules.
To many businesses, the trade-off of more money for more work seems reasonable enough. "If people are being forced to work off the clock, that's illegal and the Department of Labor has an enforcement role there, and employees are free to bring private lawsuits," said Randel Johnson, vice president for labor policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
The concept of overtime, however, can still incite strong debate. Dozens of bills now circulating in Congress address the issue. Last year, a bill sponsored by two Republicans, Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri and Representative Cass Ballenger of North Carolina, would have allowed private employers to offer employees the option of converting each hour of overtime to one and a half hours of compensatory time -- that is, time off. It passed the House, but Democrats blocked the bill from consideration in the Senate, saying it left too much discretion to employers.
Labor Department investigators say overtime violations tend to be concentrated in the retail, construction and garment industries. Union officials contend that many employers expect workers to complete a specific number of tasks in a shift, without considering the amount of time required.
For employers, it's "economically rational" to try to get the most work out of current employees, said Lawrence Mishel, research director of the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group.
Particularly in times of low unemployment, when new workers are harder to find, Mr. Mishel said, employers usually prefer to give current employees overtime work rather than hire new employees.
"If you use people on overtime, you don't pay more for health insurance, pensions and various fixed fringe benefits packages," he said. "You don't have to train new people, and you don't have to lay people off when the demand slackens."
MORE than 4,000 unionized and nonunionized employees have filed wage claims against Albertson's, which operates 865 grocery stores and drugstores in the West, Midwest and South. In California and Washington alone, the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, which represents workers at about a third of the company's stores across the country, estimates that Albertson's owes workers $189 million.
Mr. Read, the Albertson's spokesman, said: "In the past two years alone, there's been over a quarter of a billion dollars paid in overtime. If it's needed, we allow it and we pay for it. It's as simple as that."
Still, plaintiffs in the suits say managers gave them few choices: If they were caught working off the clock, they could be dismissed, and if they did not finish the work assigned them during their regular working hours, they would be replaced, they said.
James E. Restivo, 28, of Boynton Beach, Fla., said managers expected him to work off the clock from the day he started working three years ago as a member of the night crew at an Albertson's there.
"I've been told by store directors to work 50 or 60 hours, whatever it takes," he said.
Workers were expected to continue their duties unpaid after punching out at the end of an eight-hour shift, many plaintiffs in the suits say. Moreover, they contend, the company's compensation system for its top supervisors encouraged such pressures.
"Whether the department managers and store director receive their bonus is greatly dependent on keeping labor costs low," said Joe Peterson, special assistant to the union president. "It's a built-in system for employees not to report all their work time because if they do, their boss has his or her bonus reduced."
Mr. Read, the Albertson's spokesman, said that was untrue. "The bonus is tied to the overall profitability of a store, and labor is only one little piece," he said. Besides, he added, allowing or encouraging off-the-clock work is against company policy and against the law; any managers doing so "would lose their entire bonus for the quarter and be subject to other discipline up to and including termination."
Mr. Read noted that some of the suits against Albertson's were financed in part by the union.
"They want more of our employees to be represented by their union," he said. "That's their primary motivation."
But plaintiffs say the suits are not about unions. Mr. Restivo, who now works in the dairy section at another Albertson's, in Jupiter, Fla., said a 40-hour week is strictly enforced at the new store.
"The grocery manager we have there, he doesn't let us work off the clock," he said. "He's against it 100 percent. We basically do our 40 and that's about it.
"Nobody is pushing for a union," Mr. Restivo continued. "It's about the way they treat people. Let us come in and do our job and go home."
 
Time Is of the Essence
DOZENS of companies in the past few years have faced lawsuits on uncompensated overtime. Here is a sampling:
Southern New England Telephone was ordered by a Federal appeals court last fall to pay $10 million in back wages to 1,500 employees as a result of a suit by the Department of Labor. The suit contended that phone-line workers were not appropriately paid for lunch breaks -- that when at lunch in the field, they were required to secure their work areas, depriving them of free time.
"We reviewed the decision and decided not to appeal," Kevin Moore, a company spokesman, said. "We considered it an internal matter."
Longs Drug Stores agreed in a settlement earlier this year with the Labor Department to pay $3.1 million in uncompensated overtime to 1,300 pharmacists formerly or currently with the chain. According to the company, there was a disagreement over whether the pharmacists were eligible for overtime pay.
"The pharmacists were paid for every hour they worked," said Clay Selland, treasurer for Longs, just not time and a half. The settlement covered the difference. A suit brought in February in Federal court concerning off-the-clock work is pending.
IBP Inc., formerly Iowa Beef Processors, was ordered by a Federal judge late last year to pay $7 million to 23,000 cutting-floor workers in the Midwest who were not compensated for time spent before and after their shifts preparing or storing knives and protective equipment. The order was a result of a Labor Department complaint.
"Most companies in our industry didn't consider those duties compensable, but the judge agreed that they were," said an IBP spokesman, Gary Mickelson.
Guess Inc., the Los Angeles clothing maker, faces a suit in California state court by garment workers contending that it should be held responsible for what they say were violations by its sewing contractors.
Glenn Weinman, general counsel for Guess, called the suit part of an organizing campaign by the Union of Needletrades Industrial and Textile Employees, which is helping to finance the suit. TINA KELLEY

He now works in the dairy section of another Albertson's where, he said, the manager strictly enforces a 40-hour week. (Red Morgan for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3492 words

HEADLINE: Men on a Mission

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
RUSSELL PRATT knocked on the door of Apartment 18A, delivering a firm, fearless rap that echoed down the dim, graffiti-scarred corridors of the Taft Houses in East Harlem. When the door finally opened a crack, he found himself facing a snarling dog and a leery, unwelcoming glare.
"Good morning, sir," Mr. Pratt said as the man sized up his white shirt sleeves, charcoal trousers and dark tie, which made him look like an insurance salesman or an investigator from the Internal Revenue Service. Pointing to the plastic name tag on his breast pocket that read "Elder Pratt," the 22-year-old missionary from Tooele, Utah, flashed an eager smile. 
 "I'm from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints," he told the man, "and I was wondering if. . . ."
The door slammed shut. Mr. Pratt stifled a wince, uttered a cheery "Bless you," and moved on to the next apartment.
And so it went on a recent Wednesday as Mr. Pratt and his partner, Shon Denning, worked their way through the housing projects and tenements of El Barrio. In their effort to draw converts to Mormonism, one of the nation's fastest-growing religions, they have become inured to curious stares, cold indifference and the occasional unkind word.
"This is New York City," Mr. Pratt said, taking a quick lunch break in his 12-hour-a-day proselytizing routine. "You expect people here to be a little suspicious."
Still, despite a spate of morning rejections, the two found their way into a half-dozen apartments that day, secured a handful of follow-up appointments and returned to their East 110th Street apartment that night with eight fewer copies of the Book of Mormon, which they had given to anyone who showed a glimmer of interest. A crossing guard, a nurse's aide and an unemployed handyman were among those who allowed the men into their homes.
"It's amazing how many people will listen to us," said Mr. Denning, 21, his cheeks burnished red from a long day in the sun. "New Yorkers are hungry for what we have to offer."
The Mormon Church, based in Salt Lake City, has found New York fertile ground for new converts, doubling its membership to 20,000 since 1988. To accommodate the city's growing congregations, the church built a sparkling $8 million meeting house just off the Grand Concourse in Kingsbridge, the Bronx, last year. Another is under construction in Inwood, and a recently formed branch that meets at Sylvia's restaurant in Harlem is scouring that neighborhood for larger quarters. Last month, the president and prophet of the Mormon Church, Gordon B. Hinckley, filled all 24,000 seats in Madison Square Garden for a "fireside chat."
"It's amazing what's happening in this city," said Ronald A. Rasband, who oversees 240 unpaid missionaries in New York, most of them men between 19 and 23 years old. "We are a church on the rise."
Worldwide, the church has grown to 10 million members, up from four million in 1978. Most of that growth has taken place beyond Utah, where Mormonism has long had a powerful presence. "We're growing so fast, we have to build a meeting house a day just to keep up," Mr. Rasband said.
Church officials and non-Mormons who study the church agree that the intense focus on proselytizing has helped feed this astounding growth. "The missionary system is the engine that makes this church so robust," said Gary Shepherd, a former missionary who is no longer active in the church and is now a professor of sociology at Oakland University in Rochester Hills, Mich. There are 60,000 Mormon missionaries working in 160 countries, said Michael Leonard, a church spokesman. The Roman Catholic Church, by comparison, has 6,000 missionaries around the world, according to the United States Catholic Mission Association.
What separates Mormon missionaries from those of other evangelical faiths, say those who study the church, is the generous attention they pay to potential converts, known as investigators. Missionaries make repeated home visits to investigators and encourage them to join church gatherings even before they are baptized.
"This is a church where sweet-faced boys and girls make house calls, sit down and answer your questions eye to eye," said Richard Bushman, a professor of history at Columbia University and a lifelong Mormon. "Even before you're a member, they lavish a lot of time on you, offering you a wonderful sense of community. I don't know if that's matched by any other religion."
Mormonism does especially well in New York, a place rife with alienation, instability and fractured families, said Jan Shipps, a professor of religion at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis. "People whose lives are in disarray, newly arrived immigrants and those looking for a sense of community and stability are especially drawn to the church," Ms. Shipps said.
Urban converts, especially blacks, were not always so eagerly courted: Until 20 years ago, the church priesthood was closed to blacks, who, according to Mormon doctrine, carried the mark of Cain. The policy was reversed in 1978, after the president said he had a revelation.
Among Mormon men, the two-year mission is a rite of passage, one that a third accept when they reach 19. Women, who must wait until they are 21 to serve, are not encouraged as strongly as men and make up only 17 percent of the missionary force. "It's really just a reflection of the church's attitude toward gender roles," said Mr. Shepherd, who with his brother Gordon wrote "Mormon Passage: A Missionary Chronicle" (University of Illinois Press, 1998). "Women are supposed to focus on marriage and having families. And just as important, they cannot hold the priesthood, which makes them unable to perform critical church functions like baptisms and confirmations."
Although church officials say there is no pressure to win converts, many missionaries say that those with a prodigious tally can expect a hero's welcome upon their return home and promotions in the church hierarchy. Mr. Shepherd said the average missionary converts five to seven people a year.
The church does not release figures on the number of missionaries who fail to complete their assignments. Mr. Rasband says that except for those who became ill, none of his charges have left early. Mr. Shepherd estimated a dropout rate of 5 percent worldwide based on his research. "Coming home early would leave you seriously stigmatized," he said. "It would probably result in you leaving the church."
 
Long Hours, No Pay, Little Drawer Space
Like missionaries around the world, Shon Denning and Russell Pratt start their day at 6:30 A.M. They have an hour to shower, dress and eat breakfast, followed by two hours studying church teachings. At 9:30 A.M., they start their core task: proselytizing on the Upper East Side and in East Harlem.
Their day ends 12 hours later when they return to the one-bedroom apartment they share with another team of missionaries. All four men sleep in bunk beds. Their only personal space consists of two dresser drawers each.
There is not much on the walls of the fifth-floor walk-up: portraits of Jesus Christ, bus and subway maps, a battered taxi license plate and a photo of President Hinckley. A tattered sofa, its armrests worn to the wooden frame, sits in the living room. One wall is lined with copies of the Book of Mormon and videocassettes with titles like "Family First" and "Together Forever," a reference to the Mormon belief that family relationships persist after death.
Missionaries receive no salary and are expected to pay all expenses other than the cost of their return flight home. They are allowed $200 a month spending money, $80 of which is used for transportation. "We eat a lot of ramen noodles, peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, and we walk a heck of a lot," said Mr. Denning, who has worn out four pairs of shoes since his arrival.
To save money, he and his roommates cut one another's hair and most days pack a lunch. At home, they eat out of plastic bowls. Like other missionaries in New York, they rarely dine out. A visit to a pizza parlor is a treat.
Missionaries operate in pairs, inseparable units known as "companionships." Even when Mr. Denning walks down the five flights of stairs to let a visitor into the East Harlem building where he lives, Mr. Pratt is invariably by his side. Mormon officials say that companionships are intended to insure safety, reduce the likelihood of slipping into temptation and act as a firewall against "false accusers," who might claim that a missionary has behaved inappropriately.
Companionships are shuffled over the course of the two-year mission; new arrivals are often paired with veterans, and those having difficulty are sometimes placed with those whose faith and devotion are deemed unshakable.
Missionary life is strictly defined by church rules and can be grueling. Like all Mormons in good standing, missionaries do not smoke or drink alcohol, coffee, tea or caffeinated beverages. Dating, masturbation and premarital sex are forbidden. Television, popular music, magazines and unapproved books are off limits.
Communication with family is restricted to a weekly letter and two phone calls a year, on Christmas and Mother's Day. Church officials say too much contact with family distracts missionaries from their work. "Ours is a very demanding religion," said Mr. Rasband, the mission president, who conducts regular interviews with missionaries to make sure they have not strayed. "I am constantly warning them against temptation, to look away when a half-naked woman passes them on the street, to avoid being pulled in by newspaper stands that display pornographic material. In a place like New York, the distractions are endless."
To hear them tell it, Shon Denning and Russell Pratt have so far resisted New York's bountiful lures. "For me it's easy," said Mr. Denning, one of eight children who grew up in a predominantly Mormon community in rural Idaho. "My love of the Lord is so strong, nothing can knock me off course."
Like many Rocky Mountain Mormons, Mr. Denning's ancestors migrated west on the Great Exodus of 1847, when thousands, fleeing persecution in Illinois, crossed the plains in wagon trains and settled in the Salt Lake Valley.
As a child, Mr. Denning said, he never planned to become a missionary, but one day during a religion class at Ricks College, a Mormon school near his home, he received a revelation, "a burning in my bosom." He dropped out of school, sold his car and went through a month of round-the-clock instruction at the church's Missionary Training Center in Provo, Utah. His high school sweetheart, also a Mormon, was thrilled. "She said she would wait for me to come back," he said. "But unfortunately she married someone else last year."
Missionaries have no choice of where they are sent; church leaders say they make assignments largely on the basis of inspiration. Mr. Denning's parents were worried at first about his placement in New York. "We heard all the bad stories, but took comfort in knowing that the Lord would look after him," said his father, Michael, who owns a company that installs water pumps. "Frankly, we were just tickled with his decision to serve, to bring something good into people's lives."
When he returns to Idaho Falls on Wednesday, Mr. Denning is likely to be praised. During his two years in New York, he baptized 15 people, among them a Bolivian couple in Harlem, a family of Jehovah's Witnesses in the Bronx and a 27-year-old Upper East Side man who works as a production assistant on feature films.
With his blond hair and cherubic face, Mr. Denning stands out on the streets of East Harlem. Like most missionaries, he says local residents always treat him with respect.
"There are places I've felt safe as a missionary that I probably wouldn't return to as a tourist," he said. A beatific smile almost always adorns his face and, when preaching, he frequently offers heartfelt testimony to his faith. "I know the Book of Mormon is true," he says, his piercing blue eyes locked on those of his prospect. "I know that this is the true church."
 
Dreams of Returning To 'Electric' New York
Many Mormons spend their adolescence saving for a mission. Russell Pratt spent his youth training to become a professional baseball player. As soon as the sun came up, his mother, Anne, would start feeding the batting machine in the family's backyard for her six sons.
"The first thing the neighbors hear in the morning is the ping ping of the bat hitting balls," she said. But during Russell's junior year at the University of Utah, his baseball plans were scotched by a coach who told him he would never make it to the major leagues.
"When I realized my dreams weren't going to come true, the foundation of my life had been taken out from under me," Mr. Pratt recalled. Confused and dispirited, he turned to the church. Other family members were devout, Mr. Pratt said, but until then he had never read the Book of Mormon. "The church helped me realize there is more to life than baseball."
Although Mr. Pratt says that preaching the gospel has given his life meaning, he admits to feeling an occasional tinge of doubt. "When that happens, I pray and my testimony is renewed," he said.
Mr. Pratt seems to be far more attracted to the city than Mr. Denning, who says he will probably remain in Idaho to raise a family. Mr. Pratt wants to come back to New York after he completes his mission in September and returns to Utah to finish college. "This place is so electric," he said last week as he walked through midtown, offering opinions on modern architecture ("Some of these buildings are so faceless"), Latin cuisine ("They fry everything!") and pet owners ("How can they keep dogs in such tiny apartments?").
"I just love the diversity of people here," Mr. Pratt said. "You'd never get bored."
Like their fellow missionaries, he and Mr. Denning have had few opportunities to savor local culture. Socializing with non-Mormons is discouraged, and their strict schedule and budget leave little time or money for leisure activities. Their only luxury is a meal at the home of local church members, who are encouraged to feed cash-strapped missionaries whenever possible.
"It gets to the point that you don't even think about the things you're missing," Mr. Pratt said. "But when I come back, I'm going to jump all over this city."
There was little time to think about the future last Monday as the pair preached and proselytized their way from the forlorn projects along First Avenue to the staid brick fortresses of Park Avenue. Because doormen and intercoms keep them out of many buildings, their most fruitful contacts are people who have called the church's toll-free number requesting a free video cassette offered through television commercials. The advertisements, which often run late at night, feature uplifting vignettes about family values.
When Charlotte V. Vogt called the number last January, she assumed that the video would arrive in the mail. Instead, Mr. Denning and Mr. Pratt left several messages on her answering machine, which she ignored. A few days later, they showed up at her white-brick doorman building on East 57th Street. She told them she was too busy to talk, but they came back.
"I'm glad they did," Mrs. Vogt said. "I believe they saved my life."
She said a recent separation from her husband had left her reeling. "I was so traumatized, so without hope," she said, sitting on a plush floral couch as a Bach concerto filled her living room. But the half-dozen visits and daily phone calls from the missionaries, she said, helped ease her depression. "I've called other churches, but they just sent their literature," she said.
When the missionaries stopped by on Monday afternoon, Mrs. Vogt beamed as she described her baptism the previous week. "I was soaking wet and giddy with joy," she said, as she served the men orange juice in highball glasses monogrammed with her husband's initials.
Now that she has been confirmed, Mrs. Vogt will receive weekly visits from church members, who will teach her Mormon doctrine and history. Every Sunday, she attends services at the church's Lincoln Center chapel. Eventually, she hopes to receive a calling to become a home teacher.
"I feel like it's the beginning of a new life," she said. "I've finally found a community that really cares about me."
 
'There Is No Gray Area'
No one forced Aubyn Gwinn to become a missionary, but as a young Mormon growing up in Salt Lake City, Mr. Gwinn said, the alternative was grim. Among devout Mormons, he said, the pressure to serve a mission is intense, and those who don't can find themselves on the fringes of Mormon life.
"It would jeopardize your career in the church, put a wedge between you and your friends and make it difficult to get married," he said. "When you meet Mormon girls, the first thing they ask is, 'Where did you serve your mission?' If you didn't, they won't even date you."
By his own account, Mr. Gwinn was "a rock," a stalwart believer and a zealous missionary. During the two years he spent in Finland, he supervised other missionaries and helped make 10 conversions, a considerable achievement in a country known among Mormons as especially impervious to their preachings.
After returning home, Mr. Gwinn enrolled in the church-run Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. He married, had two daughters and became a member of the church's unpaid priesthood. And he tithed, giving 10 percent of his income to the church.
But at 25, he started having doubts about the church. They intensified after he moved to New York City with his family to take a job at an advertising agency, and found himself among non-Mormons. His faith began to crumble, and he eventually fell away from the church. He and his wife eventually divorced; she, too, has since left the church.
In Mormonism, Mr. Gwinn said, "You either believe everything or nothing: there is no gray area."
His twin brother, Todd Gwinn, may have lacked Aubyn's youthful ardor, yet he felt compelled to follow his lead. He was assigned to Ontario, Canada, but halfway through his mission, he said, he lost the fire.
"I wanted to belong so badly that I convinced myself to believe," he said. "I knew that if I questioned the church, I would end up as an apostate." He said he became particularly disillusioned when he discovered that some missionaries were enticing potential converts by offering access to the church's generous welfare program. Several years later, he rejected Mormonism. He also divorced the Mormon woman he had married. She, too, has since left the church, he said.
Like other lapsed Mormons, the Gwinns say that church officials make it difficult to leave the fold. They say that bishops ask relatives to apply pressure to those who try to leave, and that missionaries try to track down so-called inactives. "They feel especially threatened by anyone who wants out," Todd said.
The brothers, now 38, say separation from the church has left them with a mix of bitterness and longing. Aubyn, a creative director for a cosmetics company, wonders how he might have better used the time he spent as a missionary. Still, he is bothered by the spiritual void that nags him from time to time. "It's that hunger for something bigger than yourself, that magical spiritual life, that belief in immortality," he said.
Todd, a librarian in the Bronx, says he, too, has some regrets, though he is relieved to be free of the church's constraints. "What I miss most is the loss of community," he said. "That's something I have yet to replace." ANDREW JACOBS
 
PRIMER
The Roots Of Mormonism
Mormonism was founded in 1830 by Joseph Smith of Palmyra, N.Y., who claimed that when he was 14, he was visited by God and Jesus Christ who told him to form a new church, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
At the heart of the religion is The Book of Mormon, a religious and secular history of the inhabitants of the Western Hemisphere from about 2200 B.C. to 421 A.D. Mormons believe that Mr. Smith translated the book from ancient from ancient gold tablets he is said to have found on a hillside in Palmyra. The book proclaims that after he was crucified, Christ appeared in North America and ministered to its inhabitants, believed to be descendents of immigrants from Jerusalem and the Tower of Babel.
Mormons hold that theirs is the only true Christian faith. Through proxy, they baptize the dead, whom they believe were denied an opportunity to join the church. The Book of Mormon states that God dwells on a planet, Kolob, with his many wives and countless spirit children, whom He sends to Earth as humans to be tested. Marriage and family relationships, they believe, persist for eternity. Polygamy, once an accepted tenet of Mormonism, was overturned in 1890. ANDREW JACOBS

G's -- Sacred undergarments worn by Mormons in belief that they protect them from harm.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Classes Are Full At Catch-Up U.

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
ALL the brouhaha last week over the dropping of remedial classes at the City University of New York, one of the nation's largest systems, would make many people think that remediation was a multicultural course invented by CUNY professors.
They would be wrong. 
 In 1995, 78 percent of America's colleges offered such classes, up from 73 percent in 1988. Although they were most prevalent at public community colleges (96 percent of them offered these courses in 1995), they were common at four-year colleges, too, with 72 percent offering the courses.
Clifford Adelman, a senior research analyst at the Department of Education, found that almost half of all college students took at least one class to prepare them for college-level work. At CUNY last year, 46 percent of students entering four-year colleges failed one or more of the placement examinations in reading, writing and math. At the California State University System, about half the freshmen need such classes to acclimate them to the rigors of academia.
In the Ivy League, the official line is that there are no remedial courses or underprepared students, but these institutions typically provide help in different guises. Harvard and Yale, for instance, offer peer tutors and a writing center. At the University of Chicago, a handful of students are directed each year to a course called essential mathematics that begins with arithmetic, algebra and geometry -- comparable to the remedial math courses at CUNY.
So why are so many high-school graduates unprepared for college?
One explanation, educators say, is that there is a gap between what many secondary schools expect their students to know and what college professors require, and that there has not been enough coordination between them. Another is that many high schools offer preparatory courses but students fail to take them, either because they are not planning to go to college or because they think they can get by without them. In some cases, they get weak instruction; sometimes they do poorly.
"Students have been allowed to coast," said Joseph D. Creech, director for educational policies at the Southern Regional Education Board in Atlanta. "If students are going to have to be able to do certain things when they get to college, then we have to make these expectations clear in high school, and even in middle school."
 
Diploma as Passport
At one time many of these ill-prepared students simply did not go to college. But in a technology-driven, information-based economy, where a college diploma is a passport to a higher standard of living, more students are continuing their education.
But a growing number of university administrators and college officials do not see this trend as good news. To them, each remedial student represents a failure, and wasted resources -- a job that has to be done at least twice thus diverting colleges from their real mission of providing higher education.
Remediation is such a dirty word that some colleges will not even admit to offering it, although their catalogues list courses in algebra, grammar and other subjects many students routinely take in high school.
"There is a sense that it is despoiling the environment," said H. Patrick Swygert, president of Howard University in Washington. "Remediation -- the word -- is verboten on this campus because it carries with it all the stigma that its opponents have trotted out that students who need it are less than fully qualified.
"Some people do not qualify intellectually or have the inclination to do the hard intellectual work required in college," Mr. Swygert added. "The great tragedy is that by removing remedial classes, that is not who is being screened out. The numbers suggest that once students navigate the remedial classes, many go on to successful college careers."
Few colleges have approached moving remediation off campus with the fervor of the trustees at the CUNY, who despite widespread protests from faculty and students, voted last week to phase out remedial classes at their four-year colleges by 2001. Students failing placement exams will be directed to intensive summer or weekend classes, or to the two-year community colleges.
No one knows how many of these students would be able to complete these courses quickly, how many will opt for community colleges or how many will choose other four-year colleges or simply drop out in frustration.
But CUNY is not alone in trying to reduce its remediation.
Some universities, like the University of Maryland, are trying to foster closer coordination between secondary schools and colleges about what ground will be covered in certain courses.
The California State University, the largest public university in the country with 360,000 students, has set a goal of reducing the percentage of freshmen needing remediation to 10 percent by 2007 from more than 50 percent now. The trustees, who had hoped to move faster, scaled back in the face of criticisms that they would penalize immigrants and minority students who had attended poor high schools and fared poorly in placement exams.
Charles Reed, who became chancellor of California State University system in March, said he would like to follow a program similar to the one he introduced at the University of Florida in 1985, where it offers no remedial courses; students needing them must go to community colleges or other institutions. The students, however, can still register for university classes at the same time.
"There are always going to be some students who need remediation," Dr. Reed said. "But universities are not as well prepared to do remediation as the community colleges."
Another critical part of the plan, he said, is to give the college placement tests to high school students -- preferably by the 10th grade -- "as a wake-up call." That way students can see where they are weak and still have time to improve.
 
Playing Hooky
 Does it work in Florida? Partly.
Officials at the University of Florida say that only 10 percent of the students need remedial work -- well below the figure at CUNY and Cal State. The figure is lower in part because the university takes in many of its students after they have already completed some credits elsewhere.
But even under the Florida system, students do not always whiz through their remedial courses. Chuck Lindsey, director of general education at Florida Gulf Coast University, said that some students simply skip the hours they should spend learning basics and computer skills. "They just keep taking the class until they pass it," he said.
So Florida has taken one more step. The state recently passed a law requiring that students taking remedial courses repeatedly will be charged the full price of the course, not the subsidized price available to local students.
In the meantime, Dr. Reed said, the number of students needing remediation at Florida's community colleges continues to grow.
