PUB-DATE: May 31, 1998,

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2894 words

HEADLINE: HOMELESS HARVEST: A special report.;
As Economy Booms, Migrant Workers' Housing Worsens

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SALINAS, Calif.

 BODY:
Inside room 39 at the Westwind Motel was an astonishing scene: 10 people bedded down for the night.
On the right, five migrant farm workers slept on two mattresses. Straight ahead, two were on blankets on the floor. On the left, below a television, were three more. 
 There were eight migrant workers in Room 27A and seven in Room 7, six crammed in two double beds, one on the floor. Though most motorists would hardly glance at the drab motel, it had as many residents as a small town.
"When it comes to the rent, it's much more economical this way," said Reyna Fernandez, a 22-year-old strawberry picker from Mexico who had opened the door to a visitor to Room 39, which rented for $200 a week. "We really earn very little."
Three decades after Cesar Chavez made the shocking conditions of migrant workers a national cause, more farm workers than ever are living in squalor.
One reason is that Government efforts to build housing have not kept pace with the growing number of migrant workers. The Federal Commission on Agricultural Workers estimates there are 2.5 million farm workers, up from 1.8 million in 1960. About 800,000 of the current workers lack adequate shelter, according to the Housing Assistance Council, a Washington-based consulting group that studies rural housing.
In recent years, the agricultural work force has changed in ways that make it much harder for the Government to improve the workers' living conditions, whether by providing housing itself or pressuring growers to improve the housing they provide.
The most important is that the migrant work force, once composed mainly of United States citizens, is now largely made up of immigrants from Mexico and Central America, 40 percent of them here illegally. And a growing number of them leave their families behind, coming with the goal of sending home as much of their earnings as possible.
Eager to earn as much as 10 times what they can at home, these workers are willing to put up with living conditions and wages that few Americans would accept. The economic imperative driving them -- that they can lift their families out of poverty -- is so powerful that it has assured a plentiful supply of migrants even as real farm wages have fallen by more than 10 percent in the last 20 years.
"The root of the problem is there is an oversupply of farm workers," said Bruce Goldstein, executive director of the Farmworker Justice Fund, a Washington-based advocacy group.
Over the past decade, the Federal and state governments, working with growers, have built tens of thousands of housing units for migrants. But those units usually go to families, citizens and legal immigrants, rarely benefiting several large groups facing the worst circumstances: single men and women, illegal immigrants and workers who move from harvest to harvest.
And stricter Federal laws requiring growers to improve their migrant housing have largely backfired: rather than contend with the cost and hassle of complying, thousands of growers have stopped providing housing, since they are not required to do so.
Some of the worst conditions result when entrepreneurs fill the void by renting rundown housing at inflated prices. In response, migrants cram in as many people as they can to reduce how much each pays.
"We have to put up with this because we can't afford anything else," said Maria-Guadalupe Sanchez, a farm worker who lives with 13 other people in a three-bedroom house in Watsonville, Calif.
Watsonville and Salinas are on California's Central Coast, a bountiful agricultural region, but migrants earning $200 a week share little of the prosperity.
The Central Coast is not alone, however. The housing shortage is so severe that in harvest-time visits to farming communities up and down both coasts over the last year, workers were found packed 10 or 12 into trailers and sleeping in garages, tool sheds, caves, fields and parking lots.
"These people work very hard," said Moises Loza, executive director of the Housing Assistance Council. "The tragedy is that they're out there pursuing the American dream, and we don't treat these people, who do very valuable work, as if they merit the conveniences and decent shelter that most of us take for granted."
 
The Conditions
Different States, Same Misery
As the harvest moved from state to state, there was one common thread: miserable living conditions.
In Orange County, N.Y., an hour from Manhattan, raw sewage formed puddles outside migrant workers' trailers. In Mecca, Calif., more than 100 migrants slept in parking lots and along the road.
Along the Columbia River in Mattawa, Wash., dozens of Mexicans up for the cherry harvest slept in crude tents and lean-tos. In Belle Glade, Fla., hundreds of decrepit shacks have been demolished, only to be replaced by ramshackle rooming houses.
Immokalee, in the Everglades, boasts it is the East Coast's winter vegetable capital, but it might also be the trailer capital. It is crowded with mobile homes, many of them decades old, that absorb the population each winter when the tomato and pepper harvest swells the town to more than 20,000 people, from 8,000 in summer.
Outside, many trailers are painted a crisp white that masks the conditions inside. Because the trailers have few electrical outlets, wires crisscross bedroom ceilings so the workers can plug in fans and radios. To protect their food supplies from rats, migrants hang bags of flour and cornmeal, pinata-like, from strings nailed to the ceiling.
Ramiro Jeronimo, a 17-year-old tomato picker from Guatemala, could not hide his embarrassment. As he showed a visitor the trailer he shared with seven others, a rat jumped from behind a bag of flour on the refrigerator and scooted into a cupboard.
The bare wood around the kitchen sink was rotting. The living room had two beds, while the 10-by-10 end bedroom had three lined up inches apart. Clothes were slung over twine strung between the walls.
The trailer rented for $950 a month: as much as seaside apartments in nearby Naples and twice what year-round families in Immokalee pay for three-bedroom houses.
"It's difficult here, but it's hard to find anything better," Mr. Jeronimo said. "When you return from work, everyone wants to use the bathroom at the same time. And it's hard to sleep because some people want to hear music."
The trailers are rented out by entrepreneurs who take advantage of the seasonal crush of migrants. "They can afford to keep these trailers in terrible condition and charge abominable rents because these people have no choice," said Steven Hitov, a lawyer with Florida Rural Legal Services.
State officials say they do not have enough inspectors to find every trailer or house with illegally crowded or unsanitary conditions. And landlords often maintain that the migrants create the squalor and overcrowding behind their backs.
In the winter, Bernabe and Domingo Jacinto, brothers from Guatemala, and 10 cousins, nephews and uncles moved out of a cockroach-infested $800-a-month trailer to a $1,100-a-month, two-bedroom house. Now five slept in one bedroom, three in the other, three in the living room and one in the dining room. The shower reeked of mildew; the bathroom floor was so badly rotted that weeds were visible underneath.
The $100 a month each brother paid might seem cheap, even for such conditions, but they called it exorbitant because it equaled a peasant's monthly income in Guatemala.
"It's very expensive, but what can you do," Bernabe Jacinto said. "There are nicer houses, but they're far from the center of town. We don't have cars. All we have are our two feet."
Every morning at 5:30, Mr. Jacinto and hundreds of other migrants walked to a parking lot where trucks took them to the fields. He usually earned $5.15 an hour, or about $200 a week, and sent his wife and six children $250 a month. "It's difficult thinking it might be a year or more before I see my family," he said. "But it's good that we can earn some money here."
 
The Government Role
As Rules Multiply, Housing Dwindles
As early as Theodore Roosevelt's Presidency, government reports focused on the plight of farm workers. Ever since, insuring decent living conditions for migrants has been one of the most intractable problems facing government officials.
Masses of migrants enter the country and circulate undetected. Many are illegal immigrants who get hired through forged documents or growers turning a blind eye to their illegal status. Housing inspectors are stretched thin, and politicians and the public are hardly clamoring to spend money on housing for this largely invisible population.
Still, state officials and farmers boast that, often with Federal subsidies, they have built thousands of houses that have allowed farm workers to vacate the most rundown shacks.
Government inspectors have tried to shut down the worst housing. In Immokalee, the state has condemned all housing without electricity and closed encampments of makeshift tents.
"We used to have people who slept on canal banks, but in Florida now, all migrant farm workers are housed in some kind of structure," said Ken Widergren, one of Florida's chief inspectors of migrant housing. "There's a lot of wonderful housing that's been built and new housing is going up all the time.
"In some places, I'd still describe the conditions as deplorable."
Farm-worker advocates say far too little housing is being built. This year the Clinton Administration will spend $27.5 million on the main Federal Government program for farm-worker housing, which makes low-interest loans to developers. It is requesting $45 million for next year -- still far less than the $69 million spent in 1979.
Since 1983, 7,584 houses and apartment units have been built under the program, an average of 506 a year, and several hundred more are built yearly under other, smaller Federal programs.
Pressured by farm-worker advocates and embarrassed by exposes, in 1986 Congress enacted stricter rules for housing provided by growers. But instead of complying, many farmers stopped providing housing. In California, the number of labor camps provided by growers has plummeted to 1,000, from 5,000 in 1968.
"It got to the point where there are a lot of rules and regulations on housing and that created a tremendous cost," said Andrew Esposito, labor compliance coordinator at the United States Sugar Corporation, which closed a 150-unit camp in Florida in 1994. "It just wasn't economically feasible."
"Our job is to grow sugar and citrus," Mr. Esposito said. "We're letting the private sector take care of housing. Admittedly some of the housing isn't as good as it should be, but it's not for us to tell a local mobile home park how to take care of housing."
A recent legislative showdown in Washington State underlined how hard it is to ease the shortage. In 1997, the Legislature approved a bill allowing farmers to provide barracks without heating or hot water, but requiring central kitchens and bathrooms.
"Some of these orchards may only have a six-day harvest," said Mike Gempler, executive director of the Washington Growers League. "It's not economically sensible to build a full-scale apartment house that's sustainable for full-year living, just for a six-day harvest."
With the United Farm Workers union denouncing the bill, Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat, vetoed it. But this year growers pushed the bill through again, and Governor Locke signed it after the Legislature added money for housing and tightened rules on plumbing and electricity.
The growers say the barracks are better than sleeping in the fields. But the president of the farm workers in Washington, Guadalupe Gamboa, said: "They're going back to 1940's and 50's shantytowns. We're talking about barracks with 60 people in a room and no heat, even though it freezes here in April."
 
The Invisible
Out of Sight, Out of Mind
On either side of the stream in Southern California stood primitive huts that seemed straight out of prehistoric times, except for their black plastic sheeting. Nearly camouflaged under the trees and vines, the huts were built from branches and two-by-fours covered with cardboard and the plastic sheeting that is used to cover fields to protect young plants from freezing. Essentially crude wooden frames wrapped with black plastic, they appeared equal parts Cro-Magnon and Cristo.
"I live here because it's close to work, and I don't have enough money for food, not to mention rent," said Juan Alarcon, an 18-year-old Mexican who shared a hut with his brother. They earned about $50 for a nine-hour day picking cucumbers and peppers.
The 50 or so hut dwellers lived around a hill from the vegetable fields they tended, 20 miles inland from Oceanside, Calif.
"Two sheets of plastic are good for keeping out the rain," Mr. Alarcon said. "But it's dangerous here. There are coyotes, mountain lions, and I killed a big rattlesnake."
The hut dwellers used the stream to wash themselves and their clothes. To get to work, many had to walk over a log crossing the stream. They live here several months each year, migrating north in the fall to other harvests and heading to Mexico each Christmas to visit their families.
"I don't like it here, but I have to live here," said Claudio Villa Cuevas, a 64-year-old Mexican "There is no other work."
The farm where they worked is far from any town where they could rent housing. But there were advantages to the location: it was hard for immigration agents to find them, hard for housing inspectors to find their huts, hard for neighbors to complain about illegal immigrants and eyesores nearby.
"In Southern California, where a lot of houses go for $250,000 to $500,000, people don't want to see farm workers, they don't want to see these little brown men in their vicinity," said Claudia Smith, a lawyer with California Rural Legal Assistance. "They want them around at 6 A.M. to bid down each other's wages, and then they want them to disappear at 6 P.M."
 
The Exception
Adequate Housing Rewards a Grower
To many farm workers, there is a simple solution to the problem: pay them more.
Growers respond that competition from foreign produce makes it hard to raise wages. Farm-worker advocates retort that growers can easily increase pay, because wages are a small fraction of retail prices.
Growers cite another sticking point: if they raised wages, many migrants would send the extra pay home and continue sleeping in garages or overcrowded trailers.
Advocates contend that if Government and growers build more housing, the increased supply would provide shelter for migrants who sleep in fields while lowering rents for those who pay exorbitant sums.
Some growers do provide decent housing, like the rows of tidy houses maintained by A. Duda, a Florida citrus giant. The company, unusual in its generosity, spends $1 million a year to house almost 1,000 workers, who often sleep two to a bedroom in four-bedroom, cinder-block apartments. Duda executives say the housing attracts good, dedicated workers back each year.
But many growers say building such apartments for $25,000 each would erase their profits. These growers say the free market should supply housing. But profitability is an obstacle there because migrants rent only a few months of the year and can afford only low rents.
An increasing, but still small, number of growers say they want to contribute to a fund to build farm-worker housing. And advocates say the Government needs to put up far more money. But there is little public clamor to build such housing.
Nonetheless, there are some highly promising programs, like one in Coachella, Calif., 20 miles east of Palm Springs.
In a development called Vista del Sol, 75 families who hope to settle down permanently spent nine months building 75 homes, with the cooperative spirit of a barn-raising. Usually eight families cooperated to build eight homes at once, pitching in on framing each other's walls and shingling each other's roofs, doing their construction each day after working in the fields.
The result: handsome houses appraised at $90,000, with $20,000 of that value coming from sweat equity.
"It's a lot of work, but it's worth it," said Juan Alvarez, a 39-year-old vegetable worker. "It's roomy, and a lot more comfortable than the trailer we lived in."
His mortgage payment is just $240 a month, about what he and his family paid to rent a cramped, rundown trailer.
Vista del Sol was made possible by a $70,000 low-interest Federal loan to each family and the patient planning of the Coachella Valley Housing Coalition, a nonprofit group that has orchestrated the building of 500 self-help houses since 1989.
There is one snag: in the Coachella Valley alone, there is a waiting list of 2,000 families eager to build homes. That, housing experts estimate, is four times the number of self-help, farmworker homes built nationwide last year.
Nonprofit groups say they can oversee construction of 10,000 self-help homes per year -- if there was Federal money.
But Jill Long Thompson, Under Secretary of Agriculture for rural development, acknowledged that the will was not there for a concerted effort.
"It's very difficult because of the limited resources," she said. "We are barely making a dent in meeting the need."

Pakistan, Spurning Critics, Holds More Nuclear Tests
Pakistan said it exploded another nuclear test device, spurning worldwide criticism and calls for restraint after its tests two days ago. But the Government also said that Pakistan was ready to "talk peace" with India and that "it is not our purpose to enter into an arms race." 1

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE WASHINGTON VIEW;
Pakistan Test Leaves U.S. Out of Ideas and Angered

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
The United States reacted with anger and a sense of frustration to Pakistan's nuclear test today, as Administration officials said they had few ideas about how to stop the arms race in South Asia.
President Clinton was awakened at about 4:45 this morning and informed of the new test by his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, who in turn had been rousted by a call from the White House Situation Room. 
 Mr. Clinton condemned the new tests in a statement, saying, "Pakistan and India are contributing to a self-defeating cycle of escalation." He called on both to "renounce further nuclear and missile testing immediately and take decisive steps to reverse this dangerous arms race."
But United States officials, citing reports from the Central Intelligence Agency, said Pakistan today continued to prepare to test-fire its Ghauri missile, which is designed to be fitted with a nuclear warhead and has a range of up to 900 miles. They also said Pakistan appeared to be preparing to test a second, shorter-range missile, called the Tarmuk, which has a range of about 250 miles.
The C.I.A. said that Pakistan tested one bomb this morning, with an explosive force of between one and five kilotons, according to preliminary estimates. That is a relatively tiny bomb by cold-war standards, though it could kill hundreds of thousands of people if detonated in the heart of a big city.
Intelligence analysts believe a goal of the test was to devise a bomb small enough to fit on a missile. Pakistan is believed to be close to that difficult goal.
"My guess is that Pakistan is a screw-turn away from weaponizing their bomb, putting it on a missile or dropping it from an F-16," said Milton Bearden, a former senior C.I.A. official who was based in Pakistan in the 1980's.
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said, "This second test of nuclear devices can only further raise tensions in south Asia and undermine the global consensus on nonproliferation."
"We are very disappointed that Pakistan continues to ignore the calls to exercise restraint that were made by the international community after its first tests," Mr. Rubin said. "We again urge both Pakistan and India to cease and desist" from weapons tests and words of war.
Diplomats, policymakers and intelligence officials said today that they saw no end in sight for the arms race between India and Pakistan.
"Is this now the excuse for another whole new round of tests?" said Nicholas Platt, a former United States Ambassador to Pakistan and president of the Asia Society. "What do we do now? You have to do a lot of talking, pay a lot of attention. But there is no magic formula" to stop an arms race, he said.
"Once the Indians tested, the Pakistanis didn't have any choice," he said. "Now, of course, we're confronted with one more test and the question is whether they now feel they have reached a parity with the Indians or whether they are just escalating."
Administration officials said there was little the United States could do on its own to stop an arms race. "After a while there's nothing left on the shelf," said one Administration official. "The President has said, 'There's not a lot I can do.' "
Another, more senior Administration official said: "We're still worried about a missile test" by Pakistan and a likely Indian response. The best that could be hoped for in the short-run, he said, was that India and Pakistan would be as careful with their nuclear weapons and policies as Washington and Moscow were during the cold war -- which was, he acknowledged, little comfort.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Meeting Called on Tests
 LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) -- The foreign ministers of the world's major industrial powers will meet in London on June 12 to try to adopt a joint response to nuclear tests in India and Pakistan.
Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain said today that he would be host to a meeting of the Group of Eight -- Britain, Canada, Germany, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and Russia.
Elsewhere, Japan condemned the new Pakistan test a day after freezing economic aid in response to the first tests.
Russia also condemned the test and called for a special session of the United Nations Security Council, which scheduled consultations this afternoon.
China, an ally that helped Pakistan with its nuclear program, expressed "deep regret" over the test today.

HEADLINE: Poor Conditions Follow Laborers as They Travel North

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: FLORIDA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Every July and August, an estimated 45,000 migrant workers arrive in New York State to harvest onions, apples, pumpkins and vegetables.
Eager to work as many months as possible, the migrants, most of them from Mexico, have followed the harvest north from Florida, most often through Georgia, Virginia and Maryland. 
 The lucky ones are offered well-kept trailers and houses that could serve as a model for migrants everywhere. The less fortunate end up in foul-smelling shacks with dingy walls, plywood floors and screens with large holes that invite in mosquitoes.
In last year's harvest in this onion-growing town 50 miles northwest of Manhattan, sewage formed a puddle outside one migrants' trailer and snaked around to the front. While the small bedrooms had new bunk beds, the bathroom sink handles did not work, the toilet tank had no cover and the doorknob was missing, replaced by a stub of cardboard that had to be pulled to open the door.
At another farm in Orange County, four barracks-like structures housed dozens of migrants. In one barracks, the workers were naturalized Americans, and the conditions were acceptable. In another, workers who said they were in the United States illegally predominated and the conditions were far worse.
There, four men slept in a bedroom. The refrigerator was ancient, the freezer compartment did not freeze and the kitchen shelves were listing. One of the two toilets in the group bathroom had been broken for months.
"The housing is better in Mexico," one man said. "But in Mexico there's no work, and at least you make a little money here."
New York farmers say there is plenty of good housing for the migrant workers who bring in their harvest each year. One farmer built a spacious house, with new carpets and a roomy kitchen, for a migrant family of three. In apple country south of Lake Ontario, there are some immaculate remodeled labor camps.
But substandard conditions are easy to find. "We have an archaic system for harvesting crops, and it all falls on the backs of migrant workers," said Herbert Engman, director of the Cornell University Migrant Program. "There's no other group of workers forced to sleep in cars or tents. It's a very strange phenomenon that we haven't brought agriculture into the 20th century in this regard."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Doubleday Takes Wheel And Revs Up the Mets

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Nelson Doubleday is still in a home-run trot, a baseball lawyer said a week after the Mets acquired Mike Piazza. "He hit one McGwire distance," the lawyer said of Doubleday, "and he's not going away."
The addition of Piazza, who was not traded last Friday for the first time in three Fridays, has supplied jet propulsion to the Mets' sluggish engine. The Mets have benefited immediately from their latest -- and most electrifying -- trade with the Florida Marlins, on the field, at the gate and in the newspapers and on the airwaves. 
 Doubleday, the team's co-owner, hasn't contributed even a base hit to the suddenly explosive offense, but he is credited with an assist in urging Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, to pursue Piazza. Doubleday, acting out of dissatisfaction with the fans' and the news media's view of the team, likes the immediate results of his effort and plans to play a more active role with Fred Wilpon, the other co-owner.
"Absolutely I'm getting more involved," Doubleday said, confirming the lawyer's report of the owner's plans. "I'm around. I am back. I'm going to be much more involved. I had a lot of family stuff I was doing. It took up a lot of my time and I'm now able to concentrate on baseball."
Wilpon, as president and chief executive officer, has basically been the owner in charge while Doubleday has been more of an absentee owner. Wilpon, 61 years old, said Doubleday, 64, is welcome to play any role he desires.
"He's my partner," Wilpon said. "He's been involved. He chooses to do what he wants to do. Both of us don't make the baseball decisions. He chooses to do as much or as little as he wants. He always has."
Although the two men have not always agreed on baseball matters, they both looked at the results of the first six weeks of the season and didn't like what they saw.
"It became evident," Wilpon said, "that the perception of the team wasn't one that was exciting the fans. It showed at the box office. It just wasn't exciting them. Whether it was right or wrong was academic. It was a fact."
Doubleday said he grew tired of seeing small Shea Stadium crowds. "We weren't going anywhere, weren't doing anything," he said. "I said my experience is in marketing; let's see what I can do. I felt very strongly that we can do it better than we've done it. I'm not insulting Fred or anything."
Doubleday credited Phillips with putting together a "great" pitching staff, but it was the dull, often unproductive offense that was keeping the fans away in droves, and that's where Piazza came in.
"I thought Mr. Piazza was a viable man for the New York Mets and a viable man for New York City and one hell of a star and we ought to take a shot at him," Doubleday said. Five days after the Marlins acquired the catcher from Los Angeles in an economically mammoth deal, Doubleday passed Phillips in a corridor at the Mets' offices. "I said: 'Where does this Piazza thing stand? You ought to look into it,' " Doubleday related. "I got the feeling from reading the papers that Miami was getting ready to move him very fast."
Piazza, a .334 career hitter who has averaged 33 home runs and 105 runs batted in for his five full major league seasons, presented a pretty offensive picture for the Mets, but he posed potential problems. For one thing, he can be a free agent at the end of the season and already had rejected a six-year, $84 million offer from the Dodgers. For another, he has been portrayed as a selfish player who cared more about his own statistics than team results. Brett Butler, in the first spring of his retirement, called Piazza "a moody, self-centered 90's player" and questioned the wisdom of spending $100 million for such a player. Other members of the Dodgers corroborated that view, their agents said.
Wilpon said the Mets did their "due diligence," satisfying themselves that Piazza would be a legitimately positive addition.
Piazza rejected any criticism of him as unfounded.
"I felt like I always played hard and to win," he said. "Unfortunately, people in life, no matter what you do, aren't going to like you. Maybe I was able to learn from it. I just feel you have to be yourself. At this level, people can smell it when you're being fake."
Addressing the leadership issue, Piazza said, "I think the guy that's covering your back is just as much being a leader as the guy charging the pack."
The money issue is another matter. Dan Lozano, the catcher's agent, said he never mentioned a specific dollar figure to the Dodgers but said he wanted a seven-year contract. Another agent said that before the Dodgers' sale to Fox became official, Lozano was telling people that a deal was essentially set at $120 million. However, no Dodgers official ever confirmed that deal. Instead the new owners offered $84 million, and Piazza rejected it.
"When you offer someone the best contract in the history of baseball, it should tempt him more than it did this guy," a veteran agent said.
Rather than have him become a free agent and gain nothing for him, the Dodgers decided to trade Piazza, and he wound up in New York by way of Florida. Now he's the Mets' money problem.
Is he likely to accept less from the Mets than he wanted from the Dodgers? Are the Mets likely to give him baseball's first nine-figure contract?
Wilpon said the Mets will definitely try to sign Piazza. Doubleday said it's a problem the club will address at the end of the season. Baseball people believe that Piazza will seek $100 million or more from the Mets, especially with an attendance growth that he generates. Asked about nine figures, Doubleday said: "I don't know. We'd have to take a look at it, see what he wants, see what we can do, see what he can offer us, see what the chemistry is for the team. I think it's possible. New York City can afford it. Freddie and I are not averse to it happening. We have to look at the chemistry of the team."
It is the chemistry, Doubleday said, that should prompt the Mets to move slowly in the pursuit of any other major trades. "I feel quite strongly that if it's not broken, don't fix it," Doubleday said.
It's too early to start tracking the wild-card chase, but it should be noted that less than a week after the Mets made the Piazza trade, they became the second-place team with the best record. Four months from now, that status would put the Mets into the playoffs.

HEADLINE: Commencements;
Cadets Are Warned of New Threats

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 30

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen today urged the 865 graduates of the United States Military Academy to rise to the challenges of a post-cold war world dogged by new tools of war and the longstanding threat of weapons of mass destruction.
"You are leaving a world defined by tradition, stability and order," Mr. Cohen said, to enter a world "of rising ethnic conflicts, of regional aggressors, of asymmetrical threats, of cyberterrorists who would send poison arrows at our databases, our financial markets or our banking or space-based communications systems." 
 Taking stock of the four years since the cadets entered the academy, Mr. Cohen said great strides had been made in drawing central and eastern European countries into NATO and in stabilizing Bosnia after its civil war. But he reminded the cadets assembled in crisp gray rows in Michie Stadium that military pitfalls still existed, particularly in the Middle East and Asia.
Mr. Cohen took note of the recent testing of nuclear weapons in Pakistan and India, saying the development was a powerful reminder that even in an age when most of the world's nations are at peace, the United States must remain vigilant in its efforts to control the spread of nuclear arms.
"When America ignores the problems of the world," he said, "the world brings its problems to the doorstep of America."
He also warned of the continuing threat from Iraq, reserving his harshest words for President Saddam Hussein, whose prolonged intransigence over permitting United Nations weapons inspections led to a showdown with the United States in February.
Mr. Cohen noted that United Nations inspectors will brief the Security Council on their latest findings this Wednesday, but added that it was not the responsibility of the United Nations to uncover chemical weapons hidden in Iraq; rather, it was Iraq's responsibility to provide evidence that it had disposed of the weapons.
Mr. Cohen urged the cadets to embrace their role as the military representatives of the world's sole superpower. He challenged them to live up to the class motto they had selected: "Duty will not wait."
 
Albany Law School
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 30 (AP) -- As he dedicated a professorship named after Gov. George E. Pataki, Henry A. Kissinger told law school graduates today that the United States must recognize its diminished economic presence and increasing responsibility in the world.
Mr. Kissinger, a Nobel Peace Prize winner and former Secretary of State, told graduates of Albany Law School that the United States must realize it will be drawn into many worldwide conflicts and concerns, including the nuclear race on the Indian subcontinent.
"Your generation has an opportunity and responsibility to operate on a global scale in a way America has never had to in the past," he told the 147th graduating class of the fourth oldest law school in the country.
Mr. Kissinger said one way to help lead the country through this troubling course is through the endowed chair named after Mr. Pataki, which he dedicated at the commencement.
The chair in international commercial law is financed with $500,000 from Morris Silverman, a retired New York City businessman from the Albany Law School class of 1936.
Mr. Pataki, addressing the 250 graduates, said, "I am especially thrilled that it will be used to enlighten young minds on the subject of international commercial law, a field that is rapidly emerging."

HEADLINE: Offering Commuters Fare Cuts and Free Parking

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

 BODY:
Riders on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad out of Bridgeport, Conn., will enjoy lower fares and free parking at the station if a Connecticut proposal to help rejuvenate downtown Bridgeport and reduce traffic on Interstate 95 is approved.
The fare reductions are expected to take effect near the end of August, reducing the cost of a monthly ticket from Bridgeport to Grand Central Terminal to $272 from $283, said Harry Harris, who is in charge of public transportation at the Connecticut Transportation Department. The reductions for daily and weekly tickets will vary depending on whether they are for peak or off-peak travel time, he said. 
 The Bridgeport City Council is to vote tomorrow on the second part of the state proposal -- an offer of $1 million from the State Department of Transportation to build a lot that would provide free parking for 750 cars. "I expect it will pass," said John M. Fabrizi, the president of Bridgeport's City Council. "It's a home run for Bridgeport. It will alleviate congestion on I-95 and boost our own economy. We want to attract more people to the city."
Mr. Harris said commuters must be persuaded to take the train from Bridgeport instead of Fairfield, a town four miles away where a monthly ticket costs $254. In 1996, the most recent year for which statistics are available, an average of 2,231 people took the train at Fairfield every day, compared with 537 in Bridgeport, Mr. Harris said.
The real savings to commuters in choosing Bridgeport would come from the free parking, Mr. Harris said. Parking now costs $60 a month in Bridgeport and $28 a month in Fairfield.
"There are 1,700 people on the waiting list to park in Fairfield," Mr. Harris said. "People drive down from the Trumbull-Ansonia area, and they go to Fairfield because there has been a perception of safety problems in Bridgeport. Now there will be an economic incentive to go to Bridgeport."
Mayor Joseph P. Ganim announced on Friday that the city would receive $34 million in Federal funds to build a terminal that would connect the region's railroad, ferry and bus lines. "What the city needed was a safe, clean, accommodating parking facility to draw people off the highway," he said. "It will be easy in, easy out."
If lower fares and free parking are not enough, maybe extra trains and the promise of empty seats will help, Mr. Harris said. Express trains originating at Bridgeport may be added in September, he said.
The commuter proposals are part of a larger effort to revive Bridgeport with attractions including a new minor league baseball park, which opened last week, and a planned waterfront redevelopment project.

HEADLINE: Classical Arts Lose Their Stages to Broadway

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
Orchestras, ballet companies and opera companies -- organizations that inspired construction of performing arts centers across America over the last 30 years -- are being displaced from their homes, sometimes for months at a time, by presentations with a different esthetic and a broader popularity: touring Broadway shows.
From Honolulu to Hartford, from Tampa to Tulsa, classical arts ensembles must now search for alternative spaces to perform as shows like "Phantom of the Opera," "Les Miserables," "Beauty and the Beast" and "Miss Saigon" sell out the classical groups' usual sites and earn record profits. The classical troupes say they often lose hundreds of thousands of dollars in the process. 
 The temporary exiles are all the more painful because many classical groups already suffer from dropping subscription levels and aging audiences. Moreover, in many cities, performance centers, though owned and run by the municipalities, were built primarily for these groups with donations from their major patrons.
In Louisville, for example, "Beauty and the Beast" will take over the main theater of the Kentucky Center for the Arts for two months next year, forcing one of the center's original "resident" groups, the Louisville Orchestra, to play at a renovated movie theater run by the local Broadway presenter.
In Honolulu, "Miss Saigon" will displace the Honolulu Symphony from the city-run Blaisdell Concert Hall for three months of its centennial season in the fall of 1999.
The Florida Orchestra could obtain only 5 of its desired 21 dates in the Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center this season because of bookings by touring shows. The orchestra has experienced similar problems in other Florida cities; its executive director estimated that the problem had cost the orchestra between $300,000 and $500,000 this season.
Similar issues have arisen in nearly every city where there is one major arts complex and a sudden crush of interest in renting it, including Hartford, Des Moines, Columbus, Ohio, and Charlotte, N.C.
Behind the squeeze is the growing success of Broadway road shows. Once a second-string adjunct to the Great White Way, the touring show has surpassed New York productions in economic impact in the last five years. Industry statistics analyzed by the League of American Theaters and Producers show that touring companies now bring in twice the annual revenue of Broadway shows.
Some touring shows play for a week in each location, but the major shows sell out 2,500-seat halls for months at a time, earning, in some cases, more than $700,000 a week. Forty-six touring shows sold almost 18 million tickets last season, grossing nearly $800 million -- up from about $200 million a little over a decade ago.
The success has changed the balance of economic power in performing arts centers. The economic structures of the centers vary widely, but those built since the 1960's and modeled after Lincoln Center are generally either run by the local municipality or by a nonprofit agency established by the local government.
The Kentucky Center for the Arts, for example, which opened in 1983, was built with matching public and private money, mainly to provide a home for the local orchestra, ballet, theater and opera company. It has a budget of $7.2 million, out of which just 42 percent comes from earned income. That income is primarily made up of rentals and fees from its four theaters. They are available to "resident" artistic groups like the orchestra and the ballet. But they are also rented to outside concert presenters, conventions and for social functions.
But arts centers generally discount fees to local resident groups, which have never been profit makers. In recent years, those groups have been having an even harder time offering the center much income from percentages of ticket sales. Broadway shows, though, have become a gold mine.
"Broadway is the one slice that's making money," said Michael C. Hardy, the president of the Kentucky Center for the Arts. "It has become the tail that wags the dog."
The Broadway series at the Kentucky Center boasts about 10,000 subscribers compared with fewer than 2,000 for the Kentucky Opera and about 2,500 for the Louisville Symphony. While the opera and the symphony struggle to fill 70 percent of the hall, "The King and I" brought in $600,000 to $700,000 in six days.
Bradley Broecker, the president of the Broadway Series Management Group, the city's road show presenter, has even taken out a 10-year lease on the Palace, the vintage movie theater where he plans to regularly present Broadway shows and other entertainment, in some cases competing directly with the arts center.
In Louisville, the orchestra's executive director, Gregg Gustafson, like many other leaders of classical groups, challenged the changing emphasis of arts centers like the Kentucky Center for the Arts.
He points out that roughly a third of its $36 million cost was raised from corporate and private donors, many of whom were also patrons of the classical performing arts groups. "Their mission has drifted from what it once was," Mr. Gustafson said. "It was meant to provide a home for the orchestra. When we're kicked out of there for Broadway series, these questions come up."
When bumped from its traditional hall by a money-making Broadway hit, an art group must then find a less attractive site. It sometimes loses subscribers and may have to cancel concerts. Mr. Gustafson, for example, worries that the road show boom will undermine a long-planned effort to revive the orchestra. In the last decade, it has cut back its season and lost half of its subscription base.
But Douglas C. Evans, who runs Hartford's Bushnell theater, the largest nonprofit arts center in Connecticut, said that Broadway should not bear the total blame for the difficulties of classical arts groups. As many studies have shown, the classical traditions have become less compelling for younger audiences, who often have little exposure to them and no experience studying musical instruments.
According to a recent report commissioned by the Bushnell, the theater's 68-year-old World Symphony Series, which presents touring orchestras, once inspired such devotion that subscriptions were "passed from one generation to the next." In the last five years, attendance has dropped 37 percent and subscriptions have dropped 50 percent.
When "Phantom" came to Hartford in 1995, it played to 99 percent capacity audiences for more than six weeks. This season, "Showboat" grossed $1 million a week for four weeks. The Bushnell, which routinely sustained six-figure losses each year -- $760,000 in 1990 alone -- now breaks even and 92 percent of its performing arts income comes from Broadway presentations.
"Touring Broadway has been one of the engines to revive downtown Hartford," Mr. Evans said.
These changes have presented challenges for the classical arts, he said. In 1996, for instance, "Miss Saigon" displaced the Hartford Ballet's holiday presentations of "Nutcracker," a Christmas moneymaker for nearly every ballet company in the country.
The ballet rescheduled the production for Thanksgiving.
But the ballet, Mr. Evans said, ended up with a more successful run partly because it no longer competed with other attractions at the peak of the Christmas season. And in compensation for the move, the Bushnell gave the ballet a rental credit of $54,000.
Similarly, in Tulsa two years ago, some tempers were mollified when three performances of "Phantom" were sold as part of the subscription series of the local orchestra, ballet and opera, thus increasing their ticket sales.
The problem was more serious in Honolulu this spring as subscribers to the symphony protested plans to bump the orchestra from its hall for a three-month run of "Miss Saigon" beginning in September 1999.
Resolutions by the City Council and the Hawaii Legislature called for negotiations to avert a problem that, according to its executive director, Michael Tiknis, would have cost the orchestra about $500,000, a tenth of its annual budget. Under a compromise announced last week, the orchestra will be able to open its gala centennial season in September 1999, before the three-month run of "Miss Saigon" displaces it.
"It's the old story," said Ronald Andrew of Eagle Eye Entertainment of Toronto, which is presenting touring Broadway in Hawaii. "The business of art versus the art of business."
That is the story in Florida, as well. The Florida Orchestra does not have its own concert hall, but rents space in recently built performing arts centers in Tampa, St. Petersburg and Clearwater.
Since 1992, when "Phantom" played at the Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center, touring Broadway shows have regularly sold out halls, drawing scalpers, inspiring demands for return engagements and causing more problems for the orchestra. In Tampa, the orchestra could book only 5 of 21 favored dates this season. In Clearwater, where the Ruth Eckerd Hall also started staging Broadway shows, the usual 7 pops concerts were reduced to 4.
In both cities, said the orchestra's executive director, Kathryn Holm, the halls were built with the participation and patronage of the orchestra's board, though not owned by the orchestra. In Clearwater, the concert hall was once billed as "Home of the Florida Orchestra."
But many leaders of arts centers argue that the Broadway boom indirectly helps other arts groups.
"Because Broadway does so well, the ramifications for performing arts centers are enormous," said Judith Lisi, the president of the Tampa arts center. "Broadway allows us to keep the rent for other classical concerts lower."
In Hartford, Mr. Evans is beginning a nationwide study of the impact of Broadway road shows on the performing arts. He agreed that there were benefits behind the conflict.
The added income, Mr. Evans suggests, allows the Bushnell to subsidize classical performing arts events with half-price rentals and helps support its half-million-dollar educational program. In Hartford, as in other cities, the new conflicts have led to attempts to negotiate future seasons with more care.
Mr. Hardy, the president of the Kentucky Center, hopes that the Center's 1,400-seat theater -- to open this fall -- may relieve some of the pressure Broadway's success has created. He has also established regular negotiations between the Broadway producer and the directors of the opera, orchestra and ballet.
As Ms. Holm, the executive director of the Florida Orchestra, points out, the crisis has also forced orchestras to "make lemonade." After being forced out of its traditional sites, the Florida Orchestra has tried informal concerts for families and schools and experimented with different repertories in a restored Tampa movie theater.
Mr. Tiknis, in Honolulu, sees a more ironic "positive byproduct" out of the struggle with Broadway: "Nothing, not even a concert in Carnegie Hall, could have made the city and its people feel closer to the orchestra."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE OVERVIEW;
PAKISTAN SETS OFF ATOM TEST AGAIN, BUT URGES 'PEACE'

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 30

 BODY:
Pakistan exploded another nuclear test device today, the Government announced, spurning worldwide criticism and calls for restraint after its nuclear tests two days ago.
Speaking after a round of tests that have catapulted the impoverished countries of India and Pakistan into declared nuclear powers and raised fears of war, a Pakistani official indicated that nuclear weapons could now be swiftly made ready for use. 
 "The devices tested conform to weapons configuration compatible with delivery systems," Shamshad Ahmad Khan, a senior official in the Foreign Ministry, said at a news conference this evening.
"We have proved our credibility," he said, adding that today's test had concluded the series.
But he also said that Pakistan was ready to "talk peace" with India and that "it is not our purpose to enter into an arms race."
The Pakistani tests came two weeks after India exploded what it said were five nuclear devices.
A senior Indian official said today that India did not view nuclear testing as a competition with Pakistan requiring India to match each move by its archrival. The United States, which has imposed economic sanctions on both countries, condemned the latest Pakistani test. Articles, page 8.
Today's test came at 11:55 this morning in the same remote Baluchistan region of desert and mountains near the Iranian border where the previous tests by Pakistan were conducted on Thursday.
Initial reports said two devices, each with a force of 18 kilotons -- slightly bigger than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima -- had been exploded in reinforced L-shaped tunnels, but Pakistani officials later said there had been only one.
Scientists outside India and Pakistan have questioned some of the two countries' assertions about their tests, and it was not immediately clear what size device Pakistan detonated today. The C.I.A. put the size at one to five kilotons, a relatively tiny bomb by cold-war standards.
Again and again in his remarks, Mr. Ahmad, the Foreign Ministry's senior civil servant, referred to India's development of nuclear weapons and the struggle between the countries over the disputed province of Kashmir, which he said was under the "patently illegal occupation of India." India and Pakistan have fought three wars since 1947, two of them over Kashmir.
Mr. Ahmad said Pakistan had developed its nuclear ability "only, only in self-defense and only to deter aggression."
"It is to restore the strategic balance," he said.
Mr. Ahmad reiterated his Government's assertion that it is willing to negotiate with India. But negotiations, he insisted, must lead to a "peaceful and just" solution to the problem of Kashmir.
Jammu and Kashmir is the only majority Muslim state in predominantly Hindu India and has been the scene of brutal violence between Muslim separatists and Indian security forces. Part of the Kashmir region is held by Pakistan, which has supported separatists in the Indian-held area.
Today's test was greeted here with jubilation. Crowds have been dancing in the streets of this desperately poor Muslim country since Thursday's announcement that Pakistan had conducted five underground nuclear tests in response to an equal number by India earlier this month.
Indeed, far from bowing to the pressure of international sanctions and at least four nations' recall of their ambassadors, officials here spoke openly of loading the newly developed nuclear warheads onto missiles.
"There is no problem" putting them on warheads, Foreign Minister Gomar Ayub Khan said on Friday.
Dr. Abdul Qadeer Khan, the chief of Pakistan's nuclear development program and the country's newest hero, agreed. "If the Prime Minister asked, it would not be difficult to mount them," Dr. Qadeer Khan said. "We can really, really mount them, not in months, not in weeks, but in days."
Normally fractious parties across the splintered political spectrum are saluting Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for standing up to India, and Friday Prayers throughout the country were devoted to giving thanks for the country's nuclear ability.
In the North-West Frontier Province, mountain tribesman let loose with the traditional celebratory volleys of gunfire from weapons of all descriptions.
Office holders, usually enriched here by their public service, vowed belt-tightening to share the economic suffering to come.
The elation reflected the long tensions between India and Pakistan. With a vastly larger population and a military twice the size of Pakistan's -- 1,145,000 to 587,000 -- India has been the dominant force on the subcontinent.
Much of the tension has centered on Kashmir. With independence, the princely states that had made up the British colony were to chose which new country they wanted to join. Most of the population of Kashmir was Muslim but its Maharaja was Hindu. When Pathan tribesmen challenged his rule, he appealed to India, which sent in forces.
With the victory of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party in the Indian election this year, the tensions have sharpened, and both sides have been emphatic in linking the nuclear race and the Kashmir issue. After the nuclear tests by India, that country's Home Minister, Lal Krishna Advani, increased war jitters by speaking out strongly on Kashmir.
Both countries have been furtively developing their nuclear potential for years. But it is only in the last few weeks that India and Pakistan shouldered into the club of declared nuclear powers.
Dr. Qadeer Khan, Pakistan's nuclear director, gave new details of Pakistan's program in an interview today with a local newspaper, The News.
Describing the tests on Thursday, he said one was a big bomb that had a yield of about 30 to 35 kilotons, which was twice as big as the one dropped on Hiroshima. The other four were small tactical weapons of low yield. Mounted on small missiles, they can be used in the battlefield against concentrations of troops.
"None of these explosions were thermonuclear," a hydrogen bomb, he said. "We are doing research and can do a fusion blast, if asked. But it depends on the circumstances, political situation and the decision of the Government."
This morning's Pakistani newspapers were euphoric over the nuclear tests, carrying article after article about parades and celebrations here, and the discomfiture of the Hindu nationalists and the reigning Bharatiya Janata Party.
"Long Live Nuclear Pakistan," declared the headline on the front page of The Pakistan Observer. "Five nuclear blasts have instantly transformed an extremely demoralized nation into a self-respecting, proud nation of 140 million people, having full faith in their destiny," a front-page article said.
"Indian explosions and belligerent statements made by the B.J.P. leaders were a constant source of constant anguish for patriotic Pakistanis and a befitting response was inescapable to restore the badly shaken confidence of the masses.
"India's self-perceived towering stature, on the basis of which it hurled threats on Pakistan, has been razed to the ground in the mountains of Chagai," the area of the test site.

HEADLINE: Trump Buying The Landmark G.M. Building

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
In a deal reminiscent of the high-flying 1980's, Donald Trump and an Indianapolis insurance company have purchased the General Motors Building in midtown Manhattan for $800 million.
"It's a terrific asset," Mr. Trump said last evening, confirming the deal. "It's probably the greatest real estate asset in the world." 
 It is now one of the most expensive. The property attracted numerous bidders, but sources said that some of them began to drop out when prices soared to $750 million. Mr. Trump and his partner, the Indianapolis-based insurance company Conseco, paid a $40 million down payment upon signing the contract Friday afternoon.
"It is already a premier building but it can be greatly enhanced," Mr. Trump said.
Known as one of Manhattan's trophy properties, the General Motors Building sits in a prime midtown Manhattan location across Fifth Avenue from Central Park. Once the sale is completed, the General Motors Building will join Mr. Trump's other midtown properties, including Trump Tower at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street and the Trump International Hotel and Tower at 1 Central Park West.
The 50-story General Motors Building bestrides an entire city block, stretching between Fifth and Madison Avenues and between 58th and 59th Streets. With 1.9 million square feet of office space, it accommodates such prestigious tenants as General Motors, Estee Lauder and Revlon, Mr. Trump said.
For the past decade, the building had been owned by Corporate Property Investors, a New York-based real estate investment trust that also owns dozens of shopping malls across the country. In February, Corporate Property reached an agreement to sell its malls to the Indianapolis-based Simon DeBartolo Group, one of the country's largest owners of shopping malls. But the deal required that the General Motors Building be sold separately from the malls.
"It was sold in contemplation of the merger we hope to close in the beginning of August," said Richard Posen, a lawyer with Willkie, Farr, Gallagher, who represents Simon DeBartolo.
John Mechanic, a real estate lawyer with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, expressed surprise that Mr. Trump ended up as the high bidder. The building is 98 percent leased, and Mr. Mechanic said it is the sort of stable revenue producer favored by large real estate investment trusts.
"It's a little surprising that an entrepreneur ended up in a bidding contest like that as the high bidder," Mr. Mechanic said. "I guess ego would probably have something to do with it."
A lawyer close to the deal who spoke on the condition of anonymity said many bidders hovered at about $750 million and a few went higher.
Mr. Trump's lawyer, Leonard Boxer, agreed that pride played a role in Mr. Trump's pursuit of the property but he also cited economics. Mr. Boxer said Mr. Trump entered the bidding only about a week ago. On Thursday, parties on all side negotiated late into the night, hammering out the deal that was signed the next day. Mr. Trump said he and Conseco are equal partners in the deal.
Mr. Trump said he planned to revamp the building's existing retail space, in particular the subterranean plaza currently leased by Houlihan's restaurant. The toy store, F.A.O. Schwarz, also leases property facing Fifth Avenue.
Mr. Trump acknowledged that the purchase marked a departure from his usual practice of purchasing and developing vacant buildings.
"This is different, but there is still a great deal that can be done with the building," he said.
Mr. Trump said several of the corporate leases should come due in the next four or five years, and he predicted that he would increase their rents substantially. "Some of these leases are going to be doubled or quadrupled," Mr. Trump predicted.
Asked if Mr. Trump paid too much, the developer's executive vice president in charge of acquisitions, Abe Wallach, said no. Mr. Wallach said other development possibilities include converting part of the building to residential condominiums or to a hotel.
A 3,000-square-foot, three-bedroom apartment in another of his properties, the nearby Trump Tower, is listed for sale for $3.49 million.
David Simon, the chief executive officer for Simon DeBartolo, could not be reached for comment. The company is expected to hold a press conference tomorrow to announce the deal.
Built in 1968 by the acclaimed architects Edward Durell Stone and Emery Roth, the General Motors Building had a controversial birth. To construct the white, marble-plated skyscraper, the architects had to raze the graceful old Savoy Plaza Hotel.

Map of Manhattan showing site of the General Motors Building: The G.M. Building faces the Plaza Hotel, once owned by Mr. Trump. (pg. 27)

HEADLINE: Hardship Claim Is Doubted In Bid for SoHo Housing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article about housing in SoHo "Non-Artists' Housing Seen as Blot on Local Canvas" (May 10) ignored the real issues. 
 The Board of Standards and Appeals granted several variances based on the developer's highly suspect claim of economic hardship. It relied on property comparisons outside of SoHo and a parking capacity at 19-35 West Houston Street of 35, even though, as the accompanying photo reveals, about 57 cars are routinely parked.
What's more, the buildings are out of scale and out of character with the Cast Iron Historic District. In approving them, the Landmarks Preservation Commission sold out the idea of landmarking.
 
MICHAEL LICHTMAN
SoHo

LENGTH: 1239 words

HEADLINE: NOTICED;
Pass the Popcorn (And the Khakis)

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
NAME-BRAND apparel and independent films. There's not much connection there, really, except you might wear one while watching the other. Still, consider this: Major clothing manufacturers have decided that, in their quest to remain hip with youth, they want to associate with those low-budget films that everyone talks about and almost no one sees.
On Wednesday, Perry Ellis International presented its first Breakout Award to the two stars of the movie "Slam," a winner at the Cannes and Sundance film festivals. Next weekend, Dockers Khakis will sponsor the first Classically Independent Film Festival in San Francisco. And the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation has signed a deal to promote the stars of Dimension's "Faculty" -- Josh Hartnett, Salma Hayek and Elijah Wood; it expects the movie, about werewolves in high school, to be as successful as the studio's two "Scream" movies. 
 The list doesn't stop there. Polo Ralph Lauren sponsored the New York premiere of "Shooting Fish" recently, and Perry Ellis has co-sponsored the openings of "No Looking Back," "Office Killer" and "The Opposite of Sex" -- edgy indie films all.
So, what gives with this meeting of casual-Friday fashion and low-budget celluloid?
Max Garelick, the president of Perry Ellis International, said, "I'm interested in what's new and different, instead of what the mainstream is talking about." His company believes that its customers are the kind of hip people who could spot Saul Williams or Sonja Sohn, the young stars of "Slam," in a crowd. Inevitably, Perry Ellis is drawn to the -- how to say this? -- independent-ness of the independents.
Which can backfire. At the party at the Perry Ellis offices in Manhattan, Mr. Williams pondered the significance of a group of clothing industry executives paying homage to a film like "Slam," a drama about prison, the inner city and poetry. It's like "an old dying country on its deathbed, discovering its long lost soul," he said.
Who knows, maybe that's the kind of individuality that clothing companies are looking for. "Our customer is not part of that red-white-and-blue, Tommy-Ralph-Nautica herd," Mr. Garelick said. "They're self-assured and individualistic. They're drawn to Perry Ellis, and we see them drawn to movies that are not part of the herd."
Self-assured as the company may be, when it came time to select the winners of the Breakout Award, it wisely relied on the Independent Feature Project in Manhattan and a panel of independent-film experts.
Why get behind "Slam" rather than, say, "Die Hard 4"? Susan Malinowski, a senior vice president of marketing for Perry Ellis, said: "Independent film is consistent with a company that is trendsetting, a little hipper, a little younger, a little more sophisticated than companies that go the Hollywood route. We don't see ourselves getting involved in 'Air Force One.' "
Take that, Armani -- which supplied Glenn Close's wardrobe in "Air Force One."
Next for Perry Ellis International is the sponsorship of the glossy June 10 premiere of "The Farm: Angola U.S.A.," a documentary about the United States' largest maximum security prison, in Angola, La.
Is the support for independent film charity, or is it synergy? "It's synergy," said Amy Rosenthal, the senior marketing specialist at Dockers. Dockers Khakis (not to be confused with those swinging Gap Khakis) is the clothing label most heavily involved with independent film.
Besides sponsoring the Classically Independent festival, it ran the Fuel film tour last year (promoted in ads with people like Jon Favreau wearing Dockers) and has run advertisements starring "independent thinkers" like Asia Argento (who will appear in "B. Monkey"), Stacy Edwards (who appeared in "In the Company of Men") and Summer Phoenix ("S.L.C. Punk").
"I'm trying to blend the independent world into the brand," Ms. Rosenthal said. She argues that Dockers is a better fit with the spirit of independent film than her competitors. "If you look at Calvin Klein, it's sex," she said. "And Tommy is Americana. Dockers is about being who you are. It's about personal vision, and that's what independent film, especially for budget reasons, is about. They're hip with personal style. We don't want trendy, trendy."
Ms. Rosenthal sees some danger in getting corporations involved with low-budget and no-budget films. "Any time a big company gets involved in the arts, there's the sense of deep pockets," she said. "But the company doesn't belong in the creative process. We don't want to just slap a logo on. We're not trying to outfit casts and create big promotions."
That "outfit casts" comment is a slight directed at Tommy Hilfiger, which not only dressed the entire cast of "The Faculty," to be released at Christmastime, but also cast one bit player, Kidada Jones, Quincy Jones and Peggy Lipton's daughter. "I got her into the movie -- Tommy did," said Andy Hilfiger, the director of public relations for the company.
The expected audience for that movie is the "exact age demographic as our jeans customer," he said, adding, "It's a great marriage."
The company is also paying for a joint advertising campaign for the film that will top $10 million. "We already had the media in place," Mr. Hilfiger said. "We'd bought all the gatefolds for the fall books: Teen People, Spin, Vibe, YM. Those are perfect consumers for Dimension. It makes it a little hipper if the movie is not too commercial."
Some independent filmmakers find the prospect of a big company like Hilfiger dressing the cast and promoting a small movie to be troubling. Neda Pourang, the costume designer for "Macbeth in Manhattan," shooting in New York this summer, said that Hilfiger's outfitting the cast of "The Faculty" was "just terrible."
"If that became common with independents, I would have to retire from this business and be a window dresser at Macy's," she said.
Nor does she think it's a good idea if everyone in the cast wears clothes from the same company. "In a film, if you walk into a room and everyone's wearing Hugo Boss, that would be a nightmare," she said. "It would be like, 'Everyone's my dad.' "
Still, Perry Ellis has provided some clothing for "Macbeth in Manhattan," and Ms. Pourang admits she is grateful for the help. But she said: "I don't sell my soul to a designer. I think they realize that. It's my job to stop them." She paused for a moment.
"I have to remind myself that Perry Ellis dresses Alex Trebek," she said.
Robert Hanson, the vice president of marketing for Dockers Brand U.S.A., said that market research shows that consumers will switch to brands that share their values. "We feel pretty strongly that if you can demonstrate that a brand cares about issues and life styles, that's effective," Mr. Hanson said.
Dockers, owned by Levi Strauss & Company, is apparently not scared by the raw subject matter of many indies. "Levi Strauss has taken a stand on many controversial issues," Mr. Hanson said. "AIDS, H.I.V., youth empowerment, social justice, community-based economic development. A lot of the story lines in independent film are about those things, and this company has demonstrated an effort to air those issues."
Memo to Dockers, Perry Ellis, Tommy Hilfiger et al: There's another art form that takes risks and attracts hip, not "trendy, trendy," independent people. Poetry. It could use some new sponsors, and most poets could also use some new clothes.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 3, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Sunday Styles this week about clothing designers' inroads into independent films misstated the name of a new Perry Ellis award in the field. It is the Breakthrough award, not the Breakout award. The article also misstated the subject of "The Faculty," a movie in production with costumes by Tommy Hilfiger. It is about aliens, not werewolves.
